explanation: One who laughs at a cripple has a family defect too. A warning to those who laugh at the deformity of another, for they will be punished in the same way. Cf. 17, 54, 68.
An open reproach is best. Lawama: reproach, charge, blame, reproof, guilt.

text: Afanyae mzaha na watu humlazimu awe na saburi.
explanation: People who tease others must have patience for when they'll be teased in turn.

How amazing that a sheep mocks its image in a mirror [not knowing that it laughs at its own image]. This is said of someone who is making fun of another, while having the same imperfection or making the same mistake.

text: Ajabu ya ngamia kuchekanundu ya ng'ombe.
explanation: How amazing that a camel derides the cow for its hump. The camel has a bigger hump. Cf. 101, 3953, 3990.
The one who points a knife at you can stab you.
Do the same to someone who arrogantly insults you.
The one who insults you does not choose insults. Not mincing words and really trying to hurt you.
One who wants to insult you does not lack proclamation. That person will not keep silent and there are always eager listeners. Matango for matangazo: proclamation.
The person who hurts you is the person who knows you.
That one is happy, that person's teeth don't bite the bread. This is said when somebody in a good mood does not respond to an insult.
That person came with upper teeth. With brute force.
Those who throw mud get soiled as well.
If you throw mud it will jump back to you. That abused person will get back at you.

text: Baada ya kisa mkasa: baada ya chanzo kitendo.
explanation: After a story, a happening: after a beginning, the action. "tit for tat"

text: Baada ya kovu na jeraha ndani.
explanation: Even after it has been covered by scar tissue, the wound still hurts inside. "An insult is not easy to forget"

Trade does not quarrel. A businessman is careful in the choice of his words in order not to alienate his customers, and to attract them. This expression is used by shopkeepers when customers expostulate about the price of wares

text: Bila mtu wa pili ugomvi hauanzi
explanation: Without a second person a quarrel cannot start.
Laugh at a deformed person and you will bear a deformed child. A warning to stop people from laughing at others, and to show sympathy instead.
Mock a corpse and the corpse [in time] will laugh at you.
All that picking makes bad teeth. A person who annoys you on purpose makes you angry [bad teeth].
The stone pot calls the aluminum pot "black." English proverb: "the kettle calls the pot black.
Where there was a storm, there is calm. Where there is disturbance, there can be reconciliation followed by calm
Tempest in a tea cup. (English import.) To make much of little things. About people who are afraid about little things

text: Haifai kumtukana sungura miguu mikubwa na tembo yupo palepale.
explanation: Don't laugh at the rabbit's big feet while the elephant is present.
The owner of the [mango] tree must not make fun of the one who has one mango. "the rich must behave civilly towards the poor"
After much shouting there will be a fight. Hekaheka: confusion, much noise, also shouts of encouragement, such as in a game

text: Hujavuka mto, simtukane mamba, al tukana.
explanation: You haven't crossed the river, so don't insult the crocodile. Cf. 213, 217.
If people abuse you, pretend you did not hear it.

text: Jahazi chombo kikuu hakistahimili (or hakihimili) kubisha.
explanation: An old sail boat does not tolerate tacking. "An old person does not suffer being moved out or being maneuvered around"

text: Jani kavu mtini linalilaumu lililo chini kwa kelele.
explanation: A dry leaf on the tree blames the leaf on the ground for noise. It is easy to see other people's faults.

text: Jirani ndiye ndugu, usimkashifu hata kidogo.
explanation: A neighbor is a relative, don't slander him/her even a little. Kashifu: to slander, reveal evil.

text: Jogoo kasema usiku umekucha anikanyagae kakusudia.
explanation: The rooster said the day is breaking, so who steps on me does it on purpose. The fowl staying in the same house might be trod upon by a person going out early. A person doing harm often blames it on the situation. The reply to such an excuse would be this proverb.
A huge pot burns the cook and the eater. It becomes very hot and difficult to handle. This means that a quarrel often harms the initiator as well as the receiver.
The crab laughs at the way its young one walks.
A crab is boiled in its own water. A defenseless person will be cruelly treated
I am sitting in a little nest; make me fly away. This may be said by a woman who has deteriorating marriage, but is unable to leave and so is waiting for the final straw to set her free.
The big kalimba fish eats the small ones. Little people are the victims of big people. Instead of kalimba one could use mbota (Nile perch) or chewa (rock cod) or nguru (king fish).
The kid (young goat) died from blows with a stick. It became the laughing stock, the scapegoat.
The wound returns to the scab. It remains in the memory. The insult is not forgotten and whatever you do it comes back to you. Cf. 50, 2021, 4284.
Every joke (insult) has its own familiarity.
Every quarrel is used again.
Whoever mocks a lame [person], one day it will happen to him. Sikilia: listen to (for, with, at). Cf.1,17, 68.
Everyone who has a need goes to the rubbish heap. All people slander. [The rubbish heap was and is also the latrine, in the middle of a group of houses, to be used collectively]
A cripple does not mock a companion.

text: Kilichoniuma jana nikaona uchunguwe hakinitambai tena.
explanation: That which bit me yesterday and hurt me, does not crawl over me a second time. I'll see to that; I'll be careful not to expose myself to insults again.
Monkeys that have been circumcised [ceremonially cleansed] will not eat you.
Don't laugh at a blind person, it is not that person's fault.
Tree stump, make me stumble, so that I have a motive. One does not act without reason. If one wants to pick on someone there generally is an aversion or a quarrel.
I am sitting on a tree stump so that I may stumble. Said of a woman who aggravates the life of her husband by accusing him of everything wrong. Cf. 962, 2202, 2837.
Don't put sand in my cake. "Do not spoil my sport, do not rob my story"

text: Kitushi ni pumba ya uwongo: ukinipa la kweli takupa la uwongo.
explanation: Calling names [lit., abuse] is a handful of mud: if you give me a true [deserved] name, I will give you a false one

text: Kobe alikimbia kwa kuchekwa mwendo wake.
explanation: The tortoise fled because they laughed at its gait. A wise person keeps silent when ridiculed.
Laughing, laughing will die away. People who always laugh at others will get their due. Cf. 92.
A person who laughs at a scar has not received a wound. Laughing at peoples' misfortune shows ignorance.
One who laughs at a scar has not yet seen a wound. Cf. 2021.

text: Kuchuachua, kuchua si kwema: mchomwa mwiba hawi mtembezi.
explanation: Quarreling all the time, quarreling is not good; a person with a thorn [in the foot] will not be a walker [traveler]. It is not good to provoke someone all the time

text: Kulia kwa samaki, machozi (yake) huenda na maji.
explanation: The tears of the fish are carried away by the water. Suffering of the poor is not considered important.
The bedbug says the louse's bite is more painful. "The kettle calls the pot burnt black." Cf. 20.
By continual stabbing one stabs oneself. Always insulting people and mocking them, destroys oneself.
By constant biting the teeth start hurting.

text: Kuwa mbali kuliana, kuwa karibu magombano.
explanation: There is weeping when separated, there is quarreling when together. Said of friends or relatives who always quarrel when together. Cf. 99, 103.

text: 55a. Kwa wakaha wake nyani hufunguliwa ya ndani.
explanation: By means of insolence a person of low birth (lit. baboon) succeeds in having access to the inner rooms (lit., for that person the inner doors (milango) are opened).
In our house revenge sleeps not, no doubt about that. Dialect: ransom, fine for murder - J. Si kondo or bila shaka: without doubt.
A curse does not die.

A blasphemy, and it has come to you already. "Kila lahaula hufuatwa na adhabu ya Mungu," every blasphemy is followed by God's punishment. Lahaula: blasphemy; as an expletive: Well I never; God forbid. An abbreviation for "There is no power nor strength but in God"

text: Élanivuwaza kama shazi jicho la ndugu.
explanation: It cuts me like an oyster shell: the [envious] eye of a brother. The oyster shell cuts the skin [superficially] and hurts: the evil eye of a relative also inflicts pain. This is said about family vendettas.

text: Lao huwinda pazima ili kupatia pengo.
explanation: Their [occupation] is to scrutinize a sound place in order to discover a flaw. This is said of people who pick a petty quarrel with others.
Point a finger, start a quarrel. Lekeza, elekeza: show, point.
A loliondo tree withers if a parasite thrives on it. "A loliondo tree is very strong, but a parasite sucks the energy of the tree and withers it. Thus a rich person may be destroyed by parasites"
Slander without foundation ends up in the sky.
Words of abuse are like lumps of clay. Easy to find and to throw.

text: Matushi ni pumba ya uwongo, halikai neno la uongo.
explanation: Words of abuse are [like throwing] a handful of mud. A word of slander does not stay (no more than mud stays on the face). A pun on uwongo, clay and uongo, lie
Familiarity breeds contempt.
If you spoil what is your own you have no quarrel. Bananga, haribu: to spoil

text: Mbughudi cha nje hupata cha ndani.
explanation: A tale bearer who reports bad things outside, will get it inside. If you slander people, it will come back to you. Bughudha: abhorrence, hatred, slander.

text: Mchawi huloga kwa nduguye na kwake kuko shwari.
explanation: A wizard puts a spell on his brother, but his own place is peaceful.
A person who laughs at a cripple will not die without becoming one. Cf. 1,17.
A bad dancer blames the drummer. The lesson is that there are people who do not accept their mistakes; instead, they attribute their mistakes to others
One who ridicules the good will be overtaken by evil. A person who laughs at good works, will fall upon bad times
One who ridicules a deformed person becomes deformed. Biu and biuka from umbua: deform, disfigure. Cf. 68.

text: Mdigo mkanye akirudi, usimkanye aendapo mtagombana na safari.
explanation: Rebuke a Mdigo when he comes back, don't rebuke him when he goes: you'll quarrel with each other the whole journey. Mdigo: a person from Digo country.
Don't insult your neighbor doctor. You might need a doctor. Cf.83, 84, 1580.

text: Mguu mmoja ukijikwaa, wa pili hucheka.
explanation: If one foot stumbles, the other laughs.
An honorable person does not err. If that person errs, the blame is put on someone else, so that person's prestige is not lowered.

text: Mhini na mhiniwa njia yao moja.
explanation: The teaser and the one who is teased are in the same way. None profits, both are losers. Hini: refuse to give in. Mhini: teaser, oppressor, tyrant.
It is you yourself who stepped on the thorns which are on the road. Don't accuse others of your faults and mistakes - KB. One who commits blunders must blame oneself
A mat on which everybody sits. Insult for a prostitute. Cf. 4594.
A deformed arm gives constant trouble. So does a bad person.

text: Mkubwa akikosa amekosa, mnyonge akikosa huadhibiwa.
explanation: When an important person makes a mistake, well so be it, but if a poor person makes a mistake that person is punished. Mnyonge: a humble, abject, low, debased person.
One who avoids a fight will sprout stick marks on the body. Some quarrels cannot be avoided, stand for your rights.

One who swallows a strip of raffia is aware of it. Even if receiving an affront calmly, that person nevertheless feels it. Ung'ongo: the hard fiber of a palm leaf, used in mat making. Kajiono for akajiona (a play on the sound?), unless kajiono here is short for kajiona-to: and he saw himself well. The suffix to denotes good quality, well done
Do not say we are stupid, you who employ us in foreign fashion. Arabs and Europeans have employed Africans and often called them ignorant, but it is the employers who are ignorant of good manners
Do not abuse midwives while there is a delivery going on. Do not insult people who might be of use to you one day. Msitukane as well as usitukane (plural and singular are used.

text: Usimtukane mkunga hali (or ungali) waendelea kuzaa.
explanation: Don't insult the midwives when the delivery is not yet finished.
The one who inflicts forgets, the one to whom it is done does not forget. Cf. 1885.

text: 85a. Mti upijwao mawe ni mti wenye matunda.
explanation: The tree that people throw stones at is the tree that bears fruit.
A tree shouldn't laugh at the fallen tree trunk.

text: Mwana-mongwe ali kwao na mchanga hangelile.
explanation: If the noble son had stayed home, he would not have eaten sand. He would not have been abused and humiliated. "Let not the cobbler go beyond his last. Hangelile for hangalikula, and ali for yu, attest the antiquity of this proverb

text: Mwapiza la nje, hupata la ndani.
Apizao la nje hupata la ndani
explanation: One who curses outside gets it inside. One who curses about something not really his concern, will bring it home to himself - F. Someone who wishes sickness upon another may fall sick himself

text: Mwenye kufanya mchuzi, kiungo ni malimau.
explanation: In making the gravy, the seasoning is lemons. Lemons and limes are the best ingredients to give taste to the gravy; do not try to improve your sauce by using fancy things. Don't despise those you cannot do without. "Don't quarrel with your bread and butter"

text: Mwenyezi mungu atakushinda kama shinda la ufuta.
explanation: Almighty God will reduce you as the leftovers of simsim. (A curse. Shinda: the dregs of the sesame seeds after oil has been extracted from them.

text: Mzaha kwa mwanaume si mara mbili, ikawa ni mara mbili, mara tatu utakamatwa ndevu.
explanation: A person does not try a joke twice and if by chance it happens twice, the third time someone will grasp your beard. Cf. 92, 93.
Joke, joke, discharges pus. Do not dismiss even a small scratch as if it were only a joke; it may go bad. Another probable meaning is: too much teasing causes arguments.
Too much teasing brings fighting. Cf. 49.

text: Mzaha unaleta ugomvi: ugomvi wapoteza maneno.
explanation: Jesting brings forth quarrels; quarrels deprive control over words. Cf. 92, 113.
Turn the sailor to
The root of discord is cut. "Said when a quarrel is over"
The root comes out of the stem.

text: Na kutumiana nguvu, lema litakuwa ovu.
explanation: By using violence against each other, a good thing [e.g., a marriage] will become evil. Lema = jema: a good thing.
Let that irritate you! [or] Let that stick in you! Exclamations after a strong statement: May that stick in your gizzard, you cannot give an answer to that - J. Put that in your pipe and smoke it

text: Ndugu wakigombana (or wakiteta), chukua jembe ukalime; wakipatana chukua kapu ukavune.
explanation: When brothers quarrel, take a hoe and cultivate; when they make up, take a basket and harvest. It means not to interfere when brothers quarrel, "but also that any quarrel is a loss to society and when they make it up again it is a gain"
I cried for him when he had not yet come; when he came I hated him. When one is far apart the faults and differences seem small, but when united, disputes reappear at once. Cf. 103.
When the porcupine passes, it leaves its prickles behind. "A prickly character causes irritation and quarreling"
Monkeys make fun of each other's red behind. Without seeing their own. Ngoko: the very hard red spot, like red meat, on their behind. Also called mando, bato nyekundu.
The baboon mocks the posterior of his companion.

text: Nyigu haumi bure, ila mtu anamchokoza.
explanation: A hornet does not sting, except when it is made angry.

text: Nyoko nyoko kuonana, kuwa mbali kuliana.
explanation: Together: mutual insults; far apart: crying for one another. When together they insìult each other and when they are apart they cry for each other. This is said when a partner is sorry for a separation after a dispute. Cf. 99.

text: Nyoko! Nyoko! Ni shiba ya kuonana.
explanation: Abuses are the result of seeing one another too often. Nyoko: a sexual insult. Cf. 915, 2224.
A house of fishermen. A household with lots of quarrels and fighting
Wash your face then come outside. If you have washed your face, you can laugh at the person who hasn't. Ua wenje = utoke nje: come outside. Cf. 5. MARA quotes a poem of Ahmed Nassir Juma Bhalo

text: Shika n'nakuusia, ila za wendo silumbe
Ajabu ndawe ngamia, kuteka nundu ya ng'ombe.
explanation: Please, I pray don't question the faults of your companion. Because, bearing in mind, there is no faultless creature It would be amazing a camel laughing at the cow's hump.
Go along with your things. Mind your own business
A curse breaks a stone; how would it not break a human being? Salala, [salale]: a curse; exclamation of amazement: "May it not please God.

text: Samaha ni rahisi, mwerevu hutafuta sababu.
explanation: If forgiveness comes easy, a clever person asks why?

text: Shuka ya maskini ndiyo itandiwayo dagaa.
explanation: The dagaa will be spread out upon the loincloth of the poor. If anything bad happens, the poor and helpless are blamed. Dagaa: very tiny fish, sardines.
It is not nice to laugh at a cripple. Cf. 68.

text: 111 . Siwe sababu ya bangu, mgomvi hapendi mungu.
explanation: Do not be the cause of fighting, the brawler does not love God. Siwe = usiwe or msiwe. Bangu, vita: war, fighting.

text: Tupa tupa tope jingi, baadhi litampata.
explanation: If you throw plenty of mud, some of it will stick. Cf. 12.
Joking carried too far leads to quarreling.
Joking is the beginning of a quarrel.
Much quarreling ends in damage.
Quarreling broke up the village of the monkeys.
If you joke about fish smell, don't eat fish. If you laugh at the fishermen smelling badly, you won't get fish.

text: Ukimtukana chura upele, mtu husema: unanitukana mimi.
explanation: If you insult a frog for its pimples, someone will say, "You insult me." Bad insinuations addressed to someone will provoke another, thinking that you spoke about him.
When you mention a snake get hold of a stick.
If you talk about a snake grasp a cudgel. "Devil is never nearer than when we are talking of him." Or rather: If you call somebody a name, be ready for a fight.
Have you become a kitatange taking care of your companion in the basket?
This is a kitatange, he throws you in his basket. He puts you in danger, while he escapes. Kitatange : a person who incites others to quarrel
The one to whom you show your teeth, puts a finger in your mouth.
You are blaming the hawk, [while] the falcon is killing the chickens. Don't blame the one who committed a minor mistake and leave the one who does big harm. Yuwesha: contraction of yu-wa-isha.

text: Ushungu mwenenda nao, shingo ujeze matama.
explanation: The poison a man bears, has filled [his] cheeks with venom.

text: Usiharibu utu kwa kitu, afadhali haribu kitu kwa utu.
explanation: Don't spoil your humanity with a thing; it is better to spoil a thing with your manhood. Use things to make you a better human being.

text: Usilaumu ardhi uliyoangukia, laumu kigingi kilichokukwaza.
explanation: Don't blame the ground you fall on, blame the obstacle that causes you to fall. Don't blame the people where you arrive. If blame is to be given, blame those who sent you there or blame the reason why you are sent there (e.g., prison)

text: Usilicheke jahazi lililorushwarushwa kwa mawimbi, huenda nduguyo yumo ndani yake.
explanation: Don't laugh at the sailboat that is tossed by the waves, perhaps your relative is in it.
Don't laugh at a cripple while you are alive. Something worse could happen to you.

Do not laugh at your mother-in-law for you will get a sty in your eye. Common belief that evil will come to a person who mocks his/her mother-in-law. The remedy consists in rubbing the eye with a garment of the one who has been ridiculed
Don't laugh at the coconut picker, you might lack coconuts at home. Cf. 83, 84,1 518, 2138.
A passerby, don't make him angry. Even if that person bothers you it is only for a passing moment.
Don't kick a person who is down. Low-minded people talk evil of a fallen opponent.

text: Usimtukane pongo miguu mirefu na kondoo yuko pale.
explanation: Don't insult the antelope on account of its long legs, while a sheep is present.

text: Usipende vita na ukimkuta rafiki kiteta, sichoteÿ amua.
explanation: Do not enjoy discord and if you find your friend quarreling do not stir it up, but make peace.

text: Usishindwe kulala usingizi ukasema kitanda ni kibovu.
explanation: Saying that the bed is bad should not stop you from sleeping. About blaming someone else.
The delight of the chigger is to cut the toe. Pleasure to hurt. Creatures follow their nature.
Pinch but do not crush. Cf. 61.
Family wars [fights] do not invite. I.e., do not interfere.
Articles of trade do not quarrel. There is no harm in selling objects of different kinds

text: Wakati wa hari, watu hugombana kisima kimoja.
explanation: In the dry season people quarrel over one well.

text: Wakiwa kuhuji mtu na mkewe, jahazi la saji limevunjiwa pa mawe.
explanation: While the man and his wife were arguing, the great ironwood ship was broken on the rock. While they were bickering over trivialities, their seemingly solid marriage broke up
Fish lovers disdain the fisherman. Cf. 115.

text: Watu kuagua ugonjwa, hawaagui [siyo; sio] jeuri.
explanation: People cure sickness but do not cure violence.
Gentle folks do not quarrel.
Goodness engenders abuse. Do good to an evil person and he/she will abuse you.
Goodness causes insults. Nyoko: an old form for "your mother." Used in insults: kuma nyoko, vagina of your mother. Cf. 142.
That person has bitter and venomous rejoinders. Used when someone remembers with malice. Shingo (ushingo, ushungu, uchungu): bitterness, poison. Cf. 121.
Where is the troublemaker who inflicts suffering continuously? Understood is that trouble coming his/her way will stop that person.
Traveller, watch out for crocodiles.

text: 146a. Afadhali kuvunja uchumba kuliko kuvunja ndoa.
explanation: It's better to break an engagement than a marriage.

text: Ajaye kisimani mbele hunywa maji maenge.
explanation: The first person coming at the well drinks clean water. Those coming afterwards will find muddied water. We should not wait for others to start doing things.
When they jump, don't jump with them; set a trap and you will catch them.
The one who goes before you to the food platter will get a bigger piece than you. Use the opportunity. Chano: a big platter.
They who were there are taking care of themselves. Minding your own business. Being alert.
Beware of those who break wind, they are about to defecate. This is said if something is going to happen. Someone will fall down or something will give.
One who waits cannot come [at all]. "One of these days is none of these days.
One who asks for baking powder [soda] should have a container. One should cooperate with the help given. Cf. 824.

What the thief has left for you, take it to the witch doctor [to put a curse on the thief]. When someone has been burgled, the person will call the diviner who will 'find' the thief, for a very big fee. Your friends may cause more damage than your enemies
Let not the one in need of a gourd precede you. If you are in need of something you should make your request known early upon arrival, lest somebody coming later gets it

text: Asili ya kuchonga mwiko ni kuchoka kuuungua.
explanation: The reason for carving a spoon [to stir the porridge] is being tired of burning [a hand]. Cf. 257.

text: Asiye na macho akaazime ya kondoo.
explanation: One who has no eyes should borrow the eyes of a sheep. Don't expect anything from a narrow-minded person
A person who does not look out [is careless] will end up [saying] "If I had known.
One who is not there, nothing of that person is there. If you are absent you lose your share. "You have to be present at the division of an inheritance. Leave no business to others"
Those who are not there will not have anything falling on them. Variant

A tree drops nothing on those who are not there. The cultural reference is to the coconut plantations, of which there are many on the Swahili coast. Every morning the mkezi, the professional climber, climbs the trees and cuts down the ripe coconuts. Anyone walking underneath may get one on the head, which is unpleasant; as a result, however, that person will have a coconut, which ia pleasant. So, the proverb has two applicative meanings: (1) Ambitious and greedy people will always be found in places where advantages can be got, or where high offices are to be had, so they are seen in the company of dignitaries and wealthy people; (2) Conversely, if there seems to be a danger somewhere, it is better to be absent

text: Atahiriwapo mtoto (or mwana)wa mtemi, na wa maskini

explanation: Where the chief's son is circumcised, there the son of the poor family should also be circumcised. Opportunity given to an important person or member of the family should also be given to the less fortunate or member of another family
After death, the doctor. When it is too late one looks for the remedy. In the same vein
After the meat, the mustard.

text: Badiliko kwa mjukuu uanze na babu.
explanation: A change needed in a grandchild has to begin with the grandfather. Start early.

text: Bahati ikibisha (or ikipiga) hodi ni sharti ufungue mlango mwenyewe.
explanation: When fortune knocks at the door, you have to open the door yourself. For example: If there is a vacancy for employment, don't wait until you are called, but go after it
Without [overcoming] bees you cannot get honey. Understood: You must confront the bees. If you want to succeed, be ready to deal with difficulties
Don't join in a fight if you have no weapons. Don't start anything without making adequate preparations
A [drinking] glass is not worth a [tin] cup. It's nicer but is easily broken. Beauty versus performance.
When a roof beam falls, fix a new one. "This may refer to a widow or widower"
An owl is not caught from behind. An owl is always looking. It is not easy to challenge a brave person. Vizia: ambush.
A little yeast raises the loaf. A small fire destroys a big forest. Umua: raise.
For always postponing you discover that the child is not yours.
If a frog is thrown into water it doesn't die. This means that a person may believe to have punished somebody while in fact one has done a favor to that person

text: Chura aliapo maji yangali machache, yakijaa halii.
explanation: A frog in shallow water does not cry when the water is high. The frog cries because there is something important going on, e.g., fighting in parliament about something valuable. The frog does not cry when all is well.
A frog cries in the water. Weeps for nothing.
The sailing rope is in [your] hand. The dama is the rope which holds the sail in the wind and is important to catch the wind; it works only "when in the hand." Take your own decisions
You swift kite, if you find [a chicken] grab it. "Make use of the opportunity when it comes"
Go quickly [when you are sent on an errand] and never be negligent. Taghafali: be neglectful, thoughtless, inattentive.
Take care before building. Think carefully about the results and possibilities of your actions. Enga= angalia: consider.

text: 178a. Fanya fundo kwa siku ya mashaka.
explanation: Make a knot for the day of distress. Swahili people used to keep their money in a knot in a corner of their garment. Provide against a rainy day
Money cannot buy "if only I had known." Missed opportunity.

text: Fimbo iliyo mkononi, ndiyo iuayo nyoka.
explanation: The stick in the hand is the one that kills the snake. Often there is no time to look for a weapon, when confronted with a snake. Make the best of what you have; have your credentials with you. Cf. 181.
The stick which is far [not at hand] does not kill the snake. Cf. 207.

text: Fua chuma wakati kingali na moto.
explanation: Strike the iron while it is still hot. Cf. 318.
Never mind brings harm. Carelessness is dangerous - JKP. "If something shows signs of going wrong, it should be rectified immediately so that it can bring no harm"
It does not matter does not kill, but it harms. Cf. 368.

text: Hajikwai mtu kwenye mlima, hujikwaa kwenye kilima cha fuko.
explanation: People do not stumble over a mountain, they stumble over a molehill. "It's easier for a person to stumble over an insignificant matter than over a significant one"
Watch out - a tree and eyes. A warning: Timber! Alaala or halahala: expression of annoyance, impatience.

text: Hamadi [ni iliyo] kibindoni, silaha [ni] iliyo mkononi.
explanation: F. translates freely: "By the Prophet! I have some cash on me, is as good as having a weapon ready in one's hand in time of need." "Only what you have in hand can be relied on"
Secure is what one carries in one's belt.
What is tied in the knot of the loincloth [is secure].
That which is in one's pocket is safe.
hamadi: An exclamation in stumbling or dropping a cup or saucer
Here is not there.
It does not dawn! It does not dawn! ... It dawns! Certain things will happen, even if you believe they will not happen
They are not happening, they are not happening ... they happen - MM. It's no use sticking your head in the sand; you may keep on saying "There's nothing to worry about," but suddenly, there is!
The choice and preference is yours [your final decision]. In the last resort you have to decide for yourself
Fear for what is coming. Prepare for the future.
What is begun well, ends well.

text: Huyaondosha mavi yangali fukuto; yakiisha oza ni magumu.
explanation: One clears the excrement while it is warm, it's more difficult when it is hard. A quick decision is needed before things get worse
That which has passed is not a disease [anymore], cure what is coming. Stop meditating on past troubles, try to prevent their repetition.
One must plead the case of the banana tree while it is still standing. Speaking good of people after their death is useless. Look after your business before it is too late.
A dagger in the belt [sash] and a stick in the hand. Taking precautions.

text: Jambo kuingia sahali, kutoka ni mashughuli.
explanation: It is easy to get involved in a conflict, but to get out is an embarrassment. Sahali (-epesi): easy. Jambo: an affair, matter. Shughuli: trouble.
Tomorrow's business one gets ready today.
What? The answer comes quickly. And is often bad.
Build a house before marrying.

The rooster crows, "My bow is far away." This is what the rooster is supposed to say, as an excuse for not being ready to fight the hawk stealing the chicken. An onomotopoetic line based on the noise made by a crowing rooster. Cf. 838.

text: Jua la asubuhi halidumu siku nzima.
explanation: The morning sun does not last the whole day. Do not delay your plans.
When the sun overtakes us, the stars will be lost. Morning prayers have to be performed before sunrise. There is a right time for everything
When the village head appears greet him there and then. The jumbe are busy people and many look to them for help. Greet them before they leave. You may miss your chance to make your request. Cf. 195.
The [good] old times do not come back.

text: Kama huna saa ya mkono lazima jua likuongoze.
explanation: If you don't have a wristwatch look at the sun for guidance. Be inventive. Don't be stopped by one obstacle.
Take it when you see it, don't wait for what [might] come.
A rope far away does not tie the firewood. Cf.181, 3630.
A catfish does not let the bait go by.
The catfish is straightened when fresh.

text: Kenda fumbata, sio kumi nenda uje [kesho].
explanation: Grasp the nine, not the ten to collect later [tomorrow]. Nine things of which you are sure are better than ten you are promised. "A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush." Cf. 2493, 3481.

text: Kengele hailii bure, mpaka mtu anaichokoza.
explanation: A bell does not ring by itself, someone must put it in motion. Mpaka, ila: but, until. Chokoza: tease, bully, annoy, vex.
Tomorrow is not today. "Said when a customer promises: 'I'll pay tomorrow” - JK.
Shoe for the day of a journey.
A bailing bucket for the day of big waves.
A weapon for the day of battle. All three proverbs warn us to be ready, to be on the alert. A cordial way of greeting one's friends - JK.
The monkey that arrived first does not eat a rotten fruit.
When you see the rope, run before the bull appears. The bull is tied to the rope. This is related to the play between people and bulls on Pemba Island. Be careful and watch out for the early signs.

text: Kinga mkono upewe, kunyang'anya kuna shari.
explanation: Interpose your hand to obtain, taking by force is evil [not allowed]. Show that you are present, to have a chance to receive.

What is sharpened will become sharp [will cut]. What is repeated often enough will stay, even lies. What is cared for will remain useful. Kupata [to get, obtain]: has a special meaning in reference to a knife. E.g., kisu hakipati means: the knife is not sharp - Sacl. pata, kukata: to cut.
The blind do not know that they have information. Maarifa: knowledge, intelligence, information.
A blind person is not asked the way.
A blind one has seen the moon. Something nice happened.
A dull knife slaughters no chicken.
A dull knife cuts no hair. Cf. 285.

text: Kisu kilichomnyoa bundi, na kokotoro kimnyoe.
explanation: The knife that shaved the owl should also shave the kokotoro. The measure given to one should be the same for another. Kokotoro: a kind of nightingale. Cf. 161.

text: Kitendo ni moto, majuto ni mjukuu.
explanation: Action is like fire, sorrow is like a grandchild [it comes afterwards]. Cf. 310.
The first things should be done first.

text: Kivuli cha pungu ni kile cha nderi, mafumo ya ncha ndefu.
explanation: The eagle's shadow is like that of the vulture, spears have long points. Always be vigilant, dangers lurk everywhere - JK.

text: Kobe ukimtupa majini, kwake si mauti bali ni fur âaha.
explanation: If you throw a tortoise in the water, that brings to it not death but joy. Cf.172.
Cough and you may get a mouthful. Make your presence known, so you may be served.
The sheep was denied a beard.

text: Kondoo hakufika kwenye soko la ndevu
explanation: The sheep arrived too late at the beard-market. Animal story: Why the sheep has no beard.
Being told is deceitful, go and see for yourself. See also the section "Lying.
If there be shine or rain. "In any case, at all times"
The chicken goes on eating, [while] they have decided its destiny. People do not know their own destiny. Cf. 299.

text: Kule ni kule hakuwezi kuwa hapa.
explanation: There is there, it can never be here.
The timid bushbuck saves its horns. In spite of the tangled jungle, the long-horned antelope keeps its horns free from entanglement. Cf 257, 2005, 2006.
In order to quench your thirst go to the river. Take appropriate means.

text: Kuni juu uchaga zacheka zilizo motoni.
explanation: Firewood in storage laughs at that in the fire. Don't laugh at people who have trouble, your turn may be near.

text: Kunyolewa kipara si mwisho wa kumea nywele.
explanation: Shaving your head is not the end of growing hair.

text: Kunyolewa kukiwa lazima, kuahirisha si kwema.
explanation: When shaving is necessary, postponing is not good. "Pay your debt"
Tasting is eating. Trying drugs may become addictive.
Don't refuse what is given; time will come when you want it, and are not given.
What should be done today should not wait for tomorrow.

text: La watoro chaka ni lile kwa lile.
explanation: The woody place of the runaways is always the very same

text: Lazima kunyosha mti unapomea (or unapoota) ukiisha kukauka haiwezekani.
explanation: Put the tree straight while it is growing, when it has hardened it cannot be done. Cf. 318.

text: Lazima mti uwe ndani ya maji upate kutelemka.
explanation: For a tree to go down with the current it must be in the water. Without help it is hard to succeed. Cf. 265, 1252, 1789.
Shake the horn of the cow. Stay loose. Shape up, adjust for the changing conditions of life.
Aim well, so that you hit your target. Lekeza, elekeza: point, show, aim. Fuma, hit with a spear or arrow.

text: Leo ni leo: asemaye kesho ni mwongo.
explanation: Today is today, one who says "tomorrow" is a liar. Against procrastination, but is also used when people who boasted to do something, are now asked to keep their promise - MM. Used in wedding songs. Cf. 243, 1535, 1537.
Neglected property is for the thief. Lusu, mwizi: thief. Ghafiliwa: to be thoughtless, neglected.
What is spoiled is mended. "Said to encourage a person to apologize" - JK.
When it [the sun] comes out, bask in it. "Make hay while the sun shines.

text: Lipunguze omo tanga, kuna kusi la hatari.
explanation: Reduce sail up front, the dangerous southerly monsoon is blowing.
What has been is smaller than what will come. We should not waste time thinking about past misfortune, but think about what is coming and prepare ourselves to stand up to it
What has no hand [help] pines away.
Changing is better than resting.

text: Maisha hueleweka ukiyatazama kwa nyuma, lakini tunaishi tukitazama mbele.
explanation: Life can be understood looking backwards, but we live looking forwards. We have to look backwards in order to be able to plan the future.
The shallows are all the same. Everywhere along the coast, the shallow waters are dangerous.
Clear water but deep.

text: Maji ya nazi hunywewa katika (or kutoka) nazi.
explanation: Milk of the coconut is drunk from the nut [to enjoy its freshness]. Cf. 4610.
Faraway water quenches no thirst. Cf.181.
It is wise to cross when the water is still low.

The branches of a tree should be separated while young. This saying means that you should build good character and relationship among children while they are young; it is difficult to do so when they are grown up
The mosquito does not sting the apple of the eye. It does not get the chance. Provide security.
A sprout is a tree. It becomes a tree.

The carver of a wooden spoon saves one's hands. A general explanation by MARA: To save her hand from burning while stirring hot food, a wooden spoon is made. For the same reason that a person buys an umbrella to avoid getting wet, or a bicycle to spare the feet. Cf. 2005, 2006.
One who neglects the thorn in the foot gets elephantiasis. Said of somebody who despises small things like minor injuries; that person will be overtaken by greater evils. Cf. 368.
The alert person eats first. Don't neglect favorable occasions. First come first served. Mkalamuzi (verb, kalamuka): being alert. KS kalamazi.
While you are still on your way, we have already come back. You have to get up early to score one

text: Mkulima hulinda shamba lake la mahindi baada ya nguruwe kuzila.
explanation: The farmer guards the maize after the pigs eat it.
A fire of chaff [under the ashes], continues. A quiet spirit remembers
A distant fire does not burn. The explanation given by FSM is that of #644 A nearby neighbor is better [in need] than a faraway relative. Cf. 181, 4017, 4018.

text: Msafara wa maisha hauna kurudi nyuma.
explanation: Life's caravan never turns back.
A traveler has to think carefully.
A traveler must be self-sufficient.

The traveler is the one who is on the shore. Traveling by sailboat is dependent on wind and cargo; therefore there is no accurate time for departure. Only those who are present at the shore will embark.
One who says "now," is not answered "an hour" [later]. Do not delay when urgent help is needed.

text: Msi chembe wala uta, si muwani.
explanation: One who has neither arrow nor bow is not a warrior. "Be prepared for your task"

text: Msi nadhari ni punda, msi kujua endako.
explanation: One who has no common sense is like a donkey, not knowing where to go. A donkey is not told where the master will lead it -JK. A brainless person is like a cow. Nadhari (ji), akili nzuri: brain. Cf. 2053.
With one trap [net] there is not good hunting.

text: Mtego wa panya huingia waliomo na wasiokuwamo.
explanation: Rats that are here or not yet here may be caught in the trap. A trap does not choose. An action may affect many people; plan carefully.
A tree drops nothing on those who are not there. Cf. 160, 4017, 4918.

text: Mtoto ni baba wa mtu mzima.
explanation: The child is the father of the adult. Cf. William Wordsworth: The child is the father of the man ... [My heart leaps up; 1807.] In the child the adult is already present. Cf. 256, 325.
If you follow your heart you will usually regret it. Kaida = kawaida: usual; afuatao afuataye: one who follows.

text: Mtu akijikuna hufanya marugurugu ya mwili ì.
explanation: If you scratch yourself you raise swellings on your body. People must bear the consequences of their acts. Cf. 2599.
A person scratches where the hand can reach. Do not attempt to do things beyond your means - MM. If you have a problem, you will only solve what you can. Cf. 309, 394.
A person flees a cloud, but does not flee the rain. Flee before the rain starts.
A sickle not sharpened does not shine. Mundu: sickle, billhook, chopper.
The chick sleeps and the hawk is coming. Cf.120.
Someone who borrows a he-goat stays alert. And has to pay attention. Beberu: a he-goat; fig., a strong man. -jifunga: engage oneself.

One who walks in the dark does not stumble. Going in the dark does not necessarily harm an intelligent person. Going in the dark means in dark time, a time of hardship - FSM. With self-knowledge and mutual understanding we should be able to carry on in a hostile world. Cf. 2777.
The first to be there draws no muddy water.

text: Mwendo kikusoza chanda, na kukupiga si kazi.
explanation: If your companion points a finger at you, it is no greater matter [for that person] also to put it in your eye - MM.
One who lays a hand on something finds it easy to appropriate it.

text: Mkono wakisha tia na mguu watatia.
explanation: Having put in their hand they will also put their foot in.
One who is in need goes to the toilet. One who needs something must take the means to get it.
The woman who has a pot on the fire is continually uneasy. The verse goes on
She says: When will it be cooked? So I can serve and eat. Someone who has a small cooking pot on the fire does not stop looking. When you have something on your mind it surely will be known

text: Mwenye kisu kikali ndiye atakayekula nyama.
explanation: The person who has the sharp knife is the one who will eat meat. The person who is ready for the occasion has the best chance to succeed.
The person with the knife slaughters the animal.

text: Mwenye kukaa ni kisuguu, mwenye kuitwa (or kwalika) hakunyima.
explanation: One who remains seated is like an anthill [immovable], one who is called [invited] a gift is not refused. If there is an invitation to receive a gift, one must get up and come forward.

text: Mwenye kusafiri kwa saa ya kula, chakula kiliwe akija aleni?
explanation: If you are traveling at dinner time, and the food is eaten when you arrive, what will you eat?
If you arrive in time you do not miss your chance.
When your companion is being shaved, wash your head [make ready to be shaved too]. One person's fate is another person's lesson

text: Mwenzio akitupa chakula (or ugali), wewe mwaga mchuzi (or kitoweo).
explanation: If your companion throws away the food [porridge], you pour out the gravy [relish]. In Rome do as the Romans. Cf. 289.
A hunter does not blow the flute. Can also mean that hunters should not boast about their kills but should proceed silently.

text: Mwindaji hawezi kupumzika ila baada ya kupika.
explanation: The hunter cannot rest until after the cooking (of the game). An able person does not relax before work is completely done
A coconut is its first milk. The goodness of the coconut is in its first milk [juice]. Tui: the milk of a coconut; the first milk is the best; a much appreciated drink.

text: Ndege aamkaye mapema ndiye aliye wadudu.
explanation: It is the bird that gets up early that eats the insects.
A bird picked on the ground is not suitable for eating. "The moral is that if you want to use something, you should first find out its history to avoid possible harm"

text: Ndizi zitakuivia mgongoni na utashindwa kuzila.
explanation: The bananas will ripen on your back and you'll be unable to eat them. Of those who neglect their affairs.
Know your enemy.
A cow that does not bellow starves in the pen. People will not notice its presence and they will not feed and water that animal. If you do not assert yourself you will not be paid attention to
Stretch the hide while it is still wet. Ili stands for ilipo or ingalipo

The peaks were destroyed and the mountains slept. While people at the top came tumbling down, the people at the lower echelon did not worry about their own fate. Nguu: the summit of a mountain. A more common word is kelele. For a modern application, see 3822.

text: Ni aibu kujikwaa kwenye jiwe moja mara mbili.
explanation: It is a shame to hurt yourself twice at the same stone.
They are now the things, they are now. Now is the time to act. It's now that one has to do what must be done.
The road does not say anything to the traveller. Our destiny is unknown

text: Nyoka alipouma jirani, wewe pia umo hatarini.
explanation: If a snake bites your neighbor, you too are in danger. Cf. 289.
Tracing a snake should begin at your feet. Start looking nearby first, so you won't step on it. Looking for an enemy, look first in your own surroundings
A snake bites where it reaches. An evil person strikes where possible

text: Nyoka mwenye nduma mbili, huuma mara ya pili.
explanation: A snake having two fangs will bite again.
The lucky star is seen at dawn.

text: Nyumba ya jirani ikishika moto, chota maji ya kuzimia yako.
explanation: If your neighbor's house burns, draw water for putting out the fire on yours. If you see others in trouble, help them out and prepare yourself that you may experience similar trouble

text: Nyumba ya usiri ni nyumba mbaya.
explanation: A house of procrastination is a bad house.
When you find water take a bath. If you get the opportunity to do something useful, do it for the opportunity may never come again.
Look where you are going before reaching the place. Think about the consequences of your action. Ola, tazama: look, observe.

text: Ole wako, kanga, uliyeacha maji, ukaloweka mchanga.
explanation: Woe betide you, partridge, you have left the water for bathing in sand. Big changes in life should be considered carefully.
Take away the ceiling and cover [thatch] the roof. Do not put in the ceiling before covering the house. Do first things first.
If you are in a boat remove the water. Take prompt action.
A general warning is [like] a cap. Mind the warning when it fits you.
Don't pass the place where your enemy is.
Take and eat, the earth [of the grave] is waiting for you. Cf. 4496.
Enter where you can enter. You should attempt only that which you can accomplish

text: Pigania kosa lako kama upiganiavyo urithi wako.
explanation: Fight for your case as if you fight for your heritage.

text: 317a. Pindi simba arukapo tafuta mti ukwee.
explanation: When the lion jumps find a tree to climb! Prudence is the better part
Bend the fish while it is still fresh.
Big fish are fished at night. At the shore at night all is quiet and the big fish come to eat the small ones. At night the fishermen go after the big ones.
A shroud that is far away does not bury the dead. Cf.181, 207.
Grasp a knife and eat meat.
An axe without a handle does not cut firewood. Special meaning: Used in speaking about an impotent person. Cf. 207.

text: Sikalii kuti kavu kumtaka mungu shari.
explanation: Don't sit on a dead branch defying God. See also the section Master.

text: Siku moja utajikunia upele katika nguzo.
explanation: One day you'll scratch your scabies against a house pillar. Because you allowed the evil to grow.
A good day becomes evident in the morning. Instead of asubuhi [morning], alfasiri [dawn, daybreak] is used.
For a day of difficulties, a knot [in the loincloth]. The knot in the garment is where one keeps some money - SPK. Cf. 213, 327.

text: Silaha chukua siku zote (or kila saa), sikuye itakufaa
explanation: Carry a weapon always, one day it will be useful to you. A weapon is only a weapon when it is handy.cf. 213.
A killer lion does not roar. If you want to succeed keep quiet. Mgwizi, from gwia or guia: to catch. Gwiji: courageous, expert.
You should not be surprised to smell badly if you have decayed. If you are fallen down you find your name is no longer respected

text: Taa ya muwanga huzimwa ni kope.
explanation: It's the crust on the wick that stops the light of the lamp. Something small can destroy a person. Kope: the burnt end of the wick, the crust that develops after many hours of burning. If it is not removed the lamp goes out. Muwanga, mwangaza: light, shine. Cf. 368.
Control your fist, guard your tongue.

text: Tazama ng'ambo usiyatazame maji uvukapo mto.
explanation: Set your eyes on the other side and do not look at the water when you cross a river. Facing a project, don't get lost in details, bear in mind the end.
Walk with a stick when the person ahead of you slips.
Do as you planned.
The bad watermelon is in your garden. Dispose of it. Dispose of a bad habit.
Follow the trace of blood of the wounded animal. Take proper means to success.
Let's run while they walk. If you want to catch up with someone ahead. Also title of a book by William Edgett Smith : We must run while they walk: A portrait of Africa's Julius Nyerere (1971).
Let's weep while they rejoice. While enemies rejoice beware.

text: Twaishi kwa matendo si kwa miaka.
explanation: We live by deeds, not by years.

Get the clay while it is still wet. This proverb is usually quoted in child rearing. Also advice of elder women to a bride. Upatize, upatilize: causative form of pata, to procure the clay. Uli [ulio]: used in proverbs without a relative. Cf. 318.
A leak sinks even a big ship.

text: Ufanye kilalo (or ulalo) mtoto angali mzima.
explanation: Build the bridge while the child is alive. Prevent accidents if possible.
Youth is smoke: it goes and does not come -JK. "Simply refers to youth; once gone, it is gone forever"

text: Ujana ni maji ya moto, hayakawii kupoa.
explanation: Youth is like hot water, it does not delay to cool off.
Youth passes by like a breeze.
If your eye is swollen [closed], be sure to listen.
If you sleep away, things will pass you by.

text: Ukiona tembo, hutapata hasara: lakini ukiona siafu utapata.
explanation: If you see an elephant you will not suffer damage, but if you see [red] ants you will. Often it is possible to avoid the great dangers, but not the small ones.
If you plant a mvule tree, suffer its drops. Mvule is a hardwood tree, not eaten by termites. Instead of the mvule the mlumba tree is also used
If you plant the borassus palm, suffer also the centipedes [that live in the palm].
If you get it, grasp it. Hold what you have, take what you can

If you love roasted peanuts, get yourself a potsherd [a plate]. Make some effort from your part, don't expect everything from others. No work no gain. Kikalangio (Maniema dialect) [Kigae; kikaya]: an earthen pot used as a stove for charcoals

text: Ukitaka kubugia unga, uwe na mate ya kutosha.
explanation: If you want to chew flour, be sure you have enough saliva. Before starting reflect on the possibility and the tools you need. Bugia: throw a little something in the mouth, such as groundnuts.
If you want to defeat a rat, deny it food.

text: Ukitaka kuzuia simba wasiingie mjini, fuga mbwamwitu.
explanation: If you want to stop lions coming to town, raise jackals.

text: Ukitazama nyuma sana, unaweza kurudi nyuma.
explanation: If you look back too much, you may return there. Don't dwell on past things.

text: Ukitembea na macho angani, utajikwaa mguu.
explanation: If you walk with your eyes fixed in the sky, you will stumble.
If you go out at daybreak, know to lift up your clothing. Because the grass is wet.

text: Ukivishwa kilemba na mfalme fidra vizuri.
explanation: If the king praises you, play your violin well. Fidra, fidla: a fiddle, violin. Visha kilemba: to flatter.

text: Ukiwa na kichwa uwe na fikara.
explanation: If you have a head, you'd better think.

text: Ukiwaona wenzako wakikimbia na wewe ukimbie.
explanation: If you see your friends running, you too should run.
You are late, midday is not dawn.
When you see the chief, that's when you start greeting.
When you think that you are safe, that's when you are in danger.
The millet of the person who would have used the catapult, is eaten [by birds]. Teo: a catapult [sling], used for throwing stones at birds. Cf. 2667.
Don't go without questioning. When you are sent on an errand, you have to know why you are sent and for what. It could be a wild goose chase. Cf.1564.
Don't delay casting your spell, the night is coming. It should be done before someone else comes along

text: Usione kwenda mbele, kurudi [nyuma] si kazi.
explanation: Don't stop going forwards, going back is easy. "Do not be proud of going ahead in society, sliding back to poverty will be all too easy"
Don't wonder about things that did not happen; wonder about things that are here now.
You will bite ten [fingers] and not get one [thing].. Biting fingers signifies regret and self-reproach
Support the banana tree while it is still standing. Take care of your business before it is too late. Cf.195.
Destroy the ceiling so that you can cover the roof.
Break the bones while you have teeth.
Pull the loincloth of the boss, if you are forgotten. Show that you need help.
Time has no patience. Time does not stand still.
Time favors the eager ones [early ones].

text: 376a. Wakati wa heri sasa, sasa! Fanya mambo sasa!
explanation: The very best time - now! Do things now!
When they weep, we'll laugh. Cf. 337.
Those who are ahead of you at the buffet have bigger mouthfuls than you. They have more on their plates than you. Chanoni: at the big serving plate.
When they sleep we should be awake. Do not rest on what you have achieved.

text: 379a. Watu wengi hukutunza, watakwamba kisa pia.
explanation: Many people are watching you and they will talk about you as well.
The wate in a tin is not as good as the water in a stone pot. Water in a stone pot is the symbol of a wife at home. Tanaki: a four-gallon tin, a debe. Tundwi, mtungi: waterpot.

text: Yaliyopita yamepita, yaliyosalia kitupe cha mongo.
explanation: What is passed is passed, what remains let's throw it behind us. Mongo: abbreviation of mwongo or mgongo, back. Cf. 194.
When need comes the hungry person will be sorry (having no provisions).
The past does not come back.
Stop the crack in the wall, so the mouse will not get through. Mwanya, ufa: crack. Cf. 368.

text: Afungaye kibwebwe si bure ana mchezo.
explanation: She who ties a [broad strip of calico as a] waistbelt does not do so for nothing, she is [intent] on playing. If somebody is getting involved with something, it is clear that that person thinks it is worthwhile.
One who slaves in the sun knows [what he/she is doing]. Does not work in vain. A person with an aim or purpose.
When the sultan knows no solution to a problem (lit.,is defeated), what can the citizens do? Cf. 438.

text: Aliye na hamu ya kupanda juu hukesha.
explanation: A person who desires to rise [in society] must stay awake.
The one who is ahead is ahead; the one who follows must make an effort.
One who tries hard will profit. Encouragement to exert oneself.
One who craves for something does not get tired; and if tired, that person has already acquired it. Said to somebody who's giving up
One climbs to the top to make noise. Or: One who climbs to the top, usually makes noise. Boasts about it.

text: Atakaye kufuga ng'ombe aanze na kuku.
explanation: One who would like to raise a cow should start with a hen. Don't despise small beginnings.

text: Atetemeshae mti wenye matunda hutaraji matunda kumwangukia.
explanation: One who shakes a fruit tree expects some fruit to fall his/her way. Said of a dependent expecting favors
One who itches, scratches. "A person should do what is possible, and not wait for other people to find a solution"
You cannot cross the ocean by swimming.
If you can't build a hut, build a shack.
Iron is not broken and sand is not chewed. About something that cannot be done.
The ant hunts the honey pots.
Always forward.

text: Dau dogo huambaa mwambao, kubwa huenda penye kilindi.
explanation: A little boat keeps near the shore, a larger vessel ventures out to the deep sea. Do not try things too big for you.
Success breeds success. A person successful in a certain project is encouraged to attempt another one. Nothing succeeds like success.

text: Haja ya mwenye haki ni mema.
explanation: What a good person is looking for is doing good deeds.

Even an old person climbs the palm tree. Harvesting palm nuts asks for much strength and agility. The understanding is that an old person presumes himself capable of vigorous things like having a chance with a young woman
You do not have the strength to defeat an elephant. "Don't try the impossible"

text: Huna mshipi, hu nangwe: kuomoa tenga na nini?
explanation: You have not line nor rope: with what [do you think] to land a sea-monster? Said of somebody who undertakes an impossible task. Hu nangwe is probably a contraction of huna ugwe: you have no rope
You cannot know what you can do until you have tried.
If it gets very fat it will fry itself. Said about somebody who is exaggerating, overdoing or showing off.
Try and you'll see [know].
Effort does not annul the power of God.
All man's effort can do nothing against the will of God

Diligence and zeal do not annul what is appointed by God. Muslims believe that everything is ordained from birth to death by God. A person's means of subsistence, day and time of death are fixed. Those things a person cannot change, how much one tries. This should help a person to accept failure. One cannot change one's destiny, so don't be upset. Also in great difficulties leave the outcome in the hands of God
Trying is not the same as succeeding - J. Notwithstanding the effort, one does not always get what one aimed for.
Sit and eat, you'll eat a hill. Stand up and work to get more and you can eat a mountain.
Early rising is being ahead. "The early bird catches the worm.
When [sweet] cassava is available, cassava in fermentation is not eaten. It would be foolish to abstain from what is better. Kivunde: cassava which has been steeped until fermentation has begun.
If you [feel] bad, learn to sing. Do better, do somthing new, something positive to lift your spirits.

text: Kelele za chura hazimkatazi ng'ombe kunywa maji.
explanation: The noise of the frog does not stop the cow from drinking water.
The creaking of the door does not deprive me of respect. Does not take away my good name.

text: Kelele za mlango hazimwudhi mwenye nyumba.
explanation: The creaking of the door doesn't bother the owner of the house. One gets used to those things and doesn't notice even what is wrong.

text: Kelele za mpagaji hazimuasi mwenye nyumba kulala.
explanation: The noise of the tenant does not deprive the homeowner of sleep.  But also

text: Kelele za mwenye nyumba hazimkatazi (or hazimuudhi) mgeni kulala.
explanation: The noise of the owner of the house does not stop the guest from sleeping. One in need accepts inconveniences.
A healthy young person climbs mountains. Youth can do anything
Every one arranges his/her way of life.
All beginning is difficult.

text: Kila ndege huruka kwa bawa lake.
explanation: Every bird flies with its own wings. Each bird flies according to the power of its wings
Every bird has its own wing. Every person has his own endowment; one must not go beyond one's possibilities.
Every bird has its own food. There's no accounting for tastes. Cf. 420.

text: Kila tawangu lina kifuniko (or mfiniko wake) chake.
explanation: Every casket has its lid. Every girl will find a husband
Whatever you do, do it well.
The mud wall was too much for you [to build], how then will I be able to do it!
Don't hold dear the nice thing that you cannot achieve.
The tortoise will die without ever having scratched his own back. "Many people have never achieved a high purpose in their lives"
Living is the intention. What makes a life worthwhile is having a purpose, an aim.
Claiming something falsely is like the water beans are cooked in. It is lacking substance. Alijidai usultani: he claimed a sultanship, without having a right to it. False pretence.
Aiming is not the same as hitting.
Aiming is not the same as hitting. An extension of the proverb

text: Kulekeza si kufuma, ndiyo yaliyo, mwandani.
explanation: Aiming is not hitting, that is the case, my friend.

text: Kuelekeza si kufuma, na kuchumbia si kuoa.
explanation: Aiming is not the same as hitting and wooing is not the same as marrying. Used of people who make many plans after which they are content to sit back as though they had attained their aspirations.
The one who has aimed has not hit yet. Do not cry victory too soon
If firewood is lacking, the fire dies. An organisation without a leader cannot survive. But also: Without input no organisation will survive.

text: Kwenda mbele (or kutangulia mbele) siyo kufika.
explanation: Going in front does not mean arriving at the destination.
My word is not finished yet, yours is finished. "I have more and better arguments"

text: Mama wee! Niulaga nunda mla watu.
explanation: Eh, mother! I'll kill that man-eating monster. A children's boast/hunter's song (Nights of Zanzibar). N.B.: Ulaga (Nyika dialect) or ua: kill.

text: Mbwa kufukuza tembo ni kuchokoza bure.
explanation: A dog chasing away an elephant is a useless effort. A pretentious person is open to ridicule.
A butcher does not want to see somebody else slaughtering. Professional jealousy.
Can a dog crush the bone that defeated a hyena?
The bone got the better of the hyena, how then can a person ? This is said of a stubborn child, who does not listen to advice

text: Mimi chigi, kimara migunda, mganamba ni mdogo.
explanation: I am chigi, I finish harvests, although you call me small. Chigi: name of a small yellow bird, which comes in flocks to lay waste whole grain fields.

text: Miye mtoto wa mama kisamvu-kichacha: muhogo hauivishi ndizi mbivu.
explanation: I am a child of mother "bitter cassava leaves." Everybody has his/her own limitations
A plan [alone] is no use. It is the implementation of the plan that makes it useful
Give the child a name to grow up to. Name is important. A child tries to imitate its namesake.
A traveler has a hard time. Kula as an idiom changes meaning according to the accompanying noun
The traveller [who is determined to go] far, will pass the mountain. Cf. 1094.
A hunter is not afraid of thorns. Someone who wants to succeed must not be afraid of difficulties.
An arrow without a feather will not go far. Certain things are necessary for success, though seemingly unimportant
An arrow ill-feathered goes askew. Cf. 859.
A tailor does not choose the cloth. One must do with what one has. A teacher does not choose students.

text: Msinji ukiinama hauna nguvu; usiushtaki ukuta ukianguka.
explanation: A foundation that is not level is not strong; don't blame the wall if it falls down.

The one who wants what is under the bed must stoop for it. Good things are not easily obtained, one must strive to get them. Mvungu: "The people [of Zanzibar] make use of the place beneath the bed as a place of storage for such articles as cooking utensils, provisions, etc."
A special application: If you are interested in other peoples' dirty laundry, you will have to debase yourself
One who wants what is far away walks to it. One has to make all possible efforts to succeed.
Let a person who wants to go ahead, pass. If you don't you'll have a fight on your hands. Cf. 4084.
Let a person who desires, but has nothing, stay a-wanting. Said of someone who has no ambition, but envies others - MM.
A person who has a great need has no shame. A beggar has no fear of what people may say - Sacl.
One who looks forward does not see what is behind.
An [aimless] wanderer wears [lit., eats] away his/her feet. Lives off his/her feet

text: Mtembea saa ya chakula akifika watu wamekila.
explanation: The traveller at mealtime, when he/she arrives, people have eaten
Work for the unbeliever to obtain your goal. Overcome your antipathy towards a task or person in order to get the thing you need or want. Kafiri: an unbeliever. In this case, someone you do not like.
A person becomes what he wants to become.

text: Mtumikie kafiri ili upate mradi wake.
explanation: Serve [even] an unbeliever to attain your own ends. Mradi: project. Cf. 455.
A beginning is painful, the end is enjoyable. A happy ending comes after a painful effort.

text: Mwenye kuamka mbele anamtukana mwenzake utongo.
explanation: The one who rises first in the morning laughs at a bleary-eyed companion. Activity is better than laziness. Utongo: discharge from the eyes.
The one who makes an effort will succeed.

text: Mwenye meno makali ndiye mmaliza nyama.
explanation: The person with sharp teeth is the one who finishes the meat.
The limit of the meadow is the rope. A cow tied with a rope can only feed on the grass up to the point where the stretched rope reaches

text: Mzowea kwenda mbio, harudi kungwa kule.
explanation: One who is used to running does not turn back even if it is still far [to go]. An active character achieves his goal
I play for here below, I don't play for high-up. Present life takes precedence over the unobtainable.
I play for the earth, I don't play for heaven.

text: Ndovu ni mnyama mkubwa lakini hazai mapacha.
explanation: The elephant is a big animal but she does not give birth to twins.
Get someone who can push the boat down [into the water]. "Choose a strong and able man to help you. Advice to young girls to get themselves husbands who can perform successfully"
You get it. You do it. If you cannot compete you say: "You get it.
The inhabitant of Pemba Island does not relieve himself on the ground if he finds a tree trunk to sit on.

text: Samaki mfu hufuata mkondo, samaki hai huenda kinyume cha mk.
explanation: A dead fish floats down stream; a live one goes up stream. Cf. 1050.

text: Sifa humfanya mwema mwema zaidi, mbaya mbaya zaidi.
explanation: Honor makes a good person better and a bad person worse.

text: Sifa kama mtu huwa nyeupe kadiri inavyozeeka.
explanation: Honor is like a person getting white hair when getting older.
Do no make strivings with a person. Never match thyself with [any] person. Cooperation, not competition.
Do not compete with one who is more powerful than you.
Keep hoping until the end. Be confident.
If you destroy [your house of] bricks, build with stones.
If you are afraid to be talked about, you will not do anything. Cf. 2015.
If you observe what a chicken eats, you will not eat the chicken. If one knew all the difficulties involved in a project, one might not have started it. "Do not ask too many questions"
If you see what a chicken eats, mama you would not eat the chicken. Nunu, The twenty-fifth letter of the Swahili-Arab alphabet - Sacl. A polite way of calling someone Kiswahili sanifu.. Variations
If you watch a goose, you will not eat it.
Had you known what bees eat, you would not have tasted honey. Ignorance is sometimes better than knowledge

text: Ukila kuku - sitazame (or usiulize) chakula chake.
explanation: If you eat chicken - don't look [don't ask] what it eats. Cf. 478

text: Ukila na timsaha, hutapata nyingi raha.
explanation: If you want to eat with the crocodile, you will not have much pleasure

text: Ukilima-lima uinuke, ni vitu vya walaji wengi.
explanation: If you work hard on your farm, look up [you are preparing] food for many mouths. Greater activity profits others

text: Ukioka samaki, huwezi kuondoa manyoya ya kuku.
explanation: If you bake fish, you cannot pluck a chicken at the same time. One must not have too many irons in the fire. Do one thing at a time.
If you like dirt, you'll become clean. To obtain good things one must go through hardship.
If you want to build you must be willing to destroy.

Stretch your legs according to the length of your bed. Spend according to your means. Common sayings: Stretch your arm no further than your sleeve will reach; Everyone stretches his legs according to the length of the coverlet.

text: Upepo huchukua vingi na kufikisha kidogo.
explanation: The wind removes much but brings very little. It doesn't take you to your destination.

text: Usibabue kima wawili motoni, mmoja ataungua mkia.
explanation: Do not skin two monkeys over fire [at the same time], one will have a burned tail. Cf. 480, 1543, 1546, 1547.
Don't guess.

text: Usijaze kitungo chako kwa chikichi zisizofaa.
explanation: Don't fill your basket with useless nutshells. Look for the useful only. Kitungo: a small round flat basket used for sifting husks from grains by tossing.
Don't eat the gourd, otherwise you may be overcome by the stem. Do not start things too big for you. Kiyembo (Lamu dialect): stem of the fruit.

text: Usinywe kama tembo, utapasuka tumbo (or usifuate ¯tembo kunywa, utapasuka tumbo).
explanation: Do not try to drink as an elephant, you will rend your stomach
If you want to match the heap left behind by the elephant, something will give. Don't try to do things too big for you, such as living beyond your means. Cf. 82.

text: Usipokubali kutia mguu majini hutavuka kijito.
explanation: If you don't want to put your foot in the water, you'll not cross the brook. Take the right means.
Don't look for something difficult that has no hardship.
Don't desire to do big things before you have accomplished small ones.
Don't follow your foot where it is going. Know where you are going and what you are doing. Have a purpose in life.

What is not sharp pointed does not penetrate. Usotongelewa, [usiochongelewa]: what is not sharpened. Haudungi [hauchomi]: does not pierce. Hautungi : does not put together; e.g., put pieces of meat on a skewer. Cf. 445.

text: Uta wangu haufumi shore ila ngurama
explanation: My bow does not kill swallows, but only big birds. I am after bigger and better game. Ngurama: a big bird.
You will go, you will return. Do not be too ambitious.
Put your hope on the plant you have planted. Work has promise for the future.
All beginnings are difficult. Cf. 422.
One who is in front does not stay back [stay behind].
The one who is behind does not arrive in front.
One who does not know to forgive, should not expect to be forgiven.
A small pot boils quickly. It takes very little to anger a small mind

text: Dawa kubwa ya hasira ni kuchelea.
explanation: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
Revenge does not sleep.

text: Ghadabu ni kali, hasira ni gharika.
explanation: Anger is fierce, but wrath is like a flood. Ghadabu and hasira : hate. Ghadabu is short; hasira is more personal; resentment.
Damage [loss] is the child of anger. Cf. 505.
Anger is loss. Anger damages and is a wasted effort. Said of people who display much emotion.

text: Hasira huinua mikuki; uvumilivu huinua madafu.
explanation: Anger lifts spears, forbearance draws coconuts. "a patient person invites the provoker to join for a drink of coconut juice" - EM. Coconut juice is a refreshing drink given to visitors.
Hot tempers cool friendship. Especially if the reason for anger is not explained
Anger is a costly luxury. Especially when a valuable article or relationship is destroyed
Anger is a short madness. Kichaa: madness.
Anger is slavery. "if anger is not controlled, it controls"

text: Hasira ya mkizi furaha ya mvuvi.
explanation: The anger of the cuttlefish is the joy of the fisherman. An angry person hurts himself most often. Folklore tells us that the angry cuttlefish, when caught on the line, will jump out of the water into the boat of the fisherman.

text: Hasira za mkizi tijara ya mvuvi.
explanation: The anger of the cuttlefish fish is the profit of the fisherman.

text: Hasira za mkizi furaha [tijara] ya mwenye wando.
explanation: The anger of the 'eel' is the joy [profit] of the one who has the net
Where anger arrives shame will come too. Shame, regrets follow anger.
A sound reply does not require one to say it in anger. A person may not be obliged to answer a question, but if he does, he should do so without anger
A kind answer reduces anger.
To lose one's temper is to go astray
Water of a freshet [mountain stream] passes quickly.
Boiling water does not linger to cool off. Cf. 2838, 2886, 3083.

I am like a dugong, i die of the least wound. Do not anger me more, that could have evil consequences. Nguva:: dugong, large herbivorous mammal of indian seas, similar to a manatee. 
 Cf. 526.
A poor person is never angry. The poor are always patient and humble, knowing that they are losers. Indeed being too soft. It might help to show anger from time to time
Fire does not beget fire.
Fire does not give birth to fire, but to ashes. Could also be used to say that bright and honest parents do not necessarily have bright and honest children

text: Mpiga ngumi (or konde) ukutani [ni] huumiza mkonowe.

explanation: If the river thunders, there are stones in its bed. Even if the river grumbles, its bed reposes on stones. People in authority must accept their subjects, anger does not change anything

text: Mwenye ghadhabu mbele yake husimama shetani.
explanation: The devil stands in front of an angry person. Cf. 528.
An angry person arrives too late. Anger makes a person miss his chance.
A person who is coleric is incapable of farming rice. That person is irresponsible, lacks patience.

text: Mwenye hasira hawezi kuongoza mbuzi njiani.
explanation: An irascible person cannot lead goats on the way. Anger is the cause of bad treatment. This is said of a caretaker of a widow's children and not fit to be a tutor.
The body is full of knots [meaning bones that stick out]. A person is full of hidden rancor and grudges.
A mud hut cannot withstand great shocks. Said of a quick-tempered person who cannot bear to be put out. Only rich people with big masoned houses can afford to quarrel in private.

text: Kifua chake nyumba ya udongo, haihimili vishindo.
explanation: His chest is like a mud-house, it cannot withstand shocks. Cf. 518, 3957.
One who kneels is not killed. A person who surrenders is not killed. One who asks for pardon is not punished - EM.
It is when you are in anger that the devil will get hold of you. Cf. 522.
When you wash your face, you finish at the chin. This means that if you want to end a dispute, you discuss its causes and then end by an apology
Don't kill me as the crow and be sorry afterwards. The person killed the crow for a misdeed the crow had not committed.
Don't drink your sweat, there is water ahead of you. Don't get angry; after the rain there is sunshine.

text: Usipoteze hasira yako, wengine watafurahi sana kuiona.
explanation: Don't waste your anger, many will be very happy to see you angry.

text: Utakufa na laiti na chanda kili kinywani.

citations.page: 562. You will die with an alas [i'm sorry] and your finger still at your lips. Said of people who are not serious in their pursuit of better things. Finger at the lips (mouth) is a gesture of vexation. "said when someone is about to do something and regret it later"

explanation: Those who quarrel are those who make it up. One must not quarrel all the time: man is made for reconciliation
Quarrelers usually reconcile.

text: Waja uma kumi usipate hata kimoja.
explanation: You come and bite ten [fingers], but don't get even one. Said if someone quarrels with many, but does not listen and gets nothing out of it. Better to listen to the views of others.
They quarrel about bananas, but the tree is not theirs. Do not quarrel about things that don't belong to you.

A demon who knows you will not eat you completely. A father, no matter how angry, does not kill his child. A husband may beat his wife, but he does not go as far as to kill her. A person you are acquainted with will not cause you extreme harm. He must bear in mind your kindness. And you should have the same attitude towards him
One holding his hands together above his forehead is not beaten. That person surrenders, asking for pardon. Cf. 527.

text: Chikichi ni tunda zuri, ila hamna mnofu ndani yake.
explanation: The palm nut is a nice fruit, but there is no meat inside.
A leopard hiding its claws does not become a kitten.
There is no small blemish. One rotten fruit spoils the whole basket. A bad member of the family or neighborhood spoils all members. Dosari: blemish, defect, kink. Cf. 758.
A brainless giant is like a tree log. Don't give an important job to such a person, however big, fearsome or beautiful that person may be. Gimba or kimba: a giant.
It's useless to beautify. A good person does not need to add other things.
Flies have no quarrel with the pot. The many flies around the pot seem to be angry, but they are looking for food. Sometimes the first impressions are wrong.

text: Jamala mtuni utu, sifa ya ndege si mabawa.
explanation: The beauty of a person is mainly his/her good character; the bird is not praised for its wings. A bird is praised for its songs or meat. Jamala: beauty, goodness, kindness.

text: Kambare mzuri kwa mwili, ndani machafu.
explanation: A catfish has a nice body, but it is full of dirt. A catfish, also called mudfish, often has a bad smell.

Cut off your nose to mend your face. Used, e.g., of a person going into debt to keep up appearances. Does not have the same meaning as the english proverb, "to cut off one's nose to spite one's face," which is said of one who, to be revenged of his neighbor, has materially injured himself.
What enters town is not prohibited. That which is fashionable in town is never prohibited
A beautiful cup [bowl] has no [long] life. Beauty does not last long.

text: Kila ajaye na shoka hapo hawi msaramALa.
explanation: Whoever comes with an axe is not necessarily a carpenter.

text: Kila mwenye kucha si lazima awe simba.
explanation: Not everyone with nails has to be a lion.
A turban does not make a man civilized.
For a fat sheep, just look at its tail. A sheep stores its fat in its tail.
To adorn oneself is not the same as becoming adorable.

text: Kulima na koya, mwenye mwana hana goya.
explanation: Hoeing and resting, a parent has no (time for) his/her toilette. During cultivation time one has intervals of rest, but there is no rest in rearing children. Goya, made to rhyme with koya (rest): coquettish

text: Kwamba (or kama} uzuri waliwa kapike ule (or ale) mwenyewe.
explanation: If beauty can be eaten, go and cook it and eat it.
Fierce eyes, but soft mouth. Lacking courage when it's time to speak up.
Apes don't laugh at each other's looks.
Bow legs don't matter, the going is important.

text: 559a. Matunda si mazu, mazu ni mekundu.
explanation: The fruits are not ripe, the ripe ones are red. Said when it is evident that something is not right.

text: Mbawa nzuri ni alama ya ndege mwema.
explanation: Beautiful feathers are a sign of a good fowl. Being in good condition.
A banana tree is not overly bothered by its cluster of fruit. A parent is not overly bothered by a misbehaving child. Cf. 569.
The mkwara does not need ointment. A good looking person does not need adornment. Wood of the mkwara tree (much used for firewood) does not need oil [to burn]
