The mnyonyore shrub has no scent, [and yet] its flowers are pleasing. Said of people who do good without boasting.
A beautiful girl but just like a statue [lit., an insect]. Funza: insect, jigger; a carving, statue, figure (mbombwe). Kumbe: lo behold (amazement).
A gap between teeth is not the same as the gap of a lost tooth. Mwanya: the little space between front teeth; a sign of beauty.
A person with whiskers did not lack a razor. He wanted to grow a beard.
A beautiful person is not without a blemish.

text: Ndege mdogo kwa watu, kwao ndege mkubwa.
explanation: A bird is small for people, but big among birds. Opinions differ according to people, places and customs

A cow is not oppressed by its hump. The zebu, common in tanzania, has a big hump on its shoulders. The hump is a storing place of fat during abundance of good pastures. Do not complain about your burdens and responsibilities
An elephant is not encumbered by its trunk. Nature does all wisely

text: Ngozi ya chui uzuri kwa macho, ndani adui.
explanation: A leopard skin is beautiful to see, but inside there is an enemy. Beauty often hides a cruel heart
Big ear decorations have had their fashion. Njewe, ndewe: a pierced hole in the ear lobe.

text: Nyuki hauliwi na utamu wa asali yake.
explanation: The bee is not killed by the sweetness of its honey. Cf. 569.

text: Nyumba njema si mlango,fungua uigie ndani.
explanation: A good home is not only the door; open it and enter. It's impossible to know a welcoming family by looking at the door. It is not until you enter that you will know. You cannot know a good person until you get acquainted - MARA.
The faces of the monkeys are all the same.
A new garment does not stay (new and shiny) except with the old one (lit., rotten). Don't wear your new clothes every day
Where there is finery, there lies the snare
Character has no cure. Tiba: medicine.

text: Tabia siyo nguo, haibadiliki kwa urahisi.
explanation: Character is not like clothing, it is not easily changed.
If you approach a city dust yourself.
If you approach a city, change your clothing. Show respect to others.

text: Ukimkuta mtu mfupi penye njiapanda, hutamkuta mtoto.
explanation: If you meet a short person at the crossroad, don't take him/her for a child. Lit.., you will not meet a child. When the sukuma meet a short person [a pygmy], the pygmy will ask where did you see me [wanibonerahe?], and the sukuma will say: "i saw you from very very far", in order not to anger the pygmy. They call pygmies: wanibonerahe.
If you want beauty, you must suffer pain. To achieve greatness one must work hard. Whatever good thing you want, you'll have to pay for it
The flour which you underrated will lead to the well. Will make you successful. Don't judge appearances only. Cf. 89.

text: Urefu siyo akili na ufupi si umaskini.
explanation: Length is not intelligence and being short [of stature] does not mean being poor.

text: Usawa wa binadamu umeachana kama ngozi ya pundamilia.
explanation: The similarity of people is as different as the hide of a zebra. All people are different from each other.
Don't kill yourself for the feathers of the guinea-fowl. To harm oneself for appearance's sake is deceiving

text: Usihadaike kwa rangi, utamu wa chai sukari.
explanation: Don't be deceived by the color; the delight of tea is the sugar. Look for what is essential.
Don't kill yourself for a tall, slim person. A person's worth does not depend on shape - AL.

text: Usione wembamba wa reli gari moshi linapita.
explanation: Do not see [only] the narrowness of the railway, when the train passes by
Beauty and pride go to the grave.

text: Uzuri wa kaburi nje, ndani hujaa uvundo.
explanation: A tomb may be nice outside, but inside there is an evil smell.

text: Uzuri wa kanga kuvaa nguo si kusilimika.
explanation: The guinea fowl has beautiful plumage; [however] wearing [beautiful] clothes is not the same as being civilized.
The mulberry tree is beautiful, however inside it's full of grubs.

text: Uzuri wa makaa, ndani kipande cha miti.
explanation: The charcoal is beautiful but inside there is only wood.

text: Uzuri wa mkakasi ndani kipande cha mti.
explanation: The beauty of a round casket, inside there is only wood. However beautiful a vanity box on the outside, the inside is wood. Often used to describe a beautiful person with an evil character. But also used to describe things.

text: Uzuri wa godoro uzuri wa nje tu, kwa ndani mna pamba.

citations.page: 250. The beauty of a mattress is on the outside, inside there is cotton

text: Uzuri wa mkakasi, ukipata maji basi.
explanation: What regards the beauty or perfume of the little box, it gets wet and that is the end of it. Mkakasi: a small varnished wooden box imported from india. Uzuri [beauty], a variation of uturi [perfume] - j.

text: Uzuri wa papai, ndani hamna kitu.
explanation: A pawpaw looks nice, but inside it's empty. There is no wood. Papai, the fruit; mpapai, the tree. The inside of the papai tree is good for nothing.

text: Uzuri wa suke la muhindi unaonekana ndani tu.
explanation: The beauty of the corn cob is apparent in the inside only. In order to see the condition of the corn [ðseeds], one has to take off the bracts [overleaves]. Don't let appearances fool you.
Beauty depends on the one who looks. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
Toes and fingers are not all the same. So with people.
Ornaments and clothes are not worth more than books or education.

text: Vumilia shida kwa ajili ya panja.
explanation: Suffer hardship for a clear temple. This proverb refers to somebody who gets a haircut, which is not always painless. The one who gets a haircut turns his head here and there as the barber tells him. It is understood that the barber's knife or razor blade was not always honed.
A rose is surrounded by thorns. Nothing beautiful, perfect or good is without problems.

text: Wazuri wa mwanzi uharibiwa tundu lake.
explanation: The beauty of the flute is spoiled by the hole. Mwanzi: bamboo, reed, pipe, tube, musical pipe, flute.
The thinness of the peanut shell covers a solid [nut]. The outside is deceitful.

The weight of food one eats, does not inconvenience. The load of food someone carries does not hamper the carrier. Because it's to the carrier's advantage. Hard work that is profitable is not heavy. Cf. 569.
The hair is done, but the head is still there.
The one who scratches oneself has an itch. Cf. 735.

text: Akaaye karibu na moto huandaliwa mwanzo.
explanation: The one who sits near the fire is served first. One must have friends at court
The great intellects usually think alike.

Chickens and their kind use an identical support. They have the same behaviorism like standing on one leg. People of the same rank, country or status can be recognized. Mtegemeo: prop, support, also trust. Cf. 786.
One who eats a corpse will have his/her eaten.
One who follows a thief is feared to become a thief.

text: Amletae nyoka nyumbani akili zake hazimo kichwani.
explanation: One who brings a snake home has a head without brains.
The person who refuses rejoicing is a witch. Cf. 615.
A person who dislikes company is a wizard. East Africans especially dislike loners. Mchawi: a person of either sex who practices magic.
The person who shaves you badly is your own person [servant, member of family, son or daughter]. Cf. 1651.
A person who lives alone [keeps to self] is a wizard.

text: 617a. Asali na shurubati hayana moja ladhati.
explanation: Honey and syrup are not the same in taste. Not all sweet girls are the same. Honey has a natural sweetness, whereas shurubati, 'sorbet' is a sophisticated combination of delicious flavours
One who does not trust others, cannot be trusted.

One who does not know you, does not value you. This proverb nowadays has a special meaning: age status is not respected automatically. Now if you meet even an older person who could be your father or mother, you might not give them the same respect as you would do in the olden days. A person now wants to know that person before paying respect
It is useless for me to recognize a person who does not recognize me.
Disaster is brought upon you by your own people.

text: Baba na mtoto mwanaume: mama na mtoto mwanamke.
explanation: The father and his son, the mother and her daughter.
It is better to build bridges than walls. "It is better to unite than separate people"
Every] beam has its companion

text: Cha kichwa kitamu, na cha mkia kitamu.
explanation: If the head is tasty the tail also is tasty. If the head is good eating, the tail is even better. The tail of an East African sheep is a delicacy. "One cannot accept one and reject the other person"

My good thing is your bad thing. What is good for me is not good for you. This proverb refers to the story of the fool who stole the butcher's knife and killed a man with it. He was hanged. Yet the butcher kills every day with the same knife and remains a respected citizen

text: Chetu si changu, usitumaini cha mwenzako.
explanation: Ours is not mine, don't rely on what is your companion's. You cannot claim what is ours as yours alone.
A bad sign [guide] brings you to a bad place.
Medicine follows the sore. Medicine is applied according to the kind of sore.
You need a mirror to see a blot on the face. To know one's weakness, one needs help.
Avoid evil and evil will avoid you. Cf. 4017.

text: Fuata kondo! Fuata kondo! Dunia haifuatiki.
explanation: Follow the flow! Follow the flow! It's impossible to follow the world. To follow the life-styles of other people. Kondo (Maniema dialect), mkondo: flow of a river, track of passage. Cf. 633.
Follow where the water goes. Swim with the stream. Cf. 1326.
Follow the river to find the sea. If you follow the river you will eventually see the sea or the lake
Follow the bee so that you may eat honey. Associate with the right people. Cf. 698.

Joy has flavor when you are many. Happiness is perfect when it is shared. A related story is of the Sunday fisherman who was always laughed at because he never caught anything to show. But on the day he had a master catch, nobody was there to see him coming home.

text: Gome la udi si la mnukauvundo.
explanation: The sweet smelling bark is not the same as the [evil smelling] bark [of the Cassia occidentalis]. To live with civilized, friendly people is not comparable to living with people who have bad manners
The wheels are iron, the rails are iron. Like father, like son.

text: Haifai kutia embe lenye kuoza katika maembe mazuri.
explanation: It's not good to put a rotten mango among good ones.

text: Hakuna chawi aliyekiri kuwa mi chawi.
explanation: There is no wizard who believes to be a wizard.

text: Hakuna lisilo nduguye ni kama ngozi na mfupa.
explanation: There is nothing without its sibling, like skin and bone. "Every man can find a wife, The skin always covers the bone until death part them"
Every [pot] has its brother (i.e., a lid).

text: Hata katika kundi mtu anaweza kuwa peke yake.
explanation: Even in a crowd a person can be alone.
They don't leave each other, they are like the little dog and its caretaker. Common interest. Mtwa: a benefactor

text: Heri jirani karibu kuliko ndugu mbali.
explanation: A neighbor nearby is better than a relative far away.

text: Alla, alla, jirani kama ndugu mli kule.
explanation: By God, it is from the neighbor [that help is expected] when your relative is away

text: Hujui ginsi anavyokula mtu, je utampa chakula katika jani?
explanation: You don't know how a person eats, so, will you serve food on a banana leaf?

text: Ila ya kikwapa kunuka pasipo kidonda.
explanation: The evil-smelling armpit is like a woundless defect. Used when somebody does not try to correct minor mistakes.
Yesterday is today risen at another time.

text: Jasho ya mbwa haipiti manyoya yake.
explanation: The sweat of a dog does not go beyond its coat. You must not inconvenience others with your difficulties.
If] the eye is unable to see, the nose weeps. Cf. 650.
The eye cannot see itself.
If the eye is sick, so is the nose. If one part of your body hurts, your whole body suffers. Near relatives feel and suffer for each other

text: Jirani mwema ni bora kuliko rafiki.
explanation: A good neighbor is better than a friend. We can live without friends but not without neighbors. Cf. 644.

text: Kaa na mwenye tabia njema, utashiriki ya heshima.
explanation: Stay with a person of good character and you'll share in that person's good name.
An infidel who is of use to you is better than a Muslim who is of no use to you
The opponent has returned to solitude. One who does not conform or listen to advice is cut out.

text: Kidole kimoja kikiumia, vingine vyatoa damu.
explanation: If one finger hurts, the other fingers are bleeding. The pain of one harms the whole community.
It is as alike as milk and coconut milk. A riddle: Q. Two useful things very alike? A. Coconut juice and milk - Ingrams p.346.
A devil's house is not accosted. Keep away from evil people.
Every tool has its use. Nothing is done or made without a reason.

text: Kila kitu chageuka isipoku wa kitu kimoja tu.
explanation: Everything is subject to change except one thing. The leopard cannot change its spots.
Every caravan [expedition] has a leader.
To every child its own necklace. There is no accounting for taste.
Every hippopotamus has its own ford.

text: Kila mwamba ngoma, ngozi huivutia kwake.
explanation: Everyone who stretches a skin on a drum, pulls the skin to his/her own side. In any competition everyone tries to exceed the others. The proverb is used by elders who must reconcile the quarrels of the youngsters and must listen to both sides of the story.

text: Kilima uzuri mbali, karibu kina majuto.
explanation: A mountain far away is beautiful, but nearby it causes regrets. Living in a close relationship with somebody may be a hardship.

What is in the millet [sorghum] is millet. Weevils and things in the millet, go the way of millet: are ground and eaten. "The examples given were: a hungry man will eat anything, whether good or bad; or, an enemy conquering a village will take all the women, old or young, pregnant or not
Whatever smells well has been skillfully mixed.
Whatever shines has been rubbed.
A blind person does not forget the stick "We forget many things, but not the one thing without which we cannot live" - JKP.

text: Kizuri cha mtu kuonana na wake.
explanation: The quality of a good person is meeting with fellow humans. Respect in community.
What is good for you, [may be] bad for your friend.
After sunset the bushes are pregnant.

text: Kuku alae mtama, atakuwaye na nyama.
explanation: The chicken that eats millet, will have [good] flesh. Associate with the right people. Cf. 634.
Hawk's brood will always be hawkish.

text: Kuku wakilalamika nyumbani mwao kitu kinaingia.
explanation: If the chickens squeal then something entered their henhouse. Cf. 753.

text: Kumla nguru si kazi, kazi kumwosha.
explanation: To eat the nguru (kingfish) is easy, the trouble is cleaning it. Preparing is often the more difficult part of a job. The nguru of the Sciaenae family has a very strong smell.

text: Kuvua numbi si kazi: kazi kuu ni magawioni.
explanation: To catch a haul of fish with a net is easy; the difficulty is how to divide them. How to divide the catch, giving a just share, without complaints, when there are individual preferences and difference of status and involvement, can be a problem. Pulling the ropes of a dragnet is work involving many people. Numbi: a draught of fishes.

text: Kuvua, vua na mvuvi, penda samaki atwae.
explanation: What concerns fishing, fish with the expert, allow that his or her share be taken. Work with those who have the know-how, even if you have to pay for their expertise.

text: Kwa mwari kwaliwa, na kwa kungwi nako huliwa.
explanation: There is eating at the mwari and also at the kungwi. Mwari: seven days after the wedding the bride and groom celebrate. A meal offered by the young married and also by the initiated
A drunkard has entered the home of a fool. Both are irresponsible people. This is said when people make a lot of noise about nothing.
At a king's place food does not lack. If you are interested in acquiring anything, you should associate with those who can provide it.
The partridge shivers in the grass. If you want to hunt a partridge go to the grasslands.

text: Kwani kupenda ukowa, usipende kilichomo ukowani?
explanation: Why appreciate only the lamp glass without appreciating the light which is inside the glass?
Today yours, tomorrow your friend's. What happens to me today might happen to you tomorrow.
I today, you tomorrow. Your time will come. Cf. 1270.
Today is yours, not tomorrow.
The eyes of many are a medicine. The interest of many is like a cure. It softens misfortune. A lot of sports fans make the players play harder.

Water does not stay except in the river. Said of people who like to be with their family, in country, etc. - MM. Women grumble at the slowness of the supply of water in the river-bed, where wells are dug during the dry season, but it is there alone that water is to be had. The moral is, Don't quarrel with your bread and butter
The waters of the tidal flats are even. When the tide comes in, the water covers all unevenness. The water level is the same all over. Used to express equality of all men.
Sea water is obtained only on the shore. Look for things where they are usually found.

text: Maji yakikauka samaki wote wakaa katika ziwa moja.
explanation: When the waters are drying up all of the fish gather in the same lake. In dangerous times people come together.

text: Masikilizano ya wanaume ni mikuki na mishale.
explanation: Understanding among men is spears and arrows. Men should not talk too much but show themselves through actions
The environment is the beginning of success. Difficulties are the beginning of succeeding

When one is far from another, there is no rejoicing possible. Kiapio (Pemba dialect): shouts of joy at a dance. Wiu wiu or iu iu of the men, which corresponds to the shouts of vigele-gele of the women
A Colobus monkey is not sociable. Monkeys are supposed to be uncouth characters. Don't be surprised at the behavior of a low-class individual

text: Mbio yenye kumfukuza swala, nyama wote wanajitayarisha mbio.
explanation: The speedy flight of the Grant's gazelle alerts all other animals. In case of imminent danger everyone takes care.

text: Mbwa wa msasi mkali ni mkali pia.
explanation: The dog of a courageous hunter is also fierce. Cf. 714.

Big dogs do not bite each other. But if a small dog appears or barks at a big one, it will be bitten by one of them or both. This means that big people or nations do not harm each other, they harm the small ones - EM. Cf. 881.
They who earn calamity, eat it with their family. One who is in trouble brings suffering on the family
Skinners pull the skin to their side. Cf. 662.
One who follows an Arab smells well. Cf. 635, 711
Someone who keeps the company of a scholar will smell nicely. Smell is here used figuratively for learning, erudition and good manners

text: Mfukuz wa kwao hana pa kwenda.
explanation: One who is expelled from home has nowhere to go. If one is ostracized or boycotted, where can that person go? This is the most severe punishment a member of the family or community can receive. That person will become a total outcast.

text: Mpigwa nje huenda kwao, mpigwa kwao endepi?
explanation: Someone who is beaten abroad goes home, [but] if beaten at home, where does that person go?
If you are not wanted at home, where will you go and sleep? "This refers to marriage proposals. A young man should first look for a bride among his own cousins"
A craftsman creates his stuff. The grain crusher crushes her own flour. Funda has many different meanings: to pound, crush, pulverise; instruct, teach, educate; make a knot, tie. Cf. 662.

An unmarried person has no law [to keep]. A person with no relationship stands alone. The proverb can also mean that a person, having no relations, and no support, will lose the case in court. Mjane: a bereaved person, widow, widower; a bachelor or spinster.
The bad tamarind tree has its monkey. The general meaning is that everybody has a companion; the special meaning is that nobody is despicable. Mwajumi, mkwaju: tamarind, rather a useless tree.
The prostitute does not copulate alone. Mkware: a prostitute.

text: Mla nawe hafi nawe ila mzaliwa nawe.
explanation: A person who eats with you does not die for you, but one who is born with you will
A drunkard is the one who recognizes a drunkard. It takes one to know one.
A reasonable distant fire satisfies most. You'll keep warm, without getting burned. Beware of what can destroy you.

text: Mpiga maji maganja, huvuja kwa makwapani.
explanation: One who hits water with the palms of the hands [will have the water] oozing from the armpits. A useless effort. One does not give anything to a person who is unworthy of it
A potboiler does not like other potboilers. Potboilimg is causing discord. People who cause discord do not like others to cause discord between their colleagues
The person who cooks two pots will burn one.

text: Mrega havuki nyangwe: mkunguru na papasi.
explanation: A Mrega does not travel through Nyangwe, on account of fever and ticks. It is better not to visit places where one may risk not being welcome
The belt does not stay [with its wearer] without a clasp. E.g,. a marriage needs to be concluded in a proper way - SPK.

When you spill millet, a grain will be seen. JK. Your mistake will not remain hidden. A more literal equivalent of this proverb is the following: Panapofuka moshi panaficha moto. The place that emits smoke, hides fire"

A person who relies on the hump of a cow will not fail to grow fat. If you associate yourself with the right people, you cannot fail profiting from your relationship. Nundu: the hump of the zebu, a delicacy. Cf. 635, 698, 711.

text: Mti ukifa shinale na tanzuze hukauka.
explanation: When a tree dies at its roots, its branches dry up also. If the leader dies, the followers often give up. This refers also to moral corruption.

text: Mti mkubwa ukigwa [ukianguka], wana wa ndege huyumbayumba.
explanation: When a big tree falls, the young birds flutter around it.
The [falling] tree crushes the plants, who will cry for them?
If a big tree falls the branches cannot remain where they were. If a person with many dependents dies, the dependents' conditions deteriorate

text: Mti mkuu umeanguka, ndege wa mashakani.
explanation: A big tree has fallen, the birds are in trouble.
A river has no mud at its spring. But as it proceeds on its way it can become dirty. The meaning is that a person is innocent as a child, but growing up may be spoiled

text: Mtoto (or mwana) wa nyoka ni nyoka.
explanation: The offspring of a snake is a snake. "If intelligent parents have backward children, this proverb is also used"
The offspring of a lion is a lion. Mtoto and mwana: child, son/daughter, offspring. To show that the proverb is not always true: Cf. 519.
A kitten never falls on its back. A cunning person succeeds to get out of trouble. Cf.1111.

text: Mtu hamfanzii hiana mtu asiyoamini, kefu aliyomwamini.
explanation: People do not deceive others whom they do not trust, much less whom they trusts.
A person does what other people do.

text: Mtu hujulikana kwa sababu ya mwenziwe.
explanation: One is known on account of companions.
A person is [when] in his/her own environment.
A person is people. A person cannot live alone. Without living in fellowship a person cannot grow. A similar proverb

text: Kizuri cha mtu huonekana na wake.
explanation: A person's beauty is that person's willingness to meet fellow humans.
A loner is like a bad smell. It is bad not to associate with others.

text: Upweke si maisha, vibaya kuvaa gunia.
explanation: Loneliness is not a life, to put on sack cloth is not recommended. It should not be a permanent condition. Cf. 615, 1406.
Your family may be disgusted with you, but they will never throw you out.
Do not play with bitter cassava. Bitter cassava is poisonous. It should be properly boiled first. Do not play with a vindictive character; do not take a serious matter lightly
A good person will intercede on behalf of a bad person. We often see useless criminals being bailed out by honorable people, bad sons saved by their noble fathers
One who leaves his/her place of origin is foolhardy
One who leaves one's own people is never a hero [abroad].  A variation
One who leaves his/her own people is a liar. "A person who forsakes association makes a mistake (lit., is a liar), and will never be fully human. A person is a social animal"
Every foolhardy person [believes to be] safe.

One who leaves his/her ancestry is like a slave. Such a person loses knowledge of his/her origin, customs, tradition and therefore is looked down upon and ridiculed. Do not despise your own culture, even if people laugh at those customs. Mwacha asili: a person who leaves customs, traditions, the ways of ancestors and culture. Mtumwa: a person who is owned and used by somebody.

text: Mwacha kwao ni mwasi, endako hana kiasi.
explanation: Those who leave their homestead are rebels; they are in trouble wherever they go.

text: Mwana wa mtu ni kizushi, akizuka zuka naye.
explanation: A person is a revolutionary; if a person emerges, emerge with that person. There is no telling what a person may do: be ready, seize any advantage offered. Be ready for change. Kizushi: what appears or comes up suddenly; therefore, an unexpected guest, or somebody who does not shout hodiò(May I come in?).
The one who is supported does not fall, unless the one who supports falls
One who goes home is not a deserter. A person never forgets his home. Cf. 698, 718, 719, 722.

text: Mwenda na kuu k'owi wala haoni miuya.
explanation: One who goes with a large [vessel] bathes not, nor does he see the billows. That person is not splashed by the waves and is not in danger. About traveling in style and having good associations. Kowi from kuowa (kuoga): to bathe. Miuya: waves (mawimbi)
If your companion gives you nausea, reject him as vomit.

text: Mwenye kutembea na mbuzi anatamani nyama.
explanation: One who walks with goats desires meat.
A proud person does not like pride. A proud person does not like another proud person. Cf. 3985B.
A person who has a fishy smell does not know it.

text: Mwili wa mwenzio ni kando ya mwilio.
explanation: Your companion's body is beside your body. The pain and suffering of your friend does not hurt you as much as it hurts your friend

text: Mwitu ni mpya, komba ni wapya.
explanation: New forest, new bush babies. "If you are unhappy, move house and make new friends who may have unknown talents. Bush babies are believed to make palmwine"

text: Mwituni mna matata na wa miji hwenda mbio.
explanation: In the forest there are many hazards and townspeople walk through it in great haste."Wa miji [townspeople] are proud of their urban background, but are frightened in the bush. Everyone in his own environment

text: Mwivi huenda na wevi, mlevi nao walevi.
explanation: A thief goes with thieves, a drunkard with drunkards. Birds of a feather flock together. As a man is so is his company - JK.

She who gives birth cannot escape ritual defilement. Ujusi: "natural defilement of childbirth as affecting both mother and child and everything that comes into contact with them until both have been washed ceremoniously according to Muslim usage seven days after the birth of the child"
A bad coconut spoils the good ones. One is tainted by association; even when an innocent one is involved in group punishment. Cf. 758.

text: Nchi ya mhaini ina mengi mazuri.
explanation: The land of a traitor has many nice things. Otherwise nothing would tempt a traitor.

text: Ndege wa aina moja huruka pamoja.
explanation: Birds of a kind fly together.
A brother is like a cooking pot, a neighbor is like a pot cover. Both are useful, they complement one another. Family and neighbors help each other.
A bad member of the family is still better than a nice friend. One does not leave one's own, how imperfect they may be. Cf. 3745.

text: Ndugu mbaya si sawa na jirani mwema.
explanation: A bad sibling is not comparable to a good neighbor. Same as 740.

text: Ngoma ndio sauti ya umoja wa watu.
explanation: The drum is the unified voice of the people.
The pig dies for cassava roots. Craving stops for nothing. Cf. 1107.
It is a tree at an irrigation ditch. Said about an opportunist. A person appearing wherever there is something to obtain.
It is your brother who concerns you [or any kinsman]

text: Njia ya kupimia haki ni adhabu.
explanation: To measure justice is by way of punishment.
The bifurcation killed the family relationship. Looking for personal profit harms the family.
An ape that goes alone.
A buffalo that goes alone. The rogue elephant or buffalo driven away from the herd has a savage temper. Used to describe people.

text: Nyati mwenda pweke, windo rahisi la mwindaji.
explanation: The buffalo that goes alone is an easy bag for the hunter. A person without friends has nobody to turn to in time of need.
Monkey, monkey scratch one another [If you scratch my back...]
Itching is itching together. It is good when done together or done to each other. Nyege: itching but also tickling for sexual excitement.
Lust, don't go on by yourself. As soon as sexual desire awakes in boy or girl, he or she must be married. If their elders leave them unmarried, they will become sinners
A star is not visible in plain daylight.
The bee goes with its flowers. And sways with the flowers. It follows its natural tendencies.
The house and the age group are not deserted. The family and those who were in the same initiation rites must never be deserted. Cf. 722.
Where there is smoke there is fire.
The place that emits smoke, hides fire.
There is no lack of mushrooms on farm manure. Cf. 174, 753.
Scum floats on top, avoid it.

text: Riziki ya mtu iko kwa watu.
explanation: A person's fortune is with other people. "Everybody gets his fortune from Almighty God, but God does not give a person his fortune directly. He does so through other people"
The daily necessities of a cat are in the drums. The cat is searching for food in garbage bins. Lazy people try to get their food for nothing

citations.page: 718. If one fish rots, they all rot

text: Samaki mmoja akioza ni mtungo pia.
explanation: If one fish goes bad the whole string does also.

text: Pono mmoja akioza, huoza na shazile.
explanation: If one pono rots, the whole string rots also. Pono: name of a fish, said to be often in a torpid state. The expression goes: Ana usingizi kama pono, So and So is as sleepy as a pono
Cats are born with whiskers. Someone boasting about his special qualities.
My saying "I don't want it" is not by way of disagreeableness, or being invidious to others
Come close, I don't sleep alone. Upeka: upweke, alone. Cf. 720.
We all are ruled [influenced] by our environment.
The chief [alone] does not catch a thief.
It's not a wonder that a dry [tree] branch falls down. Or a very sick person dies, or a lazy student fails; a drunkard falls, a thief is caught.
A branch cut off a tree will dry up. A child deprived of its parents wastes away.

When the monkey has finished the branches, it comes to the trunk. When a bad person gets caught he/she will drag down as many people as possible - SAM. If a monkey lacks the trees for its living on acount of enemies it goes all out and attacks. So, don't provoke even a weak person, because you might get hurt
A good fruit does not stay for long on a tree. A beautiful woman will get married.

text: Tunda la pori haliwezi kuchekelea tunda mwenzake.
explanation: A fruit of the bush cannot laugh at its companion. In case of a forest fire both are in the same danger.
The relationship of coconuts happens to be a meeting in the cooking-pot. This is said of people who do not want to cooperate until it is too late
The meeting place of the coconut brotherhood is in the basket. When all the members agree they stay together, but when trouble comes everyone goes his own way
A youth's bravery is seen when among companions [where he can count on their help]. When confronting a lion or another danger.
Having neighbors is [like having] money in a box. But also: Help received from neighbors must be paid back by mutual services.
The songs of the coucal birds are all the same. One sings and all answer in the same tune. All other birds imitate the shundi

text: Ukienda njia ya pofu, utapofua lako jicho.
explanation: If you go the way of the blind, you will blind your own eye. If you follow bad examples you'll become bad.

text: Ukikaa karibu na waridi huachi kunukia.
explanation: If you stay close to roses, you'll have a nice smell. Cf. 698.

text: Ukikaa na kilabu hupati kitu [ila] aibu.
explanation: If you stay with the club, you won't get anything but shame
If you see the buku rat during daytime, it's on account of the safari ants. An unusual happening has its reason. Buku: a very large long-tailed rat, also called ndezi.

text: Ukipenda mtu, upende na mbwa wake.
explanation: If you love someone, love also his/her dog.
If you want to be helped, help your neighbor. Start helping others and you'll find helpers.

text: Ukosefu wa mwenenzi si wa mkazi milele.

citations.page: 866. The oddities of a passer-by are not so annoying as those of one you live with constantly. Relatives cannot hide their faults from one another

explanation: T. quotes the following verse

text: Ukoshefu wa mwenenzi si wa mkazi milele
Kufunua macho panzi si chui kufuma ndole
Kufileko kwa ndovu si uzima wa kunguni.
explanation: Traveller's straits are not so annoying as a constant inhabitant's. A grasshopper opening its eyes is not so bad as a leopard clenching his paw. An elephant's death-scene is not so annoying as the life of a bug.
Beware of the solitary person.
Avoid the solitary. [Elephant or buffalo.] Cf. 720, 748.
Do not open a shop unless you like smiling.
Don't travel under the [lucky] star of your companion. "Do not risk an enterprise only because someone else succeeded in it"
A mushroom grows on dung. This is said if someone is prevented from taking revenge or from being realistic on account of family ties, etc.

text: Vumbi la kisonzo si la ufukwe.
explanation: The dust of the cow dung is not comparable to the white sand on the beach. Stay with the good people, follow their habits and behavior and you'll be loved. Kisonzo; the thick sludge of the cow dung in the stable. Ufukwe (mchanga): sand of the seashore.
The right hand does not cut off the left one. One must not harm oneself or one's immediate family. Cf. 3089.

text: Waarabu wa pemba, hujuana kwa vilemba.
explanation: The Arabs of Pemba know each other by the turban.
The Swahili can tell each other by the turban they wear. Cf. 3294.
If the inhabitants of a country eat mice, you too eat mice. Follow the customs of the country.
Do not keep your kinsmen away"
Do not separate kinsfolk, they should join together. Changana: of people joining together for a special purpose, e.g. as of volunteers for a cause

text: Wavuvi wa pweza hujuana (or hukutana) mwambani.
explanation: The cuttlefish (octopus) fishermen know (meet) each other at the reef. People of the same profession know each other. Pweza: cuttlefish, inkfish, octopus that lives at the reefs.

text: Waweza kuishi bila ndugu (rafiki), huwezi kuishi bila majirani.
explanation: You can live without relatives (friends), but you cannot live without neighbors.

text: Wenye kusuka virago ni mabinti; siku wataolewa nani atasuka?
explanation: Girls plait the sleeping mats, who will plait them when they are married? Today prepare for tomorrow.

text: Wewe mkono, unakula na giza, unasahau kinywa.
explanation: You, the hand, you eat in darkness, you forget the mouth [of the others]. One who eats alone and in secret shows that he does not want to share.

text: Wingi wa siafu ndio nguvu yao.
explanation: The multitude of ants is their strength.
What is yours walks over to me. Visits me. Your goodness or evil reflects on me.
Forgive your debtor, and God may help you [on the day of judgment].
The rule about debts is: they are to be paid.
Who eats food of a woman gives something else in return.
That person is so deep in debt his eyelids are not even his own. Idiom: Ana madeni chungu nzima, he has a big pot full of debts
The person who asks for water asks for her own pot. All people care for their own interests. Therefore do not think that others will take care of your interests.
What one borrows does not end a pretext. One always finds a pretext to borrow or to keep the borrowed item.

text: Cha kuazima si kama chako mwenyewe.
explanation: A borrowed item is not like your own.
There is your creditor, start thrashing your millet. In order to blind him with the dust. Chaza: snail, oyster, which supposedly adheres to ships.

text: Deni ni ahadi kulipa ni muamana.
explanation: A debt is a promise, to pay is a pledge.
It is better to lack something than to borrow. "Borrowing is not considered to be a good habit"

text: Kafiri alipaye deni siye sawa na mwungwana adaiwaye.
explanation: The infidel who pays his debt is better than the free person in debt.
A borrowed kanzu , do not go with it to Friday's prayers. Kanzu: gown. Cf. 826, 1528.
Borrow! Borrow! But paying back is bitterness.
Borrow and pay.
Sell on credit so that you can leave the market. A business person will sell some left-overs on credit and go and buy more stock.
Borrowing is like a wedding, paying back is like mourning. It is always easier to borrow than to pay back. Harusi or arusi: a wedding.
Borrowing is easy, paying back is pain. Cf.1530, 4705.
Borrowing leads to poverty.
Borrowing is not the same as getting. What is borrowed has to be given back; special care should be taken in using it. "Don't be proud of borrowed wealth"
Loaning is like earth. Like a productive field.
Eat today, pay today
A person in debt is not paid.
Our possessions are only borrowed. We have to leave them behind
A debtor does not get angry. A debtor may be abused by the lender. If this happens, he should not get angry, for the lender may disgrace him/her more
Press him/her in a brutish way! Saying used when somebody wants to collect a debt.
A borrower of condiments eats dry food. Kitoweo: all relish, meat, fish, vegetables, etc.

The eater of a goat pays back a cow. The interpretation varies: A borrower loses. If you accept bribes, you will have to pay back much more. One who accepts gift, accepts obligations. "Also, refers to borrowing with interest, which is forbidden in Islamic religion"

text: Mla mbuzi, lipa ng'ombe, mla nyama usiombe.
explanation: The eater of a goat, pay an ox, the eater of meat, do not beg. Eating meat is a luxury. One has to pay dearly for it, one cannot beg for it.

text: Mlipaji muungwana, na mwibaji ni mtana.
explanation: The one who pays is the noble person, the one who pilfers is the low-class one. "Lit., slave, a man without honor. For the gentle person it is a matter of honor to pay his/her debt"
Do not call on [your landlord] if you have not paid your rent. Do not call on somebody if he has a claim on you.

text: Mwema kuwa mwovu, aliyetaka ni yeye.
explanation: Good people become bad, and they wanted it themselves. "There is no gratitude in lending and borrowing"

text: Mwenye chake ni mungwana, akikataa, kaa zako: huwezi kumfunga kamba.
explanation: The owner is a free man; if he refuses help, go home; you cannot bind him with a rope. Nobody goes to help the one who refuses help.
A person in debts sleeps with open doors. Creditors importune the borrower every moment.

text: Mwenye kuazima hatoi, mtovu ni mwenye chombo.
explanation: The borrower does not give, the giver is the owner of the thing. The borrower does not give it back, the owner is the loser

text: 823a. Mwia na muraba hulipwa haki, deni ya adabu hailipiki.
explanation: Creditor and miser can be paid their due, a debt of courtesy cannot be paid.
Those who ask for salt, ask for their own cooking pot. Chunguche = chungu chake: his or her pot.
For a person accustomed to taking, giving away is a battle. "Many people take with a spade, but return with a spoon"
To one used to receive, giving is like a battle. See also the section Gifts.

Borrowed clothing does not conceal the buttocks. It is not yours. The owner can take it back anytime and leave you without. Used in an advertisement for the monthly Ukulima wa kisasa: "Make sure that you get your own copy:" If you borrow it, the owner could ask it back while you are reading it in the middle of a story.
Borrowed clothes do not fit the wearer. Lit., Do not cover the shoulder. A borrowed thing cannot be satisfying.

text: Nguo ya kuazimu haina bindo or heshima.
explanation: Borrowed clothing has no money-belt or honor. For meaning of bindo, Cf. 186.
You cannot swagger [show off] in borrowed clothing. Cf. 828, 4754.

text: 826a. Niwapo sina sikopi, kukopa si matukano.
explanation: When I have none do I not borrow? Borrowing is no insult.

text: Pilau ya kuomba si muhogo uliojilimia.
explanation: The pilao you begged for is not so tasty as the cassava, that you cultivated yourself. As the saying goes: "The hottest fire is made by the wood you chop yourself. Pilau, pilao: a dish of boiled rice, cooked with ghee, raisins.

text: Shoka la mgeni haliwezi kumaliza kazi yako.
explanation: The axe of the stranger cannot finish your work. A borrowed instrument may be asked back any time
Do not borrow a cross-beam, you might also take the house. Cf. 2489.
I do not want to be beaten by my own [money] - JK. "Lenders will be abused as soon as they ask for their money back. So, when asked for a loan, a person may answer with this proverb"
The good morning becomes a debt. Saying good morning gives the impression that one can come to ask for service. Kindness [friendliness] invites profiteers to ask for help
The poison of a debt is in the payment.
If you start lending - you'll look for enemies.
If you pay your debt you can borrow [again].
Give back to the one you borrowed from, the lender does not give you more.

text: Usiku kucha si mwaka, usiku kungugu.
explanation: Waking] a whole long night is not a year, night is like a mist [that disappears in the morning]. It is always hard to repay one's debt. The one who borrowed will tell the lender: "I'll pay you back, be patient"

text: Usiseme madeni ya jirani yako isipokuwa ukitakakuyalipa.
explanation: Don't speak about the debt of your neighbor unless you want to pay for it.

What did the winnowing basket say? Give me and I'll give you! The proverb is used as a favorite way of getting rid of an inopportune beggar. "A widely used expression referring to prostitutes, who demand money in advance.
Things borrowed do not end desire. There remains the desire to borrow more and to keep what is borrowed. Cf. 826.

Withhold your things, so that you don't come into trouble with your own people. Be careful in lending, if you need it back, you might get in trouble. It is better to be independent; help from others is sometimes a cause of disagreement. Ziwilia or zuilia:: to withhold.
Two swords dont fit in one scabbard. Cf. 848, 894, 909.
One who is used to tobacco is not satisfied with betel leaves. Said of people who cannot change their ways. Cf. 825, 891.

text: Ana nchi yake simba, ana maji yake mamba.
explanation: The lion has its land, the crocodile has its water. "And never the twain shall meet"
One who is bitten by a viper cannot be sucked (lit., be milked). That person will surely die. The wound caused by a snake bite has to be squeezed out or sucked

text: Bibi wa ovyo anampata mume mzuri.
explanation: A nobody-woman will marry a fine husband. Cf. 887.
The fingers are not alike. All humans are different.

text: Chui na mbuzi hawalali nyumba moja.
explanation: The leopard and the goat do not sleep in the same house. There is no harmony possible between totally dissimilar people. They do not frequent the same places. Cf. 848.
Two bulls cannot stay together in one stable. Mafahari
Darkness and light don't stay together.

text: Hapachezei ngoma ya matanga penya arusi.
explanation: A mourning dance is not played at a wedding ceremony.

text: Haramu yako ni halali ya mwenzio.
explanation: What is illegal for you is permitted for your friend. Haramu: fobidden, unlawful, prohibited, e.g., by Muslim law or custom. Halali: lawful, permissible, allowed, rightful, ceremonially clean. Mwana wa haramu: an illegitimate child.

text: 851a. Hasara nda kichwa koko kuwana na mwenye pembe.
explanation: It is the disadvantage of the hornless animal to fight one with horns. Meet your rival well prepared, the craftsman needs good tools

text: Hata ng'ombe mweusi, maziwa yake meupe.
explanation: Even a black cow gives white milk.

text: Hata ng'ombe mweusi na mwekundu maziwa yao ni meupe.
explanation: Even a black and red cow give white milk. Cf. 2858.
When the handwriting is superior, the poetry will flourish. "Excellence of form and expression ought to be in harmony with beautiful contents"
They cannot be cooked in the same pot. Said of people who do not agree, who are entirely incompatible, who quarrel all the time.

text: Huwaje kuisaliti nyama ndavu na asali.
explanation: What good<!--[if !supportFootnotes]--> does it do to mix stale meat and honey? Said of something that is beyond repair; also said of people. ÒStale meatÓ refers to a woman of loose morals
Where there is justice, injustice does not last.

text: Inzi hatui juu ya damu ya simba.
explanation: The fly does not settle on a lion's blood. Even a wounded lion is dangerous. In riddles, lion's blood stands for fire.

text: Ituuzayo tia iyo isokuwako si dawa.
explanation: Apply the medicine that is not so good anymore, the medicine that you don't have is useless. Whatever little and old you have, use it. Don't throw it away. It's better than nothing. And one day you may need it. Ituuzaye, ichuruzikayo, itiririkayo: what trickles, flows. Iyo, hiyo: that.
The [arrows] that go waveringly are the ones that hit. Understood: mivi = arrows. Yua: wobbling, not flying straight.
One cannot keep two hands full of ashes - Sacl. Ashes do not fill the palm of your hand, they will escape your grasp. "Do not try to keep something useless"

text: Jogoo wawili hawawezi kusaidiana wakamate kidudu kimoja.
explanation: Two roosters are unable to help one another to catch the same insect. Two enemies will fight one another.

I don't eat the kangaja, but its gravy is a relish. We may dislike a person, but his favors are welcome. Kangaja: fish with a disagreeable smell (Acanthurus gham). Towele or kitoweo: anything eaten as a relish with the staple food: vegetables, meat, fish, etc. Cf. 2486.
A blind person cannot show the way. Onya or onyesha: to show.
What is not sharpened does not cut. One cannot work with a tool that is not in good condition. Cf. 622.
The same [head] cloth, but the ways of wearing it are different. Cf. 880, 2620.

text: Kivuli cha fimbo hakimfichi mtu jua.
explanation: The shadow of a stick cannot hide a man from the sun.
You cannot hide the sun with a sieve. Use the appropriate means. Cf. 3324.
A big hat for a big head. They go together. Two people who are well together.
A handful of water cannot be retained. Water cannot be grasped in the fist - J. One cannot carry water in a sieve
Will the chicken grow teeth?
Can you make a dog grow horns?
The bed with many bedbugs is not slept in. "There is a limit to the amount of annoyance a person can take. Said of a troublesome spouse"
Paradise cannot be gained by toughness or argumentation
In an abandonned homestead no food is eaten. Nothing edible is left.
Where there are trees, there are no builders. You do not find builders where the trees are, even though trees are used for building; i.e., things do not go as expected
There are only fools, none who can help.
You do not get peas from a pepper bush. Good people do good things, bad people don't.
Where there are cows there are horns..
Necessity has no illegality. "When a person wants to satisfy a necessary need, that person ignores even taboos attached to it. "Necessity knows no law"
Perhaps and actuality are not compatible
Bad intentions and the consequences thereof do not mix. They come back
A great amount of water cannot be retained.
Goat's milk does not spoil the tea.

text: 878a. Mbuzi angelia mlio wa ng'ombe angejipasua.
explanation: If a goat would [try to] low like a bull she would burst. ...if a woman would try to rule the house
Dog does not eat dog. Cf. 881.
Rice is one, [but there are] many ways of cooking. Things can be done well in many ways.
Rice is the same but the ways of preparing are different .

text: Mchele mmoja kila mtu na upishi wake.
explanation: One rice but every one has his/her own way of cooking.
The millet is always the same, but the cooks have different ways"
Even] a tired person cannot sleep on a distant bed [i.e., not available].
The teeth of a dog do not bite each other. Do not enter when relatives fight, they will turn against you.
Two lions do not kill each other. Cf. 892, 905.
A free thinker is abused. Few people like originality of though
A chain does not stand.
A thornbush does not grow grapes.

The palm tree can survive through a storm, but the mango tree falls. The palm tree is tall, but bends and bends. The mango tree does not bend and is uprooted - EM. "The moral is that to survive the storms of life it is better to be flexible as the palmtree"

A traveler becomes like an unbeliever. A person is sometimes compelled by circumstances to act contrary to that person's religion. E.g., Muslims are not allowed to eat pork, but away from home, they are allowed to eat pork, when nothing else is available.
A traveller does according to his condition. In case of need one gives a twist to one's religious rules or customs

text: Mshale juu ni kutembea, chini ndipo pake.
explanation: An arrow travels high in the sky, but its place is here below. Dependence is hard for the ambitious
An arrow belongs in the wilds. There an arrow can be used, not in town. Cf. 3532.

text: Mtu wa ovyo ana mali nyingi.
explanation: A good-for-nothing has great wealth. Cf. 845.
A reed is not broken by the wind. Cf. 883.

text: Mwenye kuchoma hali chenga zenye kuungua.
explanation: One who roasts corn does not eat the burned ones.
It is the dirty beehive that gives the honey. There has been lots of activity going on.
One who is used to strangling food, cannot eat slaughtered meat. This proverb refers to persons who prefer a life of hardship to a life of ease, or to those who like doing things "the hard way"

text: Ukizowea vya kunyonga, vya kuchinja huviwezi [utakonda]. Aliyezoea tumbaku tambuu haiwezi.
explanation: One who is used to tobacco is not satisfied with betel leaves.
Those two birds do not tie bundles. Here birds means eyes. A person's eyes do not tie bundles. They do not act; therefore they cannot be blamed or accused that they have done something

text: Ng'ombe na mbuzi ni wamoja; mtu kando [mbali] ni kondoo.
explanation: Cows and goats are alike; a person however is like a sheep. Do not get mixed up with other people's fights. "The sheep is regarded as a nobler animal than the dumb cows and goats"

text: Ng'ombe na mbuzi ni wamoja; mtu kando na kondoo.
explanation: Cows and goats are alike; man and sheep are different.

text: Ng'ombe na mbuzi ni mmoja, kondoo ni mtu mbali.
explanation: Cows or goats it is all the same, but a sheep is a different parson. Important people and low-class people are of the same character; only a few are good and noble

text: 893a. Ngozi na mafupa iyafunike hakuna lisilo na ndugu yake.
explanation: The skin and the bones: let it cover them, there is nothing that does not have its brother. Nothing is unique: every person may find a partner in life. Brothers and friends fit together like the skin over bones

text: Ngozi ya paa haikai watu wawili.
explanation: The hide of a gazelle does not seat two people. Said of something in short supply. Cf. 848.

text: Ngumu ngumu inazaa teketeke, teketeke inazaa ngumungumu.
explanation: Hard grains produce soft ones; and soft grains produce hard ones. This is also a riddle: Unripe maize and hard maize. Generation follows generation

text: Ngwena na mwingine ngwena, hawawezi kupatana.
explanation: Two crocodiles cannot agree. "Aggressive people do not get along together"
No grass grows on the path. No sleep comes to the worried mind
Rollers will be of no use to you [when trying to launch your boat] unless the tide is in. The high tide is needed to float the ship. The rollers can take it only so far
Do not feed in your house the snake you found begging on the roadside. Do not trust people who solicit your pity
A house cat is not chased away. "Don't cut off your nose to spite your face.
In a big place enters a big person. A capable person is needed for a difficult place or situation.
The horns do not grow before the head [has grown].
The place where there is a sound person is a sound place. Mzima, lit., whole, healthy, adult, here refers to a person of sane mind and clear judgment
Where there are experienced people the work is not wasted.

text: Pongo hawezi kulala siku moja na chui.
explanation: The gazelle and the leopard cannot sleep any time in the same spot. Enemies avoid one another. Cf. 847.

A rag of the floormat is a [shopping] bag. The difference of the two is in the making. Things that are similar go together, and so do people. The jamvi [doormat] and the kanda [a bag] are made of the same material (leaf strips of the wild date palm: mkindu).
The rails are iron - the wheels are iron. They go together. Hand and glove.

How can a plate without its cover be covered with a mat? Ironic. How can you use something so big and expensive to cover up something so little: There must be more to it than meets the eye. Don't burn your house to fright the mouse away.
A lion does not kill her young. Bad people do not harm their children.
Lions do not kill each other. Bad people do not harm each other
The small sisimizi will never be cows. About ambition. Sisimizi: a small black harmless ant (almost invisible).

text: Ukaonapi (or ujaonapi) mnandi kujenga nyumba kutwani (or barani)?
explanation: When have you ever seen a cormorant build its nest westwards [on the mainland]?
There is more flour than water. And a loaf cannot be good. This is said when somebody has a good thing going but then exaggerates somewhere and the project flounders
One single sheath cannot receive two swords. Two swords are not put in one sheath. A woman cannot have two husbands
Where did you see a hard stone float in the sea?
Will you succeed growing horns on a dog? Cf. 2127.
Rings are not put on toes. Do not put a fool in charge of an important job. Cf. 4158, 4574.
People do not climb trees with sandals. Here sandals are like handicaps. A ridiculous thing to do.

text: Watu walio pamoja si maji mtungini.
explanation: People who are staying together are not like water in a waterpot. People together will not stay quiet for long.

text: Wenye ghadhaba hawalingani, wenye mahaba hawatengani.
explanation: Irascible people do not get along together, lovers cannot be kept apart. Ghadhaba: more common is ghadhabu..

text: Ya nini kutumia bomu kuulia sisimizi?
explanation: Why use a bomb to kill a small ant? Sisimizi: a small black harmless ant (almost invisible).
What you find in Pemba island you find also in Zanzibar. Mrima: the coast opposite Zanzibar island.

text: Yaliyoko mbele yako utayaona, ya nyuma huwezi kuyaona.
explanation: You see what is before you, not what is behind you. A person cannot control all the things happening in his area of work.
What was broken can be repaired.
The zobe and the msuwele are alike. The zobe and the msuwele have legs and claws like crabs and shells like a tortoise. Stay with your associates
The one who stands aside will not be hit.

text: 920a. Afugaye ng'ombe tume mwenye ziwa la kujaza.
explanation: One who keeps a healthy cow will have plenty of milk. He who has married a faithful wife will have good children
What one cultivates is what one harvests. As one works so one earns. "The one who does the action is responsible for good or evil"
One who cultivates millet does not harvest beans. Cf. 990.

text: Alimaye njiani sharti alinde ndege (or nyuni) asipate chembe.
explanation: A person who cultivates near the road must watch that the bird gets no grain. Envy and jealousy of people might spoil one's plans "

text: Alimaye shamba chembe azipande, sharti azilinde nyuni wasipate.

citations.page: The cultivator will sow seeds, then must watch lest the birds get them. Cf. 2049

explanation: The one who has got a stick [to beat a dog] will get trouble.
The person who involves oneself in what does not concerns her/him, will get what is unpleasant. Don't put your nose in other people's business.
She who grinds flour for her mother will taste honey.

text: Apasukiwaye [na] nguo ni fundi wa kukunja.
explanation: One whose clothing is torn must be an expert in folding it. In order to cover nakedness. If a person does not take care of things, that person will be caught when things are scarce.
If you break a cup at a wedding, where you were not invited, you'll pay. A mistake must be repaired.

text: Asiye karibu na mto ndiye alalaye kiu.
explanation: The one who is not near a river sleeps thirsty.
One who does not listen to advice will listen to the stick. Cf. 1160.
One who does not travel will marry in his/her own village.

text: Avaaye kiatu kimoja hana budi kwenda chopi.
explanation: A person who wears only one shoe walks lamely.
Where the sea is there the rivers go. The few follow the many. Money goes where there is much money
There is no shade without a tree. Everything has its cause
The frog killed the buffalo. Something little can defeat a powerful person. Cf. 935, 936.
A frog can kill an elephant. A small person may inconvenience a big man so much as to cause the big man's downfall
A frog may obstruct water, while the elephant longs for it. Petty causes, big effects. A frog can prevent an elephant from drinking water by getting stuck in his trunk, and so kill the elephant.
A new stick knocking down an old one. A new insult reminds of old ones. But also when somebody uses valuable things to obtain worthless things
Throw a fruit stone [into a tree] and you may bring down a koma (fruit of the dwarf palm). Invest a little, gain much
Don't shoot an arrow in the dark. Without seeing the target clearly it is foolish to release an arrow

This log is glued [to the earth], it cannot be pushed A log that is stuck to the earth cannot be moved. Do not try the impossible, i.e., do not try to persuade old-fashioned people to accept novelties
A bag of salt sweats salt. Meaning it sweats salt, not sugar. You'll know a person by conversation and actions
There is nothing that has no beginning.
There is no rainy season without mosquitoes. A mixed blessing. Masika, monsoon, is the heaviest rainy season of the year and lasts for three or four months. Cf. 3469.
There is no coat without its gnat. The meaning is that nobody is perfect. Kapa, a sort of coat without sleeves - J. Usubi, a small biting gnat, midge, sandfly

text: Hapo ufuliapo wenzio ndiyo hupigia pasi.
explanation: It is there where you do your laundry, that your friends do the ironing. While one does all the work another may harvest.
One sitting on a dry palm leaf does not like the wind. A dry palm branch breaks easily. A person who is not sure of his/her position is scared hearing of lay-offs. Cf. 1018, 4062.

text: Hikosa mwaka naruza, silimi vuli hachekwa.
explanation: If I fail during the big rainy season I give up, I do not cultivate during the short rainy season and be laughed at. "If a rich man fails me, I don't apply to a poor one"
You cannot put a shoe on a running person.

text: Huwezi kupika keki bila kuvunja yai.
explanation: You cannot bake a cake without breaking an egg.
As you lay down a mat, so you will sit. To the extent that you prepare a matter, to the same extent you will reap its benefits
The hunting ground of the lion does not lack a bone. Signs of activity. Accidents happen when people are working.

text: Jeshi la haki hupenya ambapo jeshi la watu haliwezi.
explanation: The forces of justice enter where the forces of human beings cannot. Justice will be done. Evil will be punished. Goodness will be rewarded.
Sit with a singer and you will sing songs.

If my sitting here does not sit well with you, why don't you go so I can sit; how does that sit with you? This probably refers to somebody who is not happy with the arrangements. Kale (k'ale) = nikale: that I may sit. K'aikele, old past negative of kukala (kukaa): to sit [well], to fit, suit. Mbuka = niuka or niwuka (uwuka, mbuka) from uka: depart, leave.

text: Kama baba kama mtoto, mti mzuri huzaa matumda mazuri.
explanation: Like father like son", a good tree produces good fruit.

text: Kama hukula vitunguu vya pori hutakunya mbegu zake.
explanation: If you did not eat wild onions you would not void their seeds. Vitunguu vya pori, in Maniema dialect, masusu. Cf. 1008.
A nice place fouled is visited by flies. If a nice park is defaced, trash will be thrown on it.
Even a small brook will wet your clothes.

text: Kijondi ni nini ingawa ana mbawa.
explanation: What value has a little bird, though it may have wings. "Much ado about a trifle"

A corsage of jasmine did not come in vain. "Jasmines have a strong, pleasant smell. A corsage of jasmine brought profit to the girl who wore it, by attracting a young man [who became her husband] to her
Everyone who eats grapes must wet his/her chin. "Every lover of girls will make a mistake"

text: Kilio huanza mfiwa, ndipo na wa mbali wakaingia.
explanation: The bereaved begin the wailing, then those from afar follow. This proverb has many uses: 1. Wait for your turn. 2. Two people start a fight and soon everybody gets involved. 3. Before help can be expected one has to try to solve one's own problem.
Whatever returned the old person to the meadows is unknown. Malishoni, grazing ground, paddock. Mzee, old person, master, parent.
What rots stinks.

text: Kisiki mjini, japo kifupi, kina maneno mengi.
explanation: A tree stump in town may be small, but provokes many palavers. Cf. 4349.
A knife without a handle cannot carve meat. Use the right tools.
What moves on does not leave a big noise.

Where the thorn pierces is where it comes out. "Where the thorn went in, that is where it will come out" -Racial 588.226. A problem is solved by investigating the cause so that the remedy can be found.
Those who hate milk insult/scorn the cow.
Where there is bending, there will be rising up. "Oppression cannot last long"
A dry leaf falling down is nothing to be amazed about. It is natural: if a marriage or relationship dries up. Cf. 4062.
The reaping depends on the seed. As they sow, so let them reap. Cf. 4750.

text: Licha makoo ya kuku, hata mafaranga yako.
explanation: To say nothing of the hens, there are chicks too"
Lot was saved, his wife was dilatory. A reference to the Koran 29, 32-33. Lot obeyed God's word with alacrity, but his wife tarried on the road
Little things stop people to recognize each other. To respect or be friendly with each other.

text: Maji ya moto hayachomi (or hayaunguzi) nyumba.
explanation: Boiling water does not burn a house.

text: Mali bila daftari hupotea bila habari.
explanation: Possessions without an [account] book are lost without noticing.
Wealth without accounting is very difficult. Muhali, impossible, very difficult. Cf. 2938.

text: Mambo (or maneno) ambayo hujui mwanzo wala mwisho yatakupataje?
explanation: If you don't know the beginning or the end of an affair how can it concern you? Cf. 1008.
Suet sticks to the pot. The pot is a useful object, we have to accept the black grease
The skin is shaped by the shoulder. A shirt is cut according to the shoulders.
The arm follows the pace of the walk. The curvature of the arm goes together with the gait of the legs
A curved spine ends the strut.

text: Mchambia mgomba huondoka na mavi yake.
explanation: Free translation: He who uses a banana leaf as toilet paper doesn't leave clean. The banana leaf is not good for this purpose. Use the proper means to succeed in an enterprise.
One who plays with mud will get splashed.
One who plays with dung will smell badly. Cf. 8, 989.
One who plays with fire will get burned.
The person who roasts meat is the one who senses the smell.
One who dips a finger in honey, does not do it [only] once.
One who tasts honey does not do that once only.
One who goes to sleep early wakes up early. Used in cases of procrastination.

One who throws a stone into a crowd does not know who will be hit. Think about the consequences before doing something. Do not punish the whole crowd on account of one. This means that where there are many people do not insult your enemy
One who buys the gravy will have to pay for the goat. To slaughter a lamb for the sake of a chop. To sow the wind and reap the whirlwind.
A diver must sink. [And probably drown one day.] A risk-taker once will fail.
Hit the dog if you want to know the owner.
An arrow turns as it wants
The one who touches dung will inevitably smell. If you are in charge of other people's money you may be tempted to take a little for yourself
One who touches excrement does not stop smelling his hand. Kinyaa, kinyesi, excrement, dung, stool.
One who wants millet does not plant cow peas. In the sense that you will expect the same treatment you give to others.
The winnower raises dust. The critic will attract criticism
A tree is dug up with its fruit, i.e. digging up a tree involves the fruit also" - J. It is because of its fruits that the tree is exposed to hostilities
One who comes out of the shade is put in the sun. When people do not want to be helped they should not feel sorry if they are denied help they ask for later

text: Mtoto mwenye bidii hakosi wa kumtunza.
explanation: An active child does not lack someone who takes care of it.

text: Mtoto wa mhunzi akikosa kufua, huvukuta.
explanation: If the child of the blacksmith fails in working the metal, he will work the bellows. Somebody unsuitable or unwilling to work will be downgraded.

text: Mtoto wa mhunzi asiposana huvukuta (or avuvia).
explanation: If the son of the blacksmoth does not forge he will work the bellows.

text: Mtu aliyeipiga nafsi yake asilie na mtu.
explanation: If you harm yourself you should not cry [for pity] from anybody. If you harm yourself do not not blame it on anybody. Cf. 1036.

text: Mtu mcheza na nyimbo haibudi kumuimba.
explanation: A person dancing with songs, inevitably [someone] will compose a song on that person.
When the deceiver is deceived then he/she feels bitter about it

text: Mwana mkaidi hafaidi mpaka siku ya idi.
explanation: A stubborn child does not even get gain on the day of the Id festival. "On this day that child will suffer, when it finds that it has neither new clothes to wear nor decent food to eat while others are enjoying themselves"

text: Mwenda omo na tezi, marejeo ni ngamani.
explanation: One who goes from the bow to the stern must pass through the bilge. If you want to succeed you must also take the means, hardship, etc. But the proverb can also be translated thus: One who goes to bow and stern returns to the hold of the ship. After traveling abroad and meeting hardship, a person finally comes home to a secure place. All messages come to an important official in different ways.
One who goes to the beach does not eat dry food. Craving for food will be satisfied. Use the right means to reach your goal. Uchu, craving for food. Cf. 4730.
One who self-cleans too much, bruises the skin. One who is too clean (ambitious, precise, exacting) damages the body. Kuchamba, cleaning after call of nature. Cf. 978, 1770.
One who slaughters a beast does not hesitate about skinning it - F. Do not expect mercy from someone who has brought you down. People in power often abuse their power
The watcher does not keep watch if the eye does not see. A blind person cannot keep watch
A dance is not without a composer. Manju, an expert at composing songs and leading the singing at dances. Cf. 4782.

text: Nyasi hazikauke bure: kuna mti kati.
explanation: Grass does not dry up without a reason: there is a tree in its midst. There is a fruit tree, or a tree that gives shade.
Where a tooth is taken away, there is now a gap.
Without teeth the bone can not be broken. One needs the necessary tools to do a job.
Where there is fire there is also smoke. Nothing is perfect - AL.
Where there is a carcass there must be flies.
Where there is a stench there flies are not lacking.

Chiles which you have not eaten, how can they burn you? This proverb is used when people take personal offence at others' grievances, why should you feel guilty for something you did not do? Also used as an accusation
If the chiles burn you, it is because you ate them. You have earned your punishment.
Dung that you do not touch, does not spoil you. Cf.1009.
Why should you be irritated by pepper in the field? Something unrelated should not bother you. Cf. 1008.

text: Ndiwe ulotia moto sasa moshi umo machoni mwako.
explanation: You were the one who started the fire, now the smoke is in your eyes. "As you have made your bed, so you will have to lie in it"
Grass may cause an elephant to fall down. To an elephant grass is small stuff but if it is tied in a knot, it can trap the elephant
Where there is too much jubilation, cry for that place.

A place where there is shouting and screaming is easily destroyed. Kudamira [kuharibu kabisa], destroy completely.Pavum apo [penye kemi na mayowe] a place of screaming.Palilie, [pasikitikie] place of sorrow. Cf.1105, 3929.

text: Punda akiota pembe, watu wa mashakani.
explanation: If a donkey grows horns, people have problems. Mashaka, doubts, perplexity, uncertainty.
Cheapness brings trouble. Buying cheap does not satisfy.
Remove the rotten pomegranate; it spoils the whole ones. Dismiss a lazy, cantankerous wife or farmhand
The blow of a club on the face of an ape does not kill [the ape].
A club is not a spear. The words of some people crush and those of others pierce like a spear - EM.
Giving consent with the nod of the neck is not bitter. Giving consent is not difficult, but afterwards seeing the consequences of an easily given consent, it may become very bitter.
Days are not equal.
If you play while young, you will pay when old.
If you interfere with things that don't concern you, you'll get what does not please you. cf. 1008, 4389.
If you know to laugh you should also know to sulk. Nuna, grumble, show discontent. complain, be sullen, sulk.
If you know how to hit, you should also know how to fend.
If you know how to plait [the hair], you should also know how to shave.

text: Ukijua sana na jua litakuchoma sana.
explanation: If you know much, the sun [that knowledge] also will burn you much. The meaning is that if you think that you are good at something, that knowledge could also backfire. This seems to be a poor play on the word jua. As a verb it means to know, but as a noun it has the meaning of sun.
If you eat what belongs to a dog, you must be an expert runner. If you lower yourself, you must expect being treated as such
If you eat what belongs to lightning, look up [skywards]

text: Ukila chakula cha wizi, uangalie juu.
explanation: If you eat stolen goods, look up.
If you eat where you want, the place where you go will also eat you.
If you sleep, your business too will sleep.

If you see amber, ambergris is not far behind - F. Association of two things. If you see one you are bound to see the other. Zinduna, a fossil gum-copal, is found on the beaches. A perfume like incense and burns on charcoal. Ambari, a wax-like substance found floating in tropical seas, and in intestines of sperm whales. It is odoriferous and used in perfumery and cooking. Ambergris: ambre gris. Ambergris was eaten to become more virile.

text: Ukiona zabadi na zinduna i papo.
explanation: If you see zabadi musk you find also zinduna close by. Zabadi, civet, musk taken from the civet cat. Note: "Ambari, ambarum, species odoramenti; nomen piscis marini magni; ambergris, an odoriferous substance which is said to be eaten as a clammy matter by the whale at the bottom of the sea and then cast off in the excrements. Ambergris found at Mombasa must be given to the Government under penalty to the offender. This is owing to the great valueattached to the ambari. The natives tell a story about an island in the Indian ocean, whither the whales resort, and where the matter is found at the bottom of the sea. Fishermen are sometimes attracted and guided by the multitude of birds pouncing upon the ambari as it floats on the surface of the sea" - Krapf, a'mbari.
If you sow the wind, you will harvest a hurricane. One must suffer the consequences of one's deeds.
If you tear [clothing], you must know how to sew.
If you want the mother to come, pinch her child. Interfering with somebody's property the owner will soon appear.
If you want rain, you must not be afraid of mud.
Where you lie down there you will get up.
When you have cooked a fish you will smell fishy.
As you tapped it [the palm wine] so you drink it. If you do a thing well, you'll enjoy it. Gema, make incisions in the tree to get the sap. Cf. 921, 1575.
Those who stay with roses also smell like roses. "This means that one who lives and works with a big man also acquires some prestige which derives from the master"
People bask in the rising sun. People are always looking to improve their lives.
People gather where there is laughter.

text: Wema wa mtu humfaa mwenyewe, na ubaya wake humdhuru.
explanation: A person's good character is beneficial and that person's wickedness will do harm.
You are you. You are different from others, you act differently.
If things get extreme, even a dumb person will speak.

text: 1042a. Yambo kuingia sahali, kutoka ni uthakili.
explanation: It is easy to get involved in a matter, but it is hard to get out of it.
One who goes into the sea must swim. "Let the spoilt children fend for themselves in the world and they will have to learn to overcome their laziness"
One who holds must hang on, the one who relents will be treated like a fool.

text: Ana uso mwingine kwa mungu na mwingine kwa shetani.
explanation: That person has one face [eye] to God and another to the devil. About people who change their beliefs, or positions, continuously.
One who does not rest will get what he wants. Keep trying, working, striving.
One who really wants something does not give up [will not tire].
The one who can stand the smoke will enjoy the warmth [of the fire].

text: Bandu, bandu huisha (or humaliza, humala) gogo.
explanation: Chip, chip, finishes the log. Perseverance does the job
A flag follows the wind. It is easier to swim with the current. An ostentatious person has no steadfast character but obeys the prevailing spirit
A flag that waves very much will tear in the end. Someone who boasts all the time will get bad results. Cf. 1105.
What came before was just so. The more it changes, the more it remains the same.
Laugh at the end. "He laughs best who laughs last"
A good thing in the world does not have [a long] life. Said by a poet when his best friend departed
A grain and a grain will feed a creature.
A grain and a grain and a loaf appears. Little brooks make great rivers. Cf. 1063.
Ice will soon [be] water again.

text: Chovya, chovya, humaliza buyu la asali.
explanation: A dip and a dip finishes the honey calabash. A big job can be finished in small steps. But is generally used when someone finds that pleasant things often have a bitter ending. Cf. 1049.

text: Chungu cha mifupa huvunjwa na fupa.
explanation: A potful of bones will be broken by a single bone. A good working relationship can be broken by a single person.
If a frog is thrown away it will jam the door. About an insistent salesman.
A frog does not run during daytime without a reason. A frog is nocturnal. If something happens suddenly people will move. Cf. 3339.
A flow of water is not [as effective as] constant dripping - F. A beverage is not poured out drop by drop
A thousand starts with one. Cf. 1549.
Little by little the pint is filled. Little by little a bird builds its nest

text: Hakuachi kucha kwa sababu jogoo mmoja amegoma kuwika.
explanation: The sun doesn't stop rising because one rooster has refused to crow. In life there are things which happen even if they are opposed by one person or many
There is nothing that cannot be replaced by something else. Or, There is nothing that does not change. None of us is indispensable
However it will be, dawn will come.
A curtain is better than a flag. A curtain has stability.

text: Ili ngwe iwe ndogo, chutama uipimapo.
explanation: To make a farming area smaller, squat when measuring it. In dealing with a big matter, look at it from an aspect which makes it appear favorable
Faith never dies. Faith is a state of mind. It can change direction or target, but cannot die
What roars does not last. If a person is becoming too well known, many may become jealous and by opposing put that person down
Make an effort and you'll succeed.
A big stone is not carried away by water.

text: Kibuyu kisipopasuka, kinaweza kuchotea maji mengine.
explanation: If the gourd is not broken, it can be used again to draw water. If your plan fails, you can formulate another one

text: Kinyonga hubadili rangi kulingana na mazingira yake.
explanation: A chameleon changes its color according to its environment.

text: Kipila mwa ufukoni, shakwe mwa chakani gani?
explanation: The curlew is on the sandbanks, in which bush will the seagull be? "Normally, the seagull sits on sandbanks, the curlew is not a seabird"
There is nobody who will pick up a dead centipede. One does not come back on what one despised nor on what one has called bad. No mercy for the enemy
The framewall of a house is ugly until it is smoothly plastered. "A work started should be finished." Cf. 1095.
A sheep always follows the flock. Cf. 1050.

text: Kujikwaa si kuanguka, bali ni kwenda mbele.
explanation: Stumbling is not falling, on the contrary, it is going forward. Said of people easily discouraged: don't give up.

text: Kumbuko kama la punda wa masai.
explanation: A memory like a Masai donkey. The Masai loaded his donkey so heavily that it quit one day. But the next day it had forgotten its master's cruelty and came back to him. Said of masochists
Arranging is removing. Planning and cancelling; hiring and dismissing. Nothing is stable.
Never tire of searching [knowledge, e.g.].

text: Kwa kumpiga kenge mahali pamoja anakufa.
explanation: By hitting the monitor lizard on the same spot it dies.
By exertion one obtains one's purpose.
Water follows its course [runs in its bed]. Swim with the current. Do things normally using your common sense
Water flows down into a valley, it does not climb a hill. Favors come down, not up

text: Maji ukiyavulia nguo, huna budi kuyaoga.
explanation: If you take off your clothes for water you must bathe. Finish the job you started. If you have decided to do something, then you should do it. Cf. 1043.
Water must go its own way. Love cannot be forced
Water flows down to the valley. Cf. 1083, 1091.
Finish your work first.
Finish what you have left.
Practice makes perfect.

text: Mchimba kaburi hachoki mpaka anaona mwanandani.
explanation: The grave digger does not stop working until he sees the corpse inside the cavity of the grave. One must finish the work one has started. Mwanandani, open space in the side of the tomb, where a body is put. Cf. 4026.
