The worms follow the storyteller into emigration. Things will stay the same, moving the homestead does not help. Minyoo, intestine worms; sickness.

If you throw out lepers, you should not keep their belongings behind. "This means that if you decide to rid yourself of a certain shortcoming, e.g. drunkenness, smoking, you should get rid of all things that pertain to that habit"

text: Mkondo upitishao maji na ukae utapitisha maji.
explanation: Let the current which allowed the water to pass continue passing the water. The river bed stays, it does not follow the water. Used to speak about constant things, which are good and need no change.
The waterbed does not desert the water. Cf. 1083, 1091.

The watchman braids a sling. The bird watcher protects the harvest (millet, sorghum, rice) from the birds, using a sling and stones. One who guards the crop from birds occupies free time braiding slings.
Bird watcher, plait your sling and hold your tongue. Bide your time, sit tight, ready to strike at the right moment - SPK.
One who goes on along the road will arrive in the mountains. Cf. 4026.

text: Mtenda jambo asiishe, ni kama asiyetenda.
explanation: They who do not finish their work, are as if they had not started. Perseverance leads to the goal. Jambo (mambo), deeds, actions.
The tree you used to climb in, is also easy to climb down. Repetition makes it easy; but it is also easy to fall down from it.
A river does not change its current. Mkondo, current, flow, rush.

text: Mtoto wa nyoka hukua na sumu yake.
explanation: The young of a snake grows up with its poison.
A person cannot hide his/her character.

text: Mtupa jongoo hutupa na mti (or ungõongo
explanation: If you throw away a millipede, throw away the stick [it is on] as well. A person who wants to quit a bad habit must get rid of all the means and circumstances which may bring back that bad habit. Also the opposite

text: Usitupe jongoo na mti wake pamoja
explanation: Don't throw away the millipede together with the stick. If you hate somebody do not destroy that person, who may be useful later. Cf. 1818.
A noble person has perseverance
The beginning of hundred is one.
Noble people are bound by their word.

text: Neno baada ya neno, kitabu hujaa.
explanation: Word after word and the book is full.
Noisy drumming does not last long.
When a drum sounds too loud, it will soon burst.
A drum that is sounded loudly will soon split [its skin will tear]. Do not stretch things too far
A child's play does not last long. To make a thing last it must have content/meaning. Cf. 1108, 1826.
A pig always comes back to its tubers [truffles]. An evil fellow bears a grudge, maintains hostility. Vihama, edible tubers (cassava)

text: Nyimbo ya (or za) kufunza (or kufunzwa) haikeshi (or hazikeshi) ngoma.
explanation: Songs to be learned do not keep the dance awake. "Songs learnt from outside sources (foreign importations) are not used at a dance so long"

text: Nyoka ni nyoka hata aking'olewa meno.
explanation: A snake is a snake, even when it is toothless. Evil people will keep their evilness, even when helpless.
Marry, give birth as you were given birth.
A cat does not agree to stay on its back. Cf. 4763.

text: Papo kwa papo kamba hukata jiwe.
explanation: There at that very same place the rope cuts the stone. "Constant rubbing of a rope will cut a stone"

text: Papo kwa papo kamba hukaza jiwe.
explanation: There and then a rope will fasten a stone
A good place does not continue to be a good place if you frequent there. Familiarity breeds contempt.
Where there is a will there is a way.
If there is a will a way will be found.

text: Pia ipate kiti chake na iringe.
explanation: The top has settled on its point, it must continue to spin rapidly in order to stay upright. Nothing goes well without continuous attention"
The gazelle changing all the time gets dots [like the leopard]. A person changing his mind will arouse suspicion.
The fish always moves towards water.
An axe can fell a baobab tree. A baobab is a huge tree, and an axe is a comparatively small tool. Cf. 1049.
The difficulty is not so much in building as in thatching. It is the constant care and repair that is the testing ground of somebody's devotion. Cf. 3664.
Not all flowers produce fruit. Not all good beginnings end well.
Safari ants are removed one by one. These ants bite into your body and have to be removed one by one. Evil is repaired with difficulty.

text: Simba ni simba hata akila majani.
explanation: A lion is a lion even if it eats grass. A respectable person is still respectable even when his situation appears to be low
A well-fastened hook cannot be dislodged except by much shaking. "A thing that is firmly fixed cannot be dislodged except with much trouble"
Go forward, going back is shameful. Don't give up.
Aloes never become sweet. Aloe is known for its very bitter juice.

text: Tembo kiwa tonetone, ndipo ijaapo panda.
explanation: Sacl 308, tembo ni instead ofkiwa ; AL tone. If the palm wine is drop-drop, then the coconut shell is filling up. The sap of the palm tree flows drop by drop into the coco-shell - Sacl. Patience is efficient

text: Tone na tone bahari huweka (or huwa mchirizi).
explanation: Drop by drop the sea is established [flows over]. Cf. 1063, 1128.
A drop and a drop fills the bucket. This looks like a modern version of
A baboon cannot avoid squatting. Kuchutama: squat on the haunches as one does going to the toilet. Cf. 2839.
A monkey never forgets how to jump. It is its nature. Cf. 1107, 1117, 2839.
The stomach is not disturbed by hunger or satisfaction [plenty].
Coax the pagan until you reach your aim.
Newness of the ancestors. "There is nothing new under the sun"
The rope [of the well] by constant rubbing cuts the stone. Ukambaa, a cord of plaited palm-leaf strips; coconut fibers. Cf. 1112.
If you redeem a slave, he/she will return to slavery. People get back to their old habits, until they redeem themselves.

text: Ukimwona akipekua kwa mkia, alifanya hivyo mbeleni.
explanation: If you see it pecking at its tail, it did that also in front. Pekua, peck like a hen, search diligently, be curious, inquisitive.

If you have lost your arrow, throw away the quiver. Ngeu, red color, blood, headwound, a carpenter's marker. (An informant translated ngeu by quiver. But it could also mean the bowman's marker, bull's eye, target). Cf. 1100.
If you fly as a heron take leave of your hips. Take the necessary means to succeed.

text: Umekula ng'ombe mzima, washindwa na mkia?
explanation: You ate a whole cow, how come the tail is too much for you? Said of someone who stops to finish a project after having done almost everything.
The one you are calling has not answered yet. Notwithstanding poor results one should not give up
Never stop working and increase your prayers. Never give up
Don't make yourself a chameleon by changing color.

text: Usiwe unakunjwa na watu kama jani.
explanation: Don't allow yourself to be bent by people as a straw.
The function of a chief is instable. See also the section Master.
You'll miss the crab legs and all. It's not good for a person to be all over the place. It's better to finish one thing until its conclusion than to fail in all projects.
The sweetness of the sugar cane is in the knot.
When you serve, serve well.
The thread follows the needle. The thread cannot go through a place that the needle has not passed. This means that a disciple cannot go ahead of his master

text: Uzuri wa nguo rangi, ikifuliwa huenda na maji.
explanation: Color makes a cloth beautiful, if one washes it in water it goes away with the water. Beauty is transient.
The person with one hundred started with one.

text: Wachezaji bora ngomani ni wale waliojizatiti.
explanation: The best dancers are those who prepare themselves. Ji-zatiti: prepare oneself.
Things of yesterday are not the things of today. Cf. 3129.

text: 1153a. Ya pwani yakijaa huja ndani, yakipwa hwenda nje.
explanation: When the tide is in the water comes inside, when it is out, it goes out. Money comes and goes out, friends come and go

text: Akili ni nywele, kila mtu ana zake.
explanation: Intelligence is [like] hair, every person has his/her own. No two people are alike in intelligence. It is said as a sign of respect for the opinions of others, but also to express that everybody follows his/her own opinion.
Ideas are picked up in a meeting [of brains]. Cf. 1163.

text: Akuambiaye: "kula kitoweo kwa uangalifu" anataka ushibe.
explanation: The one who says to you "Eat the relish carefully" wants you to be satisfied, because it will do you good.
One gave a sermon and did not do a thing for self-improvement. Said of someone who gives advice but does not practice it.
The giver of counsel must not forget oneself.

text: Ampae maana shetani, hujipatisha ghadhabu za rahmani.
explanation: A person who pays heed to Satan deserves divine anger.

text: Asiyeona aibu zake, haifai aone aibu za wengine.
explanation: If you do not see your own shame [vices] you should not take notice of the faults of others.

text: Asiyesikia la mkuu huona makuu (or maovu).

explanation: The person who does not ask questions makes mistakes. If you cling to your own ideas without heeding others' advice, you'll regret your own mistakes

text: Bamba na waume (or wake ni) bamba, hakuna bamba la mume peke yake.

explanation: You need not only] a wall [but] also people [to help you defend it]. A town can only be defended by co-operation in unison

text: Warume hufanya bamba, hakuna bamba la nguvu.
explanation: Men make a council, there is no council of force. The African democracy expects common rule by consultation

text: Fanya sahibu wa heri kwa kutakana shauri.
explanation: Make a good friend for mutual counsel.
The stick of warnings hurts. It punishes when you do not listen to warnings.
Animated discussion produces peace. From contradictory advice a peaceful solution is born
To treat a wound you must see it. To solve a problem you must understand it. Tell the doctor what ails you. See also section on "Health.
One denies you a ball of food, but does not deny you advice. A person may not be prepared to give you some food, but will always give advice or information
There is conversation, but there is no listening. Especially when there are warnings involved.

text: 1170a. Mashauri ya mtu usiyashike, mtu siri husema na moyo wake.
explanation: Do not accept anybody's advice, people discuss secrets with their hearts alone.
Go on talking to each other [about your differences] that you may reach your purposes [in the end].
A meeting of frogs. "Said of a useless argument, 'hot air'"
Even a wise person sometimes needs forgiveness
One who asks questions does not take the wrong road.

text: Oni la tajiri hukubalika, la maskini hukataliwa.
explanation: A rich person's suggestion is accepted, a poor person's is rejected. Suggestions should be examined regardless of who gave them.

text: Onyo kwa mwerevu ni baraka, kwa mpumbavu ni tusi.
explanation: A warning to the wise is a blessing, to the fool an insult.
Among a group of elders nothing goes wrong. Implied that elderly, wise, experienced people give good advice
Where there are people [not even] a frog does rot.
Where there are many people, there are many words [opinions]. Or many matters, or much business, or: many quarrels

text: Palipo na wengi pana mali mengi.
explanation: Where there are many people there is much money [to be earned]
Where there are many people, there is God.
Sound advice is not attractive to many.
Now you stop, because you are in pain. One who did not listen to a warning.

text: Usiseme kibanza jichoni mwa mwenzio kumbe wewe una boriti.

citations.page: Don't speak about the splinter in the eye of your friend, while by the way you have a pole inyour eye

explanation: Don't give advice to a crowd. It's useless.
Where people are warned there also is understanding.
Two are better than one

It is better to have a little bad thing you have, than something very beautiful you don't have or possibly will have. Don't desire things that cannot be had. Ambari: ambergris. If eaten at high tide, while standing in much water, results in stoutness; if eaten at low tide in shallow water, results in slimming

text: Asiyekunywa kwenye chemchem hunywa kwenye mto.
explanation: One who does not drink from a spring, drinks from a river. Take the second best. Cf. 1540.

The good luck of your colleague should not keep you out of sleep. If your colleague is lucky, don't spend days and sleepless nights finding out why that person got good fortune, why you missed it, and how you can get it

text: Bahati ya mwenzio usiilalie mlango wazi.
explanation: Regarding the good luck of your friend, don't sleep with open doors. Don't think that you can share in your friend's luck.

text: Bahati ya pua si ya mdomo (or kinywa).
Baya baya lako, si jema la mwenzako.
explanation: Your evil is your own, the goodness of your friend is not yours. Be satisfied with what you have. It's useless to covet.
Bad luck is yours, good luck is for your companion. Bad things that happen are for you to carry alone, success is shared with friends.

text: Kibaya chako si chema cha mwenzio.
explanation: What is bad for you is not good for your neighbor. Cf. 668, 671, 3419, 4482.

text: Bora nusu kitumbua mkononi kuliko kitumbua kizima

explanation: Half a bun in the hand is better than a whole bun in the shop.

text: Bora nusu yai kuliko ganda tupu.
explanation: Better half an egg than an empty shell. Cf. 3473.
I shall not give away what is free [but my own] for something I have to pay for in exchange [even if superior]
Drawing a little water is not the same as pouring it out. Don't despise a little thing given to you in the hope of getting a bigger one.

text: Chungwa unaloweza kulifikia lichune, sio kulirukia liliko juu zaidi.
explanation: Pick the orange you can reach, don't jump for the one that is higher up.
There are two meanings: Do things the way you see fit; and Go with what you see people doing.

text: Furaha inahitaji cha kufanya, cha kupenda na cha kutumaini.
explanation: Happiness requires something to do, something to love and something to hope for. "Happiness is not mere resting and laughing. Happiness comes from working to your satisfaction, loving others and having hope for a better life" - EM.

text: Hakuna furaha ya milele zaidi ya uzima wa roho.
explanation: There is no greater permanent joy than the welbeing of the soul.
Even a lion eats grass. This means that if people are unable to get something they are used to, they may have to use something else of lesser quality. Cf. 1232.

text: Heri nitakula na nini kuliko nitakula nini.
explanation: What shall I eat with it is better than what shall I eat. It is better to have something to eat than nothing to eat.
A person living as happy as if in paradise. Said of a lazy, careless person
A big dog that is well fed does not go to the [garbage] drums.
Every person with his/her own soul (or character). Each of us has to come to terms with our own psychological problems

text: Konzi ya maji yamtosha kunywa mtoto.
Kwamba una kidogo au kwamba una wingi, uwe radhi.

explanation: Your home is your home, even in the wilds.
Being at home [with my own family and countrymen] suits me best. There is no place like home.

text: Maji meupe baharini, lakini pwani hayanishi nyota.
explanation: Seawater may be clean, but on the beach it does not quench my thirst.
When a pigeon-pea plant has no flowers, it blames the sun. It's hard to accept one's own shortcomings
A dog ought to prefer bones. Said when people are doing something they ought not to do, e.g. a wife looking at another man
You have eaten salt, it is not without taste. It is good to remember the pleasures of life. Cf. 2476.
The grumbler gets more [to grumble about]. Of a person who grumbles for no reason.
One who is content obtains respect.
One who has what is needed does not miss his neighbor's. One who has his/her own does not pass the occasion to use what belongs to another. Greed is never satisfied

text: 1215a. Mwenye moyo wa furaha, humzaidia raha.
explanation: The owner of a cheerful heart will find joy ever increasing.
It's the nature of mankind never to be satisfied.
The dove never stops crying. "The East African turtle dove has a sad call, so it is compared to a plaintive person"

text: Nyosha miguu kadiri ya kitando chako.
explanation: Stretch your legs according to your bed. Be content with what you have
The bird does not think that its own nest is shabby.

text: Pabaya pako si pema pa mwenzako.
explanation: Your own bad place is far better [so far as you are concerned] than your companion's place [which will do you no good]

text: Padogo pako si pakubwa pa mwenzako.
explanation: The little place that is yours is better than the big place of your companion
Love what is yours.
When it rains, a platform shields us. When in difficulty a person is not selective. Cf. 4093.

text: 1223a. Raha ya dunia ni mambo matatu: la kwanza afya, la pili ni kitu, tatu bahati ya kupendwa na watu.
explanation: Pleasure in this life is three things: First health, second money, third, the happiness of being loved by people.

Contentment is better than wealth. The proverb could be translated thus: A parent's blessing is better than wealth. Or, God's blessing is better than wealth. The Swahili believe that a child that honors and looks after his/her parents, will be happy and find contentment. But if a child hurts the parents its future will be miserable. Property that is lost can be retrieved, but after parents' death, the evil deeds committed against them remain unforgiven

text: Raha ya chura: tumbo ndani ya maji, mgongo nje.
explanation: The comfort of a frog consists of having its belly in the [cool] water and its back out [in the sun]. To every happiness there is an adversity. Nothing is totally perfect

text: Radhia na hicho chako kifungacho nyumba yako.
explanation: Be content with this which you have, this which ties your house together [i.e., the family]
The fulfilment of envy is regrets.
Blessed are the good old days.

text: Taabu ya mtu ndiyo raha yake.
explanation: A person's trouble is his/her comfort. A person is longing all the time for comfort.

text: Tajiri ni yule asiye na mahitaji mengi.
explanation: A rich person is the one who has few wants.
If we do not get rice, we shall eat porridge of maize flour. We'll eat cassava
We are content with mules if we have no horses. Better small fish than an empty dish

text: Ukiwa na ngozi, usitamani ngozi zenyi mikia mirefu na mizuri.
explanation: If you have a hide, don't desire others with nice long tails. Don't lead a life above your means

text: Usishindwe (na) kupika ukasingizia jiko lina moshi.
explanation: If you cannot cook, don't blame the smoke in the kitchen. The smoke has nothing to do with it. Cf. 1211.

text: Ala ala jirani hata akiwa baniani.
explanation: Thanks to God for the neighbor, even if he/she be a Banyan. Baniani, Banyan. Indian follower of Brahma, i.e., neither a Christian nor a Muslim. Ala Ala, exclamation of surprise. Cf. 2486.
The one who is useful to you has a title [price].

text: Asiye na mtoto (or mwana), na abebe (or aeleke) jiwe.
Asiyenitua kwa hili langu, akiwa na lake n'asitumai.
explanation: One who does not help me putting down my load, must not expect [help] when that person has a load. Heavy loads are carried on the head; to put them down, especially when heavy and breakable, as big water pots, help is needed and expected.

text: Bamba la warume, si bamba na maguvu.
explanation: A council of adults is not a council of force. "Adults are considered to be wise, so they will not need the use of force before coming to a reasonable agreement"
You need not only] a wall [but] also men [to help you defend a town]

text: Chombo hakiendi ikiwa kila mtu anapiga makasia yake.
explanation: A boat doesn't go forward if each one is rowing his/her own way. Cf. 1244.
A vessel of a single person cannot sail near the wind. Cf. 1288.
An empty sack can't stand upright. Refers to assistance and cooperation and has many applications. One needs capital, know how, friends. Children use it to say that they are hungry.

text: Haukweeki upesi, mti usio na panda.
explanation: A tree without a fork [branches] is difficult to climb. That means it is difficult to solve a difficult problem without assistance
It has become "pull me and I'll pull you.

One stone will not support a cooking pot. Three stones form a firm platform for the pot. This proverb is used to bring people to cooperate. It is also used to advise a person to have different ways of making a living; e.g., having different crops in the field

text: Jito likinenepa ni sababu ya mito mingine.
explanation: If a river is high, it is because other rivers have joined. A river is enlarged by its tributaries.

text: Juu ufike mzinga, sharti uvutwe kwa kamba.
explanation: The beehive cannot be raised without being pulled up with a rope. This means that for a person to be successful, assistance of others is needed. Beehives are put up high in trees .

text: Kama kusingwa ni huku, naradhiwa taka zangu.
explanation: If this is being rubbed with liwa wood [to make a bride's skin smooth] I prefer my own skin-dirt
A creeper [liana] does not climb without a tree. Without support it's difficult to advance in society.

text: Karibu isiyo kitu, siioni ni karibu.
explanation: If near [a relative] has nothing, I don't regard it as near."Relatives are supposed to help each other mutually in times of need, if they do not, are they really relatives?"

text: Kata zamani utafika kwangu kuomba dawa ya mtoto.
explanation: Later you will come and ask me a remedy for [your] child. This is said to someone who refuses to render a service, warning that person that help will be denied in future needs.
Shared works don't stop halfway. Work done together will be successfully finished.
One hand does not kill a louse.
One knee doesn't bring up a child. Cf. 1283-85.

text: Kiroboto kwa kimoja chanja, bila kucha kuwezi kuvunja.
explanation: The flea [sitting] on a finger without your nails you cannot crush it. It is necessary to stamp out evil with adequate measures
The play of the little stick is my good fortune. The old person needs a stick for walking and the rhythm of walking with the stick is like a play.
One pole cannot support a house. Cf. 1248, 1256.
Everyone who knocks at the door gets an answer.
Every person with his/her own problem. "There is a limit to the help we can give others"

text: Kilio cha ndege ndicho kilichoozesha mayai.
explanation: The lamentations [at the death of the bird] caused the eggs to spoil. Nothing succeeds without the protection of one's own family

text: Kinga na kinga, ndipo moto uwakapo.

explanation: The patch on the [floor] mat is [cut from] the basket. The basket is made of the same material. Get help from your own kind of people.

text: Kwenye makaa bila moto hakukauki nyama.
explanation: Dead coals don't cure meat. To succeed cooperation is needed.
Today it is you, tomorrow it is me. If you help me today, tomorrow I may be able to help you. Cf. 681.

text: Macho mawili huona zaidi kuliko jicho moja.
explanation: Two eyes see more than one eye.

text: Maji ya nazi yataka (or yatafuta) mvugulio.

explanation: Neighbors help one another.
Craftsman and customer. "The maker needs the consumer to tell what is wanted. The latter needs the skilled craftsman"

text: Mnazi mpata vyote, ila chujio iliukosa.
explanation: The oil palm has everything, except the strainer.
The back is not rubbed with oil. Help is needed.
Many hands make light work.
The two hands wash each other. Cf. 1281.
For many whistles the dog is lost. If a dog hears whistles from different directions it will not know which way to go. Too many instructions will confuse a person. Cf. 1295.
Two [hands] are an anointment. The body needs rubbing with oil from time to time, and two hands (of wife and husband) are needed for that purpose
The one who refuses to join in an enterprise is a witch. Cf. 615, 748, 1273, 1624.
One hand alone cannot carry a baby. Cf. 1285.
A single hand cannot slaughter a cow. Cf. 1256, 1281.

One hand cannot bring up a child. Child upbringing is a communal effort. It takes a village to
 raise a child.
One man cannot launch a vessel. Cf. 1288.
Help the person who helps you. By doing a service to someone, you teach indirectly to give service in turn.
A log cannot be moved except "properly," i.e., by under-supports

text: Mti haushuliki ila kwa mti mwingine.
explanation: A log cannot be pushed along except by another log.
One builds nothing with one tree only. Cf. 1297.
When a tree falls it leans on its neighbor. One looks to one's friend in adversity.
One who is carried [on the back] must cling on. A person assisted by another must also help
Don't expect that someone with trouble will cater for yours.

text: Nahodha wengi, chombo (or jahazi) huenda mrama.

explanation: With many captains the ship is at the mercy of the waves.
Many captains destroy a ship.
A ship with many captains is liable to sink. Cf. 3508.
Strength is helping each other.
Mutual help is wealth.
One single pillar is not sufficient to build a house. Cf. 1290.

text: Nia zikiwa moja, kilicho mbali huja.
explanation: When minds are one, what is far comes near. Difficult things become possible.

text: Ondoka (or amka or inuka) twende! Ni (or watu) waaganao.
explanation: Move, let us go! is of people who have a plan. Rise up, let's go! means that people have decided to do something. This shows that what has been decided is going to be done and what will be done is not known to others. Used if somebody jumps into others' conversation. But this proverb is also used to express disappointment: you should have told me before ... we should have made previous arrangements. Tell people early about your plans if you want them to join you.
Though there are many cats, they have allowed the rats to multiply. A girl must not have lovers that give the house a bad name
Inject money where there is a problem. Money helps to solve problems.
Where there are many good men there no child will get sick.
Where there are many good people an enemy usually dies.
Accept if you give. If you give to others, you should also accept their help, when they give it, otherwise people think that you despise their help or that you don't want to bother helping them.

text: Shida ya ndugu humalizwa na ndugu.
explanation: The trouble of a relative is solved by a relative.

text: 'Shika shika' (or shike, shike) na mwenyewe nyuma.
explanation: Hold him! Hold him!" and you yourself [stay] back. You shouldn't expect others to do all the work
Hold hands when crossing a river. When people are faced with danger, they should cooperate in dealing with it.
One leg cannot support a bed.

If you are carried don't slacken your legs. Try to cooperate and make helping you easier.
 Cf. 2660.
If many spit on you, you'll be soaked. So, don't get in that situation. Cf. 1326.
One piece of wood does not burn brightly in the kitchen. Cf. 1248, 1256.
The branches of a coconut tree squeezed together make a roof.
A platform [for a watchman in charge of crops] of the village Kwae, does not protect the village of Manda. Kwae and Manda are (old) villages of Lamu. Cf. 180, 181.

text: Umoja ni nguvu, utengano ni udhaifu.
explanation: Unity is strength, division is weakness.
When you row your friend across, you also cross. If you help your fellow men, you will also help yourself in the process

text: Vikombe vikikaa pamoja havina budi kugongana.

explanation: Gourds in a basket cannot avoid knocking one another.
Destroy your house, but build it up yourself. Don't expect help to repair your own mistakes. Also used for familial and social break-ups.

text: Wakubwa hupendelea ubinafsi; wadogo hupendeka ujamaa.
explanation: Big people prefer possessions, while small ones prefer sharing possessions. Those who have become successful and have collected much prefer to hold on to that position, but those who have little prefer co-operating in fighting against the environment which has made their situation so low, with the hope that it will improve not for some individuals only, but for the whole group
Those who made mutual agreements don't call each other. They just go and do what they promised. Cf. 1300.
Too many cooks spoil the rice. This means that if many people with differing ideas are asked to implement a decision, the implementation will be problematic
People were told "Come and live together," they were not told "Come and compete with one another." Or: Do not waste your energy on useless arguments

text: Wawili wakishirikiana mfuko wa fedha, mmoja huimba na mwingine hulia.
explanation: When two people have a common purse, one sings and the other weeps. The honest one will be exploited.

text: Wawili wenye shauri moja washinda wanane wenye kubishana.
explanation: Two people in accord are stronger than eight who disagree.
To many, give! To many it is wise to yield.
To many give it up or they will take it themselves. If there are many of the same opinion, don't be obstinate.
Stand upright, pillar, with your brothers. The poles of the roof support each other - RSP.
An orphan is nurtured by a God-fearing person. An orphan depends on a benefactor.
The one who keeps silent is not without cunning.

text: Akili ya mtu ndiyo wazimu wake.
explanation: Somebody's wit is also that person's folly. A person's spirit gives rise to the best and the worst
Someone thinking to be clever is a fool.

text: Asiye na mguu na achonge mti.
explanation: A person who misses a leg should carve a [walking] stick. The need for adaptation

text: Asiye na mjomba hujifanya mjomba mwenyewe.
explanation: The one who has no uncle must become an uncle. If no help is available, do it yourself.
The councillor's brain is in his/her head. Many people have more imagination than true intelligence. Cf. 3792.
The [property] of the cunning person is eaten by the fool.
An old sparrow cannot be trapped with chaff.

text: Chui na majani na mbuzi huvushwaje dau moja?
explanation: A load of grass, a leopard and a goat, how can they be transported in one small boat? "This refers to the fable of the ferryman's dilemma "

The cheetah catches [the prey], the hare obtains it. "The cheetah gets his food through his ability to run fast. This refers to a story where the cunning hare outwits the cheetah and has food without working"

text: Fimbo uliyonayo mkononi ndiyo iwezayo kukupiga.
explanation: The stick in your hand is the one that can hit you too. About tactlessness of speech and blunders.

text: Heri nyoka akuume, kama watu wakukame.
explanation: It's better that a snake bite you, than that people 'milk' you. "To be 'conned' is worse than a snakebite"

text: Hila za sungura, kulia kwa vyura.
explanation: The wiles of a hare [are numerous as] the croaking of the frog. A cunning person always has new schemes

text: Kaa mkuu ng'ombe wa maji akinua gando mwelemeze nanda.
explanation: If the big crab, a water cow, raises its claws put a forked stick between. In the sea the crab is a powerful and fierce being, but if you outsmart it, you can easily catch it. In the same way you can overcome a dangerous person with a trick. At the same time don't mock a person in power or a dangerous person, they may harm you.

text: Kidevu kamwambia ndevu kila apataye huwa mwerevu.

explanation: Every matter has its proper way to handle it. Cf. 420, 423, 2873, 2875.
Brains are needed to trap.
To act like the hare. The hare

text: Kumchokoa kenge katika tundu lake kwataka utaratibu.
explanation: To poke a monitor lizard out of its hole prudence is needed.

text: Kuna njia moja ya kumchuna paka.
explanation: There is one way to skin a cat. There is more than one way to skin a cat - English proverb.
People can see where the minuscule ants enter. The

text: Leo ni siku ya mwerevu, kesho ya mpumbavu.
explanation: Today is a day of the cunning one, tomorrow is of the stupid. A wise man should never postpone what is supposed to be done today.

The paw of a dog does not accumulate mud. This is said of an old rogue, whom nothing rebuffs who enters late at night afraid of nothing. Coming home late at night and drunk as usual his wife will receive him with those words.
A cheater cheated feels bitter.
One who remains silent is not [necessarly] without cleverness. Cf. 1329.
A young crow does not lose its tricks.

text: Mtoto wa mkima hamfundidhi mzee kima hila zamani mayele.
explanation: A young monkey does not teach tricks to an old monkey.

text: Mwenye hekima huona gizani, mpumbavu hupapasa.
explanation: A wise person sees in darkness, a fool gropes about. Darkness here means in a difficult situation.

text: Mwerevu hajinyoi mwenyewe, na akijinyoa hujikata.

explanation: Even a clever man cannot shave his own head and if he does, he cannot shave it quite clean. A cunning person is bound to make a mistake

text: Ndani ya akili ya mtu mna wazimu wake.
explanation: In the mind [brain] of a person, there is also madness. The mind produces good and bad.

text: Ndege mjanja hunaswa na tundu bovu.
explanation: A cunning bird is trapped by a rotten trap. Even a clever person must be on guard.

text: Panya akimcheka paka, anajua shimo lilipo.
explanation: When the mouse laughs at the cat, it knows where the hole is. Do not mock anyone who is more powerful than you
The rat does not forget its hole.
A mouse is caught at an empty maize cob. Cf. 1362.
In water there is no outwitting. If there is no possibility of choice whims are excluded.
Pacify a djinn with an evil genius. Play one enemy off against another.
Cunning increases cunning. Deceit increses deceit.
The ruse of the antelope caught up with it. Even the best trick can cause damage.
Cunning produces a quarrel. Cf. 1378.

text: Ujinga wa mtu ni werevu wake.

explanation: Don't deceive yourself [by thinking] that you have not yet deceived yourself.

If you eat with a blind person be careful. Don't eat from that person's side of the plate. "The cultural image that is used, is one which is still frequently seen: at meals many Swahili families do not have a separate plate for each person, but they eat, usually two together from one plate, each one scooping up some rice, meat and vegetables and kneading it into a ball. The implication is, of course, that the blind person does not know that you are eating together, and the blind person upon discovering may be furious, for you have stolen food from the plate and taken abject advantage of that person's blindness"

text: Usitafute ncha ya kamba, lakini shina lake.
explanation: Don't look for the end of the liana, but for its root. The intelligent person looks for the cause of things.
Don't try to be cunning without [expecting] cunning in return. A trick calls for a trick in return.

text: Watu waliona chawa ndani ya nyanya.
explanation: People saw lice in tomatoes. Nothing remains hidden for a perspicacious person.
Pure cunning does not tie a bag.
The cunning of the grasshopper has deprived it of eyelids. A foolish trick often fires back. Refers to an animal story.

text: Werevu walipo tele, mafanikio si tele.
explanation: Where clever people are many, their accomplishments are few.

text: Adhabu ya kaburi hujua (or aijua; aijuaye ni; ajua) maiti.
Adhabu ya kaburi kila mtu ataiona.
explanation: Everybody will undergo the sentence of the grave. Adhabu: punishment, sentence.
The one who dies will be buried.

text: Afua ni mbili, kufa na kupona.
explanation: Deliverance is of two kinds, dying and getting better. Said to a person who is critically ill, that even death is just as good as getting better: it will end suffering
The corpse washer knows the shame [defects] of the deceased. Cf. 4238.
A person on the death bed tells no lies. A person about to die is not afraid of the consequences.
One who has passed away does not feel oppression. "A dead person feels no cold.
Whoever died [and found] that crying has brought him/her back [to life]? About useless effort.
One who consumes your navel [i.e., your child] will not leave you the fruit of your belly. An allusion to death, which spares neither child nor adult.
The people who are left [bereft, bereaved] find that they are left with many things [burdens].
She lived in the shadow of her husband. Said of a widow living with her children, without remarrying.
Somebody has sent a wail to the scene of mourning. Said when someone does something very apropos"
The person who stays with a dead person does not stop weeping.

text: 1394a. Anokufa awachaye wana afurahi, haifi hayati, tawi hufa uhai hukaa.
explanation: The one who dies leaving children let that person rejoice! Life does not die; the branches die, life goes on
A person who does not know about dying should look in a grave. If you don't know something you should investigate. Don't laugh about things you don't know. Learn from other people's mistakes.

Let a person who does not know how to die, look at the ox. Oxen and sheep are the images of quietness into death. Asojua for asiyejua. O may stand for any relative particle except one relating to place/time
Better crippled than dead. There is no remedy against death.
What enters into the burial ground has no return. Only a free person has a choice

text: Chenye asili ya kiumbe hakikosi deni la kifo.
explanation: What has the beginning of a creature, will not miss the debt of death. What is created must die.
There is no beginning that has no end. Everything has an end.
What has a beginning has an ending. All things in the world, pleasant and unpleasant, will come to an end
There is no hill without a grave.
There is no one who can jump so high as to escape death.
There is no rich person in a grave. The grave levels all distinctions.

text: Hatuko sawa maishani, tukifa wote sawa.
explanation: During our life we are not the same, but in death we are the same.
It's better to die than to part company. Understood is total separation: ostracism, exile, etc. Cf. 720, 1406.

text: Hii pweke ni uvundo, kuondokewa si kwema.
explanation: This loneliness is disgusting, to be deserted is not good.

text: Hivi sasa ni muovu, hifa utanikumbuka.
explanation: Just at the moment I am bad, [but] when I die you will remember me. Hifa for nikifa : when I die.

text: Hofu ya kaburi kaja na umri.
explanation: Fear of the grave comes with [old] age.

text: Hucheka aliyefiwa kabla ya kufikwa na kifo.
explanation: Laughing at a bereaved person before oneself has experienced a death. It's bad to laugh at somebody's misfortune.
You haven't died yet, you don't even look like youÕre dead. Wait till you are adult, then you could start thinking about dying. Cf. 1833.
You don't argue with your grave digger.

text: 1411a. Idadi ya wenye kufa, ni mungu aijuaye.
explanation: The number of those who are going to die, God alone knows it.
If you do not know death, look at the grave. Cf. 1396.
Death is not fastidious nor is there any one who can cheat. Death takes just anybody, and there is no escape.
Death has no defense. "Death is a black camel, which kneels at the gates of all.
Death does not respect neither adult nor child.

text: Kifo ki karibu, ki kishogoni mwako.
explanation: Death is near, it is at the back of your head. The answer to this is sometimes: Au, nadhani ki karibu zaidi.

text: Kifo kikimbizwa funza chawekwa mahali gani?
explanation: The death [dead body] from which the maggot is driven away, where is it kept? Where do you find a corpse sheltered from worms?
Death which eats your neighbor will not forget you.
One death but various burials. Death is all one, but there are many ways of disposing of the dead body
Death has many doors.

text: Kifo na kiumbe, kiumbe na kifo.
explanation: Death and creature, creature and death. They go hand in hand.

text: Kila mahuluki, hufa hafufuki, kabula ya buki.
explanation: Every creature dies and will not rise again, before the trumpet [of the Resurrection].
Let all talkers talk, mortals will not remain. All human beings will die, even the ones who put on airs of importance
What died was alive.
What has consumed the father will also consume his child. One who hates the father will hate the son also. The weaker ones will be harmed sooner. Cf. 1390.
There is no death without someone culpable. A death of natural causes is not admissible. Kitumba, maiti, corpse, a dead person.
A mortal cannot break life's journey. Ari, disgrace. Cf. 511. The poem goes on

text: Mfano mkizi, ni kufa kwa ari.
explanation: Like the octopus dying in shame
Mortal man, what is the end? Be consoled, all must die. Ni before nini is n.

text: 1428a. Kufa hakwishi or kufa hakuna tamati.
explanation: Dying never ends. Dying has no end.
A free person dies like a sheep. Use kindness against violence
Death is ordained by God.
Dying is a benefit. Death has its benefits [if the dead person was rich or hated or suffered much]. Kufana and kufaana (two forms from -faa) are used here: to be profitable.
Dying is like extinguishing the lamp.
The death of many is like a wedding. When any hardship is a joint adventure, the burden becomes lighter
Where many people go there must be a wedding. "Free meals are served at Swahili weddings for all comers"
When the mouth dies, the saliva is scattered. If the leader dies the family or organization or structure breaks up. Mdomo here: speaker, leader, mouthpiece.  Earthy version

text: kufa kwa nyuma (or mkundu) mavi hutawanyika.
explanation: When the behind dies the excrement is scattered. When the supervisor leaves the workers take it easy.
Death is a necessary condition of what is finite.

text: Hatari ya kufa haikimbiki, ni faradhi.
explanation: The danger of death cannot be outrun, it's a common necessity.

text: Kufa ni nini? Ni kuonana na baba.
explanation: What is dying? It's meeting one's ancestor. If you find your ancestors you find the source of life

text: Kufa ni njia ya kila kiumbe.
explanation: To die is the path of every mortal.
To die is not [the same as] to come to an end. Life goes on. Belief in life after death.
Death is not optional, but inevitable.
As for dying, we shall all die.
Where is bereavement there is ridicule [laughter, mockery].
Sleeping and dying look alike. Both are not productive.
Running away from a place where people die, running to a place where people eat.

text: Kuna kufa na kupona, hwenda hesho tutaona.
explanation: There is dying and healing, perhaps we shall see tomorrow. "This is a common saying to an enquiry about the state of a sick person. It is considered imprudent to discuss what ought to be God's prerogative"
There is life and there is death. Two alternatives of mortals: there is a time of living and a time of dying. Cf. 1444.

text: Kunako matanga kumekuwa watu (or kumekufa mtu).
explanation: Where there is mourning celebration, there are people [someone died]. Any gathering draws people for different reasons. There is mutual assistance in difficult situations

text: Kuzika ni thawabu, yaliypbaki ni fahari.
explanation: To bury someone is praiseworthy, what is left is praise.
In the other world there are [terrible] things. It is terrible in hell
To go with the Dead-March. Poetical for "to die." Ulele, a lament; probably from lala, lay down, sleep.
The place of death has no voice. Do not raise your voice where there is bereavement.

text: 1450a. Maisha hayana pato, hutupita kama ndoto.
explanation: Life has no profit, it passes like a dream.
Life is taken away when it is sweet.
Life is sweet but short.

text: 1452a. Maisha mawi na mema piga na kulaza hema.
explanation: Life is bad things as well as good things, [it is] to set up our tent and then to strike it.

text: Maisha ni mafupi kwa mahitaji ya mwanadamu.
explanation: Life is short for the needs of a person. A person always desires more.

A dead person has an undertaker. Mzishi : a bosom friend, undertaker, gravedigger. Mazishi, burial preparations. 
 Cf. 1458, 1459.
A dead person has no blame. Cf. 1463.
A dead person does not perspire. A lazy person expects everything from others
A dead person does not lack praise. The eulogy is full of nice words, but is belated
A dead person does not bury another dead person. Two needy people cannot help one another.

text: Maiti hana ndugu, ndugu yake kaburi.
explanation: The dead person has no relatives, one relative is the tomb.
A corpse is not bothered for a shroud.
The dead man is not punished. De mortuis..."
The dead man gives no shroud. Or, The dead man does not take away a shroud. "After death it is too late to care: Who will pay for the shroud? Take timely precautions"
A dead man is not asked whether he likes a shroud. Cf. 1461, 2610.
A dead person has no evil. "Never speak ill of the dead.
A dead person reminds us of God.
A dead person goes alone.
A heavy corpse does not sink in the water. Nobody will be lost, all come home. One home for all.

A Tuesday's dead has the door removed. "Tuesday is thought to be a very unlucky day to die on. The torment of the grave is then much greater. The door is lifted off its hinges out of pity, that there may be no jolting in getting the body out of the house, which it would feel, as it remains sentient till it has passed the or deal of the two angels in the tomb. As if to say, Let there be nothing done which might aggravate the poor person's hard lot"
The poor have many graves.
The payment of death is procreation. Cf. 1508.
Loud lamentations are not becoming in mourning.
Death does not give a shroud. Death gives no presents.
Death has no appointment. Muhula, fixed time, season.
Death makes people cry. One day the seriousness of life will be brought home to everyone
Death will strike you suddenly, when you don't want it.
A dog does not die in the water, if it sees the beach.
No one can flee from the Taker of souls.
A cockroach does not die of smoke. Cockroaches foregather in the kitchen where the fire is. An old salt does not drown
The drowning person does not stop crying.
A king does not die. A new one will come. The power goes on. Sometimes this is added: na akifa hanuki, and if he dies he does not smell.
A dead person is not reproached. Said of people who cannot take care of things.

text: Mgeni mzuri ni pongo; akifa atakuachia pembe.
explanation: A handsome guest is like an antelope; when he dies he'll leave you his horns. The family rejoices in the death of a rich relative. Contrary-wise: a poor guest would oblige you to pay his/her debts, burial costs, etc. "Handsome means a rich uncle; antelope trophies fetch good prices"
A person who dies without children is not mourned. He or she is not remembered. A sterile woman has no ceremonial burial. Without offspring one is not bewailed.

text: 1477a. Mpe mtu sifa baada ya kufa.
explanation: Praise a person after his/her death. Many secret things may yet come out about a person while alive
The taker of souls cannot be stopped. Death is merciless

text: Mtu hafi ila kwa mzishi wake.
explanation: A man does not die except for his burier - JK. The last witnesses are friends accompanying to the cemetery. This means that after death we shall be properly buried, since it is a duty incumbent upon all Muslims to bury a corpse that is lying about. This is intended as a consoling proverb for those who never have luck. What can a person do if good luck does not seem to arrive?
A person does not die twice. Die well the first time.

text: Mtu huanza kufa mara tu akishazaliwa.
explanation: A person starts dying as soon as he/she is born.
A person dies for his/her belongings.
God does not know a youth. God calls young as well as old.
God does not wait.
People will die, but their names will remain.
A sailor expects to die at sea. Cf. 1484, 1861.

text: Mwanamaji wa kwale hufa maji mazoea.
explanation: To a seaman of Kwale, death by water is a common experience. This applies to all who think that they are experts. They can easily have an accident
An elephant hunter usually gets killed by an elephant. A person usually dies on the site of his occupation. Cf. 1484, 3609.
One who washes the corpse does not give a certificate for paradise. Of people who pretend to have influence in high places.
The undertaker does not harm the corpse. And keeps all the secrets. Cf. 1489, 4227.
The washer of the dead is washed also [one day]. Mwosha, a professional corpse-washer.

text: Na mwanadamu hapana kitu, mara huwa mzima na mara akafa.
explanation: And so a human being is nothing, once healthy and at once dead.
It is better to live, than to die. Cf. 1397.
The decoration of the bier. Cold comfort.
Where a tooth has been pulled is there not an open space? If an important person goes away or dies, an open space is left. Said, for instance, of a widow
Even the kite has been seized [by death]. Dangerous men do not live forever
The nose of human beings looks down [at the earth]. All men must die.
The hour does not wait for the king. The hour of death allows no delay
A dying ear does not feel the medicine

text: Siku yako itafika ya kuhama duniani.
explanation: Your day to leave this world will come.
We are going to die. Lit., going with the funeral drum

text: Tunaishi mara moja, tunakufa mara moja.
explanation: We live once, we die once.

text: Tunda la wema ni wema, la ubaya ni ubaya.
explanation: The fruit of goodness is goodness, and of evil is evil. A good person has good actions, and a bad person has bad actions.

text: 1500a. Ucheo wa kufa hauelekei mwenye cheo.
explanation: The fear of death does not benefit a noble person.
The clay will call you. The belief is that human beings have been created from clay and will return to clay on the place where the clay was taken from
Death is invincible. Death cannot be beaten.
Death is blind.

text: Ugonjwa ni suna, kufa ni faradhi.
explanation: Sickness is hazardous, but death cannot be escaped. Praying, fasting are necessities, but wearing a nice hat or dagger is a matter of custom, not a divine prescription

text:
Ukienda, ya roho y
 Akufuata, ya macho yawachwa.
explanation: If you go, [the wishes] of the heart follow you, the visible things are left behind.
If you die don't be afraid to decompose. Accept the inevitable.

text: Ulacho ndicho chako, kilichobaki ni cha mchimba lindi.

explanation: The counterbalance of death is procreation. Cf. 1449.
Beware of the grave.
You bring a wail the burial [hardship]. You come with a request for help, just when they have their hands full of trouble.
A good person is not abandoned, the partner dies. Only death separates.

text: Yuwenda endaye, mwenda kweli hana marejeo.
explanation: The one who goes, goes [but] the one who goes for real has no return. This is a kind of prayer of parents for their children The child: Nakwenda (I am going). Parent: Hujenda mama/baba/ yuwenda endaye, mwenda kweli hana marejeo. Go child, one who is going goes, but one who really goes has no return
Sink or swim. Two choices. Cf. 1444, 1445.

text: Afadhali ulifanye sasa jambo lilo utakalo kwisha.
explanation: Better do now the thing you want to finish.

text: 1514a. Asema: "sebu! Sebu!" na kimoyo (or kiroho) ki mumo.
explanation: Some say "No! No!" and nevertheless their heart is there. Said of somebody who cannot make a decision.

text: Atanguliaye kupiga mara nyingi ni mshindi.
explanation: One who begins the fight is often the winner.

text: Awali ni awali, awali mbovu hapana.
explanation: A beginning is a beginning, there is no beginning which is bad. The golden rule of life is: make a beginning. Instead of awali the word mwanzo [beginning] is used

text: Chagua na kuchagua na kuoa bata.
explanation: Choosing and choosing and marry a duck [a turkey]. Indecision. Cf. 1539, 1540.

text: Chanzo cha makubwa ni kidogo (or madogo).
explanation: The beginning of great things is small [little things]. Cf. 1519, 1550.
Good beginnings make good endings.
A shoot (sprout) is a tree A child becomes an adult. Chipukizi, shoot, sprout, blade, a growing plant. Cf. 1545, 4037.
A bridge is not a dwelling place. "This means that it is important to differentiate between ephemeral and permanent matters, and to know how to deal with them"
The dodo mango is similar to the sugar banana. Learn to substitute. Dodo, a big smooth mango. Kisukari, a small very sweet banana, more expensive and rare.
Think hard before acting.
A long stick does not kill a snake. One has to use adequate means to succeed. Cf. 1544.
By trying and trying a homestead comes into being. If you try you may succeed, so don't be afraid to start. Geza, (jaribu), to try.
This is no good, the choice will just be a small bean. Of someone unable to make a choice, even in unimportant things.

text: Juzi na jana si kama leo.
explanation: Yesterday and the day before yesterday are not like today. Days follow one another, but are not alike

text: Juzi na juzi ni kama leo.
Juzi na juzi si kama leo.

citations.page: Past days are not like today

text: Kadiria fedha uliyonayo si ile iliyoko kwa mdeni wako.
explanation: Reckon with the money you have, not with the money that is with your debtor.

text: 1528a. Kikuongoacho ki haramu, kikuongoako ni kuzimu.
explanation: If that which leads you is the Forbidden; where it will take you is the underworld.

text: Kiumambuzi kimeuma mbuzi, twatafuta kiumambuzi tutopoe mbuzi.
explanation: The goat-biter has bitten the goat, let us seek the goat-biter to cure the goat. Dawa ya kutopoa, antidote
Climbing a thorn tree, coming down is a dance. Something in haste or anger may produce an awkward situation

text: Kutema au kumeza ni hiari ya mkohaji.
explanation: To spit or to swallow is the option of one who coughs. To speak or to keep silence.
First fish, then sun dry the fish. First things first
Do today the thing of today. Cf. 812.
Alas! May be useful for Alas!
Today is today. Encouragement: This is your day; do it well.
The thing of today should be done today. Cf. 243.
Today comes before tomorrow. Never put off till tomorrow. Do not worry about tomorrow.

text: Leo ni leo, ya kesho ni leo.
explanation: Today is today, the things of tomorrow [the best time to do them] is today. Cf. 1270, 1535, 1536.
We are seeing today, tomorrow does not belong to you.
Today you are here, tomorrow you are not there.

text: Likiwika (or likiwaka) lisiwike (or lisiwake) kutakucha, [twende zetu].
explanation: Whether the rooster crow or not, it will dawn, [let's go]. In difficult circumstances instinct and experience should help us to go ahead without further evidence of a happy ending
Who chooses too much, falls upon the worst

citations.page: koroma. One who selects coconuts [with great care], gets an unripe one. Also, of someone who is too choosy, who cannot make up his mind, wasting time

explanation: One who chooses a fish gets one that is overdue. Fish which has remained [in the shop] too long Kuchina, be too late. Wondering about the origin of the word, someone has suggested that the Chinese like their fish soft
The one who chooses the weapon is not the fighter.
The one who follows the heart will regret it in the end.
One who refuses a good place, has a bad place waiting. By refusing a good thing you'll be caught with a bad thing or situation. Don't be too choosy. Cf. 1539.
One who rides two horses splits asunder. Msamba, the perineum, also called kitako

text: Mpanda farasi wawili, hujishuka miguu miwili.
explanation: One who rides two horses will come down on two legs. Cf. 1557, 1558.

text: Mpigo wa kwanza wa mti unaua nyoka.
explanation: The first blow with the stick kills the snake. Often your only chance. To correct evil use adequate means.

text: Mtu huenda na uchao, hendi na uchwao.
explanation: A person goes [travels] with dawn, not with sunset. A person starting on a day's journey late in the day will be nighted, very likely in some inhospitable place, and possibly lose goods, or even life" - T. "Night is nobody's friend"

One who tackles two wing-bones at once, one of them eludes him/her. One thing at a time. "It is difficult to obtain a satisfactory explanation of this common proverb. It may be an illustration from something in the cutting up or dividing of a cooked fowl; or it may refer to the carrying of live fowls by the bases of their wings, feet downwards, which is less usual than the ordinary way of carrying, for a length of distance, these poor creatures by the legs, with their heads downwards. It seems that only one can conveniently be carried at the time by the other method"

A person who is after two things at the same time will surely see one escaping. "Grasp all, lose all." Ponya, to save, deliver, rescue, evade danger. That may be the reason why L. translates this proverb: "Two ways of escape, one will get him out." An interesting change of meaning. Cf. 2539.

text: Mwanzo huwa na usiri, ikawa mkaragazo.
explanation: A beginning has delays and then there is a downpour. All beginning is difficult.
The beginning is a bud, the end is a coconut. Something begins small, but may grow into something big.  An interesting variation
The beginning is a flower bud, the end is work. To start something is often easy, but the end is work.

text: Mwanzo wa chanzo ni chane mbili.
explanation: The beginning of mat-making is two slips of raffia leaf. A beginning is small.
The beginning of rain is clouds. A happening is often preceded by early signs

The beginning of a drumming is a tralala. Big things have small beginnings. Before a fight there is a quarrel. Cf. Sacleux Dictionary: Nimeshikwa na ndwele ya homa, leo nenda na ulele-ngoma: I've a fever, I'll dance with the dead.
A nice song is brought to the dance. Mwimbo, wimbo, song. Cf. 1569, 1828.

text: Ndiyo kwanza mkoko kualika (or ualike) maua.
explanation: It is today for the first time that the mangrove flowers. The first day that something begins: passion, love, etc.

text: Nia haikuwa moja, ndipo usipate jambo.
explanation: Your intention was not single, hence you have not been successful -T.

text: Nia zako zikiwa moja utapata jambo.
explanation: If your purpose is constant you will get somewhere
If I accept it will be war, if I refuse what will it be? Said of a person who is faced with an impossible choice of two unacceptable alternatives
When I put a hoe blade on the shaft, the field will not be too much for me. "Once you put your hand to the plough"
Two ways hurt. Pursuing two goals is dangerous - Sacl. Cf. 1543, 1546, 1556.

text: Njia mbili zilimshinda mzee fisi, alipasuka msamba.
explanation: Two roads were too much for old man hyena, he split in two. "Do one thing at the time"
Where there is a purpose there is no failure. Hapapotei, there is no loss. Cf. 1114.
A journey is a step. It starts with a first step.

Do not do anything without a purpose If you lose the punting pole there is no more fishing. The punting pole is the indispensable tool for transport in the shallow waters out of Lamu. Preserve your manhood carefully"
A watermelon ripens in the first warm sun. It must be gathered before it gets too ripe to be of use. This is said to one whom you suspect is trying to put you off with vain promises: Do it now"
You think that it is someone, but it is not.

text: Usiende pahali bila haja, ghalibu hukasirika.
explanation: Don't go to a place without cause, you will almost always be angered. Mind your own business.
Do not say: tomorrow, tomorrow, perhaps you will not see the end.
Do not lay a bad foundation. Do not make a bad precedent.

citations.page: 270. Of two things offered to you, take one

explanation: Vyataulika. In Standard Kiswahili, vyateulika or chagulika or vyateuliwa. Tunda, pluck, pick.
Although they carry axes, they do not take the crookedness out of the tree. Corrections should be made early and gently. Cf. 4070.
A song goes with the drum or dance. A singer goes to the drum to sing a song. One in need goes where help can be found. Don't separate things which belong together.
The song will come as the dance goes along.
The songs are composed at the dance
The drunkard's [property] is consumed by the palmwine tapper. Mgema, a person who climbs in the tree and makes incisions in the tree to get its sap in order to make palmwine.

When gongo (beer) enters, the brain moves out. There are many kinds of intoxicants, e.g. status, possessions or knowledge, if it gets into the head, it corrupts the mind and this is weakness - EM. Gongo, a local dry gin. Cf. 1574.
Even a grass eater goes to the toilet. There is no exception for human functions.
The treasure of a drunkard is beer.

text: Kadiri wafyonza pombe nayo yakufyonza akili.
explanation: The more beer you consume, the more it will consume your brain.

text: Hapo pombe linapokuwa ndani akili hakuna.
explanation: Where ale is in, wit is out.
Water fouled by a dog is not potable Food on which a fly has been sitting, is not edible. A woman who has been defiled is no longer fit for marriage
If the palmwine tapper is praised for the good wine, he/she dilutes it with water.
The toddy-tapper buries not his/her mother. The occupation demands such regular and constant attention that the tapper cannot leave it for a single day. Cf. 1619.
The winetapper [has] a good life. "Because there are always drunkards"
When the drunkard is slipped away, the wine-tapper finds it [debt] obliterated. Futika, (futa), wiped out, obliterated, forgiven. Ponyoka (poa), slipped away, escaped, cured.

text: Mlevi (or kilevi) mtaka chombo, simjengee safari.
explanation: If a drunkard wants a ship, don't help with the voyage. Don't give directions for the voyage. Cf. 1863, 1864.

citations.page: 1415. Do not speak ill of palmwine tappers as long as drinking goes on. You may cut off your supply. Cf. 84

text: Mtu hunawa akala na aliyepo kanawa.
explanation: When a person washes the hands before eating, the one who is there washes the hands also. "Eating" also refers to sexual intercourse where also certain rules of purity have to be observed"
A staggering person may [soon] fall. "Expect a drunkard to go from bad to worse; also said of proud people"

text: Mwana wa yungi hulewa kaifa wa mwalimwengu.
explanation: The little waterlily gets giddy, so much more a human being. The little waterlily moves [on the water], so much more a human being
In the house of beer, no beer stays. Too many customers. Cf. 1767.
Where the wine is there is the danger. Habitual drunkeness endangers all and everything
Where there is drunkenness, there is trouble.

text: Riziki ya wagema-tembo mikononi mwa walevi.
explanation: The livelihood of the winetappers is in the hands of the drunkards.
Stop building card-houses. Do something that is useful
Those who reject a call, reject what they are called for

One who calls you has [already] satisfied his/her wishes. "If someone calls you to do something profitable, you should know that that person has profited fully. A human being generally does not like to see that somebody profiteers, until he/she has enjoyed it and had enough! Never reject a summons"
When you are called do not refuse, go and listen [to what is asked of you]. Pulikiza, sikia, listen. Cf. 1589.
The one who calls you has made it full, if you delay the caller will diminish it. You'll be the loser. The caller may change his/her mind.
It is the one that is first who is asked about the bent grass stalks. It is by observing in which way the grass stalks lie that one can tell in which direction a person or animal has gone.
What is given is not yours. One who gives it to you can take it back

text: Chanda dharau kitanda wa ujinga wajibu.
explanation: The finger despised the bed of stupidity, somebody's duty. Used if somebody is expected to do something, but doesn't do it.
You cannot manage horses, how can you cater for elephants. Do not take more responsibility than you can handle
Attend and listen, don't refuse a call. "Accept a call, and when you know what it is all about, you may agree or disagree to implement it"
Justice has no owner. It cannot be bought. Haki, right, justice.
Justice cannot be bought.
Justice elevates a nation.
Justice is stronger than falsehood. Batili (Arabic), worthless, perverse, transgression.
The right of a poor person is not lost. God will take care of it. Cf. 2750, 3356, 3846, 4646.
A person's honor is not lost, nor can it be shared.
The judge has no personal preferences. A judge favors no one.
A judge gives a verdict on justice not on people.
Rain comes in season. Everything has its proper time. Cf. 1607.

text: Jawabu na wakatiwe, na wakatiwe si zani.
explanation: The right answer at the right time is appropriate
Responsibility never dies. You cannot avoid to do your duty.

text: Kama huli panya na wali hupewi.
explanation: If you don't eat mice, you will not be given rice [pudding]. "From a song (quasi) addressed to a cat, if you don't do your normal duty, you will receive no extras"

citations.page: Every person has a station in life

explanation: Makazi, dwelling, mode of living, residence.
Every person has his/her place.
Picking mushrooms: plant lice. Among the mushrooms covered with lice choose only the intact ones. Be selective.
Delaying justice is not justice. To delay one's right is not justice.
A hen will make a nest [to lay eggs in].

text: Kuna matatu mfano, asubuhi na jioni.
explanation: There are three things [ever] alike, morning and evening. Marriage entails responsibilities. Matatu: three things, may be the meko, the three stones which form the kitchen range. The tending and the supplying of food on these is a part of the bargain on either side
You will end at that floating of toy boats. Get beyond child's play - T. A favorite play of all children. Kuolesha vidau, to float small vessels. This proverb ends with the words
To be partial is not good. Favoritism is not good.
Existence is necessary. Maujudi, things needed for existence, provisions?
Respect the one who respects you.
A person who dances at home is rewarded [or cared for]. One should let one's own people benefit from one's art

They who consume their wages, do not bury their mothers. A decent burial costs money, the official mourning lasts for seven days, and all visitors and mourners have to be fed. Not being able to give parents a proper burial is a very serious breach of a child's responsibility
The one who enjoys the first fruits of a country is a child of that country. First come, first served.
Fire has no preference, burns anybody.

citations.page: People do not object alone to being called, but also to what they are called for

explanation: A person refuses advice, but not a call. Cf. 1589
A person does not sell his/her clan. People should be faithful to those who brought them up. Cf. 722.

text: Mtu wa kikoa asipolipa ana kipara cheupe.
explanation: If a member of a mess [or club] does not pay, that person has a bald patch. That person is marked, everybody knows it

text: Mla kikoa kwa mwenziwe asilipe, kama ng'ombe asio pembe.
explanation: One who eats a meal in turn at a friend's, without returning a meal, is like a bull without horns.

text: Mnyapara wa kikoa asipolipa hubaki kichwa cheupe.
explanation: If a bald person of the club does not pay, the shining head will remain. Mnyapara, foreman, supervisor, but could also mean, a bald person. Para, bald. Cf. 1273, 1624.

text: 1624a. Mtu wajibu wake kutuza nchi yake.
explanation: It is your duty to give [help] to your own country [your people].

text: Mvunja kwao hakui, ila huwa yeye mbombwe.
explanation: People who destroy their native land do not prosper, but will become despicable. Mbombwe or bomwe, a maggot; a potsherd
The person who destroys the country is the inhabitant. It is the insider who does greatest harm.
A call is not refused.

text: Nahodha mtaka chombo si mjinga wa safari.
explanation: A captain who desires a ship is not altogether ignorant of a voyage. If someone accepts responsibility that person should know how to handle it.
Who will tie the bell to the cat?

text: Ndaulia! Si ulinzi: bora ni kwenda mwenyewe.
explanation: See after it for me! is no [effectual] minding [of the crop]; that which avails is to go oneself
If there are holes in the hide, the shepherd is responsible.
If there are holes in the hide the flayer is responsible.
Forgive me, forgive me, broke the pots and destroyed them. Repeated excuses are destructive.
The road of the traitor is razed. Every service is refused. Cf. 1625.

text: Paka akiwa hakimu panya hawezi kushinda kesi.
explanation: If the cat is judge a mouse cannot win the case. Cf. 1604; 3356.
Tear and then stitch. If a person spoils something he should repair it
If the chiefs forget the drum, don't remind them. Better keep away from other people's responsibilities.
If you are called, go, you might refuse to do what you are called for. Cf. 1589, 1590.

text: Ukirithi jina urithi na mambo yake.
explanation: If you inherit a name you must also adopt its affairs. If appointed you must fulfill all the obligations attached. Mambo has often the meaning of bad things, e.g., debts.

text: Ulipo si kitu, unachofanya hapo ndicho muhimu.
explanation: It's not where you are, but what you do there that matters. It is not important at what level of responsibility you work, but how you conduct your life.
Don't take the world to carry it on [your] head. "Do not take more responsibility than you can handle"
Trustworthy people [insiders] are also spoilers. Haribifu,spoil, destruct. Aminifu, trusting, believing. Cf.1626.
You who marry, marry, we'll eat at your place in turns. Profiteers take any occasion to advance
It's easier to confront a witch doctor than a slanderer. Suta, confront a person who has spread an evil report about you. Cf 3131.
An evil person cannot be stopped.
Evil cannot be hidden. Afriti, an evil spirit.

text: Aliyemfunza chui kula watu ni binadamu.
explanation: It was a human being who taught a leopard how to eat people. "Our forefathers say that the leopard wanted to eat people but did not know how to kill them until it overheard someone telling another that if the leopard was clever, it would jump on someone and prick its claws into the person's neck. This saying means that someone, through carelessness, may teach the enemy how to hurt "
The leopard did not know how to grab the throat until it was taught. Cf. 1626.
The evil spirit of a human being is a human being. When a human being does evil that person is not a victim of the devil. A person is free to choose between good and evil.

text: Adui mkubwa wa mtu ni mtu.
explanation: The greatest enemy of a human being is a human being.
Mankind is bad.
No person has to learn corruption.
Scum floats on top, avoid it. Bad people show off, good people are not noticed

text: Buyu kali ni dawa ya mwanamimba [mwenye mimba].
explanation: A foul calabash is a cure for a pregnant woman. Something bad for one person may be good for another
If you see activity of a bad person, be afraid of it. Mtu mavi, a bad person.
The food of a camel is a camel. The food of revenge is revenge.

text: Chawa aumae yu upindo wa ndani.
explanation: The louse that bites is in the inner skirt
The louse that bites you is inside your clothing. The person who slanders you or steals from you is your own servant or relative or a close friend

text: Chenye pembe hakifichiki, ukikificha kitapasua nguo.
explanation: You cannot hide something that has a horn; if you hide it, it will tear the cloth. Evil cannot be hidden.
The leopard which devours your lamb is more wicked than you

text: Dhambi za ahera ndizo zitakapopatilizwa katika ahera
explanation: Mortal sins are the ones that will be punished in the next world.
The good person is indistinguishable from a bad one.
There is no rice without some that is not husked. Don't expect that all people are good people even in one's family. Ndume, a grain in its husk.
There is not one person with a [completely] clean intention. Alo or aliye, who is.
There are not two people who have a pure [harmless] intention. Cf. 4859.
Even a sexually impotent person has lust. Hanithi, a sexual pervert; impotent. Mkware, a lascivious person, male or female, a prostitute.

text: Heri ngumi ya usoni kuliko neno baya rohoni.
explanation: It's better to receive a cuff in the face than to have a bad word in the heart.
Mercy [coming] from an evil person is cruelty.

text: Jambo baya likitokea nyumbani yatima hukaribiwa.
explanation: When evil leaves the house the orphan is welcomed.
During building, destroyers appear. On a big project, some things may be damaged, such as in widening a street, trees may be cut. Cf. 482.

text: Kibuyu cha mgema hakivunjwi na mti.
explanation: One does not break the calabash of the wine tapper with a stick. Being aggressive spoils happiness. Cf. 83, 84, 1580.

text: Kichwa ulichokitoa damu napo usiokote chawa zake.
explanation: Don't collect the lice of the head you bloodied. Don't expect any good of an enemy, even after his/her death
A little of a just person is excellent.

text: Kijumba cha ufisadi mbele kina sumbuko.
explanation: A house of ill fame has trouble ahead. Kijumba cha ufisadi, a house of debauch
Better a cut-off hand/arm than committing a sin

text: Kikulacho ki[mo] nguoni mwako, kimefichwa kwa machoni.

explanation: What bites you is in your feet. Chiggers destroy your feet. Cf. 1651.
No adulterer has good character. Asherati, debauchery, adultery, fornication. Mwashirat, immoral person. Cf. 3271.
Every [divine] messenger is faultless. Maasumu, without sin, without defects. Mtume, messenger, especially of Muhammad; Apostle, Moses, Job.

text: Kiwi cha yule, ni chema cha yule: hata ulimwengu ukaisha.
explanation: A bad thing for one person is a good thing for another, until the end of the world
One wrong does not repair another wrong. When you cheat somebody because he cheated you that does not make your cheating good. Forgive and forget.

text: Kuku na mavi, mlowe; ukimuwasa aleni?
explanation: A chicken on the dung heap, it is her food; if you keep her from it, what will she eat?

text: Kutenda vyema ni kujiepusha na vibaya.
explanation:
To do good things is to avoid doing bad things. To avoid doing evil is, in itself, doing 
 good.
Not joining evil [doers] is a saintly duty.

text: La mtu usisikilize, la uwi ulikataze
explanation: Do not listen to what people say, prohibit what is evil. Uwi, ubaya, evil

A curse comes on its own. "A curse is punishment due to somebody's bad acts. This punishment does not wait to be pronounced by the ill-treated person or the offended one as some people believe; it happens on its own"
Feathers float, the cup sinks. A good person floats, a bad person sinks on judgment day.

text: Maovu mengi huwa huru zaidi usiku wa kiza.
explanation: Many bad things are set free at the darkness of night.
Yesterday's dung does not lack flies. People like gossip.
Old droppings do not stink.
Old droppings still stink. Evil misdeeds are not totally forgotten.

They who honor the devil are devils themselves. Mcha, often used with Mungu [God]: 
 God-fearing.

text: Mchimba kisima (or kiwi) huingia (or hutumbika) mwenyewe.
Mchimba kisima njiani huingia yeye, mwandani.
explanation: One who digs a well in the road gets into it, my friend.
One who digs a pit will land a friend in it.
One who digs a grave will put a friend in it. Cf. 1690.

People who cut down a forest will cut themselves in the end. Kufyeka : to make a clearance in the wood, either for a camp, a road, or a garden. Therefore it also means to flatten things, to destroy things.
When you remove the limits, you will break your country. A pun on hadi, frontier, limit. Meaning: the strength of a nation is broken by the citizens removing the limits of decency and morality.

text: Mkono uliotia jiwe majini, ule ule utaopoa.
explanation: The same hand that put the stone in the water will pull it out. The culprit must pay. The borrower must pay back. Cf. 4228.

text: Mla nyama mbichi ana hofu ya kuumwa na tumbo.
explanation: One who eats uncooked food has fear of stomach ache. Said of people who do evil: they live in fear.
The evil-doer should be told [about it].

text: Mtu mbaya ni sawa na kakakuona.
explanation: An evil person is like a small pangolin. A pangolin projects its tongue and traps ants. Kakakuona, an animal like an armadillo, a kind of anteater.

text: Mwenye nia mbovu ndiye atakaengia kisimani.
explanation: A person with ill intentions shall go into the well.

text: Nia njema ni tabibu, nia mbaya huharibu.
explanation: A good intention is [like] medicine, an evil intention corrupts. Tabibu, medicine, doctor
In a place where good is done, bad deeds do not pass. Itifahi, matendo mema, good deeds. Ikrahi, matendo ya kuchusha, hateful deeds
A dog comes to curl up at a fire. An evil person, after harm is done, comes to enjoy the evil
Where you find a good person there also is a bad one.

text: Pongo hawezi kutoka ndani ya mtego.
explanation: The gazelle cannot escape from the trap. A person who has been in fault will relapse.
Bribery is the enemy of justice.
The devil is the human heart.
The devil of a person is a human being.
Not every killer is evil.

text: Si mzuka pekee [pana mkono wa mtu].
explanation: It's not the devil alone [the human hand is also involved]. Mzuka, spirit, ghost.
The ant gets inside and bites a soft spot.

text: Ubaya hauna tongo, wema hauna kibanda.
explanation: Evil has not [even] a deserted village, [where one can stay overnight], but goodness has an open house. Tongo, a deserted village or home. Kibanda, a square house.
Evil reverberates more than good.
These matters are the talk of the town.
Evil has a bad ending.

text: Ubaya wa mtu ni umdhuruo, nao wema wake ni umfaao.
explanation: A person's evil is what harms that person, but goodness is useful to that person..
The evil of the soul is poison for the body. Body and soul are interdependent.
The sharp roof-pole is trimmed for the roof, [but] pierces a human being. Harm comes to someone who does harm

text: Ukimwombea kifo mama kambo, kifo hicho humchukua mama yako.
explanation: If you ask for your stepmother's death, the death will take your mother. Wishing someone evil comes back to you for the worst. Baba kambo, mama kambo, ndugu kambo, stepfather, stepmother, stepbrother or sister.
A bad piece of firewood cannot be hidden. It will not burn and will produce a lot of smoke.
If you feed dogs, you will have trouble. If you do evil you'll suffer the consequences
You stopped touching dung for touching urine. You left one bad thing for something worse.
One who does unpleasant things, meaning "You are in the wrong place," in order to get rid of that person.

text: Wema hufanywa na mbaya, ubaya haufanywi na mwema.
explanation: Goodness is done by a bad person, evil cannot be done by a good person.
Goodness is the father of goodness. Goodness bears goodness. A good deed calls forth a good turn from the receiver.
Goodness is a thing of character.
The goodness of a person cannot be seen on his/her face.
A bad egg floats on the water. Evil is visible. It shows.

text: Zani haina hazana: ni ukuba wa mbeleni.
explanation: A crime admits of no hiding; it brings its retribution in the future
Whatever is superior is found at great price. Advice given to youth.

text: Adhama ya mtu hutoka kwake mwenyewe.
explanation: Greatness and respect come from the people themselves. Implied is that you become what you want to become and that if you want to be respected, begin by respecting yourself
Only angels are free from mistakes.
A thick wooden board is not [as good as] a thin one of iron. Do not judge people according to their size, expensive clothing or titles, but judge their human qualities
A duck eats clean food. [And has nothing to be ashamed of.] What is good/clean for one person is not necessarily so for another. Do not imitate senselessly.
To reduce the price does not always result in selling the wares. "Everything has its value and must be duly appreciated"
