The value of a sheep is in its tail. The tail is where fat is stored and shows that the sheep is healthy and well fed.
Good food needs no coverlet against the flies. Good food is eaten, nothing is left for covering. Kawa, a conical dish cover, made of plaited grass. Cf. 1733.

text: Chambo chema ni baraka ya mvuvi.
explanation: Good bait is the blessing of fishermen. A generous person is well liked. A fine piece of craftsmanship sells. One who treats the workers well will see work well done.
A good things sells itself.
This seems the opposite of the above: A good thing is hawked, a bad thing sells easily. Bad habits are taken over more quickly.
Iron is passed through fire to be hardened.

text: Chura mpumbavu alinda kisima na maji yatekwa
explanation: The stupid frog guards the well and yet the water is taken. Frogs are symbolic of cuckolded husbands, since they have no control over their wives

A person going to the farm should go when the town is quiet. A person living in town often has the garden rather far from the city. That person should go early to the field, before other troubles or cares appear that would make the trip to the garden impossible. If you have a plan, prepare yourself and make sure that you have taken care of all the problems as far as possible.

text: Eneo la maisha si hoja, jali unachojenga hapo.
explanation: The area covered by your life is not as important as what you build on it. To live a long time is not important. What matters most is how that life is spent
A new broom sweeps clean.
An old broom is smooth in the hand. It takes time to get used to new tools, shoes, methods or people
What is covered is not comparable to what is left open. A thing well cared for is more desired and respected. Funika for iliyofunikwa. Cf. 3505.

text: Gogo la mbuyu si la mvule
explanation: The trunk of the baobab is not like the trunk of the teak. The mvule has good timber for making furniture; the wood of the baobab is useless. Substance above appearance. Mbuyu, baobab. Mvule, East African teak.
Need breaks need. Sometimes a person has to demolish something needed in order to get something needed more
There is nothing beautiful without a blemish
There is nothing so great that it cannot be surpassed.
There is no rice without small [broken] pieces. Nothing is totally perfect. Cf. 1655.

text: Hapakosi ndege wengi penye mti mkubwa.
explanation: In a big tree there is no lack of many birds. People will go to a great person for help

text: Hapana kizuri kilichohitimu kwa watu wote.
explanation: There is not one good thing that everybody appreciates. What is good for one is not good for another. Moreover, our own desires change from day to day.
Wisdom is better than pearls.
Wisdom is in the head, not in the eyes. Wisdom is in understanding things one sees, reads or hears.
Wisdom is not grey hair. Cf. 552, 1819, 2829, 2944.
Respect should be given to one who knows respect.
Honor does not come by itself, it must be brought in. It must be earned by deeds. Cf. 1725.
You are not too late to change. Any time you have done wrong, correct yourself
The stability of a boat is the anchor. In life support of family and friends is needed. Cf. 1755.
The toughness of a hoe, go and wait in the garden. The test of a person is in practical life
A good thing is not easy to get. A good thing can be obtained only through serious effort and considerable difficulty

text: Jino la pembe si dawa ya pengo.
explanation: An ivory tooth is not a cure for a gap [a lost tooth]. A substitute, however grand, is not the real thing

text: Johari za mtu ni mbili, akili na haya.
explanation: The most precious qualities of a person are two: intelligence and modesty. Johari, a precious stone.
The total amount of days is seven. Seven is a perfect number.

text: Kama hutaweza kuvuta mtumbwi, usiuondoshe nchi kavu.
explanation: If you are unable to guide a pirogue, don't leave dry land.

A rope breaks where it is thin [or rotten]. The poor and the weak are most often blamed, even if they are not in fault, while the bourgeoisie are not blamed. The chain is no stronger than its weakest link
If the rope is broken we tie another. A misfortune should not stop the movement of life. Said in case of money lost or a wife who has left or divorced. Cf. 368.

The dry coconut does not reverberate, how much less that which is yet green - T. If the coconut you thought was ripest is proved to be unripe [being full of milk], why should you go on to shake others, which are manifestly green?
The match burns, but it cannot compete with resin. Modern matches are no match for our old-fashioned resin sticks. New inventions are not always as good as old standbys.
Greatness grows at home. When appreciated among its own people something is big indeed
Every human being has some faults.

text: Kilicho kitamu hakiwekwi ndani ya shavu.
explanation: What is sweet is not stored in the mouth.

The young gourd is spoiled when big. Kimumunye, mumunye: a gourd-like vegetable. This is cooked when young, but not when it has grown big. It becomes a gourd to carry water. Said of a youth who turned bad when grown up.

text: Kina cha maisha ni bora kuliko urefu wake.
explanation: The depth of a person's life is more important than its length. A person may have a short life, but may have done much for the community

text: Kiongozi dhaifu ni fedheha kwa wanaongozwa.
explanation: A weak leader is a disgrace for those who are led.

text: Kitanda cha mbao hakina bei sawa cha chuma.
explanation: A wooden bed does not cost as much as an iron one. Bridewealth is expensive but a prostitute is not as good as a spouse

text: Kutafuta makosa si kazi, kazi ni kuyasahihisha.
explanation: Finding faults is not difficult, the task is rectifying them. And there are few people who can do that.

text: Kutunga na kunadhifu ni kama kwomoa nyuki.
explanation: To compose a verse and make the lines rhyme and scan, is like getting out the wild honey from the hollow tree. Nadhifu, put neatly in order. Omoa, dig out, bring to light.
Do not compare an old [roof] with a roof with a hole. An old roof is better than a leaking roof, or an old pot is better than a broken pot.

text: Kuvua maji ya kina kwataka wakurufunzi (or wakafunzi).
explanation: Fishing in deep water requires craftsmen. To do a skilled job expertise is needed

text: Macho yataweza kuacha moma bila kumwona, na kumwona nyoka mdogo aliye karibu naye.
explanation: It is possible that the eyes do not see the puff adder and see the little snake next to it. One must not keep oneself busy with trifles while neglecting the important matters. Moma, pili, puff adder
Early ripe, early rot. Often said about girls, though the prefix ma- may refer to matunda (fruits) and to maneno (words)
Bad boards become dust. A house [marriage/family] must be built with first-rate wooden beams. Marriages have to be concluded between partners of the same social class

text: Mcheza hawi kiwete, ngoma yataka matao.
explanation: A dancer should not be crippled; dancing calls for grace. Said to people without ambition. Matao, curves, twists, bends.

A good shepherd does not stay in front. If the shepherd is behind, it is easier to see and press the flock to move forward and also to ensure its safety. Similarly a good teacher should be behind the group of people

text: 1779a. Mjeledi humpasa farasi na hatamu humpasa punda.
explanation: A harness fits as equipment for a horse, a bit fits a donkey. Beings of a higher class do not need a strong control
An excellent farmer is welcomed everywhere.
A passerby does not enjoy the honors that are given to him/her.
There is no rice without some empty ears [husks]. Cf. 1778, 3467, 4573.
Even a well-adorned person has some imperfection.
A hero wastes his/her strength. Great individuals are generous and self-sacrificing

text: Mtemba ni mtemba bora unatifua moshi.
explanation: A tobacco pipe is an excellent pipe if it raises smoke. Tifua: cause to rise, stir up.
A person who laughs at someone who is at home, is a fool. A person who is at home is surrounded by his own people. Juha, mpumbavu, fool, stupid. Dharau, despise, mock.

text: Mtu ni kitu, lakini si kitu.
explanation: A human being may be regarded as a thing, but a person is not [only] a thing
A person is people, a thing is not. Animals are created, therefore they are creatures, but they are not [real] creatures, a human being is the creature by excellence -AL, mtu. Cf. 719, 4601.
A person is not a dog.

text: 1787a. Mtu wa heshima humpa yake mama
explanation: People of honor maintain their mother. To be known as people who do not give their mother what she needs, would be a disgrace
A skilled skipper ties [the vessel] with two (vitani, ropes).
A good skipper is not afraid of waves. Cf. 1628
The boat which has no outriggers does not survive. Essentials should never be missing

text: Ngoma ikolee huambwa huku na huku.
explanation: A satisfying drum is beaten on both sides. "For a drum to give its best, the drummer must use both sides of it in proper time. The meaning is that to maximize the benefit of a matter, it is necessary to examine all of its aspects"
A house built on sand cannot withstand the storm. A matter which has no good basis can easily be destroyed.

text: Paka hashibi kwa wali, matilabae ni panya.
explanation: The cat is not satisfied with rice, its quest is mice. You attract people by their weaknesses. Matilaba, desire. Cf. 4094.

text: Pale uliponunua ngoma inayolia vizuri utaparudia.
explanation: There where you bought a good-sounding drum you will go back.
Where there are experts, there is no lack of learners. Cf. 873.

text: Punje moja ya mtama ni bora kuliko almasi.
explanation: One grain of millet is more precious than a diamond. A grain of millet is productive; a diamond does not fill the stomach.
Cheapness is expensive. A cheap thing does not usually last.
Cheapness does not satisfy.
To be cheap spoils the cooking. Cheap goods always prove expensive - V. To be cheap spoils good cooking
Easy always does not happen.
Clean the cup inside and out. Do a job well.
The fulfillment of the clothing is the turban. Only when you put on the turban are you fully dressed. Cf. 1802.
The beauty [value] of the cloth is the embroidered hem. Cf. 1801.
The beauty of heaven is that there are angels. A description of heaven includes angels.

text: Swifa za mti zafungwa ndani mwa yaliyochungwa.
explanation: The qualities of the tree are tied inside [the fruits] that have been well cared for
The sweetness of the coconut juice is best when the juice is taken in the nut. Something taken in its natural state is more appealing

text: Hapendezi mwanamke illa ndani dafu yake.
explanation: A woman is not liked except for her coconut juice [in her youth]. Cf.4610.
Doing favors to a dog, how can it recognize its benefits? About doing good to people who do not appreciate it.
The value of people is their personality.
Make room and then build. If you point out the wickedness of something, you should also show how to rectify it
The juice of an immature coconut is not like coconut oil - F. An unripe coconut full of milk is not creamy juice
It is the ripe fruit that is eaten.
The pit gives quality to the tree. A person's value derives from the heart.
A person's excellence is not [determined] by the color of skin.
The quality of the soap is in its foam. A well foaming soap is a good soap.
The solidity of a house comes from the foundation. In a family or organization it comes from the key person.

text: Uje, upitie mwamba, tukujue u rubani.
explanation: And come, pass by this rock, so we may know that you are a pilot. Prove your worth by deeds.

text: Ukiona chungu kipya, usitupe cha zamani.
explanation: If you see a new cooking pot, don't throw away the old one. All new things are not always better than the old ones. Cf. 2254.

text: 1816a. Ukitaka nyumba njema utie msingi mwema.
explanation: If you want a good house lay a good foundation. Conclude a good marriage
If you cut firewood, cut it well. If you do a meaningful thing do it well. See note on to, temato #82. Cf. 1148.
Let the woodcutter show you it [the wound] by cutting him/her-self. Take a warning from experienced people

text: Ukiua nyoka, ukikate kichwa, usije kuumwa mara ya pili.
explanation: When you kill a snake, cut off its head lest you be bitten a second time.

text: Kama unataka kuua nyoka mpige kichwani.
explanation: If you want to kill a snake hit it on the head.

text: Ukuukuu wa kamba si upya wa ukambaa.
explanation: A well-worn coir-rope is better than a new rope made from raffia

text: Ukuukuu wa kamba si upya wa mkano.
explanation: An old rope is not so good as a new tendon. Mkano or mshipa: a tendon.

text: Upepo umepinduka, la shamba lake mjini.
explanation: The wind has changed, the produce of your garden is in town. Change your occupation. To go and live in town is now better for you; go with the flow.
Equality is spiritual. Human equality is not a matter of physical body-height or weight or of the intellect. Equality is a spiritual matter

text: Usidharau kiselema. Chalima kikapita jembe zima.

explanation: Do not despise an old hoe; there is none better for hoeing. A new [wife] is not always better - SPK. Cf. 2254, 3996.

text: Usifikiri mama yako ndiye mpishi peke yake.
explanation: Don't think that your mother is the only cook.
Do not eat [use] what is broken, do not break what is whole
You behave soap-like. Even a small piece of soap will lather. One who behaves soap-like is one who works hard to maintain prestige even when the ability to do so is almost gone

text: Wapiga mbio ni wengi, washindi ni wachache.
explanation: There are many runners but few winners.
It is the intelligent people who find solutions.
People learn from their mistakes.

text: wasile wawa, - kelele, mbio, na kufukuzana

explanation: A modern lament [1885]: They have gone, they are no more, the heroes, the genuine ones. There are left behind just these: noise, haste and chasing one another; there is no longer any sobriety

text: Wenzile hawaslile wanaume wenye maana, wasele walo kelele, mbio na kufukuzana.
explanation: They have gone, none remained of the men of significance. There remain only the shouters, always running and chasing each other.
No one ever hushes a babe with a bad song
A child is not guided with a bad song. "Songs are much used in Africa to teach children proper behaviour."
A bad prayer does not mention the needs of the child.
Don't think that all that glitters is gold. Don't judge from appearances only
All that glitters is not gold.
One who knows about groaning [of sick people] is the one who sleeps with that person. Msono, snoring, groaning, snort; whistling to attract attention or to express derision or contempt.
If someone wants a piece of [live] charcoal, give that person fire. If someone is looking for a quarrel, give that person 'hell'
One who has been pricked by a thorn values shoes.
That person has eaten much salt. Has lived long; has much experience.
Trust what you see, do not believe all you hear. Cf.1887.
The person who has been shaven with [a piece of] a bottle can never forget. About evil done to somebody. Cf. 1885.

text: Asiyejua faida ya mwangaza aingie gizani.
explanation: One who does not know the advantage of light should enter darkness. To appreciate good things one should experience the opposites
One who does not travel has no shining lamp. Has nothing to tell.
One who wanders much by day knows. Said of somebody who learned through experience. Cf. 1850.
The one who visits relatives knows the clan. Ukoo, relationship, kinship, affinity, ancestry, family.

text: Avaaye kiatu ndiye ajuaye msumari uchomapo.
explanation: The one who wears the shoe knows where the nail pierces. "There is nothing like first-hand experience
Smooth seas do not make skillful sailors.
Without a sign, you will go astray
An old bull fights with experience.

text: Hakimu mjua methali hutoa mashauri ya hekima.
explanation: A judge [counselor] who knows proverbs gives wise advice. "Proverbs are the quintessence of the teaching of tradition and customs. They are a treasure of the lessons which a society has accumulated for a long time"

text: Hali ya mtu haijui mtu, mwenye hali kaijulia.
explanation: Nobody knows the condition of another, except that person. Cf. 2220.
If it does not make you hot, then you have not tasted it. Cf. 1008.

text: Jambo (or neno) usilolijua ni kama usiku wa kiza.
explanation: The matter you do not know of is like a dark night. Ignorance is like a dark night. One cannot judge things unknown
You do not know the bugs of a bed you have not slept in. Cf. 1877.
The koko is never reached by water. It grows in the water but its branches are high
To live long is to see much. Experience is the best teacher.
Eat much salt. Cf. 1833.
To lose the way is to know the way. Experience is gained by mistakes. To know that one is lost is the first step to improvement
The eyes which have seen the mountains are not terrified by valleys. One who has seen much is not so easily astonished as the one who has never left his village.
You do not know the extent of waters you have not been to.

Give a wizard [local doctor] a child to bring up. The wizard will use his craft to protect the child. Witches and other black magicians practise evil for the lack of love and a purpose in life. Give them a child, something to care for
The shepherd knows about fat. A shepherd knows which animal is fat. Cf. 1866.

text: Mguu ulioumwa na nyoka hawishi woga: hata ukiona kamba hudhania ni nyoka.
explanation: The foot of someone bitten by a snake has always fear; even seeing a rope that person thinks that it is a snake. Cf. 1870.
One who knows how to go does not stumble. One who leads a good life has nothing to fear

text: Mla ndizi husahau, lakini mtupa ganda hasahau.
explanation: One who ate the banana will forget, but the one to whom the skin is thrown will not forget. That person will not forget not only on account of the insult, but also for being sent away hungry. The difficulty with the translation is caused by the word mtupa, the thrower. The translation surmises the word mtupwa or mtupiwa: the one to whom something is thrown. A misprint? Cf. 1885.

One who becomes blind in old age does not lose the way. If you get trouble in your old age, there are many friends and relatives to help and you are supposed to have developed your own survivors's skill
The punter's pole does not sink. An old salt is not easily killed in his element

text: Mtoto akibebwa hutazama kisogo cha mamaye.
explanation: When a baby is carried on its mother's back, it looks at the nape of her neck. A child follows its mother's footsteps - MM. A child follows the instructions and character of its mother. Kisogo, kishogo, nape of the neck Cf. 3656.
If a child cries for a razor give it. One learns the hard way. Wembe, razor, also kisu. Knife is used. Mtoto, child or kijana, youth. Cf. 3711.
If a child wants a nut, don't withhold it. If a child wants to try something too big for it [e.g., breaking a nut with its teeth] allow it. The child will experience the limit of its own strength.
People know where they came from; they are ignorant about where they are going. Isi, old present negative form of jua. Siisi, I don't know
The one who wears the shoe knows where it pinches.
A fisherman knows where to look for cuttlefish (octopus). Cf. 1344.

text: Mwana mtamba kule hupita mzee wa kale.
explanation: The child that travels far excels the elder of old time [in experience]. Mtamba from kutamba, to strut proudly, walk in a swaggering, conceited way, leap, dance

text: Mwenda bure si mkaa 8ure, huenda akaokota.
explanation: One who travels without an aim is not like the one who sits without an aim, for the traveler usually picks up something. Activity is better than doing nothing. Cf. 4730.
Don't tell a¹nything to a person who goes to the coast, until he/she returns. Let that person experience first.

text: Mwenye kuumwa na nyoka akiona jani hustuka.
explanation: Someone who has been bitten by a snake is startled seeing a [moving] leaf. A very popular proverb. Instead of jani, leaf, also ung'ongo, palm-leaf, is used; ukuti, liana; kamba, a rope; kenge, lizard. The Kenya section of Leslau's African proverbs has the following: "A man who has once been tossed by a buffalo, when he sees a black ox, thinks it's another buffalo." Cf. 1857.
The person who has an axe does not lack firewood. With know-how or experience one always finds means of earning a living
A thief is caught by a fellow thief.
How to eat is not taught a child. It comes naturally. Mzungu, skill, instinct; teaching given during initiation of youth. Instead of mzungu also ujanja, the art, cunning, is used. Cf. 2979-80.

text: Neno la mbali ni usiku wa kiza.
explanation: A far-off matter is a night of darkness - T. A matter you postpone is like a dark night

text: Neno moja la mwenye hekima lapita kumi ya mpumbavu.
explanation: One word of a wise person surpasses ten of a fool.

text: Ng'ombe hajui thamani ya mkia wake mpaka umekatwa.
explanation: A cow does not know the value of its tail until it is cut off. Children often do not value their parents until it is too late.

text: Nilale usiku chumbani, nikajua tundu paani.
explanation: Let me sleep a night in the room and I shall know the hole in the roof. Experience is the best teacher. Cf. 1382, 1880.

text: Njia ya siku zote haina alama.
explanation: An everyday path has no signpost. Experience makes things easy

text: Nyani akishindwa kuukwea mti, una kilema.
explanation: If a monkey fails to climb a tree, the tree must have a defect.

text: Nyumba usiyolala ndani huijui ila yake.
explanation: You do not know the defect of a house you have not slept in.
You don't know whether the house you did not sleep in, leaks. Cf.1848.
When you are near the fire, warm yourself up thoroughly. If you get an opportunity profit from it.
Where there are problems, ingenuity increases.
Effortlessness of the hawk. The hawk takes its prey so easily.
To use the long handled hoe is a matter of experience. Shilanga, ngwamba:1. a long handled hoe; 2. hard labor.

The axe forgets, the tree does not forget. "This proverb usually refers to the relationship between older people and their children or pupils, whom they punish, forgetting later what they have done. But the young do not forget"
One who harmed has forgotten, but the one to whom harm was done has not yet forgotten.
It's your behind that knows a good chair. Cf. 1848 and see also the section Secrets.

text: Tamba uone, kama hukutamba huna uonacho.
explanation: Travel far to see; if you do not travel you see nothing. Cf. 1867.
The sweetness of sugar cane is known by the taster. Cf. 1383, 1848.

text: Tendo husahauliwa na mtenda, mtendwa hasahau.
explanation: An action may be forgotten by the doer, but not by the receiver. Cf. 1885.
If we hear we don't understand, if we learn we know. If you want to master a certain skill, e.g., ploughing, it is not enough to be told how to do it; you should learn ploughing by ploughing

text: Udhaifu wa wenye nguvu ni nguvu wa wadhaifu.
explanation: The weakness of the strong is the strength of the weak. If a person with a certain shortcoming discovers that a better placed colleague also has similar shortcomings, that person becomes encouraged and more self-confident and could do greater things
You think that is the one, but it is not. Barking up the wrong tree.
If you go [as fast] as the cheetah, you will not lack food. An able person will always find a way
Go and look for yourself, to be told is deceitful. Cf. #1887.

text: Ukisitaajabu ya mussa utaona ya firauni.
explanation: If you are amazed at Moses' deeds, you will be more amazed at Pharaoh's. Moses declared himself to be a prophet, but Pharaoh declared himself to be God

text: Afadhali ya musa kuliko ya farao.
explanation: It's better to fall in the hands of Moses than to fall in the hands of Pharaoh
Wonder not, earthlings, at the matters (God's works) in the world. A parody on it

text: ukistaajabu ya chawa huona ya kunguni.
explanation: If you wonder at a louse's, you will find a bug's
What goes into your eye is not visible to you
You will see the thing of the wood-cutter. You will experience [the fate] of the wood-cutter
When you have gained some experience in life, it [lifel is over.
Experience is the mother of knowledge.
Old shoes know the way. If one is used to an old tool, it works better than a new one

text: Wajitia sogoro kwa yote, jinyoe kisogo chako.
explanation: When they pretend to be experts of everything, you better shave the nape of your neck. Be alert.
There is no escape from fate. Death, sickness, good or bad fortune often come without warning.
Fate cannot be warded off. Haikingiki or haina kingi, has no shield.
Fate [death] has no prevention; if it comes, give thanks. Cf. 3432.
There is no prevention or sacrifice of avail against fate. Ajali, fate, death.
Fate is but a respite

The person who builds [a house], is not [necessarily] the one who sleeps in it. That person may die, fall ill or leave the house for other reasons. So if you do a good work or finish a fine project, you will not necessarily profit from it. Others may spoil your work out of jealousy.
So and So is in difficulties.
That person has got a run of ill-luck. Someone has got into the grip of unemployment, etc.
Someone has been caught by the changes of the world.
One who is not fortunate must not take any risks.
A lucky person does not trust to luck.
An unlucky person never becomes lucky or successful. But

text: Mwenye bahati hubahatisha, asiye bahati habahatishi.
explanation: One who is lucky takes a chance, one who is not doesn't.
Good fortune does not wait for good fortune. Cf. 1914-15, 1920-21, 1930, 1938.

text: Bahati humnadia wa mbele na kumfanya wa nyuma.
explanation: Fortune calls upon the first and harms the one who is behind. And the opposite

text: Bahati humwacha wa mbele na kumfuata wa nyuma.
explanation: Fortune leaves the foremost to fall on the hindmost.

text: 1914a. Bahati hwenda kwa wawi, wema wakalia ngowa.
explanation: Good luck goes to the wicked and the good cry with envy.

text: Bahati ina miujiza, lakini haina ahadi.
explanation: Good fortune has miracles, but no promise. Do not rely just on luck.

text: Bahati mbaya ikimwandama kiumbe kumbanduka ni shida.
explanation: If bad luck pursues a person, it is hard for that person to get rid of it. Andama, fuata, to follow. Banduka, acha, to leave.
Luck is effort. Work and effort are the roots of success. Chudi, chadi for jadi, diligence.

text: Bahati ya mjomba si ya mpwa.
explanation: The good fortune of the uncle is not [necessarily] that of niece or nephew. Cf. 3337.
A good thing does not last. Cf. 1921.
A good thing does not last, it has no duration. Said by the poet when his best friend departed
Your sins cannot be wiped away, you do not write [i.e., determine] your fate. "Be careful to act; once written down (in the doomsday records} no word can be erased"
It never rains, but it comes down in buckets, doesn't it?
Someone fortunate. One who has no bad forecast. As in Roman times, future events [success of a journey, etc.] are augured by the way birds fly. Nyuni, ndege, bird.

text: Hayo yote yataisha, hata wivu, ni filimu tu.
explanation: All will pass by, even envy; it's like a film. Cf. 1990.
It [food] is better to be raw than burned. A bird in the hand is better than ten in the bush
It is better to be obstinate than to be burned. Before accepting a new idea it is better to be obstinate, to argue the pros and cons, in order not to be burned.
What is the use of your arguments, it was written at the beginning of time. Huja, haja, need, want, request, appeal.
You do not know what will encounter you [is in store for you].
Glory [good luck] is for whom it is written [destined]. "If you are unlucky, God wants you to be so, resign yourself" - JKP. Nda, ni ya, is of.

text: Kaa akiinua gando mambo yamekatika (or yapisie kae).
explanation: During the time that the crab raises its claw, things have passed a long time ago. If a crab catches another creature with its claws, that's it. That creature cannot get free. If you know how, you can do a thing quickly and easily

text: Hadhari haifai: hayaondoi amri ya mungu.
explanation: Caution is useless: it does not annul the decree of God. Cf. 409.

text: Kama ilivyo kwa kuku ndivyo ilivyo kwa kanga.
explanation: What happens to the chicken will also happen to the guinea fowl. All creatures are subjected to the same destiny. Cf. 3510.

text: Kianzacho vema si lazima kumaliza vema.
explanation: What is well started does not necessarily end well.

text: Kidaka huanguka na nazi ikawa palepale.
explanation: The totally unripe coconut falls down while the ripe one stays tight. A young child can die and the old ones stay alive.
Every pleasure has some bitterness.
Every dog has its day. Of health and sickness, hunger and thirst.
Every piece of boneless meat has an ending. All joy has an end.
All people walk their own paths.
Every devil has a companion. An accident never comes alone

text: Kila siku ni udhia, mwanaadamu huchoka.
explanation: There is trouble every day, a person gets tired. Udhia, trouble, annoyance, harassment, vexation, pain, grief.

text: Kilichompata ngwena na kiboko ni chicho.
explanation: What caught the crocodile also overtook the hippopotamus. People in high places are not immune to what's common to all
A good thing will not stay in this world.
The creature's lot is parcelled. A person has a certain amount of joy and suffering. Fungu, portion, piece, share, lot.

text: Kulala (or kutwa) na kucha ni mwaka: hupita mambo mangapi?
explanation: The setting and rising [of the sun] is [like] a year; how many things go by?
A night is like a year. A lot can happen in one night. This expression is often used by many as a good night warning, to which is answered: Sote tulimo, We are all in it.

Meetings are ordained [by God]. When one meets a friend, and the occasion has turned to the profit or pleasure of the parties, on leave-taking one reminds the other that it was not by chance they met - T. [A Swahili way of saying au revoir. It is regarded as imprudent to refer to a definite meeting. It is considered wiser to leave it to God to write, i.e. prearrange the next meeting of two friends]

text: Kupata si kwa werevu, [na] kukosa si [kwa] ujinga.
explanation: Gain is not acquired by cleverness, nor is destitution the result of ignorance - JKP. Said of people who become rich or poor
A vessel running aground has no [need for a] captain.

text: Lango la baraka hufunguka mara moja.
explanation: The gate of blessings opens only once.
It is at mine today, and at yours tomorrow. Good or evil can go from one to another. Don't be jealous and don't mock. Cf. 681.

What is written cannot be rubbed out. Muslims believe that God records every deed or happening of every human being. That record is written when a person is born and with all things that will happen to that person
What is written [by God] is what is. It must come
What has been ordained to be, has no hindrance.[no stopping]. Lijaliwelo, lililojaliwa, lijaliwalo from jalia, to allow - KB.
Whatever it is, it be so. Let come what may

text: Lambiwalo liko liko na likiwa haliko, li njiani laja.
explanation: That of which it is said: "it is there, it is there!" Even if it is not there. It is on its way. It is coming
When it is to be, it will be.
What has been directed to be, is. Loziwelo from kuoa: to behold, to accord, to dispose
What has been written down will happen.
Two [corn] stalks never correspond [in heightl. If you reap a good harvest after this year's cultivation, next year you may fail

text: Mambo mawili ya maisha ni kupata au kukosa.
explanation: There are two things in life, obtaining and lacking.
Matters [of life] are like weeds, they disappear and come back. Life and death, good and bad luck, follow each other.
Waves never wait for anyone.
One who dwells [sleeps] in a nice place must expect to live in a bad one. Good fortune is followed by misfortune

text: Mkataa (or mkimbia) ole (or wele) wamngoja mbele.
explanation: One who refuses [runs away from] his/her fate, finds that it waits ahead.

The person for whom it was intended [by a human being] does not eat it, but the one for whom it is ordained does. God writes the final destination on the food. Death may come suddenly. Thank God for the food you eat.

text: Mngalegeza demani, chombo ki juu ya mwamba.
explanation: Although you slacken the sail, the vessel is on the reef. Shut the stable door when the steed is stolen. Cf. 175, 2402.

text: Mngamba mwakaza dama, kuna kiwingu joshini.
explanation: Although you tighten the sail, there is a squall to seaward. "You think you have all your business under control, but there is a storm brewing up. Never cease being alert" -JPK. You maintain that you will stand up to the rough sea to confront the danger, although you have no power over it. "On people who engage in a futile struggle against superior forces"

text: Mny ama asiye na bahati huzaa wakati wa mawindo.
explanation: The unlucky animal calves at the time of hunting. The unlucky person may feel happy while bad luck is closing in.
People get what has been destined for them; not that which they want. Cf. 1984.
Rain does not wait to be invited
It always rains on you - JK. Said of someone who is never lucky. Nii: an ideophone for pouring rain, soaking a person through. Associated with -nya, rain.

text: 1967a. Mvua ya mwaka kikaka hupanda shamba na taka.
explanation: New year's rains precipitate and raise the weeds on the fields. After Swahili new year (in March) the fields have to be planted at once

text: Mwaka wa kakakaka panda shamba na haraka.
explanation: When the rainy season approaches there is a flurry. Plant your fields in a hurry.

text: Mwaka ni majira, leo mvua kesho jua.
explanation: A year has seasons, today rain, tomorrow the sun shines. Life of a human being is full of changes. Don't think that the good or bad things you have now will not change
The lucky fellows, let them go to sleep
People praise a lucky person. Lucky people will be flattered without deserving it
Blessed person stay in the wilderness. Normally, the Swahili will not stay in the bush, especially not at night. A lucky someone can do whatever is wanted

text: 1970b. Mwenzo kipata bahati, silale mlango wazi.
explanation: When your friend has a stroke of luck do not go to sleep with your door open. Cf.822.
Let the case be and do what it will. Let be whatever may happen.

text: 1971a. Naswibu hwenda kwa wawi, wema wakalia ngoa.
explanation: Luck goes to the wicked, the good can only cry with envy.
Stars fall on the same plot. Luck follows the same people
Life's necessities follow the mouth. The explanation given is that your necessities for living, like food, are yours and nobody can taken them away from you. They are for your mouth only.
Life's necessities are in the hands of the people. Obtaining good things follow good behavior. Good people get it, bad people don't
One's providences [God's gifts] are like one's fate, [for] you do not recognise it when it comes. Good luck or bad luck cannot be foreseen
Necessities of life are given to a person for whom they have been destined. Cf. 1962.

text: Riziki ya mwanadamu imo maishani mwake.
explanation: The necessities of life are in a person's life. As long as God gives life so long will a person find food and necessities

text: Siku moja upate kilango cha jaha.
explanation: One day you may find the small door of Fortune. Kilango cha jaha: the gate of Paradise - J. Jaha, honor, glory, prosperity
You don't know the day of misfortune.
A beautiful face has no luck. Said of a beautiful wife with an ugly husband.
The physician cannot prevent death. A physician cannot prevent destiny.

text: Ukiona sahani moja katika salala, zamani ilikuwa ikitiliwa chakula.
explanation: If you see a plate on the rubbish heap [remember] formerly food was put on it. Have respect for old age
Destined for you by God!
What you desire you do not get [always]; you get what is ordained for you.
Do not bring bad luck to me. Ukuba, nuksi, laana, baa, bad luck, curse, disaster.

text: Usishindane na kari, kari ni mja wa mungu.
explanation: Do not argue with Kari, Kari comes from God. Do not argue with your fate. Kari from karimu/karama, a special gift of God, an honor
A sandfly can get through fire, [everything]. A sly person manages to enter everywhere. Probably the original proverb had mote[everywhere] instead of moto, fire. Cf. 1417.
Yours is what you ate. The rest can be taken away.
They drowned there where the punting pole could stand [in shallow water]. About any troubles from which, under ordinary circumstances, there would have been an easy escape

text: Hufa maji pondo-ima, na kondoka na kilema.
explanation: One that gives full play to one's passions and does not restrain the heart, will die by drowning in shallow water, and die with disgrace.

text: 1989a. Wole wako hukatai, wole wako huepuki.
explanation: You cannot refuse to accept your fate, you cannot avoid your destiny.

text: 1989b. Yapitayo hayabadiliki (or hayageukani), na yajayo hayaelimiki (or hayajulikani).
explanation: The past cannot be changed and the future cannot be known.
Everything ends, even jealousy.

text: Ila yote itaisha na roho mu kuungua.
explanation: All defects will pass by, even envy [heartburn]. Cf. 1925.
The one who is afraid should not go.
The one who opposes you is afraid of you.

text: Aliyetishwa na nyoka usiku akiona kamba hushtuka.
explanation: Someone frightened by a snake is startled at night seeing a rope.
Who dares to mock the roaring lion? People often laugh at or mock people in power in their absence, but not when they are present
Who will dance to a lion's roaring?

text: Saa simba anaanguruma hakuna mchezaji, wote huibunja.
explanation: There is no dancer when the lion roars, all hole up.
When the lion roars, all [animals] are quiet.

text: Chura hupenda maji lakini si maji moto.
explanation: A frog likes water but not hot water. Said if something gets too dangerous.
The monkey is happy when the dog is not there. The monkey likes to play joyfully on the ground, which it cannot do when an enemy is there.

text: Hakuna mzee atakayesema alikuwa mwoga utotoni.
explanation: There are no senior persons who will say that they were cowards as children.
The small kabunda-fish plays in a corner away from the others. A certain kind of person who is afraid to show up in public.
If the monkey laughs it knows that a stronghold is nearby. If weaker persons can laugh in the face of stronger people, it is because they know that help or easy escape is near.

The thing to fear is fear. "Let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself." President Franklin D. Roosevelt. First Inaugural address, 4 Mar.,1933 (Oxford Dictionary of Quotations).
Even a dead snake causes fear. One is never careful enough with dangerous matter
Too much fear creates slavery. A timid person is easily misused by others.
To be careful is not the same as to surrender"
No use troubling yourself, life has no price. "Time is too precious to be wasted in anxiety"

text: Kuku akila cha ungo anamdharau mpetaji.
explanation: The chicken that eats from the winnowing basket despises the winnower. One who seduces the wife of a neighbor despises his neighbor and exposes himself to revenge

text: Kunguru mwoga hukimbiza madoa yake uchafu
explanation: The timid crow avoids soiling its white collar. Don't interfere in matters that don't concern you. Cf. 2006.
The timid crow withdraws its wings from harm
The timid crab withdraws its claws. A prudent person is careful to avoid danger. Used to give courage to timid persons who do not trust their own ability. Cf. 257.

text: Kwa mwoga huenda kicheko [na] kwa shujaa huenda kilio.
explanation: With a coward goes laughter, with a hero goes wailing. The coward escapes the war and goes laughing, while the hero goes fighting and leaves wailing and suffering
Mourning goes to the brave.

text: Kwa mkali kwaenda kilio kwa mwoga kwaenda furaha.
explanation: Weeping goes to fierce persons, but rejoicing goes to the fearful.
One who dislikes peace is always crying. Cf. 2005, 2006.
What growls/roars does not devour but scares.
Fear the one you don't know until you come to know that person.
One who is afraid of the sea does not like traveling. Cf. 2014.

text: Mcheka bahari si msafiri, na mtaka shari simwepi.
explanation: One who laughs at the sea is not a traveler, and I do not avoid a person who means evil.
One who fears to go to sea is not a traveler. Cf. 2010.
A person who is afraid of doing the right thing, doesn't act correctly. A person in order to do lawfully must love the law and not fear it.
A person who has a thorn in the foot is not a good walker - Sacl. It is useless to count on a person who is impaired
One who carefully examines the sea is not a traveler. This is said of people who after much preparation suddenly abandon everything. Cf. 2011.

One who hides nakedness [vagina] will never have a child. Often used in reference to greed and stinginess, which are barren in social relations. If a woman hides her pregnancy, she might hurt her child; or, if somebody does not reveal hurts and bothers, that person can not be helped. Cf. 4625.

I'm like the dew, I'm not afraid of my brother-in-law. I conquer my fear of dew, that wets my clothes, I will also courageously encounter my brother-in-law, whom according to custom I must not meet. This is said to give oneself courage to face danger or a difficulty.

A peacemaker must not be afraid of a wound. A peacemaker is one who reconciles two quarrelling people. In doing this, that person may be beaten by one or both of the parties and sustain a wound. If a peacemaker is afraid of being so wounded, he/she should not attempt this task

text: Mtembezi mpe mwezi, mpe kiza mwizi.
explanation: Give the traveler bright moonlight, but give the thief darkness.
A person who walks at night is not afraid of dark areas. Kichaka: dense clumps of trees, the bush.
The one who was once burnt fears the fire.
Will the sailor flee from the waves?
Don't be afraid of the singing of the mwanguo [bird]. Mwanguo or kipwe, the Senegal bush shrike, a bird with many songs and believed that its singing near a house foretells a disaster.

text: 2020a. Mwasha moto hahofu taa ya kombe.
explanation: The stoker does not fear the oil-lamp. The person who lights the fires in the ovens and keeps them going is not afraid of the little flame in the dish-lamp
One with a scar, don't think that person healed. Instead of usidhani (don't think), usimtaraji (don't expect) is used by AL; KA; KS, kovu and simhasibu (don't expect) by
A person with a scar does not forget the wound. "The wound in the mind remains"

text: Mwenye kukimbia hawazi giza wala haoni jua.
explanation: One fleeing does not think of darkness or feel the sun. Cf. 238.

text: 2022a. Mwenye kuumwa na nyoka hamaliziki uboka (or woga).
explanation: The one who was bitten by a snake does not finish being afraid.
Cowards die while they have not yet died.
Fear a weakling more than a wizard.
Be more afraid of the weakling than of the strong one. Mnyonge, weak, humble, abject, low, debased person.

citations.page: KStume; AL 1619. The cow that is frightened will be slaughtered. Scrupulous judges condemn a defenseless person
The shy girl will be seduced

explanation: Being afraid is also a shield. Cf. 2006.
Where there are cowards the brave ones are also present.

text: Pasipo na cha kupoteza, hapana cha kuogopa.
explanation: When there is nothing to lose, there is nothing to fear. That makes a person free to do or to say what one likes.
A scar is easily wounded. A scar bleeds easily. A person who has been wounded spiritually or mentally will easily be wounded again if something reminds him of the experience that caused the wound

text: Shujaa hufa mara moja. Mwoga hufa mara elfu moja.
explanation: The brave dies once. The coward dies one thousand times.
Courage proves itself in difficulties. Cf. 1755.
I am not afraid of the thickness of the baobab. It has very soft wood.

text: Sitaacha kula mkate kwa kuogopa kiungulia.
explanation: I won't stop eating bread for fear of heartburn. Don't stop doing a good thing for fear of criticism or slander.
Courage is not the same as fighting someone stronger than you. Running away from a fight is not always a sign of fear.
If] you are a leopard, show your claws.
Storm calm down, I've a child at sea. A wish, a prayer.
Don't turn yourself into a wash table so that people want to do their laundry on you. Have a mind of your own; don't allow everything. Also used when hospitality is misused

text: Usiku wa kiza mangazimbwe: mtumbuu huwa papa.
explanation: On a very dark night, with very poor vision, a sprat becomes a shark. Mangazi-mbwe,dark night. Fig., inscrutable person. Cf. 1847, 1852.
The face of a fish does not react to the pickle. It remains unchanged by cooking.

text: Uume ni wa leo na kesho
explanation: Courage is of today and tomorrow.

text: Wakati wa hatari, kila mtu hulilia roho yake.
explanation: In time of danger, all will cry for their own life.
Children, children, they do not fear the fire.

The salvation of a coward is shouting. We should ask for help when we are facing obstacles too big for us. Zindiko, hifadhi, kinga, preserve, protect, save, shield. Kemi, kelele, ukelele, a shout. Cf. 283.
One who follows destruction is not bright. Upotevu, loss, impoverishment, wastefulness, immoral life.
It is a shame to fall twice over the same stump. It is a shame to make the same mistake twice.
Although some get their clothes caught, they go again. After a narrow escape
Wits are wealth. Brains are an asset
Understanding surpasses wealth. Also: Meditation is a source of wealth, i.e. the treasures of Paradise] -SPK.

text: Akisema mwendawazimu, msikiaji awe na akili.
explanation: When a mad person talks, the listener should have some wits.
One who cultivates on the beach does not harvest.
So and So went out stark naked in broad daylight, after the sun was up and the stars had disappeared

text: Mara akatoka mbio na kupotea porini kichele kuzimu hakuna nyota.
explanation: Suddenly he came running out and got lost in the bush stark naked in broad daylight. Used to express loss of senses.
So and So wrecked the ship for [the sake of] a pancake. Cf. 2091.
So and So has sent back dates to Arabia. Cf. 1393, 2061.
Do not associate with a brainless person. Meant as a warning against bad company.
I don't associate with a person who has no common sense.
A person who has no understanding is stupid like a cow - JKP. "A cow will eat first, then call her calf. That is considered stupid"
Someone who does not recognize reason is not told the reason. A person who cannot appreciate a rational explanation cannot expect to be given one
Don't tell the meaning to someone who does not understand the meaning.
One who does not know the meaning is not trusted. Cf. 2056.

One who is not afraid of a bull, is itself a cow [a dumb animal.] Be afraid of a brainless person. If you do not keep away from those people, you will become like one of them. A careless person is called ng'ombe (a cow) in Swahili. Cf. 657

text: Asiyeona kwa yeye na akionywa haoni.
explanation: If you do not see for yourself, you will not even see, if you are warned.

text: Asiyethamini chake ni mjinga wa vya wenziwe.
explanation: If you do not value your own goods, you are also ignorant about other people's belongings.

text: Ateteae mtuku ni tangauko la bure.
explanation: One who supports a worthless person has trouble for nothing. To reason with a good-for-nothing person is a loss of time

text: Ateteaye utupu ni sumbuko la bure
explanation: One who argues with a nobody gets involved in useless troubles. Tangauko for masumbuko, trouble, effort, bother. Mtuku, wa-, a vile despicable person. Vita dialect. Mtukutu, a restless, troublesome person
It's useless to cry when there is no one listening [lit., no ear].
The food that you throw away is desired by somebody else. Spoilage is unwise, foolish.
Do not bring salt to the sea. Do not make things worse by adding bitterness
A fool am I. Said if something is missing or gone wrong.
A metaphor mystifies a simpleton, but the intelligent person perceives it. The problems of this life are to test the intelligent

text: Hata mpumbavu huweza kumshauri mwenye hekima
explanation: Even a fool may sometimes give a wise person counsel. "The moral is that you should not despise anybody's ideas, for you may learn something, even from a person who is belittled"
One does not put fire in the wild area that is afire. A fool acts without discrimination
Prestige, prestige, the wells are dried up. People will ruin themselves to show their noblesse, lest others think them mean. Meanwhile the wells are not repaired"
Respect for a stupid person is stupidity. Cf. 1751.
So and So builds skyscrapers. Of somebody who does not make his dreams possible.

text: Hutia iye mpunga shinani la mlilana?
explanation: How can one plant rice at the foot of a mangrove? "Mangroves grow in salt water, rice in fresh water"

text: Ingawa ni usiku butu, mnofuni usithubutu.
explanation: Although the night is dull, don't trust the boneless steak. Mnofu, boneless meat. Butu, dull, not sharp. Cf. 2119.
When the fool becomes intelligent [in the eyes of society], then there is no more intelligence. "When a society no longer recognizes fools as fools, then no one is intelligent"
Know what is yours.

So and so changed into an octopus, heaping live coals upon itself. Said if somebody over-self-incriminates about something that person did. Don't be a fool, jumping into things. Chachandu, pweza, cuttlefish, octopus, a fish that jumps in the boat of a fisherman, when caught. Cf. 2134.
A basket without a bottom is never used to put food in it. This means that you should not leave your valuable article with a person who is grasping: you will lose it
Be an octopus and cover yourself with charcoal. Cf. 2073, 2134.
The head of a snake cannot be loaded with a pot. Cannot carry a heavy pot. A fool should not be put in charge of an important matter
Whoever rears a snake, will be bitten. It is useless and harmful to show kindness to a person of evil character - JKP.
Don't trust what is inside [what is hidden]. Cf. 2119.

A fool does not climb the lighthouse of the teacher. A fool does not attain the leadership of the teacher. Zuzu. a fool, inexperienced. Mnara, tower, lighthouse. Kinara, a small lighthouse, a candlestick.

text: Kiumbe mwanzo hajuti, majuto huja kinyume.
explanation: No mortal regrets early in life, regrets come in the end. Cf.2095.

text: Kosa ndilo lenye aibu, si adhabu yenye aibu.
explanation: Shame belongs to the crime, not to the punishment. A mistake is shameful not the punishment.

text: Kuchinja mbuzi kwa ajili ya kinofu.
explanation: To slaughter a goat for the sake of a chop. When a person takes great trouble for the sake of a small gain.

text: Kugombana na udongo, unakishtakia (or utakielezea) kisuguu.
explanation: You quarrel with the soil, are you going to take your complaint to [tell] the anthill?. About having a dispute with someone and then looking for support from a member of that family. Earth and anthill are close relatives; to dispute and tell the other ensures that the case makes the round in the family.

text: Kuku yenye kuwa kwao inadondoa paka ya pori.
explanation: A chicken at her own place invites the civet cat. When at home one feels secure and more audacious.
Doing foolish things is getting in difficulty. Nyange, kelele, making noise, ringing a bell; being foolish. Zidiwa, being in difficulty.
Firewood begets ashes. About doing something not useful.
To buy a cow by its hoof mark. Buy a pig in a poke. Cf. 2091, 2119.

text: Kutaka lisilokuwa, ni maana ya ujinga.
explanation: Wanting the impossible is caused by ignorance.
Ignorance puts a snake to sleep in the kitchen.
Selling a basket for palm leaves.

text: Hana wenyeji, mngwame, mwuza kapu kwa miaa.
explanation: Mngwame [King of Vumba] has no subjects, seller of matting bags for the palm leaf slips

text: Kuwashia taa pofu ni kuharibu mafuta
explanation: To light a lamp for a blind person is waste of lamp oil.
By giving light to a blind person you'll finish all the millet stalks in the field. Trying to explain something to a fool is waste of time. Cf. 2124, 2127.
Said of someone who claims to reconcile people by reviving hostilities. Mafuta wilaya or mafuta Ulaya, oil from Europe.
Silliness is not revenged. A mentally sick person is not punished. Mafuu, a person not responsible for his or her actions.
Regret never ends.

text: Majuto ni mjukuu, mwishowe huja kinyuma
explanation: Regrets are like a grandchild, they come a considerable time after the event.
Regret comes afterwards.
Remorse is like an illegitimate child. Questions of conscience come after the supposedly evil deed is accomplished.
Mistakes can be explained.

text: Mamba hutoka majini na kulamba umande
explanation: The crocodile comes out of the water to lick dew. This is said of somebody who leaves opulence for trifles.
A goat wants to escape from the kraal. A stupid girl wants to run out on the street, to the boys
The billy-goat is not milked.
A grasper at smoke. Building on sand. Cf. 3521-2.
You will know your share by the amount of leaves you receive. Majani, leaves, grass; in this context, shares.

text: Mikononi mwa mjinga shoka ni mshindo basi.
explanation: In the hands of an ignorant an axe makes only noise. "It cuts no wood"

text: Mjibu mjingwa sawa na ujinga wake.
explanation: One who answers a fool is a also a fool.
When a fool becomes enlightened, discovering that he/she has been cheated, the wise person must look for an abode
The ignorant praise their own ignorance. Fools do not recognize the degree of their ignorance
A fool has no self-knowledge. Fools do not know that they are fools.
Fools strangle their mothers who are in their graves.
Honor a fool and you see it in his walking. Struts about, looking down on others. Even people in power should take this into account. Cf. 2057, 2076, 3957.

text: Mke azaaye mchana haulizwi amezaa nini.
explanation: A woman who gave birth in daytime is not asked what she birthed. Asking for something obvious, feigning ignorance.
The tail does not direct the head. Ongoza, drive forward, lead, guide.
The chief did not have stones for a fireplace [a stove], but carried firewood. Even a person high up does foolish things.
Farmers do not plant coconut trees in rice fields.

text: Mlaji ni mla leo; mla jana kala nini?
explanation: The real eater is today's eater, what has the eater of yesterday eaten? You can't eat your pie and have it
The fool is talking, the scholar is quiet.
One who tries to shake a baobab tree only shakes oneself. A baobab is a very big tree and there is no person who can shake it. There are things that cannot be changed.
A person who says "I don't understand" is not stupid.
Praise a fool and put yourself in order. Or as someone said: "Prepare your way to heaven.
A person who is threshing on a rubbish heap leaves dizzy. Such a person does a useless job. Mtitigo, msukoshuko, dizziness. Twanga, crush, grind, thresh.

text: Mwasha taa mwezini hasidi wa mafutaye.
explanation: One who lights a lamp during full moon is the enemy of oil. Said if somebody is doing useless things. Cf. 2092.
A clever person will lack no wealth

text: 2115b. Mwenye akili tukufu ni kama kwambiwa neno.
explanation: The person of superior intelligence, it is as if that person has been told already. A word to the wise is enough

text: Mwerevu kanga, mwenye kuacha maji akaoga mchanga.
explanation: Woe to you, guinea fowl, that leaves the water and bathe in the sand. Instead of mwerevu, cunning also wele-wako, woe to you is used. Wele or wole or ole. Cf. 1961.
A foolish word and a fool go together.

text: Ni kama nguvu ya mayonda, zitakwishilia (or hufilia) nyangwani.
explanation: It is like the strength of apes, it spends itself on the fields. As long as the apes keep to the thick tropical growth of mangroves, which skirt these creeks and flats, they are not to be come at; but once out in the open, they fall easy prey to the leopard or to the hunter
Meat [bought] at night [in darkness] has no fat. Buy a pig in a poke. Cf. 2096.
Where there is ignorance, cleverness is ignorance. It is folly to be wise where ignorance is bliss.

text: Pweza ndiye ajikaangaye na mafuta yake.
explanation: It is the octopus that fries itself with its own fat. Said of a person who harms himself by his betrayal.
If one fish is rotten don't throw away the basket.

text: Si busara kukimbia mvua kwa kujitumbukiza mtoni.
explanation: It is not very clever to run away from the rain and jump in a river.
Do not light a lamp for a one-eyed person. Be careful to whom you give information or do kindness
Do not fight against time. Do not do the impossible.
Do not cut off a hand that [can offer you] nothing. Do not harm or blame a person who fails to help you
Do not light a lamp in a blind man's home. Used also about telling secrets. Cf. 2092.

text: Sizidi kilio matangani, sipeleke tende umangani
explanation: Do not add weeping at a funeral service; do not send dates to Arabia. Cf.2051.
The tokomile dance is not played in initiation rites. Every matter has its proper time; e.g., a death dance is not played at a marriage ceremony
Let's not push a car without wheels.
Ignorance is the poison of life. Stupidity poisons life. Ujinga, foolishness, ignorance, stupidity.

text: Ujinga wa kuuza si ubaradhuli wa kununua.
explanation: Being foolish in selling is better than being duped in buying. The meaning is that if you buy what you do not need you'll sell what you need. You can sell with one eye but you need two eyes to buy without being cheated.

text: Ukiwa mwerevu sana jiwekee ujinga kidogo
explanation: If you are very clever cover yourself with a little ignorance.

Have you changed into an octopus heaping live embers on yourself? A cuttle fish (octopus), when roasted on the fire, may spasmodically pull coals over its own body. The expression kujipalia makaa means: to put oneself into trouble by doing something unlawful or foolish.

text: Ni mimi pweza mwenye mikia minane?
explanation: Am I an octopus with eight tails? A busy mother might say that. Cf. 2073.

text: Upande wa pili wa mto wavutia.
explanation: The other side of the river is attractive.

text: Upumbavu wa mamba, anakimbia mvua katika mto.
explanation: How stupid of the crocodile, to escape the rain it jumps into the river. Cf. 2096.
Don't trust the weather.

text: Usigombe na mkwezi, nazi imeliwa na mwezi
explanation: Don't argue with the palm climber, the coconut has been eaten by the moon. Don't accuse the harvester, he did not spoil the nuts. Mkwezi, one who climbs in the coconut tree to pick the nuts. Kuliwa na mwezi (idiom) or imeharibika, it is spoiled, rotten.
You are a grown-up, now do not have illusions.
Do not endanger yourself going to forbidden dances. Hamnazo: carelessly.

text: mwenye kulichung a tanga, ajue kupima.
explanation: Don't appoint an ignorant person instead of an able captain, the one who observes the sail and knows how to estimate [the wind].
Don't make a laundryman's donkey out of me. Don't make a fool out of me. See "The story of the washerman's donkey." (Steere's Swahili Tales, p.l.

text: Usione giza kwako ukaamua kufuata mwangaza wa jirani.
explanation: Don't despise the darkness at your place, before deciding to follow the light of your neighbor. Don't follow another person's star.
Do not see a wildebeest instead of a mosquito.
Don't try to grow grass on the footpath. It won't grow.

text: Usipo na nywele, chanuo ni ya (or nda) nini?
explanation: If you have no hair, what use is a comb? "A woman without virtue, a man without merit should not be flattered"
It's the fools who get eaten. Used when a person feels tricked.
It's the fool who gets killed.
The goods of the fools are eaten, let's profit.
You run away from a simple burial and go to a place where your corpse is eaten. If you try to run away from ordinary difficulties, you'll find yourself in even greater problems.
You are repairing the house of your companion, while your own house is falling in ruin. Timid people easily go full out to serve other people, forgetting their own needs
You are watering wild trees [in a forest] while your coconut trees are dying of drought.
Madness has forty phases [endings, variations]. Cf. 3136.
It's better to die than to live in slavery. Kama or kuliko, more, over, better (comparative).
Whether that person comes or not, it is all the same to me. Fauwa, also fahuwa (Arabic) or sawa sawa, it is all the same.
The person who feeds you beats your mother while you are looking. Of a person totally in the power of somebody else.
An open pool is not freedom. Freedom without limits is like a free pool; freedom must have limits and order to maintain peace
A prison is not walls. "A prison is not necessarily a place with visible walls. A person may live without being free even if he is not in a physical prison"
Choice is better than compulsion. Hiari or hiyari, freedom, free choice, liking. Cf. 2160.
The guinea fowl does not breed or lay eggs in strange surroundings or captivity. "The guinea fowl is the symbol of a noble woman"
The parrot does not breed in captivity

text: Kila mtu ana hiari katika yake dari.
explanation: People are free [to do as they wish] in their own house. Dari, ceiling, roof.
Chicken do not scratch about in a strange environment. Cf. 2157.

A servant of God has no choice. Implied is that what God has destined for you is what you get. It is said whenever something good or bad happens to someone. The use of this proverb is two-fold: a person often has no choice when his/her conscience is clear about a way of action, and whatever plans one makes for the future, one cannot foresee superior forces. Mja and abdi are often translated as servant of God. Cf. 2157.
One who does not like his home is a slave. Another translation: One who is not accepted at home is like a slave. Where can that person go?

text: Mkate mkavu wa nyumbani ni bora kuliko nyama ya shuwa ya pengine.
explanation: Dry bread in one's home is better than good meat somewhere else.

text: Mtu akifika chengo cha mtu, humtegemea.
explanation: If a person goes to another's place, that person becomes dependent. Chengo, house, a dwelling place, a village, a camp

text: Mtu huzaliwa huru, lakini siku zote ni mfungwa.
explanation: A person is born free, but is tied up all days.
A thorn with which you prick yourself [on your own accord] does not hurt. Self-imposed tasks are cheerfully borne. Ndunga or toboa: pierce

citations.page: Understood: there is no pity for the people who stab themselves on purpose. "An aggressive character who gets into trouble will reap no sympathy"

Nobody feels sorry for you if you put yourself in a bad and dangerous situation. E.g., a young person who rebels against his/her parents has no peace. A girl who gets herself into trouble is not pitied

explanation: The load you bind for yourself is not heavy. A profitable job is easy to put up with.
Support those who love freedom, they will be free.
When freedom leaves slavery rules.
If freedom increases the country will be destroyed. Freedom must be tempered, regulated.
Enemy or friend has no mark [of identification]. They look alike.

text: Adui ukimtahadhari mara moja, rafiki umtahadhari mara elfu moja.
explanation: If you are careful with your enemy once, be careful with your friend a thousand times.
The enemy of darkness is a lamp [light].
The person who helps you in need is a friend.
Whoever turns the back on you is not your friend. Instead of kisogo nyongo is used also.
Don't despise the one who loves you, forget the one who turns you down. "Advise to young lovers"
Stay with the one who loves you.

text: Akusaidiaye shidani, ndiye kweli ni wako mwandani.
explanation: The person who helps you in need is truly your friend. Cf. 2173.

citations.page: Pay [back] the one who mistreats you

explanation: Tenda has a simple meaning of to do, but most often it has the meaning of to do something evil to somebody.

text: 2178a. Ambaye hashikamani nawe, si wako mwandani.
explanation: The one who does not stick with you is not your friend.
The one who loves you is not your slave. Friendship must not take away one's freedom
A person who gets [wealth] is not your friend [any longer]. "When you were both poor, you were friends together. Money put the other person in a higher class"
The person who is loved has no faults. "Love is blind"
One without friends has no enemies.
One who does not understand friendship is not a friend.

text: Asiyefawa na wake hufawa na mwenziwe.
explanation: Those who are not helped by their own people are usually helped by the people of their friends. Asiyefawa or asiyesaidiwa.
Someone who is not in sight, is not in the heart.
Nearby is beloved, before the eyes, in the heart. Cf. 2211.
The person who is not in sight, finds also that his portion is not there. Said if someone does not appear in time. See also the sections Alertness and Hurry.
Change your life style, but do not change friends. Starehe, comfort, peace, calm. Used also when entering a room and people are standing up, you say, starehe, please don't get up.
Never mind, let us live as hitherto. Forget the evils of the past [even our own] and live in friendship. This is said by friends who have offended each other

text: Bora kuwa mwiba kwa upande wa rafiki yako kuliko sauti yake ya mwangwi.
explanation: It is better to be the thorn in the side of your friend than to be your friend's echo. A real friend should warn a friend in case of wrongdoing.

text: Bora siku ya kuunga urafiki kuliko ile ya mlimo.
explanation: A day devoted to friendship is more precious than one given to work. Cf. 2206.

text: Cha bei yafaa wawili; wa tatu ni mlozi.
explanation: Two people are enough for something valuable; a third one would cast a spell. In business, friendship, and love it's better to limit oneself for fear of becoming superficial. A third might bring confusion.
A friendship of two is better than one of three. Cf. 2214, 2253.
If you see bad activity of your friend respect it. Don't talk about it, stay away.

text: Chakula kilicho mbali usipokipata, unaweza kupata kwa wengine
explanation: Food that is beyond your reach, you can get from others. Friends sharing and helping.

text: Cheko la rafiki lina bei ghali
explanation: The smile of a friend costs dearly. To keep up friendship by means of gifts.
Short reckonings make long friendship.

text: Chui umkutapo kwako, umfanye rafiki yako.
explanation: If you find a leopard in your house, make it your friend.

text: Hapana kisichochukiza katika msiba wa rafiki.
explanation: There is nothing that annoys in the misfortune of a friend. A friend's misfortune does not cause dislike.

text: Heri adui mwerevu kama rafiki (or mwenzi) mpumbavu.
Heri adui mwerevu kuliko adui mjinga.
explanation: It is better to have a clever enemy than a stupid one. An interesting variation. A person might guess what a clever enemy might do, but a fool does not follow logic.

text: Adui shujaa ni bora zaidi kuliko rafiki mwoga.
explanation: A courageous foe is better than a cowardly friend. Cf. 2198.

text: Heri kuliwa na simba kama kuliwa na fisi.
explanation: Better be eaten by a lion than by a hyena. Here simba, a lion stands for an enemy; fisi, hyena stands for a treacherous friend. Cf. 2197.
Plant the roots of generosity. "If you want friends be one"
The wound of your friend is a solemn oath. It concerns you by solemn agreement. Whatever hurts your friend hurts you.
If people [in a certain place] like you, stay [with them]. "The best place to settle is where you have friends"

text: Kisiki hafi mjane ndege asipotua kwake.
explanation: A tree stump does not die deserted without a bird perching on it. Nobody dies without love; everyone knows love, even if only for a fleeting moment in one's life. A prostitute or a Don Juan finds a mate

text: Kuanzisha urafiki si kazi, ngwamba ni kuupalia.
explanation: Striking a friemdship is not difficult, the challence is to maintain it. Ngwamba, hard work
Separation needs not to destroy friendly relationships.

text: Kuku akiacha wana yuna mai matumboni.
explanation: If a hen leaves her chicks she has eggs inside her. If a friend leaves you, it is because your friend has found other attractions. A mother who is not involved with her family has lovers

text: Kulima ni raki, njia ni rafiki.
explanation: Cultivating means slaves, counsel means friends

text: Kulima ni raki, njia ni rafiki.
Kulima kwa mtu pweke ni kujihiliki

explanation: Cultivating is slaves, way is a friend. Cultivating to a person who is alone is killing the burnbakes and weeds are not to be got together
To fit together like ...
Like ring and finger.
Like finger and ring.
Like the tongue and the saliva.
Like the bow and the bowstring.
Like the whetstone and razor.

text: Kama kupe na mkia wa ng'ombe.
explanation: Like a tick and a cow's tail.
Like a dish and its cover.
Like a bed getting a mat. i.e., To make a bed complete; the finishing touch. Cf. 2246.
Having doubts towards each other kills the friendship.

text: Kupendana kama pete na kidole, huachana kwa usiku.
explanation: Loving each other as ring and finger, separating for sleeping. Cf. 2246.

text: La kale jeraha, huwa ndugu saha.
explanation: An old sore/wound becomes a true friend. "Some old people like complaining about their ills and ailments, but also they like to boast about old wars and heroic deeds"
What is not in the heart is not in the eyes [eyesight]. You don't care for those you do not love. Cf. 2185.
Water and sugar. This is said of two people that are inseparable. Cf. 2207.

text: Maji na tumbawe: mama na mwanawe.
explanation: Water and the coral rock [are together like] mother and child. Cf. 2207.

text: Marafiki kumi, miti kumi yenye kuoza.
explanation: Ten friends are like ten rotten trees. It's better not to squander your friendship. Cf. 2191, 2253.
Great friends must leave each other.
The load of your friend don't throw it from your hand. Don't deny help. Mfuko, bag, bundle. Tupa mkono, throw away, cast off, abandon.

text: Mfupa wa mbuzi wa mwenzio ni mtamu.
explanation: The bone of your friend's goat is tasty. Even a little gift of your friend is sweet.
Mountains do not meet, but people meet. Used to soften a departure. This can be said for "It's a small world," but more often "Do not forget to visit your old friends", which is a must
Two bodies, perfect happiness. Verses of a wedding song

text: Moyo wa mwenzio ni msitu wa giza.
explanation: The heart of your friend is a dark forest. It is impossible to fully understand even a friend.
The one who turns his back on you is not your friend.
One who turns his face away and looks somewhere else is not a friend.

text: 2221a. Msi nacho si mwendiwe, mwenye nacho ende nawe.
explanation: The one who has nothing is not your friend. Let the one who has something go with you.

text: Msitu ni mpya na komba ni wapya.
explanation: The forest is new and so are the lemurs. If one comes back to an old familiar place, everything is changed, both place and people. New lords, new laws. Komba, the galago, a small racoon-like animal, lemur.

text: 2222a. Mtu asiye na sadiki yu kama yamini bila shamali.
explanation: A person without a true friend is like a right hand without a left hand.

text: Mtu asiyekuwa na mke, sahibu yakwe huwa shemejiye.
explanation: An unmarried person's friend is like a brother-in-law. "The strength of Oriental friendship is proverbial. Its affection equals or surpasses that arising from natural ties, which, on the other hand, are apt to hang very loosely"

text: Mtu na rafikiye ni kama kombe, haziachi kuchakacha.
explanation: People and their friends are like shells always clattering. About friends disagreeing. Chakacha, rustle, as of grass when one goes through the forest
A noble person is a servant.
A noble person is a measure. A noble person is moderate, modest, composed, thus setting an example

text: Mungwana ni kamba, hufa na uao.
explanation: A noble person is [like] a rope, and dies with the raft. A good rope does not snap, it survives the raft it was made to serve - JK. A noble person has a high sense of responsibility
If you desert your friend in a battle you will regret it later.
A comic does not offend people. Mzaha, fun, joke, ridicule, derision. Fanya mzaha, do in fun.
Your friend who admonishes you, loves you.

text: Mwili wa mwenzio ni mkondo wa mwili wako.
explanation: The passage made by the corpse of your friend is the one you'll pass too. A good friend does not desert a friend in difficulties. Mkondo, riverbed, gulfstream, passage. Cf. #731.

text: Mzigo wa mwenzio ni kanda la usufi.
explanation: The burden of your companion is [only] a load of kapok [to you]. We make light of other people's burdens.

text: Neno la mwenzako, unipe kiti nikae; neno lako unasimama hata wima.
explanation: Regarding your companion [you say] give me a chair; but regarding your own affairs you are standing straight. The meaning is that misfortune of others is minimized.

text: Neno la mwenzako, unipe kiti nikae; neno lako, unakaa hata chini.
explanation: For the case of your friend [you say], give me a chair to sit down; but for your own case you even sit on the ground. Misfortune of another is nothing, but your own is like a burial.
Do me a favor during a rainy season and I shall do the same to you during the dry season. A promise of mutual help in times of difficulty.

text: Uniponye wa jua, nitakuponya wa mvua.
explanation: Save me from the sun and I'll save you from the rain.
On the road is where you meet friends.

text: Nyumba, ijapo ndogo, mpenzi hakosi nafasi
explanation: Even if the house is small a friend finds a place.

text: Panzi mwana mwaka-moyo, hifa kwa wewe vina nini?
explanation: If I, the impetuous grasshopper, die for you so what? Do not waste your time and energy when not appreciated

text: Penye mbaya wako na mwema wako hakosi.
explanation: Where you find one who does you evil, there also is one who does you good.
A friend criticising you is better than an enemy who praises you.

text: Rafiki huwa adui na adui huwa rafIKI.
explanation: A friend may become an enemy and an enemy may become a friend.
Measure friends by their deeds.
A good friend is better than a bad relative. But in great need a bad relative may help you. Cf. 3625.

text: Rafiki wako wa kudumu na wa msimu.
explanation: There are permanent friends and seasonal ones.

text: Rafiki wanakufahamu unapofanikiwa na unawafahamu unapoanguka.
explanation: Friends know you when you are prosperous and you know them when you are in adversity.
Your friend is your enemy. Friends know so much about you that they can harm you deeply. Cf. 1668.

text: Rahisi kumpoteza rafiki kuliko kumpata tena.
explanation: It is easier to lose a friend than to find him/her again.

text: Salamu nyingi, mchanga wa pwani ni haba.
explanation: Many compliments, the sand on the sea-shore is too little. Not a proverb, but a polite phrase of greeting in a letter.
Many greetings as there is sand.
Hold together like the finger and the ring. Cf. 2207.
Do not desert your friend when your friend is in trouble. Simkimbie, usi-m-kimbie, do not run away from a person.

text: Tulingane sawasawa, kama sahani na kawa.
explanation: Let's be to each other as a dish and its cover. Let's live harmoniously together like the coffee, which takes the shape of the cup. Used in wedding songs
We die, like the cordage with the hull
The pain of your companion cannot harm you. It is not your pain. Cf. 2229.
The pain of your friend is yours.
Special friendship brings disaster, generosity prospers. Halili.a beloved person. Filisi, make bankrupt, ruin.
You obtain a new thing and reject the old one. New things are always nice. Cf. 2569, 3439.

Friendship during hardship is avoided by many. When a friend is in trouble many ignore the demands of friendship. As the joker said: "A friend in need is a good person to avoid. Hepa from epa, avoid, get out of the way.

text: Urafiki wa wawili unapita wa watatu.
explanation: Friendship of two [people] is better than that of three. Cf. 2191, 2214.

citations.page: 3. Don't leave your old mat for a [better] prayer mat which you see, in passing. Do not desert your old

explanation: friend for a new one who may not be permanent
The living will surely meet again. Even after long separation, the chances are that they will meet again. Said when people leave each other or are away for a long time. Cf. 2218.

text: Walio mbali kwa mbali huonana kwa nyaraka.
explanation: People who are far apart are wont to meet by letters. A favorite phrase in letters. Cf. 2258-9.
Two friends, let their purpose be one. Wandani, wa ndani, intimate friends, of the inner side. Bosom friends.
A letter never finishes words. There is always more to say and a letter is not a good enough apology.
A letter [a written message] is half a visit. It bridges the pain of separation. If you cannot go and see your friend, at least you can write a letter

text: 2259a. Wengi huwa kama paka urafiki wa mradi.
explanation: Many people are like a cat, friendship for a purpose. About people who become friends in order to profit.
Do not laugh at your friends, be loyal to the one who is loyal to you.
That person is an eye brother. A friend or relative not available when needed, or who is not doing nice things behind your back.
Presents strengthen friendship.
Presents are fertilizers for friendship. Presents strengthen friendship
Let go of a kernel, so that you may have the edible part. Give something so that you may get something bigger in return. Koma, the edible fruit of the dwarf palm.
The person who gave you a bone thought about you. A small gift, a kind thought.
The one who gave you a bone is your friend.
The person who thought about you is your relative.

text: Aliyejaliwa kajaliwa, ukimwombe akose, mungu anampa.
explanation: Even if you pray for a person that person may not get it. God gives to a person. The one who is destined will be favored. It is useless to pray for gifts. God has all destined.

text: Aliyemnyima mwenzake nyama ya senji, mbuluku akamnyima nyama ya mbogo.
explanation: To the person who denied a companion meat of the large rodent, the little antelope has refused the meat of the buffalo. Help denied will turn against you.
The rooster has discarded clothes, [but] his wife did not get any. Of people spending their property on others, but not on their family. Cf. 2269.

text: Ametoa sadaka na wanawe wafa njaa.
explanation: That person has given to charity while the children are starving. Of people who neglect their own while spending money on others.

The one who is being served does not know when the food is finished. The cook served the food from the kitchen and those at the dinner table don't know how much food is left for those served afterwards or for a second helping. Pakulia, to serve food.
The person to whom is given will be given more. For someone to whom things have been given, it is possible to increase his/her possessions. A poor person has no means to produce anything
A free thing is expensive. Nothing is free: people often give free things only to bind others to them. Beware. Cf. 2275, 4647.
For nothing does not restrain. People do not usually refuse free things
For free hurts. It enslaves, ties, taking away freedom. Cf. 1594, 2275, 2279.
A gift is not refused.
