A gift has no encore. It is not supplemented. Therefore don't put your future on expectation. One who expects too much will be disappointed. Nyongezi or nyongezo, increment.
A given thing is of little value. It is not something obtained after a great effort.
A gift is sweet. People like free things. Cf. 2275.
You take my things, but you do not give me yours. Lit., yours is poison for me
Generosity generates slavery. Said of someone who is becoming dependent by receiving gifts. Fadhila or fadhili, generosity.

text: Jumbe (or yumbe) asiye na uji haamkiwi.
explanation: The headman who has no porridge is not greeted. Nobody will come to pay respects in the morning. Election candidates must offer meals
Everyone should contribute when a collection is made. People should work together.
Not everything acquired is earned.
What is thrown away is the property of the rubbish heap. Jalala or jaa, rubbish heap.

text: Kitu ni futa la moyo, humpa umpendae.
explanation: A [tangible] thing is the oil of the heart; you give to whom you love
You do not look at a sheep that someone has give you. "Never look a gift horse in the mouth.

text: Kumpa mwenzio si kutupa, ni akiba ya mbeleni.
explanation: Giving to your friend is not throwing away, it is a reserve for the future."Said by a generous person to his critical wife"

text: Kumpa aliyekupa sio kupa, ni kulipa; kumpa asiyekupa sio kupa, ni kutupa.
explanation: Giving to one who has given you something, is not giving but paying; Giving to one who does not give you something is not giving, it is throwing away.
Throw it ahead and collect afterwards. A service given prepares for the future.

text: Kumpa mja si kazi apendapo ramahani.
explanation: Giving to a servant [of God] is no trouble since God wishes it.
Giving is not trading.
When a gift comes your way, just enjoy and get it. Lekea from elekea, point to, be directed towards.
It's not every day you obtain [something].
Giving is setting a trap.

text: Kutoa (or kupa) ni moyo usambe ni utajiri.
explanation: Giving is a matter of the heart, don't say it is a matter of wealth. It is wrong to regard a good deed as motivated by a bad purpose
Taking is not [the same as] bringing. Taking is not giving
Inherited wealth has no blessing. Easy come, easy go.

text: Maskini ana huruma kwa mtaka msaada [kuliko tajiri].
explanation: A poor person has mercy on one who needs help [more than a rich person]. Cf. 2291.
That person's hands are like a spoon. A man with hands like a spoon is one who does not hide what he has, that is one who is generous
An empty hand is not licked. The Swahili eat with their hands. After eating and before washing their hands, they lick their fingers as a sign of respect for food

text: Mkono ulikupa maji, ule ule utarudisha kopo.
explanation: The hand [that] gave you water, that same hand returns the cup.
The hand that gives is the one that will receive. Cf. 2296.

text: Mla ng'ombe na watwana, mlifi ni mwungwana.
explanation: The one who eats beef with ill-bred men [should know that] it is the gentleman who pays.

text: Mla ng'ombe ameshiba sana, mlifi ni muungwana.
explanation: The eater of beef is well sated, the one who pays is the gentle person Cf. 4430.
A giver and a receiver, who is [more] burdened?

text: Mshenzi mpe mpya nguo asahau kwao.
explanation: Give the strangers new clothes so that they may forget their homeland
A mosque which has no water is not prayed in. Understood is that a mosque must have water fountains, or a well or a large tub, for ablutions before prayer.
A trap without bait catches nothing; not even a worm.
Without bait you catch no fish.

text: Mtu akimpa maskini kichache, mungu humruzuku kingi.
explanation: When a person gives [even] a little to the poor, God will give that person ample blessings.
A person does not choose gifts. This is also said by a needy person, who hopes to be given help.

text: Mtu kiomba sadaka, umpe aloyataka, nakupe mungu jazaka.
explanation: When a person asks you for something, give it to that person, and may God give you your reward. Jazaka for jaza, a reward.
May God give you yours. "Said when someone admires a friend's new garment or other acquisition"
If a noble person is done a favor, he/she returns a favor.
When your friend needs what you have, give it.

text: Mwenye kilio hulia, nami nikawa msaadae.
explanation: Someone cries and I become a help. There may be two explanations: Someone shouts for something needed and I just happen to have the very same thing; or in the sense of: Do not look a gift horse in the mouth
The one who gives will be tired. One day even a generous person will say no to a beggar, or even the government.
If your neighbor invites you to a chicken dinner the [chicken's] legs will point to you. If you take gifts you bind yourself.

text: Mzigo wa chungu ni chembe moja [ya mchele].
explanation: The load of an ant is one grain [of rice]. This might be said by an inferior, who has been given a present by a superior, for the smallness of which the latter apologized

Someone used to auctions will not necessarily be a good shopkeeper. Every procedure asks for a special know-how. Udalali, the business of auctioneer. The word dalali, in some Bantu languages (e.g., Sukuma) has the meaning of free [bure]. In this sense the proverb could be understood as : Someone who is used to getting things free cannot manage a shop.
When the elephant travels, it is the hot season

text: Ng'ombe atoaye maziwa ndiye kipenzi cha mfugaji
explanation: The cow that gives milk is the sweetheart of the breeder.
Money and presents remove wrong (or enmity).
I do not set free, while I am in debt. Be just before you are generous

text: Ukarimu wa maskini hupotea kwa roho.
explanation: Generosity of the poor is a failure of the soul. The poor's desire of being generous cannot be fulfilled.

text: Ukimpa mwenzio zawadi, furaha uijaze fuadi.
explanation: When you give your friend a gift, let joy fill your heart. "Do not fret about it"

text: Ukimpa popo, mpe na wenye huzuni.
explanation: If you give to the bat [the announcer of grief], give also to the ones who are grieving.

If you see poor people, or those struck by disaster, help them, do not hold back. Hini or nyima, deny, refuse. Muawini, or mwawini (from auni), assist, aid help. Musibani, msibani (from sibu), also, shidani, calamity, disaster, misfortune.
If you got it free [for nothing], give it free.

text: Ukipata mali nyingi, usisahau ndugu yako.
explanation: If you become rich, don't forget your sibling.
What you ate is what you bought. Things freely given to you have to be paid for. Free gifts are often given to bind the benefactor to the donor. Jihadhari na vya bure, beware of free things.

text: Upatu wa maridadi wakusanya kila pembe.
explanation: An ornate collection plate gathers from every corner. Upatu, a plate on which gifts are placed. Kusanya, collect, gather, bring together, amass.
Don't give [presents] to anyone as long as you owe something.
The face of one who receives favors is cast down.

text: 2326a. Watambuao fadhali ni mmoja kwa alifu (or elfu).
explanation: Those who recognise a favor: one in a thousand.

text: Wengine hutoa na kusamehe, wengine hupokea na kusahau.
explanation: Some give and forgive, others get and forget.
Never', only God knows that.
Cross the river first, then praise God. It is not good praising a ford till a person is over.

text: 2328b. Adui akutayarishia shimo la upotevu, mungu akikuonya njia ya uwokovu.
explanation: Your enemy plots your downfall, while God shows you the road of salvation.

text: Afanyaye tambiko, hutabika kwa mzimu wake
explanation: One who brings a sacrifice usually offers it to his/her own ancestor. Mzimu, spirit of an ancestor.
The one who knows is God. God knows the unspoken secret
A person saved by God is not crooked. The upright person [saved by God] cannot be made crooked by anybody else

text: Allahu jirani yetu kama ndugu mli kule.
explanation: God is our neighbor when our brother is absent

text: Amevua shingo yake mbele ya mungu na moto wa kesho siku ya kiyama
explanation: Before God someone has saved his/her neck from tomorrow's fire on the day of the resurrection. Said of somebody giving freedom to a slave.
A command is with God. The na in ina stresses association rather than possession

Put the person who revolts against the loving Creator back on the right path. A person who revolts stands in the need of prayer. It is a dangerous business to revolt against authority. Azizi, the strong one by excellence.
That which God the Judge has written for a person, that will happen to the slave (i.e. the mortal).
Someone who accuses God is in for the final judgment. A person who accuses God as the cause of his/her sufferings, is angry and dangerous. Beware, because that person is capable of doing anything
God gives me [a load to carry] to the extent of my strength.
What He (God) wishes is destiny. Anything God decides becomes our inescapable fate.
What He (God) wills, will happen.
One who cannot create us cannot uncreate [deface] us.
The Creator is the [onlyl defacer. A human being cannot create or undo creation.
The creator destroys also. "Nothing is eternal"
The one who spread them [the clouds], also takes them away.
The blessing of God makes a person better or rich. Tononesha: getting better, richer, more at ease
The conscience is a compass. It assists a person to know which way one is heading in spiritual life
A clear conscience is a soft mat [or pillow]

text: Fimbo ya mnyonge hulipwa na mungu.
explanation: God will pay for the oppression suffered by the poor person. The evil person will be punished. Fimbo, a stick.
God provides a stick for the poor. God supports the poor and will punish those who harm the poor. Mlifi = mlipaji, the one who pays. Cf. 3153, 3757.
God's stick is noiseless.

text: 2345a. Fundi wa mahaba ni yupi nambia

explanation: The teacher of love, tell me where is he The teacher of love, his heart is impassioned. A good teacher ought to be involved (engaged) in his subjects. This refers to the religious teacher, who teaches the love of God, and so his heart will be full of just that passion.
No human being can wipe out a matter that has been 'written' over a person. Our fate (ole, makutubu) was written down in Heaven before our lives began

text: Hako mwenye kuharibu, ila yeye alwahabu
explanation: There is no one who can destroy except God the Giver. Hako or hayuko, there is no one.
Unlawfulness is destructive. One who is unlawful [of Islamic law] is a spoiler. Cf. 4172.
Virtue comes from faith.
Good is what God wills, what God wishes is best.
You cannot force a person to believe.
He sees, but cannot be seen; He speaks but cannot be heard, God.

text: Jema, jiwi lakwelea: siwe pweke usosali.
explanation: The matter, whether right or wrong, is clear to you: you are not the only person that does not perform one's devotions - T. Said to one who tries to be excused from the obligations of religion. It is not knowledge, but will, that makes a person religious
Help yourself and God may help you. Don't wait for help. Start doing.
God's pen does not make any mistakes.
His [God's] word comes true, because it is what He has destined.

text: 2352b. Kalamu ya mungu haipingiki, maandiko yake hayafutiki.
explanation: God's pen cannot be stopped; His writ cannot be wiped away.

text: Karamu ya miraji ni sumu, na kitoweo chake ni ngumu.
explanation: The feast of Miraji [ascension of the prophet Mohammed] is poison and its relish is hard. A feast on a fast-day is poison, and its relish is strangled meat
Everything [God] does is good, for it is [God] who chooses. Hitari or hiari, choose.

text: Kila dini ni ya kweli, sawa na nyingine.
explanation: Every religion is true and equal to the other.
Every evildoer (or fool) is safe [in the hand of God]. Jahili, merciless, cruel; foolish, ignorant.

text: 2356a. Kila kitu hupotea illa uso wake.
explanation: Every thing will perish except God's face.

text: Kila lahaula hufuatwa na adhabu ya mungu
explanation: Every blasphemy is followed by God's punishment. Lahaula (Arabic), an abbreviation of there is no power nor strength but in God"

text: Kila mtu lazima asaliwe, hata mudhinibu
explanation: Every person must be prayed for, even a sinner

text: Kila mtu lazima asaliwe hata ikiwa afanye madhambi makubwa.
explanation: Every person must be prayed for as long as he/she commits only minor sins. Do not interfere with a person's life as long as he commits only minor sins"

text: Kila mtu ni kwa ajili yake mwenyewe, lakini mungu ni kwa sisi sote.
explanation: Everyone for oneself, but God is for all of us.
God creates every morning.
Protection comes from God.
A mortal person speaks not so that it comes to pass, only God, the Beneficient. Manani or Al-Mannan, The Beneficent; one of the 99 names of God.
What spoils blood is meat.

text: Kiwekwacho na mungu, mwan'adamu hawezi kukiondoa.
explanation: What God has established, a human cannot take away. One does not contradict authority
What God has written cannot be wiped out.

text: 2364a. Kucha mungu ni kwepuka wovu na kiburi na tabia mbovu.
explanation: Fearing God is avoiding evil and pride and wicked character.
Paying respect to God is not the same as the wearing of a white turban. It is the action that makes a person pious, not the dress.
Fearing God is not a game
Sweeping at night chases away the blessing. Sweeping at night is considered bad. People only sweep at night in an emergency, e.g., death, to be ready for early morning visitors, i.e., a funeral

text: Kufumba macho na kusujudu sio kusali, kusali kumo moyoni
explanation: Closing the eyes and prostrating is not praying, praying is in the heart.

Not following the taboos is to harm a child. This is said when parents disregard the taboos prescribed from birth to weaning of a child. This is considered as harming the child; e.g., sexual relationships of the parents during this period are supposed to afflict the child with a kind of rickets called ngongea or chiwa
Receiving depends on God. Cf. 1945.

text: Kupindua kiatu chini juu ni kumtukana mungu.
explanation: To put a÷ shoe upside down is to show disrespect for God. By facing the footsole up to heaven.

text: Kuwa au kutokuwa kumo mikononi mwa mungu. Mtu ni kujitahidi.
explanation: To be or not to be is in the hands of God; a person must do one's best.

text: Kuzunguka mbuyu si dawa ya shetani
explanation: Going around the baobab tree is not a cure against the devil. It is not easy to convince a person to drop a bad habit. A person may say I have changed, but in practice is still going on as usual
With God the better person is the one who knows him/herself.
With God no person is abject.

text: Kwa mungu hakuna kule, wala hakuna jambo zito.
Kwa mngu k'aya kule, wala haku yambo zito.
explanation: With God nothing is far nor difficult.
Cry to obtain, but not obtaining is the doing of God. To get things is the work of God.
Whatever happens in this world, God has ordained it.
Payment on earth is the reckoning of the hereafter. God returns one's good or evil deed often while one is still on earth - SAM.
Payment today is tomorrow's reckoning.

text: Malipo ni duniani, ahera kwenda hesabu.
explanation: Paying is done on earth, in the netherworld comes the reckoning.
Payment comes afterwards.
God pays all payments. God rewards and punishes.

text: 2380b. Mambo hutenda jabari sisi sharti hukubali.
explanation: God (in His aspect of Jabari, the compeller) is the one who acts, we have to accept.

text: 2380c. Mambo ya mbele, giza la wele.
explanation: Matters of the future [are in] darkness of destiny.

text: Mambo yote (or vitu vyote) mtenzi [ni] mungu
explanation: All things are God's doings. All things are in God's hand.

text: Mambo pia kwa manani, umbile kwa yake shani
explanation: Even things belong to the Beneficent, the creation is to His glory. Pia: denotes a totality, everything, everyone.
Things He has written cannot be wiped out. God's hand can be seen in all events

text: Mema mungu atwegeshe, kama mkono na kanwa
explanation: May God bring good things close to us, as hand and mouth.

text: Maovu atuambaze, kama ya mbingu na nchi.
explanation: May [God] cause evil to stay away from us, as far as sky and earth. This is a commonly quoted type of prayer
May evil pass far from you.

text: Mja akiteswa hafanyi machungu; hupiga shahada, kashukuru mungu.
explanation: A suffering servant of God does not become embittered, he recites the [Muslim] Creed and gives thanks to God.

text: Mja hatindi rehema ali hai duniani
explanation: A human being does not lack God's mercy while living on earth. So don't lose courage.

text: Mja hatwai daraka ya kuondoa na kuweka.
explanation: A servant of God does not assume the responsibility of removing and establishing
Obey the Lord, who does not desert nor hate thee.
The real [only] giver is God. Mpaji: giver; is said especially of God.
The Giver who is never given. The complete text is

text: Mpaji wa kupa ni mungu, usiaminie mwanadamu.
explanation: The giver of giving is God, do not put your trust in man.
God is the [real] physician.
A person has his or her ideas, but God thinks differently. "Man proposes, God disposes.

text: Mtu hawezi kuumba, na kuumbua hawezi.
explanation: A person can neither create nor destroy. "Our fate is ruled by God"
The abused person who keeps silent, God is the judge. Kinyamale for anayenyamaza: the person who is silent. Mwakuzi for mwamuzi: the judge

text: Mungu akikupa kilema, hukupa na mwendo wake.
explanation: If God gives you a lame leg, He also gives you a way of walking with it. The belief in Allah inspires not only fear but also faith and confidence, peace of mind, and a clear sense of purpose in life. God may be severe, he is also compassionate, understanding, and just

text: 2391a. Mungu akitaka kitu hukiambia uwe tu kikawa.
explanation: If God wants a thing, he merely tells it, Be, and it becomes.
When God blocks a passage here, he opens one there. If God takes something away, He will give something else
As God puts you, so you stay.

text: Mungu amemwenezea kila mtu riziki yake
explanation: God has put the means of living in everybody's hand.
God gives to whom He wants.
God sees the truth but waits [His time].
God is much blamed for many things.
God says, look after yourself; shall I then look after you? Do not take unnecessary risks expecting God will protect you - MM. Each for oneself and God for us all
God does not let his servant down.
God never fails in his appointed times. A semi-pious expression used in remarking on coincidences in time: the same thing happened last Wednesday, etc.
God did not create an evil person. When a bad person should not blame God because God has created a person with brains to think and choose what is good and what is evil
God does not hide a hypocrite. Sooner or later hypocrisy will come out.
God never refuses everything to his servant. Cf. 3447.
God has no secret of a person. God knows all, does not need humans to tell him.

text: Mungu hapi kwa mvua, hanyimi kwa jua kali.
explanation: God does not give by rain; and does not deprive by fierce sun

text: Hapi kwa mvua nyingi; hanyimi kwa jua kali
Hapi kwa kuza na kuwa, wala kwegesha mahali

explanation: God does not dispense his gifts as a rain, He does not take them away as the burning sun which destroys everything; If He gives, it is not a trading of gifts, nor has He ambition or need of us: God almighty gives out of His power and omnipotence.
God does not strike twice. God causes no two disasters for the same people at the same time
God does not forget the hour. Implied is: the hour of our death, the hour for prayers and other duties, which humans forget
God betrays not.

text: Mungu hatoi upesi, wenye kupewa ni wengi
explanation: God does not give quickly, [even so] there are many who receive. Some who are unlucky accuse destiny of being partial.
God does not forget us.
God resuscitates meat from the mat. Never despair

text: Mungu hupa alalaye na akaaye kitako
explanation: God gives to the one who sleeps and to the one who sits.

text: Mungu hupa awindaye, mungu hupa alalaye.
explanation: God gives to the hunter, God gives to the sleeper. Good luck comes to those who work and to those who do not
God expects our co-operation. Cf. 2398.
God spoke: Ask me and I'll give you.
If you have forgotten God, you have forgotten yourself.

God changes things. Do not lose hope. God can change everything. Nobody's condition is stable. God gives health and sickness. So a healthy person should not close the eyes to less fortunate people, because some day that same person may be in need of help.

text: Mungu mkazi wa ulimwengu (or sama) shida na raha hutuma.
explanation: God, the establisher of the world, sends adversity and prosperity. It is God who puts [us in] the world and who gives everyone trials and joy - Sacl. God who resides in Heaven sends us hardship and happiness
God and work
God is the one who knows the secrets.
God is the great healer.
God is the Granter of needs. A title of God.
God is a God of truth.

text: Mungu ni muumba wa viumbe pia.
explanation: God is the creator of animals also. Respect for living things.
God is not like Athumani [or John Doe]. The meaning is that God has no favoritism, bias or special liking. The greatness of God cannot be compared to that of any human being
God is not an old person.
God is pure and loves cleanliness.
The person who prays to God does not tire. Do not lose hope praying and try different ways of solving your problems - MM.
The person who trusts in God lacks nothing.

text: 2424a. Mwanzio wa maaswio hi kuzibwa masikio.
explanation: The beginning of rebellion [against God, i.e., evil] is that one's ears are blocked. Evil is the disobedience of divine laws. A person starts out on the path of evil by refusing to listen to reason
A living being will receive its daily food. The Lord will provide

text: 2424c. Mwenye kupewa sumu hakufa, mwenye kupika ndiye wakufa
explanation: The one who was given the poison did not die, the one who concocted it, is the one to die. God will find the culprit - SPK.
Taboo is a matter of faith.
God will save us.
The perfect parent is God. In procreation and education of children, the parents are the cooperators of God.
The blessings of God cannot be stopped.
The matter you refuse, is [perhaps] the very thing God wills
God's house is not shut. Said to comfort a friend who has been struck by misfortune

text: Pato kuu ni la mungu apao wawi na wema.
explanation: Great gain is from God, who gives to the bad and the good. Cf. 2370, 3904, 4476.
The soul has no price [is priceless]. One should go to any length to save a soul
Salvation for the mortals is to watch out
We [Allah] change the days among men
Repentance is deeds. Words are not enough to prove a change of mind.
We have been told [by God] "live" [in peace], We have not been told: "quarrel!

text: Tunatembea kwa imani, sio kwa kuona
explanation: We walk by faith not by seeing.
Fear God, fear no human.
If you play with a dog, you'll enter the mosque [for purification]. Playing with a dog makes a person unclean - Koran.
If you are content with little, God will give you much more. Ukikinai or ukitosheka, be satisfied.

text: Ukitaka kula mfu, kula wa kunona.
explanation: If you want to eat meat, eat the best part. Cf. 2439.
If you want to eat pork, choose a fat pig. Muslims are forbidden to eat pork. If you do a bad thing, do it big. The punishment is the same
When you are in need, never stop praying.
Being a sharif is a matter of the heart. Nobility must come from the heart. Usharifu, descendant of the prophet Muhammad - KS. Nobility, excellence, respectability
After the purification of Friday, try for Thursday. One should try to strive for a good life every day. The [ritual and mental] purity of Friday, pronounce it [wake up] on Thursday

text: Utajiri ni raha ya leo duniani, mateso ya kesho ahera.
explanation: Richness in the world today is comfort, but is suffering in the world here after tomorrow. With the understanding that wealth is not used properly
You will get what is destined for you, you do not get what you love.
Be a lamp in this world, pray the merciful God. Rahamani: name of God, the Merciful.
God's ink is indelible. Cf. 1949.
The gratitude of a donkey is a kick. A euphemism for 2457.
One who praises rain has been rained upon. Has benefited by it, or has been refreshed by it. Good fortune is praised by those who have experience of it
The sun has shone on him who praises it.
Do not kick the one who helped you up. "Do not look down on your humble origins"

text: Aliyepandisha wengine ngazini, hupigwa teke menoni.
explanation: The one who has helped others climb the ladder, gets kicked in the teeth.

text: Aliyepandisha wengine ngazini, hupigwa teke menoni.
explanation: The one who has helped others to climb the ladder, gets kicked in the teeth.
An empty 'thank you' does not fill the pot.

text: 2451a. Asokumbuka fadhila si mtu ni hayawani.
explanation: One who does not remember a kindness is not a human being but an animal.
After being kind one receives punishment. After receiving kindness, the ungrateful respond with evil.
The sieve does good, [even though] bad things fall upon it.
Do not despise a bridge on which you have crossed. Do not despise somebody who has helped you. Cf. 2461.
If you do a favor, wait not for repayment.

All the thanks a bee gets is fire. Reference to smoking them out of their hives to get their honey. However, V understands moto [fire] as the sting: The gratitude of the bee is a sting. Even though the bee's sting is painful, the honey is much desired. When someone is undeniably wrong in keeping something back from others and for this reason is judged a bad person, drastic measures are justifiable to obtain what would in the long run be the best for the larger number of people"

text: Fadhili za punda ni mashuzi; na msihadhari ni ng'ombe
explanation: The gratitude of a donkey is the breaking of wind; and the witless person is [butl a cow. Generally only the first part is quoted. Shukrani, gratitude; sometimes used instead of fadhili, kindness.
The gratitude of a donkey is kicks. "No thanks at all. Used when bad has been returned for good"
No benefactor is paid back in the same way.
It is the honor of the noble person to know what is done for him/her.

text: Huimbana nyimbo zake, wasahau jina lake
explanation: They sing the [hero/praise] songs to each other, [but] they forget his/her name. A prophet (here: a poet) is not honored in the prophet's town, even though the prophet's work is made use of"
The ferry that takes you across is [looked back on as] rotten. Reproach to a person who does not appreciate the help received
That what ferries across is [only] a tree trunk. Cf. 2454.

text: Jema hulipwa, lakini jema jingine halilipiki.
explanation: A good deed is returned, but there is a good deed which cannot be returned. When the good deed is so great that it cannot be returned by a deed of equal greatness. For example, when someone sacrifices his life for you.
The rooster, always beneficial, is eaten. Rewards of doing good.

text: Lifaranga, ukimtakia uzima, anajitupa katika moto
explanation: If you want a chick to be alive, it throws itself in the fire. Cf. 3865.
t does no harm to be grateful.

Sleep on the mat if you are offered a mat. Be grateful for the mat. If you ask for a bed, it is possible that your hosts do not have one and this request may embarrass them or they have a defective one, or used by somebody else. As a guest, accept with gratitude any form of hospitality offered to you
The eyes you cured are the same that now look wickedly at you. "Eaten bread is soon forgotten.
The dead person does not see the shroud. A thankless person is not grateful for gifts received.

The person who taught people how to grill the fish was killed by the fishermen. The fishermen ought to have been grateful to the grilling teacher, for that art made the fish tastier and thus more saleable.

text: Mguu ukiumwa na mbwa ni mbaya
explanation: A leg bitten by a dog is [declared] bad. One sees the bad that is now and forgets the good that was
A [good] farmer does not forget the old worn out hoe. Don't throw away people who have been useful to you. Kiselema, an old hoe, worn out, most of the blade is gone.

text: Mtenda mema kinyuki jazaye kulipwa moto
explanation: One who does good is rewarded like a bee, with fire. Cf. 2456.
When your friend invites you, say "thank you." "It is considered rude to turn down an invitation"

text: Mwenye kukusifu mbio, maana aliisha kukufuata.
explanation: One who praises you at once has followed you. That person has benefited of your generosity.
The boat that took you across the river, don't call it useless. Kinyangalika, useless, old, dilapidated.
I have anointed you with kohl, you [in return] anoint me with pepper.
May I not come to eat salt anymore? Don't I have a right to live? Chumvi, salt; here means food. Cf. 1212.
You should preserve a cave that has saved you. Because you might need it sometime again.
If a mouse eats your food, it returns droppings.
A blind person does not forget the walking stick. A needy person does not forget the benefactor.
A donkey shows no gratitude. A lowly-born person shows no civilized behavior

text: 2480a. Roho uwe na usawa na kushukuru vipawa
explanation: Let the soul be well-balanced and grateful for God's gifts.
Give thanks for what you have.

text: 2481a. Sindano huwa na uzi na kushona isishone
explanation: The needle is well threaded but does not sew. "Said of a capable person who does not receive the respect earned" - JKP.

text: 2481b. Umsaidiaye kwenye mvua, anyanyukapo hushirikiana na maadui zako kukucheka
explanation: The person you helped in the rain, getting up, will join your enemies to laugh at you. Some persons often resent the help you gave.

text: 2481c. Umtendaye wema asijue, ukimtenda uovu hatajua.
explanation: If the persons to whom you do good should not know it, they will not know it even if you do harm to them. "If someone does not appreciate favors etc., even if you become angry and abusive will not change his mind, i.e., he still will not appreciate your favors. Becoming "bad" oneself cannot make another person "good"
Don't treat a drunkard generously and expect thanks.
Kindness, dirty insults. Doing good is answered with sexual insults. Kumanina, his/her mother's vagina. Kumanyoko, your mother's vagina.
One who eats alone dies alone. The one who refuses to share blessings with others will have to endure all hardship alone.
So-and-so has chosen the fully grown coconut and got the unripe one. This is said of somebody who is not satisfied with possessions. The chances are that that person might lose all. Cf. 1540.

text: Anayekuwapo penye mgawo asijitandikie sahani (or jani
explanation: One who is present at a sharing must not show up with a plate [leaf]. Greed is not appreciated.

text: Atokeapo mtoto wa fuko, mshike, japo wawinda fuko.
explanation: If a small mole appears, catch it, even if you are hunting for its mother. Do not despise small favors or gifts if you need bigger ones. Cf. 2493.
An evil Indian, his shoe is a medicine

text: Bata mtaga mayai usimchinje kwa tamaa ya wingi.
explanation: Do not slaughter a laying duck from the desire of getting many eggs quickly. Do not kill the goose that lays the golden eggs

What is theirs is consumed by them. There are people, such as the rich, who do not co-operate with those who do not belong to their group or class. If they hold a party, for example, they will invite themselves only. Thus what is theirs is shared among themselves only
If you are given a finger, do not swallow it all. Be grateful for the little
If you are given a span, do not take a fathom. Shubiri: a span, from thumb to little finger of the open hand, about nine inches. Pima: a fathom, two yards, the stretch of a man's arms.
If you are given a span, don't desire a reale. Reali or rea: a German crown or dollar, that was current on the Swahili coast. Its name is derived from the Portuguese and Spanish coin real. - Krapf.
Mine is ours, yours is yours. If sharing is the principle, then everyone should share
Follow the bee and then die in the hive. Greed can be killing. Cf. 635.
Jealousy kills. Hasadi for hasidi or husuda.
Let the envious person pass by on the road. A jealous person will not join you in a friendly way.

text: Heri kenda shika, kuliko kumi nenda uje
explanation: Better nine take it, than ten go and come back. It is better to get nine now, than [perhaps] ten later.
Taking one is better than ten upon return.
Hang on to one, you will not get ten. Cf. 2507.

text: Heri moja mkononi, kama kumi mwituni
explanation: Better one in the hand than ten in the bush.
Take it" is much better than "You'll get it the Lord willing." Cf. 2493.
You cannot beat the length of the pau and the height of the ndakaka. Why are you so thickheaded?

text: Husudi yaua kwa jicho la wivu.
explanation: Jealousy kills with the eye of envy. Husudi or hasidi, grudge,jealousy.
It has become everything for ourselves only. About people who work and care only for themselves.

text: Inzi kufa juu ya kidonda si haramu.
explanation: For a fly to die on an ulcer is not bad. After all, it got what it wanted

text: Mwenye kufa kwa asali ya nyuki hana kilio
explanation: One who dies in honey is not lamented.
Follow the bee and die in the hive.
A pig cannot leave rooting.
A pig does what it must do.
A dry leaf falling down is nothing to be amazed about.
The drowning of a fly is no loss.
A fly does not mind dying in coconut cream - J. The death of a fly in coconut milk is not a big thing

text: Jicho la hasidi huenda kila pembe (or upande).
explanation: The envious eye goes everywhere. Looks everywhere to satisfy its greed. What the eye sees, the heart covets.

Don't beat a dog for the ashes you don't sleep in. Dogs and cats like to sleep on warm ashes. Humans don't. So why should you hit a dog for sleeping there? We should not refuse the use of things we don't use or need. Give help where you can. Jibwa, a big dog.
A big snake cannot spit. A snake swallows what it can. A big snake does not reject anything. It can only swallow. Some people will only receive, without giving anything back.
The big snake of the lime tree guards against those who pluck the fruits. Said of a jealous husband

text: Joka la mdimu halitundi wala halili, huwasa watundao na walao.
explanation: The big snake in the lime tree neither picks nor eats the fruits, but wards off the pluckers and eaters. Used to describe people who do not allow people to use or to enjoy things they themselves don't use
A greedy chief impoverishes the people. Jumbe, chief, headman.

text: Kama una ngozi yenye kufa na mbaya, usitamani ngozi yenye mikia mirefu na mizuri.
explanation: If you have an old and damaged hide, don't desire those with long and beautiful tails.

text: Kenda fumbata si kumi njoo kesho.
explanation: Nine grasped in the hand is better than come tomorrow for ten. If someone pays you half of what is owed, take it; it is better than the promise: tomorrow I'll pay you all
A little does not suffice for you, a lot does not feed [your greed] either. A greedy person always wants more.
The greedy person may try as hard as possible, but will not escape poverty. Daku , "from the saying : Leni upesi, kesho kuna ndaa kuu, eat quickly, tomorrow there will be great hunger"
What is abundantly full overflows. When the measure is full it overflows

text: Kila mtaraji kingi hapati hata kimoja
explanation: Whoever expects a lot, does not get anything.
My son, don't encounter a jealous person. Kimasomaso, a person who is envious.
Don't rely on what is not yours.

text: Kitu kisichokufaa wewe wamzuwiliyani mtu kimfae?
explanation: If a thing is of no use to you, why do you prevent someone else from using it? Wamzuwiliyani for wamzuilia nini. Cf. 2525.

text: Kobe, unipe. Anasema, mkono ni mfupi! Lakini wanamwambia, twaa. Anakamata
explanation: Tortoise. give me. The tortoise will say: my arm is too short. But tell it, Take, and the tortoise will grab it.
Eating much is not necessarily being satiated. About someone who has received his share but wants more.
Your growing fat is my growing skinny.
Begging for help is not [as disgusting as] stealing.
Wanting is a habit. "One could stop wishing things if one had the character"
At your neighbor's, half a helping, but at your own place a succulent portion. A bragger depreciates the other person.
Those who scorn little things will be without big things. Gutua, take away suddenly.
A dead person likes to receive. The more a person is without things the more that person wants.
A dead person likes peace.
Possessions for possessions. Nothing for nothing

text: 2523b. Mali ni ja ngazi, utakapo panda
explanation: Money is like a ladder, when you want to climb up.

text: 2523c. Mali ni ya kuchuma, roho haichumi
explanation: Money is for spending, but it is never spent on the soul. Unless it is spent on alms
That person consumes all. About a person who is selfish and does not share with others.
Give that person what is due.
Why drive away the chicken from the dung which you do not eat yourself? Denying others what you don't use or need

text: Maziwa ambayo hunyonyi ni sawa utomvi.
explanation: The milk that you have not sucked is like [tree] sap to you. The fox said that the grapes were sour.

text: Mbegu moja ya karanga mkwe alilala nje.
explanation: For the loss of one groundnut the in-law slept in the open. Stupid obstinacy is harmful

text: Mbwa dume hawezi kumpokelea mwenzake chakula.
explanation: A male dog cannot receive food for his companion. He will eat it himself.
One who sets out two boats [outriggers] runs one aground. Cf. 2539, 2542.
It is forbidden to eat with many hands. Eat with one hand only. Cf. 2538.
A jealous person has a curse. That person envies others and does not want others to enjoy anything and so has no joy. Hiana, udhalimu, uchoyo, unyimaji, envious, jealous, mean spirited.
A person that puts his/her mind too much on water, drinks it not
One who fixes his mind overmuch on water does not drink it, and if he does, it chokes him
Everyone who greatly desires water has water coming out of his nose. Ania, intend, desire.
One who refuses a sliver [of meat] will get a big chunk. The ironical understanding is that if you refuse a little favor, you might get a misfortune. Cf. 2533.

text: Mkataa ya kuchinja hupata ya kunyonga.
explanation: One who refuses slaughtered meat will get strangled meat. One who does not want to commit even small mistakes will fall into big ones. Cf. 2533.

text: Mkowa wa mlafi hurarukararuka ukiwa mpya
explanation: The belt of the glutton gets torn again and again, when it is new. By eating too much. Mkowa, money belt.

text: Mla kuku na mbuzi atamla mtu
explanation: The animal that eats chicken and goats will also eat a human being.

text: Mla kwa miwili hana mwisho mwema
explanation: A person who eats with both hands will come to a bad end. Eating with both hands is a sign of impatience and greed, and is very impolite. The left hand is considered unclean
An eater with two hands, I will not eat with him /her. Cf. 2550.
The heart is full wishes, it will all end in the shroud.
One who grasps two things, must allow one to go.
A person who desires two must leave one.
The one who sews roomy, sews his own garment. Cf. 662.

text: Msi nacho hasidi wa mwenye nacho
explanation: One who doesn't have it is jealous of the one who has it. And the one who has it does not want the other to have it
Do not overload yourselves. Do not be too greedy
The covetous person does not get what was not destined for him/her.

text: Mtaka yote(or vyote) hukosa yote (or vyote).
Mtaka yote kwa pupa hukosa yote.
explanation: One who wants everything in a hurry loses everything.

text: Mtaka vingi kwa pupa hana mwisho mwema
explanation: One who wants many things eagerly does not have a nice death. Cf. 1546, 1547.
Why drive away the birds from the millet that you do not eat yourself. Cf. 2504.
A chooser [a critic -J] is always wishing
An active hard-working person is never satisfied with his work

text: Muacha kiwi hanacho, na chema kimpotele.
explanation: One who discards a bad thing is without it, and the good thing escapes. Abandon not your old clothes till you get new ones.

text: Mwend (or mzazi) mwenye ubahili, zao la mwana ni ubatili
explanation: The inheritance of the offspring of a parsimonious parent is emptiness. Nothing is left for the children. Ubahili, miserliness, parsimoniousness. Ubatili, emptiness, vanity, futility, uselessness, falseness. Cf. 4498, 4499.

text: Mwenye kufa kwa asali ya nyuki hana kilio.
explanation: He who dies of honey has no mourners. Cf. 2499, 2500.

text: Mwenye ndimi mbili hula na miwili
explanation: A person with two tongues eats with two [hands]. Only one hand may be used while eating. Only greedy children eat with both hands. Therefore, somebody who speaks with a double tongue will have the hands in some other dirty business
Do not permit passion and wealth to rule you.

text: Nyuki hutafuta ladha, watu hufuata fedha
explanation: Bees search for a sweet taste, people run after money.

text: Pongo mwenye kula kunde (or kalanga) hachoki.
explanation: The pongo antelope eating peas [peanuts] doesn't get tired [eating them].

text: Pua ulale, vyenye kunukia si vyako.
explanation: Sleep my nose, what you smell is not for you.
Greed never finishes

text: 2554a. Roho ni kama mtoto yahitaji kurudiwa.
explanation: Our greedy soul is like a child, it wants to be rebuked.

text: 2554b. Roho ni kuacha mema ikatamani maovu.
explanation: Desire, that is to abandon good things out of greed for bad things.
The soul needs cleaning, shaking up.
Strong desire overrides prudence. Passion makes blind or imprudent
Do not look for a fruit that does not belong to a tree. "Or, do not look for a fruit [read: bride], who has no family "

A rich person is enriched by other people. The rich get many presents. People give to the rich in the hope to get something out of it. A wealthy person is made rich by the poor. "Wealth is not a result of an individual's efforts, but the effort of many people...if only one of them becomes wealthy, that person does so because of the joint efforts of all of them including that person, for one's own efforts would not make that person wealthy "
A millionaire does not refuse one [shilling].
Too much eagerness kills a person. Passion leads to crime.
Desire in front, death behind. Used as a warning to greedy or over-ambitious persons
Much desire ends in desolation. This is said of a greedy person. Ana mkono wa birika. A person with a hand like a vessel.
A craving is stronger than any pain. Tasiliti or tasliti: a great love, craving. Belua or beluwa, loss, pain, trouble, misfortune. Cf. 2559.
Exploitation is beastly (not human).
Do not show greed. For the original text in the Lamu dialect see JK's Proverbs from the Lamu Archipelago and the Central Kenya Coast; and his Four„ Centuries of Swahili Verse.
If you want big profits, stop your ears. Lest you hear the cries of your victims

text: Ukusuta hata uwe mjini, uko peke yako, tajiri hata porini anafuatwa
explanation: If you are penniless you are alone even in a town, but a rich man is followed even into the wilds.
Do not forget to break open the traps [with caught game] while you go on setting traps. Kumamamua or Kunanua take out of a trap, force apart, open by force. Cf. 2542.
Do not cry with jealousy

text: Usione mlango umefungwa ukakata tamaa ya kubisha, labda ukarimu ndio uliofunguliwa
explanation: Don't be amazed that the door is closed since you gave up inviting, perhaps generosity will open the door.

text: Usitupe shaba yako kwa mng'ao wa dhahabu.
explanation: Do not throw away your copper for the sake of gold's glitter.

text: Utumainie inayokamata gumba, usitumainie yanayoona macho
explanation: Put your expectation on what your hand can grasp, not what your eyes see. Gumba, thumb.

text: Wakisha tia chanda, watatia na mkono: wakisha tia mkono, watatia na mguu.
explanation: When they have put in the finger, they will also put in the hand: when they have put in the hand, they will also put in the foot.
Grapes that are far away have become bitter.
More and more you want, may God help you. Said to a greedy person
A person who goes to the medicine doctor is never without something wrong. Understood is that the doctor will always find something wrong.
One who hides sickness will not be cured.
Health is best with God's pardon. Ghofira or Ghofora: [God's] pardon.
Health is priceless.

text: Afya! Kulia juu, chini ku moto.
explanation: Health! Grow tall, below there is fire. Grow tall! To remain small has inconveniences. This is said when a child sneezes.
Health, grow like a banana tree.
Grow up like a banana tree, the coconut tree is too slow.
Good health is a blessing from your Lord.

text: Afya ni taji hakuna aijuaye isipokuwa mwenye maradhi.
explanation: Health is a crown and no one knows it save a sick person.
The one who is sick is not [necessarily] the one who dies. A healthy person may die suddenly.
So-and-so is like a boat which draws water. About a very sick person. Cf. 2590.
A sick person is cared for
Health is the chief thing and it is better than wealth
Rest when ill, it is better than medicine

What goes to the doctor does not come back. Gifts given to your wife or mother-in-law should not be claimed back. This is also used to calm a person who has given things to cheats and thieves and does not expect to get them back
What goes to the cemetery does not come back
The medicine which hurts, likes you. Bitter pills may have blessed effects.
Medicine is never given freely
The cure of a boil is to open it.
An incurable ulcer finishes medicine. This is said of someone who does not want to improve his ways. There is no substitute for loss or separation of a dearly beloved person
Does a sibling-sore [ever] get well?
So-and-So is like a pirogue drawing water, and almost sinking. Near dying. Cf. 2582.

text: Ganga ganga la mganga humlaza mgonjwa na tumaini.
explanation: The continual care of the doctor encourages the sick person.
Prevention is better than cure.
Rheumatism is a spoil-work. Jongo: a kind of rheumatism, a swelling of the joints. Mavunda or mivunja: a spoiler.
Work is like a medicine. Work cures.
A little is sweet, a lot is oppressing. "Makes you sick." "Too much of a good thing; advice to a young girl about lovers"
Hurt the sore of somebody and it will reveal itself. A sore that is revealed can be cured.

text: Kizuizui mgonjwa wa macho hawezi kabisa.
explanation: The deaf person who gets an eye disease is sick indeed.
To grow long [finger] nails [is] to invite sickness [injury]. A rule of health. This is said with reference to something unpleasant that is caused by one's own negligence
Moving restlessly is not a remedy against dying. What is spoiled is spoiled. Kutaataa, the restless moving of a sick person.

text: Kwa mdogo pumu, kwa mkubwa mafua.
explanation: Asthma to the small, colds to the big. If a child and an adult have the same disease, the child's is called properly asthma, but the adult is given a more respectable name (e.g., cold), so as not to lower that person's respect. The same in life. A small person is called by his proper name, but the important person is given a more respectful name
A medicine man [midwife] is never without a song. Neither ever lacks an answer, even if it is only fictitious.

text: Mali ya mgonjwa faida ya mfumu.
explanation: The property of a sick person profits the healer. Mfumu, or mganga, a healer, doctor.

text: Maradhi yakija, huja kwa shoti ya farasi; yakitoka hutoka mtambao wa chungu.
explanation: When sickness comes it comes in the gallop of a horse, but going away, it goes like a creeping ant.
The way a disease enters [the body] that is not the way it departs.
The short rainy season is filth. The weather is cold and water is scarce, not inductive to cleanliness. Mchoo: the period of short rains in July.

text: Mfarijii aliyeumia hata kama ni adui kwako.
explanation: Console the sufferer, even your enemy.
One who hides his/her sickness doesn't get medicine. The best cure for difficulties and problems is to come out with them and talk about them. Cf. 2937.
A [witch] doctor does not cure him/herself. Mganga wa miti shamba. A native doctor with local medicine.

text: Mgonjwa akiugua sana, si lazima afe.
explanation: Even a very sick person does not necessarily die.
A sick person is not asked if he wants a remedy. Just give what is needed. Do not ask a beggar what he needs; instead, satisfy that person's needs.
A sick person should not be asked if he wants porridge
A bed is the companion of a sick person.
The person who recognizes the illness is the physician. Only when a person recognizes the cause of trouble can it be cured. Cf. 3169.
If a child does not jump about, it is not healthy.
A person is health.

A person suffering from elephantiasis has no lap [for a child to sit on]. Tende, teende: A thick or swollen leg. The person does not feel pain. This sickness is common in cold and damp places e.g. on Pemba island

text: Nduli na mchimba dawa shauri lao ni moja.
explanation: The angel of death and the pharmacist [the root-digger] are in accord
A cow that chooses grass is sick. Cf. 4724.

The one who has a cold gets emphysema. A person who is weak will get a greater sickness. The understanding of this proverb is that someone with a minor illness as a common cold, complains that he has a lung decease. Used, e.g., when a child cries his heart out for a minor hurt.

text: Shibe ya waganga hutoka kwa wagonjwa.
explanation: The bounty of the physician comes from the sick.
I shall not suffer illness while doctors abound

text: 2618a. Tunza maji ya kisima, jamaa wawe wazima
explanation: Take good care of the well so that the family may be well.
Sickness can be hidden, but death cannot be hidden.

text: Ugonjwa ni mmoja, matabibu wana tofauti ya elimu.
explanation: Sickness is one [is the same], but the doctors differ in their science. Cf. 880.
The sickness of the heart is known by the patient.

text: Ukiona ndwee ikishindana na dawa, mganga sijisumbue, pana jambo litakuwa.
explanation: When you see a disease struggling with medical treatment, doctor, don't be upset, something will happen. Cf. 409.
If you fall ill, have patience. Recovery will take longer than you think
The tree has been overtaken. A powerful person is sick.

text: 2624a. Usipouguza mwele una koo la ujuko.
explanation: If you do not look after a patient you will have a family of the shroud (i.e., all your relatives will die).
There is no cure for old age.
Life [health] and wealth are not bartered.
The health of the brain is related to the body.
Time is a healer.
Pickles cause [the guests] to eat. A request must be couched in pleasant terms

text: 2629a. Akomelepo mwenyeji na mgeni koma papo.
explanation: Where the host has stopped, there the guest stops also. When the host is convinced about something, the guest stops arguing
One who chases you away does not tell you "leave." Do not wait until you are told. If you are not welcome, stay away. The visitor must be careful not to overstay his welcome
If one wants to be without you, that person will not tell you: get out! One can see it from that person's behavior. It has changed. You can say: Stay. You cannot say: Go away. Cf. 2631.

text: Akuwingaye kwake hakwambii ndokea, hukutendea vitendo ambavyo vya kukuchukia.
explanation: One who expels you does not tell you go away, but he'll treat you unkindly. Cf. 2630.
Your happiness is my happiness. "Said to a guest"
Invite the stranger but do not scrutinize him. Kumwekea macho, put the eyes on somebody.

Work knows no guest. When a guest arrives at the host's, the guest gets time to be entertained and to rest. When that period is over, and the host resumes his work which even the guest can do, the guest joins in without hesitation

text: Kuku mweupe ni hatari kwa usalama.
explanation: A white chicken is a danger for security and peace. A white chicken stands out in the village, and so does a stranger. That easily upsets the tranquility of the village.
A white fly. A red herring

text: Kula ni faradhi ya kila mtu.
explanation: Eating is the right of everybody. Nobody must ever be refused food. Cf. 1435.

Standing and still going. Said if somebody is invited to come in and to sit down, but keeps on standing and talking. Another meaning: Whether you sit on a chair or stand, if people see you they will say that you were there
Old rust is for the visitor

text: Maji! Ni kumbwe na kinyweo! Matupu yasonga moyo.
explanation: As for] water, [give me] a morsel of food and [then] the beverage; all by itself it [water] gives a person the colic [lit., compresses the heart]
A stranger does not roast an oyster in a village and then get accused of smelling of it
A guest does not take over the house.
The visitor and the owner. Omitted is husaidiana, help each other. Cf. 2643.
May the guest come and bring some relief to the host. The arrival of a guest is a blessing
A stranger is like a white chicken. And is very noticeable
Don't become a white chicken. Becoming different from the others. Showing off. Cf. 2635, 4064.
A visitor is like rain [does not stay]. But also a visitor is welcome like rain in a scorched land.

text: Mgeni ni mtumwa wa mwenye nyumba
explanation: A visitor is the slave of the owner of the house. In a strange environment one acts subdued

text: Mgeni pofu ingawa ana macho yake.
explanation: A stranger is blind even if the visitor has eyes. If the visitor sees bad or unpleasant things nothing must be said.

text: Mgeni siku mbili, ya tatu mpe jembe
explanation: A guest two days, the third give him a hoe. Do not exceed your hospitality. Cf. 2634. Here a well-known poem about hospitality

text: Mgeni wa mvua hafukuzwi, mwache aweke mzigo wake
explanation: A visitor arriving in the rain is not refused entry, let him put down his load.
A host kills the guest

Somebody going home is not fastened to a palm-strip. A parting guest must not be loaded with commissions. It was customary for a person going home to tie a palm-strip on the arm in reminder of an errand given by the host.

text: Mwenye kuwa na mgeni haoni mwezi mwandamo.
explanation: One who lodges a visitor does not see the appearance of the new moon. The host must not alert the visitor to the passing days.
Welcome guest and save the host. All will enjoy delicious food and quarrels will be put to rest. Cf. 2643.

text: Nyumba yangu ni joya, atakaye huingia.
explanation: My house is like a spongy coconut, anyone who likes goes into it. Everyone is welcome. My house attracts profiteers

text: Pema usijapo pema, ukipema si pema tena.
explanation: A good place you do not go to is a good place; if you go too often, it isn't a good place any longer

text: Shereheka na mgeni wako kama vile ambavyo ungependa ushereheshwa ugenini
explanation: Celebrate with your visitor as much as you would like to be celebrated as a visitor.

text: Siku njema ni zawadi ya msafiri
explanation: A good day is the gift of a traveler

text: Simlishe paka wa jirani, atavunja kombe na sahani
explanation: Do not feed the neighbor's cat, it will break cups and saucers
A smile satisfies hunger. Even if there is little food, if the host gives it with an open and happy heart, the guest will be satisfied
When you are overtaken by the sunset, sleep. This saying is often said in combination with

citations.page: ukishikwa. When you are pressed, allow yourself to be held. Where you are caught, stay. Where it pleases you, stay there. Taken as advice: If hospitality is offered to you, take it, don't go further

text: Ushikwapo shikamana, si wengi wa kupendana.
explanation: When someone offers you friendship, hold on [to him/her] there are not many people who love one another.
Being a stranger is bad, you have no neighbor to turn to for help.
When you receive a visitor, don't frown.

text: Usigombane na mgeni; siku zake ni chache
explanation: Don't quarrel with a visitor; his stay is short.
Don't rearrange the furniture while you are a visitor or a newcomer. When new to a place, don't start changing things before you have studied the situation. Fanicha, furniture.
Do not break [even] a chicken's leg. Nobody is allowed to take liberties with the wife of the host.
Ignorance belongs to the one who comes from afar. Uzuzu, inexperience, strangeness, incompetence, foolishness, ignorance.
Indecision is the house of hunger.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Laziness is a house of hunger.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Sloth is the key to poverty.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: The one who eats it (i.e., the food) is the one for whom it was destined.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

text: Akosaye la mama, atalamwa la mbwaye.
explanation: One that is not suckled by his/her mother, will have recourse to a bitch. A man without a good wife will seek the company of bad women
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: One who has had a full meal does not know the hungry person. One judges others according to oneself, or one does not know how the other feels. One cannot know the hardship of others until one has experienced them. Used when somebody has no feelings for others.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: One who is satiated does not remember the one who is hungry.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: A human being is lead by his stomach.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: The belonging of the chafi- is its stomach. Said of somebody who eats ferociously. Chafi or tafi, a kind of broad black fish. Rasilimali, treasure, capital, fortune, property.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Food is life.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: The debt to the stomach can never be paid. "Every day the stomach demands more. Said of paupers"
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

text: Hana njaa fisi, kwani hula najisi.
explanation: The hyena is not hungry, because it eats unclean food. Do not be fastidious
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Yo íu will not be satisfied with the fragrance of the food.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: In a large family no food is bad. They value any food they can get and don't waste it
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: That which exposes you [to danger] is your stomach. The stomach commands the Swahili merchants, fishermen, sailors, and drivers to go out on dangerous journeys to earn their living
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

text: Kila kifaacho huliwa, lakini si kila kiliwacho kinafaa
explanation: Every useful thing is eaten, but not everything that is eaten is useful (good).
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: One who obtains food [wealth] does not know his/her companions. Sucessful people forget their poor old friends - MM. Used for ungrateful people, who forget the help given them in the past, or for people who made it. and who do not want to remember the situation they came from. Cf. 2669.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

text: Kula bakisha njaa, kesho ule tena.
explanation: Eating keep a little hungry, tomorrow eat again. Eat with moderation.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Eating never ends.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Eating is a God-given necessity of life.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Eating meals in turn in each other's places weakens the stomach. One does not get his usual food and sometimes the others forget their promise of serving food. Cf. 1624.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: You like to eat, but when you are told to hoe you dry up.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: I ate but did get no satisfaction.

explanation: Eating is with friends.

Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

text: Kula ni faradhi, kufa ni wajibu.
explanation: Eating is a duty, dying is a necessity. Cf. 1435.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: To eat a lot is not the same as being satified. Cf. 2516, 2535, 2550.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Eating is not the same as filling the belly. One who eats least eats most, will live longer.

Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Eat to live, do not live to eat.

text: Kula ulishe milio, roho nayo ipe mlo.
explanation: Eating you feed your body, but give also some food to your soul.
theme:

explanation: Eating in a hurry will diminish your reputation. Nukusu, nakusi, diminish

explanation: The dwelling place of hunger is the stomach.

text: Matikiti na machango ndiyo maponyea njaa.
explanation: Melons and gourds, these are the ones which help people through famine. Honor the people you lived with, and who helped you when you were poor and in need of help.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

text: Matikiti na machango ni baraka ya mlango.
explanation: Melons and gourds are blessings of the house. This refers to children

explanation: Sauce is not food.
theme:

explanation: If you eat your own [food], you do not have to be ashamed.

text: Mla na kijiko hajui mla na mikono huchomeka
explanation: One who eats with a spoon does not know that the one who eats with his/her fingers has been hurt.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: A sleeping person doesn't feel the onset of hunger, one who is awake is not told, "let's eat." You know when you are hungry

Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: A compulsive eater cannot manage a home. About spending all on food. Mbuge, someone who is constantly nibbling on food.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: A hungry person observes no taboos. A starving person is excused to eat any kind of food.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: A hungry person does not plaster the house. That person is not interested in improving the house. First things first.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: A bird that does not fly dies of hunger. If its food supply is exhausted in its immediate dwelling place, it dies. A person must move to where he can survive.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Hunger does not know the farmer. Hunger is unknown to the farmer. The farmer does not suffer hunger. Result of his labor.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

explanation: Hunger has no relative. Nobody comes to the hungry person.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: When hunger hurts the dog[s], [then] will my hand be licked. Low-class people will only be polite when forced by need
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156. 
                Laziness is a house of hunger.

text: Njaa ya leo ni shibe ya kesho.
explanation: Hunger today, abundance tomorrow. Hope is the poor person's bread
theme:

text: Njaa ya leo si shiba ya kesho.
explanation: Hunger today is not tomorrow's plenty. Today hunger, tomorrow famine.

explanation: The flesh of the koroma (an unripe coconut) is not edible before the ripe coconut has been cut. The elder daughter has to be married off first
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

text: 2705b. Nyenje inajaa bonde na sikio, nyenje haijai tumbo na vilio.
explanation: The cicada fills the valley and the ear with its noise, but it does not fill the stomach.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

text: Nyumba penye huli, ikitoka moshi ni kungugu.
explanation: If smoke comes out of a house, where you are not going to eat (you are not invited, you say) it is a mist (that comes out of the house, not smoke). Don't keep false hope. Sour grapes.
theme:
Uvivu [ni] nyumba ya  njaa.   Z 173; FSM 156.

explanation: Put some gravy on my dry portion. Someone who has a good reputation must expect some evil criticism and maligned curiosity

explanation: Babbling is the source of hunger.

explanation: Where there is famine, there is no justice. It is difficult for hungry people to remain calm.

theme:

explanation: Where there is famine, food is the truth. Anything a hungry person is told does not satisfy. Food for that person is truth or real.

                Laziness is a house of hunger.

theme:

theme:

explanation: The person who walks with calm and care will arrive without fail. This proverb is illustrated by the story of the tortoise and the hare.
The one who is in front usually comes behind.
Some people put bells on their legs. Are in a hurry. Mbugi, a collar with bells.

text: Apendaye kula wali husubiri mpunga kuiva.
explanation: One who likes to eat rice will wait patiently for the rice to be ripe. Wali, cooked rice. Mpunga, rice in the paddy. Michele, uncooked rice.
A patient person will not regret.

text: Bi.kidumu, usikukurike, mwenye safari ni ndoo.
explanation: Ee, earthen pot don't take it too seriously, it's the bucket that goes on the journey [to the well]. It is possible that this proverb is intended for the wives of polygamists, whose expectations are not fulfilled
The earthen jar is full of excitement, but the traveler took the bucket. "Earthen jars look very dignified but they are fragile. Travelers are practical, they prefer strong buckets. Refers to women

text: Kukukurika kwa ndoo, mwenye nyumba ni kidumu.
explanation: The bucket is working hard, but it is the earthen pot that has the [chosen place] in the house. Love and attention in a household are uncertain, especially in polygamy
Place the pot on the stones after you've lit the fire. Set not your loaf in till the oven is hot
A young coconut, a person afterwards. Everything has its time. Dafu: an unripe coconut.
Cross the bridge when you come to it.
Mr/Mrs.] Run-fast cannot be caught. Endambio, a composite of enda (go) and mbio (fast).
There's no bad patience. Subira, or saburi, patience, resignation. Cf. 2796-7.
Haste, haste has no blessing. Haste makes waste.

text: Ka ka ka ka haina mbaraka.
explanation: Too much haste has no blessing. Baraka: blessing; usually conveys to a Swahili the exclusively physical meaning it has here

text: Haraka haraka ilimfanya chura akose mkia.
explanation: The great haste caused the frog to lose its tail. Refers to a story.

Climbing in haste, coming down in haste. A person who suddenly becomes successful may fall suddenly. Maybe the time of that person's rise was too short to learn the skills needed. "Hasty climbers have sudden fall"

text: Harara bila daraka ni barabara bila daraja
explanation: Zeal without responsibility is like a road without a bridge. "Zeal without knowledge is like a runaway horse. Enthusiasm in doing something without caring about the consequences is as dangerous as driving on a road without a bridge"

text: 2742a. Heri kawa ufike kama karibu harabu.
explanation: Better arrive late than early and so meet, or cause, ruin.
The coconuts are left on the trees. Until they are ripe. Be patient. Do not try to do something too early
Don't expect that they will give you back two and a half francs. Faranga : 1. young chicken. 2. franc (money).
Better delay and get there. The important thing is to reach your goal.

What has fallen into the sea, go and wait for it on the beach. What is lost at sea, go and wait for it on the beach. The example I was given is as follows: Once a girl has taken 'the plunge' and given herself to a man other than her husband, she will inevitably slide further down and end 'in the gutter'
A tortoise will not break a leg in walking. It walks so slowly. Cf. 2779, 2791.
The tortoise has arrived, going carefully.
Running is not the same as reaching your destination. The race is not [always] to the swift. CF. 2745.

text: Kulimatia si kazi, kifungo ni salamini.
explanation: Delaying is easy, and the end is in peace. Never hurry
To stand up for justice needs patience.
To cut out the tunic before the child is born.
How can one look for an [ornamental] dagger and the child is not yet born.
Not caring to wait is like digging your grave.
Enduring hardship produces sweet fruit.
Forbearance is maturity. "It is not easy for a person to have forbearance, but a mature person practices forbearance in all circumstances"
To keep a person waiting a reason is needed.

text: Kuzaa kwa haraka mbwa alizaa kipofu.
explanation: In being in too great a hurry the bitch gave birth to a blind puppy. Cf. 2795.

text: Kwa kukimbia mno mvua, mtwa akajichoma mti.
explanation: Running away too hastily before the rain, the Pygmy hurt his foot at a tree. Mtwa, kibete, mbilikimo, mumbote, a Pygmy.

text: Kwanza kwa saburi, kwisha kwa sururi
explanation: Begin with patience, end with pleasure.
Running in not [necessarily] arriving. Cf. 431, 2745.
Going slowly [is] going far. "Caution travels a long way. This proverb is illustrated by the story of the tortoise"
What jumps up in a hurry is what escapes. Be prepared. Cf. 285.
The chameleon does not go astray, does not walk in error. A chameleon can be seen to tread very carefully wherever it goes
Matters work out better for a person who has patience.

text: Mawindo ya kwanza hayaui na ya pili hayajarudi.
explanation: The first hunt caught nothing and the second party has not yet returned. So, do not count them yet as successful. Cf. 2787, 2792.

text: Mbegu za leo si miti ya kesho.
explanation: Seeds planted today are not trees tomorrow. One must have patience.

text: Mbio za kobe (or kasa) si mbio lakini zakufikisha uendapo.
explanation: A tortoise's running is not running, but it helps you reach where you are going
Running on a smooth floor finishes at the edge - F. Running upon a flat roof will end at the brink - T. Cf. 2779.
One does not throw a stone at an approaching crunching sound. Wait and see what it is. Cf. 984.
One hundred - it begins with one.

text: Mimba ya pili haizaliwi kabla ya kwanza.
explanation: The second pregnancy does not mature before the first. One cannot advance or skip certain events.

text: Mkamate mamba kabla ya kuuza ngozi yake.
explanation: Catch the crocodile before selling its skin.
A person that has no patience eats no ripe fruit.

A patient person eats ripe [fruit]. A patient person eats well cooked [food]. It takes a long time for a seed to bear fruit and waiting is not enough, the tree has to be protected. Instead of mstahamilivu, JK has mtulivu. RSP has mvumilivu. Both have the meaning of patient.

text: Mtafitafi hula swi, mtulivu hula nyama.
explanation: A restless person eats fish, but a reliable person eats meat. A person too much in a hurry
One who stores half-grown fruit eats the rotten. Do not pick unripe fruit because it will rot.  But also
A person who stores unripe fruit eats it when ripe .

text: Mwacha kiwi hanacho na chema kimpotele
explanation: If one throws away a bad thing a good thing will also be missed. If you threw it away before you had the good thing. Kiwi or kibaya, something bad. Kimpotele, kimempotea, escaped somebody.

text: Mwana hazaliwi mpaka kwa siku zake
explanation: A child is not born before its days.

Wait for the fast walker to tire [and then pass him by]. Don't lose your time competing with those who are in a hurry. Used to show that an overactive person does not achieve much and is often a loser. Don't imitate or compete with that person. Go your own way. Also don't counsel people until they have calmed down and are ready to listen

RunnerS must be in good relation with their hips. If we want to undertake something, we must make sure that we can realize it. Don't do things beyond your power. Agana or patana, sikilizana, be in agreement.
A person in a hurry stubs a toe.
A careful traveler goes far. Cf. 1858.
Those who dive on dry land graze their face. Cf. 2766.
Going slowly does not [even] hurt a toe.
And if he/she stumbles it does not hurt.
The prudent walker needs no doctor.
A hasty person misses the sweet things. One who eats in a hurry, does not enjoy the taste of food. Work in a hurry does not satisfy anybody
If a careful bird stumbles, it does not break a leg.
Wait dawn is not far. Said to someone in trouble.

By waiting too long, the chimpanzee missed its tail. Based on the story that when God was giving tails to all animals, the monkey waited too long to appear. This is said when somebody postpones the fulfillment of a promise.
Wait, wait!" does not fill even one stomach.
Wait! Wait! hurts the stomach.
Wait, wait; the child is not yours. If you wait too long your girl will sleep with another man

text: Ni heri kujizuia, kusubiri ndio njia.
explanation: It is good to control oneself, patience is the best way.

text: Nyama angali mzima katika mti, nawe unaanza kucheka na kucheka, ukisema: leo nina chakula kizuri.
explanation: Although the game [animal] is still alive in the tree, you start laughing and dancing saying: today I'll have delicious food.
If you run through the high grass, a snake will bite you
Being careful is moving ahead. Also a political slogan

text: Pole pole ndio mwendo, siasa ya wazalendo.
explanation: Careful is the political move of the inhabitants.
Slowly, slowly, the porridge is cooked.
The slow gait of the tortoise takes it far.
Patience and respect is half of wisdom.

text: Samaki angali majini, usimhesabu katika kundi lako.
explanation: Don't count the fish still in the water as your catch.

text: 2792a. Sikienue kilaa ila na maji yajaa.
explanation: Do not raise the mainsail [to depart] unless the tide is in. Sail out at just the right time
One day [of waiting] does not spoil the meat.

text: 2793a. Siku zote subiria na zidi kumwabudia.
explanation: Every day be patient and continue worshipping Him.
Do not launch the boat at high tide. This is said to someone who asks premature questions of a story teller. Don't put yourself in dangerous situations.

text: Subira huzaa mwana mwema (or wa kufaa).
explanation: Paraphrase

text: Haraka haraka ilimfanya mbwa azae watoto vipofu.
explanation: Hurry, hurry, made the dog breed blind pups.  And

text: kujaribu kujifungua haraka, mama alijifungua mtoto asiyekomaa
explanation: Trying to give birth too quickly, the mother gave birth to a premature child. Cf. 2756.
Patience is the key to happiness. Time cures pain. Patience is bitter, but its fruits are sweet

text: Subira yavuta heri, huleta kilicho mbali.
explanation: Patience attracts happiness; it brings close what is far away. It makes difficult things possible. Cf. 1298, 1555.
Wait, wait, the tide will rise. When your boat has run aground only patience is needed and it will come afloat by itself
Slowly is indeed the way to go. Affairs [transactions] should be approached with care, not force
Careful, that is the way; much force is not successful
The impulsive run broke the leg of the pongo antelope.

text: Uji ukiwa moto haupozwi kwa ncha ya ulimi.
explanation: Gruel, when it is hot, is not cooled by the point of the tongue.
If you are patient, you will lack nothing.

text: Unipe, unipe, ulijipesha nyama ya mfupa.
explanation: By saying] Give me, give me, you got a meatbone. Ulijipesha or ulijipatia, you obtained.

Don't start collecting stool, while the child has not yet produced any or not even broken wind. Hajayamba (Maniema dialect), hajaenda choo: has not yet gone to the toilet. Hajajamba (Kiswahili), has not even broken wind.
Don't cut the grass before you have killed the animal. When an animal has been slaughtered it is placed on grass, cut for this purpose
Don't cut the ubeleko before the child is born. Ubeleko, cloth to carry a child
Don't curve your finger before you have seen the pot [with food]. Don't anticipate before receiving. Cf. 2751, 2804.
Delay brings abandonment. Cf. 308, 2784.

text: Usisafishe kibuyu kabla ya ng'ombe kuzaa.
explanation: Don't clean the calabash before the cow has given birth. Cf. 2804.
Don't say that you lack [a shroud] before you are dead.
Don't prepare the baby's swinging cot before the child is born. Too much caretaking is foolish. Moreover there is a belief that preparing a birth brings out evil spells

What carries you will also drop you. If you jump upon something moving, one day you will fall. This is used for somebody who is used to being helped and who may some day find out that no help is coming
Patience is the beginning of victory.

text: Vumilia ule mbivu, fanya haraka ule mbichi.
explanation: Be patient and eat what is ripe, if you are in a hurry you'll eat what is unripe.

text: Zayenda siku zayenda na miyongo i asia.
explanation: They go, the days they go and even ten-day periods are a trifle. Time goes ever more rapidly
Take a long way and arrive. Take a safe road in order to arrive safely

text: Abudu mungu kwa njia ya kuabudu, ukiwa huwezi usipoteze wakati wako.
explanation: Worship God in the way of worshipping; if you cannot, do not waste your time. Said of people who worship in order to show off.

text: Ajabu ya shingo kukataa kulala kitandani.
explanation: How amazing, the neck refusing to lie down in bed. Said of somebody who refuses something while longing for it
Someone pretends to be blind in one eye, although seeing well. Cf. 4258.

text: Ajuaye dhambi yake ana moja; asiyeijua yuna dhambi mbili
explanation: People who know their sin have only one; but those who do not know their sin have two sins. People who pretend never to have sinned, are sinners since they are dishonest
If it is awarded to somebody else, then that person has been favored; but if it is awarded to me, I deserve it. Used when someone is jealous.

A person who tramples you during daytime does not say "I'm sorry" at night. If a person abuses you openly, he is capable of finishing you off in secret. Or, he who harms you without reason will do worse given a pretext. Understood is that your enemy does not come to help in difficulty; on the contrary, he'll gloat at your misery. Cf. 31.

He who shines a light on you [i.e., shows up your defects] by day, sets fire to you [destroys your reputation altogether] by night. - F. If one praises you in your presence he will slander you in your absence
The one who does not know how to dance says, "wait, let me dress.

text: Cheka ukiaga, ukidhani nakupenda, kumbe nakukanyaga
explanation: Laugh when you say "goodbye" [so you] may think that I love you, but [as a matter of fact] I step on you.
