The leopard dressing up like a sheep.

The pot has leaked the meat, but the water is left. About people who are unreasonable and use the advantages of a situation without fulfilling their obligations; e.g., a man marries a woman for her money, and although he will not give her her rights, uses her property

text: 2826a. Duri na mlio wake, ha ishara hana chake
explanation: The false prophets with their proclamations, they have no signs, they have nothing. Dura, duri, a parrot.
Avoid those who always praise you. Cf. 2822.
Even when I am praised with flattery, I cannot be made proud. K'ishauzwa for nikishauzwa; shaua, give praise, give honor. Shawishi, persuade, tempt, coax.
One does not become a Moses by carrying a rod. The Prophet Moses was enabled by God's grace to perform miracles by means of his staff

text: Hawi mwerevu mtu kwa kuchukua vitabu.
explanation: A person does not become clever by carrying books along.

text: Hizi staha si huja: nawacha nanyi nichani
explanation: This politeness is out of place: I fear you, and you do fear me. Said to unmask the enmity of a person who conceals it under an assumed politeness

How can one use the gravy without eating the meat? Said of someone who refuses to admit wrongdoing, although that person is obviously guilty. Why are you busy doing the accessories and neglecting the essentials?

text: Ikiwa unaweza kummaliza ng'ombe, utashindwaje mkia wake?
explanation: If you can consume a cow, how can you fail to eat the tail? If people are capable of doing big things, how come they cannot tackle something small? Cf. 392, 396, 438, 488.

A flashing smile should be allowed to an actor. A tooth of ivory should not be denied someone who laughs. Laugh with that person and hide the insult in your heart. Jino la pembe, an ivory tooth. An idiom, meaning that somebody embellished his teeth.

text: Kama chui kumvisha nguo za kondoo
explanation: Like putting sheepskin on a leopard. Denying someone's evil character

text: Kilio uliacho ni huruma za mamba.
explanation: Your crying is the compassion of a crocodile.
During the day a tree stump, at night a human being. Peaceful at daytime, but dangerous at night.
Even boiling water does not forget its natural frigidity. Leopards cannot change their spots. Cf. 2839.
The ape's tail never becomes detached from an ape. An ape's habits never change

Give it, don't be stingy, and don't let that person go to the market. Said to be used by the host as a secret sign to the servants that they are not to be lavish with provisions and hospitality to an unwelcome guest, to whom, at the same time, they wish to seem to be urging to greater lavishness

text: Mpishi asingizia moto, ikiwa chakula kimevia.
explanation: The cook blames the fire if the food is not well cooked. Cf. 4737.

text: 2841a. Na midomo ukitabasama na uchungu katika mtima
explanation: You are smiling with your lips but in your heart is bitterness. Cf. 2849.

citations.page: 1008. The double-mouthed snake bites and blows at the same time. Beware of the friend who flatters you - MM. The double-headed snake is supposed to bite and to blow at the same time so that the person who is bitten would not feel the pain

explanation: Kuuma ukivuvia, to praise someone with evil intent. Nduma kuwili, also the name of the blindworm which is popularly believed to have a mouth at either end. Cf. 2843.

A rat blows where it bites. Do not trust a flatterer. Also used of blowing on a sore place, to deaden the smart, and figuratively, of a person who, after using bitter, strong language, follows it up by a kind or gentle expression to take the sting out
The axe is burned, the handle remains. Cf. 2826, 2832.

text: Tamu ikizidi tamu, si tamu tena.
explanation: If sweetness is excessive, it is no longer sweetness. Overdoing something is not good.
When you see them they do not confess, will they when you only hear [about them]? Kaifa or kefa or kefu, much less, much more, not to mention - J. Kiri, confess or agree, give in.
Don't give me meat of the tongue. Don't just flatter me. Cf. 2848.
Do not put a turban of grass on my head. Do not flatter me.
A smile on the face, people are not good. Some who smile have in their hearts masses of mischief.
The appeal of having a blind eye is that the eye sinks in the cavity.

text: Wanipaka mafuta kwa nyuma ya chupa?
explanation: Do you rub me with oil with the back of a bottle? The oil is still in the bottle and the one who does the rubbing pretends to use oil, without touching the oil - MM. Said by people who think that they have been treated less than generously. Paka mafuta kwa mgongo wa chupa, to deceive, to cheat, to outwit somebody.

text: Watende wao, wakitenda wenzi wao iwe mwao.
explanation: We should not mind what they do, but if their companions do likewise, they raise an alarm
Noble people ought not to do what they forbid those who do it.
Where they bury one another there they chew one another. Instead of praying they start talking evil. Doing evil under the cover of piety. Said of somebody piously attending the burial of an enemy.
When [your] enemy falls, lift him/her up. Helping an enemy in trouble may make a friend.
One who does not wrong is not done wrong. Cf. 3013.
There is no one who does not make mistakes.
The one who does well, will be paid likewise.
A sparrow has no kindness. "A person of low class is not expected to be mild-mannered"
Even a leopard has a mother- or father-in-law. Even the most cruel and mannerless people have at least one person that they respect
A frog has no feathers. Don't be too demanding
A stick can break a bone, but not a vice. Brute force generally does not correct bad behavior, but patience and gentleness might.
Even the bowels are meat. Respect for all.

text: Haya imemaliza shamba langu la muhindi.
explanation: Shyness has consumed my corn field. I could not decline any request.
Kindness does not go bad.
Sympathy should not be spent on oneself.
A loving relationship should follow acts of kindness. Said to someone who is not grateful for a service. Ihsani or hisani, kindness. Cf. 2662.
Your kindness will not be lost.
The reward of kindness is kindness. A person who receives kindness should give kindness in turn. Jaza or jazaa, malipo, fadhili, zawadi, reward.
The heart's eye sees many things. The heart feels many things, some of which are visible and others that are invisible.

text: Jicho lako likikuonyesha masawi ya watu, sema: e, jicho wale wana macho vilevile.
explanation: When your eye shows you other people's immorality say, "Oh, Eye, those people have eyes too." Masawi or ubaya, uovu, ufisadi, uzinzi, immorality.
The sun makes it bad for my eyes. The sun obscures the eyesight. Too much of a good thing
Every pot has its lid. Cf. 2873.
Every good deed is an act of charity.
Every door has its own key. There is a correct way of doing things.
Every padlock has its own key
Every person has his/her person. Every human being needs a helper, a friend or a confidant who listens and helps in difficulties. Cf. 2861, 28731.
Every house has its door. Cf. 2873.

Every devil has its own baobab tree. Everybody has somebody to talk to freely and is in agreement with. People believe that devils live in baobabs. Mbuyu: the baobab or calabash tree, often of enormous girth in proportion to the height, producing a large nut, the hard shell of which is used for drawing water, and the kernel for flavoring food
A little kitten is not hit to the ground. This refers to the quality of perseverance in a cat; like a person who will not give in. Na'chi or na nchi, to the ground.
Giving service does no harm. A good deed is never lost.
The hen with eggs is left alive. Cf. 2880.

citations.page: 42. A stone is not thrown at a hen with chicks. It's foolish to destroy one's future profit, or one's descendants

explanation: To beg and to beseech, the crocodile is inexorable. Aggressive people have a heart of stone

text: Kusahau maudhi ndio njia nzuri ya kulipiza kisasi.
explanation: To forget a wrong is the best revenge. Because then you will have defeated the wrongdoer
Where good things go, there good things return from. Doing good is receiving good in return.

text: Lala uli simba. Amka uli ndovu.
explanation: Go to sleep like a lion, wake up like an elephant. The lion is a symbol of strength and anger; the elephant is a symbol of even greater strength and of regal temperate behavior. Let sleep cure your anger
That which is passed is allowed to pass - F. What has passed [long time ago] must be forgotten; let bygones be gone; forgive and forget

text: Maji hayapozi moyo ila yakiwa baridi.
explanation: Water does not cool off [refresh] the heart except if the water is cold. Good manners and words do.
A mother will feel pity for a mother. Because she knows the sufferings of a mother

citations.page: 106. Gentle matters conquer the strong person. Carefulness in all things conquers the powerful

explanation: Action taken with care, and well planned, will succeed.

text: Maneno ya mwendawazimu hayana maana, lakini ni maneno.
explanation: A mad person's words have no meaning, but they are still words. A person should be able to listen even to fools, for they have something to offer.
A dog does not look for a bone for its fellow-dog. Cf. 2528.
Your play is our death. From the story of children throwing stones at the frogs in the pond.
Good deeds never spoil. A good deed is not forgotten. Cf. 2862.
The good things go in hiding, the bad things come out in the open. The bad side of a person is often better known than the good side.
The banana tree is not planted in gravel in order to make it grow. Cf. 2905.

text: Mjinga ni mtu usinene ni ng'ombe.
explanation: A fool is a person too, don't say that person is a cow.

text: Mjua kutenda vyema, sambe viwi havijui.
explanation: The one who knows how to do good, don't say that this person doesn't know evil. Give a good person full credit for his/her generosity. Don't say: "That person knows no better"

text: Mkuki (or kigumba) kwa nguruwe kwa mwanadamu [wa] uchungu.
explanation: A spear [arrow] for a pig [is painful,but] is agony for a human being. So think twice about sticking spears or arrows into pigs in future

text: Mkuki kwa nguruwe matamu, una uchungu kwa binadamu
explanation: The spear for the pig is sweet, but for a human being it is suffering. Suffering of another does not hurt us as much as our own suffering. One who does not pity others assumes that nothing hurts them
One who does good things is paid back bad things. Said when people take advantage of one's goodness.
Bad things happen to a person who does good. Cf. 2883.
A benefactor is [like] a mother. Follows mother's example. The cha asks for a ki-noun (such as kifani or kifano).

text: Mtenda wema kwa watu atendea nafsiye.
explanation: People who do good to others do it [also] to themselves. Being polite and helpful will make people helpful and polite. The benefactor will be rewarded later
Treat your neighbor justly and honestly.

text: Mti wa kufa ngedere, miti yote huteleza.
explanation: The tree on which the ngedere died, causes all trees to be slippery [from weeping]. Ngedere or kima, small black monkey.

text: Mtu awafanyae watu mema, nae mungu humlipa mambo mema.
explanation: Someone who does good to others, God requites that person with good things too - T. Awafanyae or awafanyiaye, one who does to others.

text: Mwenye kumridhi mwenziwe, na mungu humridhi.
explanation: To a person gracious to fellow humans, God is gracious also.
A person is consumed by being kind.
The cassava plant does not send its roots down in stony soil. It does not thrive in stony soil. Nobody is supposed to do the impossible
Good people charm [others] by their nature.

text: 2905b. Mwenye kumridhi mwenziwe, na mungu humridhi.
explanation: God is gracious also to a person who is gracious to others.

text: Mwenye kutenda jamala, naye hulipwa jamala.
explanation: To the person who does kind things, kind things will be done.
If somebody covers the roof badly, throw up bundles of grass. Being kind to a person encourages doing well

text: Ndege njema, uenende ukale na vipofu.
explanation: Good luck [on your trip], go and eat with the blind. A wish for a good journey. Ndege njema. lit., good birds, as in travel under lucky stars. Ukale na vipofu, eat with the blind, because they cannot give you the evil eye. Cf. 2909.
The boat above, the wave below. Used as a wish for a good journey, or congratulations after a happy journey.
A cow that produces much milk does not last in the pen. A cow that gives much milk has a short life. A good person does not live long
Bring me flowers while I am still alive.

text: Nimekula asali udogoni, utamu ungali gegoni.
explanation: I ate honey in my childhood, and its sweetness is still in my tooth. A person often turns to childhood to recall the bliss and easy circumstances of life.
Doing good works kills. Cf. 2898.
I am sorry" comes from a merciful person. Pole, said to a person who is hurt.
Concern is like medicine.
Happiness has an end. Nothing is everlasting. Radhi, pardon, apology, blessing, contentment. Cf. 1224.
It is easy to be good if you are not provoked. Character comes to a test when provoked
Compassion is [like] a well.
One greeting gains another greeting.

text: Si lazima kuzimia taa ya mwenzio ili yako ionekane.
explanation: It is not necessary to blow out the other person's lantern to let yours shine.
Guidance is not easily found.
Hiding is to let the garment down - MM. Hiding a fault and letting down the raiment. Charitable concealment is seemly
The gratitude for goodness is insults. Do good without expecting good in return.
If you make yourself [like] honey all the flies will devour you
The tongue ever returns to the bad tooth. A good person tries to help the one in trouble. The bad tooth hurts. The tongue tries to still the pain.
The one to whom you lent [money], give respite when that person comes. Uliomkiridhia or uliomkaridhia. Muhula, space of time, period, interval.
Do not render evil for good.
If you get] bad food, you lick the platters! If [you were given] good food, how you would eat it! If you welcome bad things like that, how would you welcome good deeds?
Kindness [good deeds] never goes bad. They will receive their reward. It is like storing something. Even if you forget the good deed, the one who received your kindness will not forget
Goodness and kindness are stronger than harshness.
The one who thinks to know a lot, does not know anything.
One who studies goes on learning. No learning is a waste of effort
A person who is here in the world has not yet been totally created. A person goes on learning until death. A person is being formed [createdl as long as that person lives.

text: Asiyejua kitu, hawezi kujua thamani yake.
explanation: A person who does not know an object cannot know its value.

People who do not see by themselves, do not see [even] when it is shown to them. This is said of an intelligent adult who does not see the difference between good and evil, between justice and injustice, between politeness and rudeness
Whoever has no knowledge, let that person be taught and learn and thus follow [the rules].
One who does not ask a question learns nothing. Cf. 2968.
Business is arithmetic. Arithmetic is an essential tool in business. Hit and miss business is like a journey undertaken in the wilderness where there are no paths

text: Cha mkufunzi mwanafunzi hali na akila hufa: cha mwanafunzi mkufunzi hula na akila hafi.
explanation: A student does not eat [the food] of the teacher, and if a student does eat, that student will die; but if the teacher eats [the food] of the student, the teacher does not die. Used if a junior does not respect his seniors

text: Chakula kilicho mbali usipokipata, unaweza kupata kwa wengine.
explanation: Food out of reach, you can get it from others. By learning, knowledge.
A cerificate is a surety. Rank is a trust
A person's ceiling is the head. In many places the ceiling of the house is used as a store. A person collects a lot of ideas and preserves them in the head until called upon to use them
A person's value is the head.

text: Elimu bila amali, kama nta bila asali.
explanation: Knowledge without practice is like wax without honey.
Learning without practice is lost. Mtalaa, lessons, practice
Education has no end. One is never too old to learn.
Knowledge is the arbiter. "No judge or umpire can decide without knowledge"÷
Education is life, not books. You cannot learn all the things that matter in life from books.

text: Elimu ndio mwanga uongozayo kila shani.
explanation: Knowledge is the light that leads to everything wonderful. With intelligence one emerges from a difficult case
Learning is like an ocean.

text: Elimu ni kama bahari haina sahili.
explanation: Knowledge is like an ocean without shores.

text: Elimu ni kama bahari, haina kuta wala dari.
explanation: Science is like an ocean, it has neither walls nor a roof. The pursuit of learning is like a voyage for life: it will never end against a wall nor can the spirit be stopped when rising up

text: Elimu ni mali ambayo adui hawezi kuiteka.
explanation: Education is a possession that no enemy can capture.
Education cannot be stolen. Teka or chukua, twaa, to take.
Knowledge is like a lamp, it will shine everywhere.
Search for knowledge [even] in China, whenever you need it.
The advantage of knowing is following. "It is useful to know people's views and habits beforehand. So one can avoid giving offenses: good public relations"

text: Fimbo umpigayo mtoto yamfikia kwa ngozi, haifikii tabia yake mbaya.
explanation: The stick you beat the child with reaches its body, it does not reach its bad character. Physical punishment is most of the time inadequate
A fool learns by his troubles. It is because the fool did not listen to advice.
Light is the enemy of darkness. Ukweli utawapeni uhuru, the truth will set you free. Cf. 849, 3150.
A child should not be afraid of dew. Unpleasant things are character-forming.
Knowledge/wisdom is independent of age and color. All can acquire knowledge.
These sums are [easy like] a toothbrush. Said by students. Easy to make. Mswaki, a toothbrush made from a small tree-root.

text: Kama kungwi wandazi nipe changu kitumbua.
explanation: If I am a pastry teacher, give me a rice-fritter. When a student does not follow the rules that are taught, the teacher will use this proverb. It's a way of telling the student that a fault was made. It could also be used by the teacher to tell the student that a reward should be given to the teacher, which might be of more common usage.
Work is no good unless you have been taught the art. Kunga, secret, trick, device; private instruction.
A youth is like a twisted twig. Should be educated while young.

text: Kila mnyama hufundishwa na mizungu yake.
explanation: Every animal is taught by its instincts. Mizungu, instructions given during puberty or initiation.
Learning is imitating.

text: Kujua kidogo hatari kutojua kabisa usiku wa manane.
explanation: The danger in knowing a little is knowing nothing at midnight. Not knowing enough when needed. Usiku wa manane, midnight

In drying the palm nuts, the stone has dried also. The palm nuts are put on a stone or rock to dry, but also the stone on which the nuts were crushed is drying. Too many loveless admonitions disturb the child

text: Kula nyama ya mwalimu ni kula sumu.
explanation: To eat the meat of scholars is eating poison. Slandering a teacher is like eating poison. "Scholars, i.e. Islamic scholars, who teach the Koran, are holy men who must not be harmed"
The ability to read does not make a secretary. More is needed to be a good secretary.
Asking questions is not ignorance.
A questioner has knowledge. A student who asks questions learns more than one who does not; a wise person questions before beginning an enterprise.
Degrade yourself in order to know. Cf. 2937.
Life is the best teacher.
First there is darkness, then there is cleverness. An inexperienced person can become clever.
An old dog does not learn new tricks.
Teach the ignorant, open [the door of knowledge] that is closed.

text: Mkono kufunua usikie, mkono kufungwa hukusikia.
explanation: Understand the meaning of the open hand while you did not understand the meaning of the closed hand [fist]. One who is eager to learn will grasp any occasion. An open hand explains, but a closed hand does not.
The hand that raises the child rules the world. Education forms the child's future.

text: Mpumbavu alienda porini, akaokota tembo, akasahau njia yake.
explanation: The fool went into the forest, picked up an elephant, and forgot the way back. It is not enough to bear children, one must also educate them

text: Mtaka maarifa huwa rafiki wenye maarifa.
explanation: One who is after knowledge befriends people with knowledge.

text: Mto ulikunjama, sababu ulikosa mtu wa kuungoza.
explanation: The river meanders, because it did not have a guide. Poor education ends up with a good-for-nothing person.
A child starts crawling and that's how it may stand up.

text: Mtoto yatima hawezi kutanda wavu mrefu.
explanation: An orphan is not able to set a long net [to catch game]. Without education a child is not ready for life.
A scholar does not have hardship.

A chick is not taught how to scratch up the ground for food. Some things come naturally. Kifaranga,or mwana wa kuku. a chick Tony Hillerman writes about a "belagana", a busybody:"His mother would have called her in Navajo, 'One who tells sheep which weed to eat'." Skinwalkers, p.95 (N.Y.: Harper Perennial Library, 1988). Cf. 2980.
The young of a snake is not taught to bite.
One who has eyes is not told to look. Be alert, use all your gifts.
One who has a mouth gets no help in speaking. Someone who is able to do a job is not helped, but on the other hand, we should help those who cannot help themselves.
When the moon appears the stars disappear. The moon is the symbol of nobility and scholarship
The meat of scholars is poison. If you harm a scholar you will die. If you refuse to feed a scholar, the food that he ought to have received will be poisonous

text: 2981c. O! Akili na elimu zitakapo kukutana.
explanation: Oh! intelligence and knowledge when they meet!

text: Popo huning'iniza kichwa chini aone wafanyao ndege wengine.
explanation: The bat hangs with its head down watching the actions of other birds. It is better to observe or investigate a matter silently than ostentatiously to make a lot of noise about it
Donkeys that don't know each other first sniff each other.
The soul is a stranger. Is difficult to know.
In a field where peanuts were planted, there is no lack of young sprouts [after the harvest]. A good education leaves its marks.
Never stop studying so you may acquire wisdom.
Walk around and see for yourself, don't wait to be told. Cf. 3177.

text: Ujualo ni hazina ya maisha yako.
explanation: What you know is a treasure of your life.

text: Ujuzi bila vitendo ni ujinga, sio mwendo.
explanation: Knowledge without deeds is stupidity, it's not a life.
Knowledge never gets old. Ujuzi, knowledge, wisdom, sagacity, practical experience.
Knowledge is strength

text: Ukitaka kujifunza, mwishowe utashinda, ukichoka hupotea.
explanation: If you want to learn something you will succeed in the end, but if you give up, you will lose.
If you know this [side], that [side] you do not [necessarily] know. One cannot know everything: there is always more to learn. There is always someone who knows more about it.
What beats you is what teaches you. The misfortune that strikes you teaches you. Ukupigao + ukufunzao, the u and o refer to the noun msiba (misfortune), that is understood.
The night does not bring forth a comely child. Upbringing and education produces a child you can show off.
Go fishing with a fisherman who loves fishes
Those European articles don't end ignorance. One always has to learn more, even from strangers.
You know where you came from.
Time is a tutor. A person may not understand something the first time. But after living with it for a sufficient time, one may understand it
Two learned men will learn from each other. Hufundana or hufundishana.

text: 2999a. Watafutao elimu wako njiani kwa mungu.
explanation: The seekers of knowledge are on the path of God.
Things have happened to a person for knowing too much. To show off one's knowledge may get one into trouble. So, it is better to be humble
An enemy does not fall down when discarded. The enmity remains.
Love [your] enemy.

text: Adui mpende, kumchukia ni kumchukia ndugu yako.
explanation: Love [your] enemy, your hating is like hating your own brother.

text: Adui mpende leo, yawezekana mkawa rafiki kesho.
explanation: Love an enemy today; it is possible that you might become friends tomorrow.
A person who loves calls one-eyed a squint. Love thinks no evil. Love is blind. Lovers do not judge mistakes or faults harshly.
If one loves a one-eyed person, that person sees only a squint. Chongo : blind in one eye. Kengeza : squint or cross-eyed. A person in love mistakes a pimple for a dimple." Japanese proverb.
The person who hates you will not lack faults to put on you. Cf. #3.
Do harm to the one who harms you.
Do harm to the one who harms you, and fear the one who harms you not. A vicious proverb.

Do harm to the one who harms you, do not fear who harms you. An eye for an eye. Kumtenda has the special meaning of doing harm to someone; while kumtendea means doing good to someone. The same for kumfanya and kumfanyia. [Do evil to--do good to.
The person who cut your hair has also diminished [taken away the need of] combing. If one harms you, you are excused from being kind to that person.

The one who cut your curls took away your need of combing. Shungi: plait of hair, tress, crest, forlock. Said when someone took something away from you that you really did not need. A person who lost something not really needed is consoled in this way. Cf. #1271.
One who withholds pigeon-peas from me reduces my passing of wind.

The person who withholds lentils from a donkey, reduces its passing of wind. If someone refuses me a service, I don't have to show any gratitude, either. If someone denies you something, don't complain. Perhaps you escape other difficulties, such as paying a debt. This proverb can be used whenever assistance is not forthcoming.

The one who denies you beans helps you to escape bloating. If somebody denies you something that could harm you, even if you would have liked it, it's for your good, because it diminishes your trouble.
The one who denies me something reduces my pain. Simanzi (huzuni): pain, sorrow. Don't be sorry for lack of friendship that might bring chagrin. Cf. #1270 and #1272; # 1032.

text: Anipendaye nami nampenda: anikataaye, napunguwa simanzi.
explanation: The one who loves me, I also love; one who rejects me diminishes my grief. There are several similar proverbs, e.g., #1271, denoting a breaking off of a relationship. In this case, a relationship of love. Love and vulnerability go together. If someone does not love me, that person spares me grief.

text: Anipendaye, nami nampenda: anikataye, nami namkataa.
explanation: The person who loves me, I love too; the one who denies me, I deny that person too.
I love someone when that person loves me.
When a person loves (a garment), she'll sew it, if she does not like it, she'll tear it (even if new). Said of a critical person. No compromise. Easily applied to personal relationships.

People who are loved know it and do not stop showing it in their way of walking. People don't like to see that kind of behavior. So, don't show it. Kujishaua or kuringa: walk with a swagger, put on airs.

text: Asili ya huba, mwanzowe ni jicho.
explanation: The beginning of love is the eye.
A person who has no enemies is not a human being.
Please the one who does not please you. Do good to a bad person in order to make friends.
The one who agrees with you, agree with that person.
Do no harm to the person who does not harm you. cf. #1229, #1274, #1951.
The person who wants to beat a child will find a stick. That one will find a reason to do so.

text: Barua ya moyo husomwa juu ya panda la uso.
explanation: A letter from the heart can be read on the face. The face mirrors joy and sorrow. The heart's letter is read in the eyes. Panda la uso or kipanda cha uso: forehead. Sacl.

What the heart loves is what it wants. Good or bad, if the heart loves it, it will be good for the heart, like medicine. Mtima (poet.) or moyo: heart. Cf. #1290, #1290b Also Pamoyo pa mtima: If the heart loves a place, it's a good place for the heart.
If what is yours rots, you dry it over and over again. If your affairs go wrong, you try your best to rectify them for the better.
Even if your sore is putrefied, you don't smell the bad odor. You don't see your own bad behavior or that of your family and if you see it you don't hate is as other people do.
A dirty hand is cleaned, not cut. Cf #1306. #1300a.

text: Chozi la akupendaye hutoka kwenye chongo.
explanation: The tears of one who loves you will come even from a bad eye. A friend in need is a friend indeed.
Hate burns its preserver. Do not nurse hatred, it will hurt you.

text: Chuki kwa chuki, mwanga kwa mwanga.
explanation: Hatred for hatred, light for light.
The remedy for teeth is teeth. Tit for tat; a tooth for a tooth
The poison of a word is - a word. Cf #1282.
The cure against fire is fire. Fight fire with fire.
Suspicion is never good.
When the quarrel gets in the open, evil will grow. More people are getting involved. Dhihiri: to be evident, plain, clear. Kithiri: to increase, grow.
The disease of love has no cure. Love-sickness has no remedy. Love is blind and blinds.
There has never been mutual love without mutual respect.
Longing does not come without loving.
Enmity is like flames of fire. Enmity and rivalry bring troubles and fights.

text: Hasikii la mwadhini wala la mtia maji msikitini.
explanation: So and So does not listen to the muezzin nor to the one who puts water [for the ritual ablutions] in the mosque. JKP has mteka maji (fetcher of water), instead of Mtia maji. The person who puts water in the mosque.). A person totally absorbed in love, even neglecting religious duties.
Even a toothless lion does not please and remains hostile. Chujua: washing out color; pleasing.
It is better for the eye to die than the heart. Better blind than despairing.

text: Heri moyo mkubwa kuliko akili kubwa.
explanation: A big heart is better than a big brain. Love is better than knowledge. A person with a big heart is concerned about others; a man of knowledge may ignore them.
Respect is of the heart. Respect, like love, is a free gift. A person can be forced to obey, but not to respect.
How is one to love a person by being told [to] love someone. One cannot love on command; love is freely given.
You cannot bring back love or life. Understood: Once they have gone. Cf. #1324, #78.
When it rains, the one inside does not worry. A person who has a strong relationship or has a stable position will not worry about those who want to harm.

text: Ikiwa unawapenda watoto wa wengine, utawapenda wako zaidi.
explanation: If you love other people's children, you will love your own even more. Increased love for others will increase love for your own.

text: Johari bora ni mapenzi kuliko maisha yetu.
explanation: Love is a more precious jewel than life. Johari: jewel. Cf. #688.

text: Jongoo hupenda watu, na watu hawampendi.
explanation: The centipede pursues man and man avoids it. Man is afraid of the centipede and the latter likes to be indoors with people. This is said of somebody one does not really like, but cannot get rid of.

text: Kidole chako kibaya chaweza kufaa siku baya.
explanation: Your bad finger could be useful on a bad day. About a bad relative, etc.
Don't cut off your bad finger. Don't cut off a bad relative. Cf. #1306; #1289A.

text: Kijana mpende akilala, akiondoke mwumie chanda.
explanation: Love young people when they are asleep; if they gets out bite your finger for them. A child should never be shown excessive love.

text: Kinacholeta ugomvi duniani ni kugawanya fedha [nyama].
explanation: The cause of dispute in the world is the distribution of money [meat]. People need money, but they are never satisfied with it. Money is the root of all evil. For meat eaters the root of dispute is meat.
What the heart desires is like medicine to it. A little of what you fancy does you good.
What pleases the heart is medicine. Having a hobby is like a medicine.
What the heart loves is a cure for the soul.

text: Usiseme sitaki; kipendacho moyo ni dawa.
explanation: Don't say I don't want; on the contrary] what the heart likes is like a remedy.
What is loved is music for the heart. Ngoma: drum, dance, music. Cf. #1290.
What the heart likes is like fresh meat. A man prefers a young woman.

text: Kula nyama mbichi ni moyo kupenda.
explanation: Eating raw meat is a choice of the heart. It's unfair for those who do not like to eat raw meat to blame those who do. Don't blame people for liking things you don't like.
A slap of love does not hurt.
Same translation. Mpenzi: lover.
To fry a person in his/her own fat. Taking excessive advantage of someone's generosity and kindness, especially by cheating.

Someone fried the shark in its own fat. This proverb is used when somebody is giving some of a person's own medicine, e.g., a judge may tell a drunk who misbehaved while drunk not to drink; or a thief to pay back with his own property. Thonya.
Loving one another is feeding one another.
Loving each other is not the same as being similar in spirit. Lovers keep their own characteristics and should develop their own attributes.
Being deeply in love is a sickness that cannot be cured.
Victory makes a man popular, and to fall in love means to be conquered. RSP.
Something can be in the heart without being seen. What you do not see, you can remember in your heart.

text: Kwamba mimi ng'ombe ni bora, ningaligandamwa na kupe.
explanation: If to me a cow is good, do you think the ticks would bother me?

text: Kweli iwe katika upendo, na upendo katika kweli.
explanation: Truth should be in love and love in truth. Proper love is that which does not hide the truth from the loved one, and proper truth is that which is expressed in love without hatred or bitterness.

text: Mahaba ni tamu, mahaba ni sumu.
explanation: Love is sweet, love is poison. Verse of a song.
Love has its own hand. Love has its own time of coming.
Love kills.
Water does not boil if taken away from fire. Hostility and love end when not encouraged.

text: Mapendo kwa asiyekupenda ni sawa mvua porini.
explanation: To bestow love on somebody who does not love you is like rain falling on the uninhabited wilds. A waste of energy.
Love blinds.

text: Mapenzi hayana macho, wala hayana maarifa.

citations.page: , mapenzi has first half of proverb

explanation: Love has neither eyes nor understanding. Cf.#1933.

text: Mapenzi ni hakika, hupanda na kushuka
explanation: Love is real, it goes up and down.

Love is like a cough, it cannot be hidden. Amor tussisque non celantur, Love and cough cannot be concealed. The Cyclopaedia of Practical Quotations, Latin proverbs, p. 579. We know that there were early visitors to the east coast of Africa.

text: Mapenzi yakifa yazike na usiweke maua juu ya kaburi.
explanation: If love dies, burry it and don't put flowers on the grave. Get over it.

text: Mapenzi ya kiswibu wawili ndiyo mapenzi.
explanation: Love is love only when it affects both sides. Kiswibu or kisibu, conditional tense from sibu: affect, happen. Kuswibu is an old version of usibu. The word siba, from the Arabic, presents the difficulty of correct spelling in Swahili. The Arabic s is pronounced in two ways, like the English s and like the s sound which has no English equivalent. To differentiate the two sounds, some people add a w : sw.
Love of the [metal] cooking pot: off the fire it cools at once. Puppy love.
If one steps in excrement one does not cut off the foot. If a member of the family has gone wrong it is not a reason to repudiate that person. Cf. #1306.
Kiss the hand you cannot cut. Respect those who have authority over you, or they will destroy you.
The hand], which you cannot cut, kiss it.
If you cannot fight someone, join that person. It would be safer to be on that person's side. Work with the competition.
If your hand gets soiled, you do not cut it off. This means that if your relative errs, you should help so that that person may avoid any recurrence of the mishap.
The heart has no patience. First half of a verse.
The heart tells its grandfather. The heart tells the owner to do something. Babu: grandfather; here, the owner of the body.

text: Moyo hujua uchungu wa nafsi yake
explanation: The heart knows its own pain. Nobody else does.
The heart sees further than the head.
The heart is like a book. The human heart knows things that it never learned. Even the 'second sight' or the sixth sense (hisu ya sita) is believed to slumber in the heart.
The heart is deep.
The heart is like bile, if it changes still more it becomes clay. Either the heart is full of sad thoughts or it is like molding clay.
A pure heart is weapon enough
If the heart desires it will entice.
A loving heart has no equal.
A loving heart is not argued with. Someone in love will not listen to a harsh word about the beloved.

text: Moyo wa kupenda na kuwiza huwa
explanation: A loving heart can also reject. Can change to hatred.
The heart of love can also begin to hate. Impossible to commit to eternal love.

text: Moyo wa mwenzako ni tunda la chupa.
explanation: The heart of your friend is like the hole in a bottle. Difficult entering. We are ignorant of what goes on in the heart of a neighbor or friend. Cf. #.3084.

text: Moyo wa mwenzio tundu ya mwanzi hauingiliki.
explanation: The heart of your friend is like the hole in a reed, impossible to enter. Cf. #912; #1303b.
The lover of people is not loved by the people. A person who is kind to others is not necessarily loved by them. Cf. #1289.
Love your brother.
Love the one who loves you. Also the first line of a love song.
A lover has no grudge. One does not criticize a friend Love thinks no evil.
A person if loved, should love. When someone is loved that person should love in response.
When a child dirties your thigh, [the thigh] is not cut off. Against undue resentment, senseless spite, etc., such as would most of all harm the person that exhibits it.
The palm of the hand a child dirtied is washed, not cut.
When a child dirties your arm you don't throw it away. Kiwiko: wrist.
A person who nurses vengeance is not called wise.
Someone in love is drunk. Ishiki=ashiki: strong desire, affection, usually of sexual desire.

text: Mwenye kuja na baridi usimpe moto
explanation: To one who comes to you cold-heartedly, don't give warmth. Don't show that person kindness. That kind of attitude inspires defiance.

text: Mwenye kupenda ni jura, wala hana maarifa.
explanation: One who loves is a fool and has no understanding. Love makes fools, and takes away all wisdom.

text: Ndugu akipenda kuwa sumu hajali mali wala uhai.
explanation: If a relative becomes poisonous, that person does not care about wealth or life.
When brothers quarrel separate them. The meaning is that you do not quarrel or fight them, because then they might turn against you.

Baboons long to make love in the trees. One must be content with little; baboons do not even have a house for privacy; the other meaning is contemptuous: only baboons would make love in the open air. RSP.

text: Pato la mahaba, ni haba ni haba
explanation: The gain of love is little, is little. Give and take.

text: Pendo lisilo na kitu, katu halibainiki
explanation: Love without a thing [i.e., gifts and presents] does not become evident at all.
There where is trouble put money. It will cost money. Indirectly: Money is the cause of trouble. Rupia: a rupee.

text: Penzi la kujitolea ndilo penzi la daima
explanation: Love of self-renouncing is an eternal love.
Love is like a flower, it must be watered. Take care of it.
I'm sorry is an excuse although weak. A bad excuse is better than none at all.

text: Radhi hafifu ni bora kuliko kutokuomba radhi kabisa
explanation: A weak excuse is better than no excuse at all.
Forgiving is victory. A person who forgives has mastered the force of hate.
The blessing of a person is reconciliation after a quarrel. Masilahi: 1. reconciliation, agreement 2. price after bargaining, profit.
Do not follow someone who does not love you. Sandamane = usi-andamane: do not join Ambao = ambaye: who.
Forgiviness is given three times. Koran.
It is not I, it is the heart. It is not my fault, it is my heart that loves you.

text: Songolea si mkuki, kutongoza si kuowa.
explanation: A hunting-pole is not a spear, to seduce is not the same as marrying. One has not the same rights over a mistress as over one's wife, and when one would make similar claims, the mistress would make that clear.
The poison is in the tail. After a nice relationship one discovers that someone tries to harm you.
The poison for a word is a word.
Give more love than you receive. Love many even those who do not love you. Kindness is one commodity of which you should spend more than you receive.
If we love each other very much, we cause each other much distress.

text: Tumekwisha kunywa kahawa, machicha ya mwenye ndoa.
explanation: We have drunk the coffee; the grounds are for the husband. This is said by paramours upon the return of the woman to her husband.

text: Ubaya ukiingia mlangoni, wema hutoroka dirishani.
explanation: When evil enters the door, goodness escapes through the window. When evil enters a loving family, that lovely relationship disappears.

text: Ukali wa chui lakini watoto wananyonya.
explanation: The leopard may be fierce, but the pups are sucking.

text: Ukimpiga kuku wamtafuta mwenye kuku huyo.
explanation: If you hit another's chicken, you find the owner of that chicken [and have a quarrel].

text: Ukimtaka baniani umtake na ubinda wake
explanation: If you like a Baniani, you must like his loincloth too. The meaning is that if you like somebody you must take that person as is. Baniani or Banyani: Hindu; Indian tradesman or craftsman. Ubinda: a type of loincloth worn by some Indians in East Africa. Cf. #322.
If you love blood, love pus too. If you love people in health or wealth, love them also in sickness and poverty. Cf. #1317.
If you love, love what is yours.
If you cannot cut the stone lift it. Give it a place of prominence. Cf. #1300; #1321.

text: Ukiumia kwa kisu chako wewe mwenyewe, huwezi kukitupa
explanation: If you hurt yourself with your own knife, you can't throw it away. Blame yourself, not the knife. One is more tolerant towards one's own.
Brotherhood is greater than friendship.
Where you like it, is where you must go. RSP.
If you have no big knife, kiss your enemy. Cf. #1300.
Two things cannot be loved at the same time. The heart loves only one thing at a given time.

text: Wa mtu mtima, u kama kisima
explanation: The heart of a human being is [as deep] as a well.

You know that sweetness kills, why have you given me poison? Your love for me, your attentions, will kill me, so no need to look for poison. Said of a wife or close friend who by overdoing their attention cause the person to want to run away. "Please go away peacefully.

text: Wajua tamu ya ua sumu umenipiani
explanation: You know the sweetness of a flower, why then give me poison?

text: Wema hauwezi kuepuka meno ya kusudi.
explanation: Goodness cannot escape the teeth of envy.
The ancient things are with us no longer. Let bygones by bygones.
The intoxication of love is the worst disease. Ndweo, kiburi, majivuno: pride, arrogance. Upeo: horizon, ultimate.

text: Afadhali kuwa na jirani mchawi kuliko mwongo.
explanation: It is better to have a wizard as a neighbor than a liar. A liar cannot be trusted; a wizard, though dangerous, can be trusted.
One who speaks the truth is loved by God.
Saying a lie abuses your companion. Hurts friendly relationships.
One who is absent will not be a liar. One not associating with liars is not counted as one.

text: Binadamu ni waongo, hata mwizi hawezi kukubali ni mwizi.
explanation: Human beings are liars, even a thief denies being a thief.

text: Habari ya uwongo ina ncha saba.
explanation: A false story has seven endings. It can be told in many ways. Like a snowball grows as it rolls along.

text: Habari ya kweli ina ncha moja.
Hakuna akweaye mbuyu na viatu miguuni
explanation: Nobody can climb a baobab tree with shoes on his feet. Truth and falsehood do not go together. The liar will fall down.
Knowledge does not defeat the truth.
Free translation: It is better to see than to hear. It is better to be an eye-witness then a [hearsay] witness.

text: Kinywa cha mzee kina harufu, lakini hakisemi uwongo
Katika kinywa cha mkubwa muna haruu, hakuna uwongo.
explanation: The mouth of an elder may have an offensive smell, but has no lie. The truth can be hard to hear or to admit.
Seeing is believing.
Dreaming is not the same as witnessing.
Speaking the truth is no disgrace.
Telling the truth is a [God-given] gift.

text: Kusifiwa si kuona, shani nda kuionea.
explanation: Being praised is not seeing, a wonder becomes evident when one sees it.
Hearing is not seeing. Do not believe all you hear; investigate. Hearing and seeing is twofold.
Hearsay is not arrival.
The truth is bitter.
Truth hurts.
Buy the truth, but don't sell it.
Speak the truth when it is appropriate.
Bitter truth is better than a sweet lie. To tell the truth can be painful and the one who tells the truth may not be loved by others. A lie may please, but it brings doubts in people's minds.
When the truth appears, untruth hides itself.
Where truth stands, falsehood must yield.
When truth arrives, falsehood yields.

text: Kweli iliyo uchungu, si uwongo ulio mtamu.

explanation: If truth is bitterness, falsehood is an outlaw [is forbidden].
The truth, even though bitter, tell it me, and do not hide it from me. Said of people who want the truth so they can change their ways.
Truth is the walking stick to grasp. Truthfulness is the best help in life.

text: Macho ya mbwa hayazuii mwanaume kula.
explanation: The eyes of a dog do not prevent a man from eating. Truth has nothing to be afraid of; the caravan passes by while the dog barks.
Giving explanation is not the same as bearing witness.
Things are not as you see them.
The one who ate the poison did not die, the one who died was the one who prepared it. Slander often backfires.
A person who plants deceit harvests poverty.
One who tells the truth makes no mistakes. Cf. #1343.

text: Msema kweli hukimbiwa na marafiki zake.
explanation: One who tells the truth is deserted by friends. Flattery brings friends, truth enemies.

text: Msema kweli yu mpenzi wa watu.
explanation: One who speaks the truth is loved by the people.  Cf.#?

text: Msema (msemaji) kweli yu mpenzi wa Mungu.
explanation: One who speaks the truth is beloved by God.
A person who speaks alone cannot go wrong.

One who speaks alone does not break a law. Everybody pulls the law to his own side. Give both parties a fair chance to explain their case. Used, e.g., by parents when their children accuse one another.
One who speaks in private [when alone] will not get rid of mistakes.
One who reads alone does not get rid of his mistakes.
One who talks to himself does not offend anybody.
An honest man has no debt.
Rain is what hits you. Investigate for yourself.
The illegitimate baby was put in a jar, but its finger stuck out. A sin always comes out, even if you try to kill it.
A liar does not inspire trust.
Searching someone is better than locking that person up. Give people under suspicion a chance to clear themselves.
Searching someone is better than harming that person. Cf. #37.
The person who found the small cooking pot is the cook. A person who started the lies implicating somebody is the one who did it in the first place.
A tale has seven endings [variations]. Cf. #1327.

text: Pori moja fundi akienda kuua mbogo, lazima alete mkia wake.
Mwindaji akiua mbogo porini, lazima alete mkia wake.
explanation: If a hunter kills a buffalo in the bush, he must bring back a tail. Truth must have its evidence.

text: Sema kweli, ishi kweli, peponi utawasili.
explanation: Speak the truth, live rightly, in Paradise you will arrive. From a song.
Never give up what you have seen for what you have heard.
Travel and see for yourself; what they tell contains falsehood. Traveling shapes a person.
Travel and look. Travel and learn.
Travel and observe; grow up so you may see that. See also the heading "Experience.

text: Ugali ni tepetepe, hata alipika mama.
explanation: The [stiff] porridge is too soft [watery], even if it is the mother who cooked it. A misdeed is a misdeed, even when committed by a parent.
The fierceness of the fire is [caused by the fact that someone] stoked it up.
The truth has no hiding place. Truth will come out in the open.
The truth does not have only one way. The truth can be told in many ways.
Truth lives for a long time.

text: Ukweli ni kisu chenye ukali pande mbili
explanation: Truth is like a two-edged knife. Truth can be hard for both parties.
Truth [causes] bitterness, but it [comes] from God.

text: Ulimi mtoa uwongo hauvumilii: una machukizo kwa mungu.
explanation: A lying tongue has no patience; it bears God a grudge. One accuses God of the harm caused by one's own lies. A lying tongue is unbearable; is hated by God.
You have a lie, you have a road. A lie to save one's face.

text: Usiseme kuna mamba mtoni kama hujavuka.
explanation: Don't say there is a crocodile in the river if you have not yet crossed that river. Don't affirm what you do not know for sure.
Lying blesses not.
Lying is like running on a smooth [flatl roof. Cf. #1154.
Cheating does not work.

text: Uwongo wa mganga ni nafuu ya mwele, ni mwele kupona.
explanation: The lie of a witch doctor is a relief to the sick person. It cures the sick. Even the lies of a witchdoctor are relief to the sick one.

text: Uongo wa mganga, [ndiyo pona ya mgonjwa].
explanation: The lie of the doctor [cures the sick].

text: Uwomgo wa mnyapara si kweli ya kibarua.
explanation: The lie of an overseer is stronger than the truth of the day laborer. An overseer is trusted more than a laborer, even when telling a lie.

text: Uwongo wa mwenye nyumba si ukweli wa mpita njia.
explanation: The lie of the householder has more value than the truth of a passerby.
Liars should have a good memory. In order to remember the tales they invented.

text: Waweza kuwadanganya wakubwa siyo wadogo zako
explanation: You can deceive adults, but not your little ones.
When fear enters, truth escapes. A person who is threatened and becomes afraid may lie.
The custom is to show the way to a stranger.

text: Ada ya mja, hunena: mwungwana ni kitendo.
explanation: There are two different translations  1. Public opinion maintains: "A gentleman is judged by his actions.
A gentleman is deeds [not mere words].
Good manners is civilization.

text: Adabu si adhabu, faida yake yaonekana mtoto akuapo.
explanation: Good manners is not a punishment, the good of it is seen when a child grows up. Used to stop a child short when it objects to rules of conduct.
One who comes must call
The invitation is

text: Ajaye bila ya kadi huondoka pasi na kuaga.
explanation: The one who comes without a card leaves without saying good bye.
Don't scrutinize the person who arrives. Cf.#?
If you invite yourself bring your own chair. Behave humbly. Cf. #1367.
When angry that person shouts, and when tired, complains. A moody person.

text: Anayekuja pasi na hodi, huondoka pasi na kuaga.
explanation: Who comes in without "May I come in," leaves without "Goodbye. About a person who comes without a warning. A person without manners is incorrigible.

text: Anayewahi au achelewaye kwa mtemi huambua mzoga.
explanation: A guest who arrives early at the chief's courtyard or leaves late removes a dead body. Being dead tired of all the extra work that person is asked to do. Know when to come and when to leave. It's not good to put yourself forward. This is said of those who come early or late.
Pardon me" is not an insult.
A person who has no manners does not care about others. Lack of manners shows contempt for others. Cf.#?

text: Asiyefunzwa na mamaye, hufunzwa na ulimwengu.
explanation: A child who is not taught by its mother will be taught by the world. If a child is not taught good manners by its parents, it will have to learn them in the school of hard knocks.
A child who is not taught by its mother will be bruised by the world.

text: Asiyefunzwa na wazazi atafunzwa na dunia.
explanation:
Those who are not taught [manners] by their parents, will be taught by the world. 
 Cf. #418, #419.

text: Atambaaye na nyasi mtambulie ni nyoka.
Fanya heshima kwa wazee hata kama si wako
explanation: Honor the elders, even if they are not yours.

text: Farasi huenda kwa hatamu; punda huenda kwa mchapo.
explanation: A horse obeys the bridle, a donkey goes when hit. Different methods, same results.
Lost respect is like a broken egg. It cannot be repaired.
Respect is free. It does not cost anything to honor a person.
Courtesy is to respect each other
All right" and "thank you" does not cause disagreement. Civility does not cause disagreement. Civility costs nothing but is worth much. F.
Correct yourself before you correct others. If you are not a perfect example, others will not follow you nor listen to you.
A rooster does not crow in a strange environment. Cf. #1637; #883.
Behave yourself.

text: Kama si kizuri usifanye, kama si kweli usiseme.
explanation: If it is not nice don't do it, if it is not true don't say it.
Welcome is a courtesy, not [an invitation to] eating. It does not mean that one is invited to a meal.

text: Ada ya nchi kwa wenyewe ni sheria.
explanation: A country's customs and traditions are laws for the inhabitants. A country's culture and all that goes with it, should be respected. MM.
To look at a hidden thing is not proper.

text: Kiti cha mkewe si cha kukalia
explanation: The chair of the housewife is not for sitting on. Don't interfere with other people's business. A chair has a special value in most cultures.

text: Kitwitwi akishindwa kumwaga mgeni, anaugua wazimu.
explanation: If the sandpiper is unable to say goodbye to his host, [its excuse] is that it is suffering from hallucinations. Somebody looking for an excuse in breaking the rule of good manners.
Paying respect is not the same as being afraid. Cf.#975.
It does not harm to be of service. Said by one who offers to help.
Judging is judging oneself. When you judge another person, you are also judging yourself for you are showing your stand.

text: Kuku anakula kadiri ya mdomo wake.
explanation: A chicken eats according to its beak. Avoid exaggeration. Cf. #147; #232.
A chicken does not crow in the presence of a rooster. One should keep one's place.
To bother one another is not a thing a free man does. It is not a good thing to cause trouble for another.
Politeness is not slavery. Being polite does not necessarily mean servitude or base flattery.
Gratitude is not servitude.

text: Mbwa hata awe wa kizungu, haachi kunusa vyombo.
explanation: Even a European dog does not leave sniffing pots.
A dog always sniffs the pots. Comes naturally.
Among people a dog does not speak. It's better not to interfere in other people's business.

text: Mchama ago hanyeli, huenda akauya papo.
explanation: Delicately translated by F: "A traveler does not make a mess where he makes camp as he might one day come back to the same place".
Do not do your call of nature in the camp. Cf. #610.
One who follows the rules will profit by them.
A stranger cannot see the moon. A stranger is not able to know the customs of the inhabitants. A stranger is ignorant until settled. A visitor cannot give advice.
A stranger does not see the moon. Possibly the moon may stand for rites to be observed.
Stupid people do not know where they come from.
You will talk in daytime, at night you will sleep. This is not only a general rule of conduct, but also, take counsel with your pillow.

text: Mtoto wa kuku, kausha mdomo ule.

explanation: Born here" is the sensible slave.

text: Mwana mtumishi hula chake na cha mwenziwe
explanation: A child sent on an errand eats its own food and its companion's. A messenger usually benefits from errands made.

text: Mwana msikizi hula chake na cha mwenziwe.
explanation: The obedient child eats its own [food] and its companion's.
A kid [of a goat] sweeps where it sleeps. Its tail sweeps the place before lying down.
One who squats [call of nature] is not ashamed. One must tolerate human needs.

text: Mwenye kufuama haoni haya, kefu yule mwenye kuangalia
explanation: One who squats is without shame, but the one who stares at that person should be ashamed. Natural needs are human, but also secret.

text: Mwungwana asiye ari kama ng'ombe asiye na pembe
Mwungwana hanuni kwa masmavu, hununa moyoni.

explanation: I hold a tradition where there is no choice.

text: Ndiyo, ndiyo, jua lako, usijue ya mwenzako.
explanation: Indeed, know your problems, don't try to know those of your friend.

text: Ni lipi lisilo nduguye na mwamu wake?
explanation: What [affair] is there that has not its in-laws?

text: Nilimwona mnyama katika makundi, kenda kamwegema; kanipiga pindi.
explanation: I saw an animal in a herd [in a crowd], I went [I tried] to make acquaintance; it went away like a snake (turned its back on me).
The he-goats greet each other with their horns.

text: Shitaka kwa nyani au kwa ngedere hukumu moja.
explanation: The judgment of a case submitted to an ape or a monkey is the same. People of the same kind give a similar judgment or answer.

text: Sionje haramu kwani ni kama sumu.
explanation: Don't taste anything forbidden [like adultery], it is like poison.
Character is like one's skin. One cannot change one's skin. It is equally hard to change one's character.

text: Tabia ya mtu ni kia cha mwili.
explanation: The character of a person is like a joint of the body
Are you a child or a grit? Don't you hear at all? Are you altogether shameless?
What shall they do to a grit for it ever to become soft?
The filth of your relative does not cause you to vomit.

text: Ujinga huo wa kuacha kinywa kutia puani.
explanation: This stupidity of removing your finger from your mouth and putting it in your nose. In society the rules of good behavior are to be observed.

text: Ukenda kwa wenye chongo, [nawe] vunja lako jicho.
explanation: When you visit one-eyed people, destroy also your own eye. One must howl with the wolves.

text: Ukenda kwa mwenye chongo, nawe fumba lako jicho.
explanation: If you go visiting a person with one eye, you better close also one eye.

text: Ukikaa mji wa mwenye chongo, nawe vunja lako jicho.
explanation: If you live in a village of a one-eyed person, destroy also one of your eyes.
If you go to Pemba, you should wear a turban. Cf.#289 Waarabu wa Pemba...
If you go to Rome, do as the Romans do.

text: Ukienda usiage, ukirudi u mgeni wa nani?
explanation: If you leave without saying goodbye, coming back who will invite you?

text: Ukikaa na simba, vaa ngozi ya mamba.
explanation: If you live with a lion, wear the skin of a crocodile.

text: Ukila pamwe na namiri, igiza zao desturi.
explanation: If you eat with the leopards, imitate their habits.

text: Umekaa kama ngawa, kwani huna mazoea.
explanation: You behave like a civet-cat, don't you know how to behave? Said of someone who does not associate with others.

text: Usichekelee mbwa kuchutama, hujui ukao wake.
explanation: Don't laugh at a dog squatting, don't you know that it is his normal pose. Don't judge others.
Don't mock the little joke of your in-law.

text: Usiwe joka la mndimu, hatundi hatikizi watundao.
explanation: Do not be like the lemon tree snake: it does not pick the fruits nor does it tolerate the pickers.

text: Usiwe kidoa cha kuharibu nguo za wenzio.
explanation: Don't be a stain spoiling the clothes of your companions. Said of people who are envious of others and do not maintain the standards of the group.

text: Vijana hawana hekima, hisana wala kupendana.
explanation: Children have no wisdom, kindness, or love. They have to learn all those.
The people with objections are unbreakable. There always will be objections.
If the natives eat rats, eat rats.
You can [say] Stay, you cannot [say] Get out.

text: Afadhali kufa vitani kuliko kufa mtumwa.
explanation: It's better to die in the war than to die as a slave.
The one who sits on the stool must be obeyed. Said of a man invested with authority. Kigoda: stool, traditional seat on which a man of respect and authority sits.
When a great person blunders, a junior person is punished. A scapegoat.
Fear the one who is stronger than you.

text: Aliye juu yu juu : mbwidi haliwina funo.
explanation: The one who is above is above: a beast of prey is not eaten by the

text: Aliye na nguvu hula, dhaifu hulipa.
explanation: The mighty feasts, the poor pays.

text: Aliyekalia kiti cha enzi ndiye mtawala.
explanation: The one who sits on the throne is the ruler. The one who possesses an article at the time is the owner.

text: Aliyekupa wewe kiti ndiye aliyenipa kumbi.
explanation: The one who gave you a chair is the same who gave me a coconut husk [to sit on]. Do not despise me. I occupy the station God gave me, just as you do.

text: Aliyekupa wewe kiti, mimi kaninyima kumbi.
explanation: The one who gave you a chair, refused to give me a coconut husk.
The one who put you on a chair, is the one who put me down. The one who put you high up in rank has put me below. Cf. #1482; #449.
If they climb high up and fall they break.

text: Amefanyaye kafara na dawa ili awe na bwana, mwisho wake hulemewa na mazito kujaliwa.
explanation: Somebody made an offering of an amulet and medicine in order to be with the master, at the end that person will be overloaded with all the things granted.
The one who stands will not start running before he is chased away. It is not easy to dislodge a dignity once he is in power.

text: Atangazaye mirimo, si mwana wa ruwari.
explanation: The one who allocates the tasks is not [necessarily] the son of the headman.
The sardine also employs the shark.
The sign of Sheikh-hood is a turban. The headgear has thus become a sign of work and station in life.
The prayer of the chicken does not seize the hawk. Something more has to be done than praying. One suggested that being heard by God depends on your status with God. Prayer in Islam
The prayer of the hawk does not get the chicken. Prayer alone is not enough, one must act in order to obtain what one desires.

It's shameful to be ruled. To be ruled rob people from their essential qualities of being human, i.e. to make their own decisions. This applies to parents as well as their growing and grown-up children. But one can also be ruled by bad habits.
No chief is a bachelor.

text: Hata mtumwa alipata kuwa mtoto wa mtu
explanation: Even a slave has once been somebody's child. Even a slave once tasted parental love. This is said to remind a person to treat a servant as well as any other person.
That [sin] can be wiped out, this one cannot be wiped out. A common expression in the mouth of women when scolding their slaves; as though to say, "It is no venial sin if you disobey my orders.
That's the way it is, isn't it? This is often said when managers get all the praise and money, while the contributions of others are not considered.

What is full will be diminished. A person in charge should not be sad or angry if attacked, accused or spoken ill of. It is because people want to make a person in charge smaller. Or if a person is good, they want to smear that person.

text: Jicho la mkubwa ni jicho la tai
explanation: The leader's eye is like an eagle's eye. A leader sees many of the things in the sector overseen.
A master's eye makes a slave fat. Every person likes to be recognized by people in charge.
The rooster does not crow without permission.

A big cock does not allow a small one to crow. A big rooster wants to keep its prestige. A small one will be disciplined. A bigger person can oppress a smaller one, who may be able to do as good a job.

text: Jongoo, kunja mkia, wazuri wapite mbele.
explanation: Centipede, curve your tail and let the beautiful people pass by. Little people should not be pretentious.
Only few can sit on a platform. The top positions anywhere are few. Cf. #335.
If the headman hurts (offends) you, smile. The
It is up to the [school] master to give permission.

text: Kambara anapotembea na "mpenda kula","mpenda kula" anakula mavi mengi.
explanation: When the catfish goes walking with the Glutton-fish, the Glutton-fish will eat a lot of excrements. The little ones get only the left-overs from the big ones.

text: Kidole cha mkubwa kilimpatia mbuzi mimba.
explanation: The finger of the headman has made the goat pregnant The experience of a superior proves to be effective.
A young chicken cannot fill the pot. An inferior usually cannot take charge.

text: Kijacho na maji, cha mwenye mji.
explanation: What is brought along by the water belongs to the chief. What comes with the water is appropriated by the chief. Flotsam and jetsam includes not only wood, but also ambergis.
Greatness gone bad is a sore. People in power being corrupt is a sore, it harms the whole community.
Wherever the lion enters it carries the goat away. The lion always wins. The powerful person or ruler will collect taxes at will, or carry away your daughter.
Every group has its own leader.
Every authority originates from God.

text: Kila mmoja ni mfalme nyumbani mwake.
explanation: Every person is a ruler at home.

text: Kila mtu akae kwa cheo chake.
explanation: Let every person stay in his or her rank.
The heel follows the foot. A servant must follow wherever the master wants the servant to go

text: Kivuli cha miti mingine hustwisha, cha mingine hukausha.
explanation: The shade of some trees is healthy for the undergrowth, while that of others dries it up. Some bosses favor the growth of the juniors, while other discourage them.

text: Kivuli cha mvumo huwafunika walio mbali.
Vuli la mvumo humfunika alo mbali.
explanation: The shadow of the
A big tree develops a big shadow. Cf. #324, #1430.
The tortoise does not bite the leg of a leopard. Revolt against authority is dangerous. Don't insult a strong man.

text: Kondoo wawili hawawezi kunywa pamoja kwenye chungu kimoja.
explanation: Two sheep cannot drink out of the same pot at the same time. Their heads are too big. Only one leader can lead at the same time.
The place of one's coat is on one's back. Everything has its place.
Is giving orders the same as enabling?

text: Kuku hali anakwenda akila ameisha hukumiwa afe.
explanation: Although the chicken is going on eating, it is already condemned to die. Little people don't know what the ruling power has in mind for them.
The chicken is no match for the knife. It is the earthen pot against the iron pot.
Can a fowl fight a knife? Cf. #1424.

text: Kuna chuma cha suwezi, hushindana na sukuo?
explanation: Is there iron from Suez, that can fight the grindstone? Of useless resistance against superior forces.

text: Kwa kukaukani, maji visimani, hata mfalume, kiu kimuume.
explanation: When the water in the wells dries up, even the king suffers from thirst. In time of dearth even the king loses his rights.

text: Kwa simba fisi huinama: ya simba fisi hula nyama.
explanation: For the lion the hyena bows [and so] the lion's food it eats.
Among the blind one-eye rules.

text: Kwa vipofu, mwenye chongo huwa [ni] mfalme.
explanation: Among the blind one-eye is king.

text: Macho ya vyura hayamzuii mteka maji kuteka.
explanation: The toad's eyes don't stop a water-drawer from drawing water. Words and warnings of small people don't stop big people to do their things. Cf. # 1417a.
The floods make their own path.

text: Mali ya mjomba si ya mpwa.
explanation: The property of the (maternal) uncle is not going to the nephew/niece. Don't count on help from others.
The dying king forgets his authority.

text: Mbiu ya mgambo ikilia ina jambo.

explanation: The dog dies, but its bell remains. Power is transferred to the successor, another hunting dog will carry the bell.
The mouth of a dog is held tight by the owner. A dog does what its owner wants.
The dog of the chief is also a chief. Receives the honor of a chief: respect, food.

text: Mfalme akifanya biashara, raia watakuwa maskini.
explanation: If the king goes into business the citizens will become poor.
A king is not honored in his own country.
From a short banana tree one cuts the leaves. It is usually the little and meek person who carries the burden.

text: Milio ya vyura haiwazuii ng'ombe kunywa maji.
explanation: The cries of the frogs do not stop the cows from drinking water. Who is bothered by the cries of a frog? Mindful of a Native American proverb: A frog does not drink up the pond in which it lives. Cf.#3355.
A person who is with you should listen to you.
A messenger must not be slain. The messenger is innocent and must be respected.

text: Mkoba haungeharibika hungetembea na furushi mkononi.
explanation: If your shoulder bag were not broken you would not walk with a bundle in your hand. The inferiors suffer when their chiefs are becoming worthless.
The arm of the government is long. Cf. #1411.
The leader is greater than you.
The great one is on top. A powerful man always wins.
The cry of the frog, whom will it harm? The frog is considered a funny, defenseless animal, a symbol for a cuckolded man.

text: Mnyonge kupata haki ni mwenye nguvu kupenda.
explanation: The poor's right depends on the liking of the powerfull.

text: Mnyonge hupata haki na mwenye nguvu kutaka.
explanation: A poor person usually receives rights as a gift, but the powerful just takes them. Power is stronger than right and money is all-powerful.

text: Moto ni mtumishi mwema, lakini bwana mbaya.
explanation: Fire is a good servant, but a bad master.
Let the strong man pass by.

text: Mti wa kimo chako hauwezi kukupa kivuli.
explanation: A tree of your height cannot shade you. A person with the same ability as yourself cannot help you in matters which require greater ability than you have.

The one who cuts the hair on the head. This is said of chiefs: they don't know the day they will be dismissed. When someone tresses the hair of somebody, who will not know what kind of hairdo he or she will get?

text: Mtoto akipanda juu ya mti, chini yuko mkubwa.
explanation: If a child climbs in a tree, there is an adult below. One who is protected will take risks.

text: Mtu mmoja hawezi kutumikia mabwana wawili.
explanation: A person cannot serve two masters.

text: Mtumbwi uheshimu maji na maji yaheshimu mtumbwi.
explanation: May the dugout canoe respect the water, and the water respect the canoe. About the mutal respect of employer and employee, superior and inferior. Cf. #1233.
A slave values his master's goods. He takes care of them.

text: Muko ndani ya koko, vishindo vya mwenye nyumba.
explanation: You are still in the bush: triumph of the mistress of the house. Freely: "Concubine: the first lady always conquers.

text: Mungu tusalimu kodi, mayumba hayana vitu.
explanation: May God preserve us from taxes; even the big houses [the rich families] have nothing left.
If the ridge pole leaves the roof, the other poles fall aside. Without a chief there is disorder and failures.
A ruler cannot sleep.
The hunter also is hunted.
A gentleman is not pushed. He moves freely.
A free person does not abandon an old piece of clothing. One does not easily discard an object one is used to. It is hard to abandon customs, habits, pleasures.
A coconut cannot compete with a stone. A junior cannot beat a senior.

text: Ndege tele katika mti, mwenye midomo mekundu ndiye mkubwa.
explanation: There are many birds in the tree, but the chief is the one with a red beak.
If I were at home, I would be a king.

text: Nyumba kwa kuwa na nguvu, lazima iwe na mwamba
explanation: A house in order to be solid needs a ridge pole. In order to keep a family or a society strong it needs a head.
Hair is carried by the head. Hair on the head is hair. Hair needs the head in order to be hair. Used for people, who depend on others being in order to exist or to do a job. Dependency.

text: Nywele ziliheshimu uso, uso ukaziheshimu nywele
explanation: Hair respects the face, and the face respects the hair. Superior and inferior respect each other, etc.
The hair has grown and was afraid of the face. The inferior must stay within certain limits.
Locusts have no chief. Nobody controls them from doing harm.
Fear the one who sends you and not the one who receives the message. The one who sends you has more authority over you.
In the headman's domain you should not be a challenge. You should observe the regulations of that place.
At the place of an axe, a knife does not enter. If an axe is needed, a knife is useless [to split a coconut, to cut a tree}. Use adequate tools or means.

text: Paa akitoka shimoni, haya ya mchimbaji.
explanation: If the antelope escapes from the hole, blame is the digger's. Imperfect work is offensive to the headman in charge.

text: Pahali pa mtu kufawa ni mtu aliye juu yake.
explanation: The place for a person to get good is [with] the boss.
If the cat leaves, the rats jump. A cruel ruler is better than no ruler.
When the cats are gone, the rats will rule us. Young ambitious leaders are no better than the old traditional chiefs and elders.

text: Safari ya mabwana, arusi ya maboi.
explanation: The journey of the masters is like a wedding feast for the servants.

text: Samaki anaogelea majini nayo maji yatamla.
explanation: The fish that swims in water will be eaten by the water. A flatterer risks being exploited.
A fish begins to rot at its head. When leaders are corrupt, the whole community will become corrupt.
The fish rots at the head.
The government has a long arm. There is no running away from it. Cf. #1411.
The law does not know force. The law is impartial.
Where law ends, violence starts
The law and iron [weapons] have no mercy.

text: Sheria ni msumeno hukata huku na huku.

explanation: It is difficult for one who has ruled to submit to a former subordinate.

text: Si nyumba, si nchi, haiwezi kukaa bila kiongozi.
explanation: House nor country can stay without a leader.
The ears should not surpass the head.
The neck does not surpass the head.
The shoulder does not surpass the head. Cf. #1339.

text: Simba alaye nyama ya mtu hana nguvu
explanation: A man-eating lion has no strength. A sick or disabled lion goes for easy prey. Some people make their fortune off weak and old people. Cf. #1852
When a man-eating lion is devoured, what matters it? Why be amazed if an evil person falls down.
The needle turns on the point of the compass. The needle of the compass determinates the direction of the ship.

text: Sungura, bakia pembeni; tembo mwenye shindo apite
explanation: Hare, stay in the corner, let the elephant in heavy stride, pass by. Wise people let the ambitious people pass.
The trumpet is the master. The trumpet is dominating and listened to.
Give orders and receive orders. What you do to others, you should be ready to accept it, when it is done to you.
The forbidden fruit is sweet.
Exploitation is work of the devil.
Exploitation is beastly.
If you get it, use it; if you miss it, regret it. This is said of people who become arrogant when in power; when they lose their power they'll get their due.
If you get it, use it; if you lack it, be patient in it. Take the good with the evil.
If you want to travel, pay due respect to the master o£ the wilderness.
If you are an important person, scrutinize your own behavior.
Greatness is like a rubbish hole.
A great person [is like a] rubbish hole. A person in charge is like a garbage heap, much abuse, blame and accusation is thrown upon that person. This is said to remind people in power that
Leadership is like a rubbish pit. Leadership is the place where rubbish is thrown; that is, all blames, insults and evils concerning an organization or business are levelled against its leader.

text: Ukuu si pembe kama mtu ataota.
explanation: Greatness is not a horn that grows on the head of somebody. It must be earned.
Don't quarrel with the wind; it's the pigeon that landed badly. It is dangerous to contest people in authority.
Don't eat from a plate, and forgetting [that you were eating from] the earthen bowl. Cf. #925; #1661; #1438
Don't be afraid of the person in charge, but fear to be in charge.

Don't ignore a lion that has been caught in the rain. The lion might shiver and look like a wet old dog, but it is still very dangerous. Don't look down on people who seemingly lost their power. Cf. #1721; #1719.

text: Usisahau ubaharia kwa sababu ya unahodha.

explanation: Do not forget the lot of the seaman because [you are now] a captain. Do not despise those who are beneath you. Cf.925.
You'll go, [but] you'll come back. Independence has a catch.
Obedience is better than a sacrifice.

text: Viovu vya bwana si vyema vya juma kitwana
explanation: The bad things of the master are not the good things of Juma, the servant. Bad people in power often hinder good people doing good.
The big ones eat the small ones.
Big little people have difficult times. If a small or little persons are put in charge they will have difficulties.
The cooked rice is angry with the plate. The subordinate is always angry in vain with his superior.
People respect the ruling king.
Two people dispute the job of the chief. One person only will be in power. This is also a riddle. The answer is
You are the stone, I am the coconut. I am helpless, you have the power to crush me. Cf. #1421, #1442.
You are the knife, I am the handle. You are the hammer, I am the anvil.

text: Yai litakuwa juu, la mamaye kuku kuu.
explanation: The egg will be on top of its mother, the big hen. The next generation will try and teach their elders.
Yours smells bad, ours does not smell evil.
It is better to suffer from the heat than from calamity.

text: Afadhali nusu ajali kuliko ajali kamili.
explanation: Half a mishap is better than a whole one. A minor accident is better than a big one.
An accident does not ask for permission to enter.
An accident has its cause. Many accidents can be avoided. Cf. #766.
A person arrives and will go away. What comes to you will also go away from you, be it good or evil.

text: Akosaye [ukikosa] la mama hata la mbwa huamwa.
explanation: If a child has no [If you lack] mother's breast to suck, even a dog's tit will do. If we cannot get the best, second best will do.

text: Aliyeanguka mwanguko wa mende hana bao.
explanation: One who has fallen cockroach-style has no chance. To fall that way is to fall on the back with legs up and head down. This means to fall so badly that help is needed in order to come up.

text: Kuanguka mwanguko wa mende mdani ya chupa ya mafuta.

explanation: The wrestling of the cockcroach falling on its back.

text: Mweleka wa mende chalichali: mpaka kuokotewa na mdomo wa kuku.
explanation: The struggle of the cockcroach on its back: until it be picked up by the beak of a chicken.
The one who put that load on you is the one who can unload you. This is said when someone is complaining about misfortune and hardship, after that person self is the cause of trouble.
So and So has thrown the boat on a cliff. Has lost everything.
So and So has eaten wheat. Muslims believe that the "forbidden fruit" was wheat.
So and So has eaten wheat, it turned that person out of Paradise.
So and So has eaten Satan's fruit.
