So and So has touched the garden fruits. Has eaten the forbidden fruit and lost paradise.
That person has fallen into the well. Has got into a plight where help is needed.

text: Anayechomwa na mwiba ndiye anasikia uchungu.
explanation: The one who is pierced by a thorn is the one who feels the pain.

text: Apatikanaye na mkasa hupatikana na visa.
explanation: A person who gets involved in an accident gets involved in tales. Everyone will try to explain how and why it happened and blame the person. Cf. #6.

text: Asemavyo kabla hajanaswa sivyo asemavyo anaswapo.
explanation: The way a person speaks before being caught is not the same way that person speaks after being caught.
A person comeing down is helped. When people are going downhill, everyone will give them a push.
One who has not many, has a few. About troubles and imperfections. Nobody is perfect.
A person who has not this has that.
Everybody has his own [defect or possession].
One who does not know tears [suffering] should look at the one who weeps. Before starting a major interprise consider the consequences, or consult those who have.

text: Azibaye masikio kwa lio la maskini, mungu hatamsikia aliapo kiyamani.
explanation: If you block your ears (refuse to listen) from the crying of the poor, God will not hear you when you cry on the day of resurrection.
Misfortune does not get [only] one. If one person of the homestead is in trouble or has done bad things, all the others suffer too.
When a mishap comes about, let the person be at ease.

text: Baa pia hutokana na vijana na watumwa.

explanation: There is no [long] road without corners [curves]. Nothing is ever perfect

The coolness of the dawn keeps licking. Every day is a new beginning. It is commonly understood that the morning dew cleans grass, trees, everything. Used for almost any situation: misfortune, worries, disputes. Cf. #1505.
It is better that the eyes die than the heart.

text: Bora kupigwa dhoruba ya dhahiri kuliko ya siri.
explanation: It's better to be hit by a hurricane in the open than in private. If a calamity befalls you in the open [in public] help may be available. A person accused openly can defend himself.

text: Chenye kukufukuza hakijasimama, wewe usisimame mbele.
explanation: The danger you flee is not yet standing, so you should not stand up the first. The early signs should not force you to give up.

text: Chura akianguka na mtoto chini si mbALI.
explanation: If a frog with young falls, it is not far it falls. Don't despair when misfortune falls upon you. Don't exaggerate what happened.
The remedy of grief is forgetfulness.
Don't enjoy the disgrace of your fellow being.

text: Furaha ya mwenye meno, mwenye mapengo hacheki.

explanation: A potsherd becomes a vessel in time. This proverb has a surface meaning which does not seem true: Potsherds remain potsherds. But the applicative meaning is that a young boy who may not seem to be very promising may yet grow up to become a useful member of society.
When darkness becomes more intense, dawn is near. Cf. #1495, #1497.
Relief is not far away. The darkest hour is shortly before dawn.
There is no extreme distress. Cf. #1635.
There is no joy without pain. No rose without thorns.
There is no word [story, matter] that has no end.
There is no matter so big as to have no end.

text: Hakuna la kudumu, kiumbe uwe na sabura.
explanation: There is nothing that lasts, mortal, just have patience.
There is nothing that does not end.
There is no pole without an end. Cf. #1461.
There is no rose without thorns.
There is no sea without waves.

text: Heri nusu (ya) shari kuliko shari kamili.
Kheri nusu shari kama shari kamili.
explanation: Better the half of an evil than the whole evil. Better a little trouble than a disaster. Sometimes used in lending. By refusing to lend to someone, a person might get a dirty face, but it is better than having all the trouble when the borrower is not going to give back. Evil of refusal is less than the evil of loss. Facing several evil things, try to choose the least evil.
It's better to be in a leaking house than to be rained upon. Cf. #1456, #1473, #1464.

Rain is better than the dew. Walking in the rain one can protect oneself, but walking in the dew it is impossible to escape the wet grass. Used also with a nagging spouse when it is impossible to escape the nagging.

text: Huyu ni chimvi amemchimba mama yake.

explanation: Often what one rejects is what one likes.

text: Ipo siku ya upepo itakuleta karibu nami.
explanation: Perhaps a windy day will bring you close to me. Keep hoping.
The monitor salamander bit because it was out of breath. In desperation a person hopes that an uncertain solution will appear.
The small sardine has turned bad for So and So. One's small enterprise has gone bad.

text: Kidonda cha mwenzako unakisafisha na gunzi, chako unatafuta pamba.
explanation: The sore of your companion you clean with a corn cob, but for your own you find cotton. Lack of concern for others.

text: Kila likuepukalo mja, lina heri nawe.
explanation: Whatever you lack, human being, it is for your happiness. God will give you happiness.
Every misfortune has a companion. Misfortunes never come singly.
Every point has an end. Someone made fun of. Cf.# 1461.
Every cloud has its end.
Whatever cries
One weeps for those who are bereft. One does not weep for oneself or hypocritically.
A new thing pleases, even if bad. New songs are eagerly sung.

text: Kiwanja mtu mwona taabu : jua yake, mvua yake.
explanation: The courtyard is like a person, suffering from sun and rain.

text: Kiwanja mwona taabu, kila mtu kukikanyaga.
explanation: The courtyard is like a suffering person, every one steps on it.

text: Kiwi heri kukipata kama kukikosa kamwe.
Kiwi kiole dawamu kama kukikosa kamwe.

explanation: Hardship is suffered by all.

text: Kosa la ndugu halifiki kwenye mfupa.
explanation: The mistake of a close relative does not reach the bone. It does not hurt too deeply.
That person has gone down like the breast of an old woman. Cf. #1446.

text: Kuku mnyonge hasemi, machungu yake rohoni tu.
explanation: A feeble chicken does not speak, it keeps its grief deep in its heart. Suffering is often mute; what good does it to talk about it? Cf.1387.

text: Kupotea kwa ufunguo baraka ya sanduku.
explanation: The loss of the key is a blessing for the trunk. Cf. #1473.
To retreat is not the same as giving up.
To be defeated teaches how to succeed.
The south monsoon brings the rain.

text: Kussi mja na mtama, kaskazi mja na sui (samaki).
Kuvuja na kuchuruza hakulingani na wazi.
explanation: Leaking and trickling are not to be compared to the wide open. Better a leaky roof than none. Do not despise such shelters as you have from the attacks of slanderers, or the inroads of misfortune.

text: Kuvumbua dawa ya nyogolo, ukiisha kuwa mapengo.
explanation: You discover a cure for toothache when you are left with gaps.

text: Kwale aliyelala na njaa kichwa chake ni kizuio cha umande.
explanation: The head of the partridge that sleeps with hunger blocks the dew. On account of hunger, the patridge is ready to face greater hardship.
There is no incense for what is rotten.
What is rotten smells. Cf. #786.
What has a root has an end. Everything has an end: suffering, joy.
What got to the old winnowing basket the new basket will also get.
What cannot be cured must be endured. You must live with the problem that cannot be solved.
Tears of the elders hurt the heart. It is painful to see elders weep.
If the water is spilled it's indeed spilled. Cf. #78.
There is no adversity in water. No bad luck. Keep on trying.

text: Malalamiko ya leo ndiyo ya siku zote.
explanation: The complaints of today are the same of every day.
Lamentation is not a cure.

text: Maumivu ya kaka kwako usingizi hukosi.
explanation: The suffering of your older brother at home does not hamper your sleep.
I can cook no relish from the goat of the day before yesterday. Lost things are no longer useful.

text: Mfa maji hata banzu hufika limuokoe.
explanation: One drowning in water hopes that even a wood splinter may come to save.
A drowning person grasps at water. Clutches at a straw. Cf. 859.
A person in need must have patience.
The thorns [you put] on the road, it's you that will step on them. One who commits blunders must blame oneself.
My bean plants have been spoiled. My plans have fallen through. Cf. #1491.

text: Mja mtesewa mno, afuae ni karibu.
explanation: For a servant of God, being greatly afflicted, the liberator is near.
The important person falls with his salt in the water. Misfortune falls on rich and poor.
An important person falls with the door [of the house]. Even after entering a thousand times, an accident is possible. See also heading "Fate.

text: Mla cha uchungu na tamu hakosi.
explanation: A person who eats bitter things gets sweet things too.
One who eats bliss, eats bitterness also.

text: Mlala pabaya hangoji usiku kuu alalamike.
explanation: One who sleeps on a bad place does not wait the whole night to complain.

text: Mnyama aangukapo shimoni hatoki na manyoya yote.
explanation: If an animal falls in a hole it does not come out with all its hair intact.
An arrow going into a forest is not necessarily lost. A good deed is not lost, even if it seems so.
Misfortune does not come singly.
A misfortune that is wanted has no lamentations. Nobody has pity on someone who has brought misfortune upon oneself.

text: Mtu aliyeanguka majini hawezi kuopoka na vyote.
explanation: A person who has fallen in the water cannot save everything. After a divorce one does not get all of the bride's wealth back. Cf. #1482b.
It rains when you don't have an umbrella.

text: Mvua wa mchana hainyeshei mtu mmoja.
explanation: Day rain does not fall on only one person. Understood : bad luck.
The last rain destroys the bridges.

text: Mwaka wa ndui, upele hautavuma tena.
explanation: In the year of smallpox, scabies loses its right. When something very bad happens, smaller evils are forgotten. Also used when somebody very bad succeeds a less bad person in power.
One who serves food left over from yesterday, eats it with the family. Unpleasant things are shared with your own people.
One who has a tower will necessarily come down.
A person in trouble is easy to find. A person in trouble is looking for help and shows it and is willing to agree with you.
After joy, grief.
May [new] hardship come and take [old] hardship away. If one hardship takes over from a former hardship, that former hardship probably will be forgotten. KA has
I will not cry over a mishap and injure my eyes. It is no use crying over spilt milk.
A motherless calf licks its own back [in desperation].
When a cow breaks a leg, it goes back to the stable. In time of need one returns to old friends or family.
When a cow breaks its leg, it is sure to go back to the yard.

text: Ng'ombe akivunjika mguu malishoni, hujikokota zizini kusaidiwa.
explanation: When a cow breaks a leg in the meadow, she drags herself to the stable to be helped.
Strength is to be patient.
I'll do something else. After having spent all the money, and driven away the spouse, one consoles oneself by saying "I'll find something new.

text: Njaa ni yako, ya mwenzako ni kizunguzungu.
explanation: Your hunger is really hunger, the hunger of your friend is just a little giddiness. Other people's pain is always minimized compared to ours.

text: Nusu ajali si kama ajali nzima.
explanation: Half a misfortune is not the same as a total disaster.

text: Nyama ya ng'ombe ina mipaka yake.
explanation: Beef has its limits. There is an end to all supply. There is an end to good and bad.
The snake that passes by does no harm.
Where it slopes down is where it goes up. There are two sides to a problem. Human conditions change continually for better or for worse.

text: Kuvuja kwa pakacha, nafuu kwa mchukuzi.
Uvuaji wa pakacha ni nafuu kwa mbebaji.
explanation: The leakage of the basket is a gain for the carrier. Used, e.g., at work when the foreman takes away a task from a worker for being too slow. The worker, who did not like that task anyway, but doesn't want to say so openly, will think about this proverb: it's just fine with me.
There where it itches there is also the owner. When peple are hurt, they will let it be known; or Where there are hot feelings, someone will cause them.

text: Pembe la ng'ombe likivunjika haioti tena.
explanation: If a cow's horn breaks, it does not grow again.

text: Penye wimbi na mlango u papo.

explanation: Strike your heart with a fist. Be brave. Take courage.

text: Pindi yakikaza mawi, huwa kari8u kwisha.
explanation: It is when hardship is at its worst that it is near its end.
Your joy is my grief. What is good for one is bad for another. Cf. #1218.
Forgetting is the cure for human suffering. Without the ability to forget, life would be unbearable. The remedy for injuries is not to remember them.

text: Samaki ikilia machozi yake yapelekwa kwa maji.
explanation: The tears of a fish are carried away by the water. About useIess tears.
Misfortune does not ask to enter, [there is nobody who does not get it unexpectedly.
There is nobody who is not attacked by difficulties. Cf. #1500a.
Problems never end.
Hardship reveals personality.

text: Shida huimarisha wengine na kudhoofisha wengine.
explanation: Hardship makes some people stronger and makes others weaker.
Problems produce problems.

text: Shida ni kama watoto; unavyozidi kuzilea ndivyo zizidipo kukua.
explanation: Trouble is like children; the more you nurse them, the more they grow.
Necessity [misfortune] is the mother of invention.
The farmer knows the hardships of the fields. Cf. #1563.

text: Siku unayojipaka mafuta hukutani na mkweo.
explanation: You don't meet your in-law on the day you anoint yourself. The day you look your best, you do not meet your inlaws. The day you want to show your big catch to your friend, nobody is at home.

text: Siku utakayokwenda uchi, ndiyo siku utakayokutana na mkweo.
Siku utembeapo mtupu [uchi] utakutana [wakutana] na mkweo

explanation: The day you go naked is the day you meet your mother-in-law [or father-in-law]. You always carry your umbrella, except on that one day when you get soaked.

text: Siku za upungufu ni nyingi kuliko za wingi.
explanation: The days of shortage are more numerous than the days of plenty.

text: Taabu zisizo sababu hukutia taabu, usimtambue bibi wala babu.
explanation: Useless trouble will put you in real trouble, don't hurt your grandfather or your grandmother.

text: Tabu ya leo mdiyo raha ya kesho.
explanation: Today's trouble is tomorrow's bliss. To encourage people in hardship. It won't last.
Farm today that you may harvest tomorrow.

text: Tamu tulikula sote, na uchungu vumilia.
explanation: We ate the sweet [things] together, then endure the bitter too. Cf. #891.
One who has fallen down is not kicked.

text: Ukiona kwako kunaungua, kwa mwenzako kunateketea.
explanation: If you see your house on fire, [you may be sure that] your neighbor's is burning even more fiercely. If you suffer a loss, think about the much greater loss of others.

text: Ukiona unga wako waungua, wa mwenzio watateketea.
Ukiona kwako kumepasuka, kwa mwenzio kumevunjika.
explanation: If you see a tear in yours, your neighbor's is spoiled.

text: Ukiona kwako kwafuka, kwa mwenzio kwawaka.
explanation: If you see smoke at your place, your neighbor's is burning. Said to a person who laments about his misfortune as the end of the world.

text: Ukisema kwangu kwaungua, kwa mwenzio kwateketea.
explanation: If you say that my house is on fire, [you should know] that your friend's house is burning [even more fiercely].
If you get bad luck, don't look at the pain.

If you obtain something, use it; if you lack it, be grateful. The meaning is to be grateful to God, the Giver of gifts, hoping that God will reward you for your attitude. If you are grateful for half a loaf God will give you a whole one.
If you obtain something enjoy it, if you miss it, regret it.
If you lack it give thanks; receiving things depends on God.
If you are looking for adversity, you'll find it. If you look for a fight, you'll find one.
Dew misses nobody. Work and burdens should be shared equally by all. This is also said when somebody asks for special favors.
Have you become a manatee, that you cannot bear a shock [wound]?

text: Unaposhuka wa juu, wa chini penyeza guu.
explanation: When you come from somebody who is above you, the one below you stabs your foot.

text: Usifurahie misiba hata hata kwa yako.
explanation: Don't enjoy misfortune, certainly not your own.

text: Usiku haujaingia, usiseme utalala na njaa.
explanation: Before the night has set in, don't say that you'll sleep hungry.
Don't drink the dew, there is water ahead. Cf. #190.
Do not add shells to the peanuts. Do not make a mountain out of a molehill.
Unless you accept toil, you'll not taste peace.
A plant that is well shaken will grow well

text: Utamu wa asali haupunguzi uchungu wa mvi wa nyuki.
explanation: The sweetness of honey does not lessen the pain of the bee's sting.
You will get your lucky hour. Your lucky time will come.

text: Uvumilia matata madogo: maisha ya sasa.
explanation: Suffer the small inconveniences in this life.
Where they weep there also they laugh. Weeping changes into joy. But also: While some grieve, others rejoice on account of their misfortune. One's profit is the other's loss.

text: Wanja wa manga si dawa ya chongo.

explanation: Mascara does not improve the eyes of one who squints.
Mascara is not a remedy for squinting. Cf. #687; #787; #788.
Those who destroy the body are not destroyers of the soul. A person sustaining bodily injury may grow better and stronger.

text: Wema hawana bahati, wana dua na salati.
explanation: Good people have no luck, they have only prayers.
What comes, accept it. Be it good or bad. Live with it. Overcome it according to circumstances.
It will come to pass. Cf. #1461.
Heavy times follow the peaceful days. Cf. #1455.
Teach a child good manners when it is still small.
A child's discipline is a small stick.

text: Adabu ya mtoto huwapatia sifa bora wazazi.
explanation: A child's good manners give great credit to the parents.

One who marries a cousin dies in a war. Judge carefully before undertaking a serious business. In marrying one becomes involved in the life of in-laws, but if one marries a member of the same family, the involvement is much greater. If it is relatively easy to divorce somebody of an outside family, it is extremely difficult to divorce someone who belongs to the same family.

text: Aliyezaa vibaya husalimiwa na wakwe wake.
explanation: One who is ill-born will be paid off by the in-laws. An ill-born child and badly educated is a disgrace to the parents. Refers to the obligation of well educating one's children in view of a happy future.
She leads her husband like an ox by its nose-ring.
She is lucky as one who gave birth at home [in the family].

text: Anayenyimwa ugali na mkewe huvunja nyumba.
explanation: He who is denied food by his wife will break up the marriage. From a song taught during initiation.
He whom mother loves is my father. They are looking after me. Their decisions for me are right decisions. cf. #1528.
A wedding is a bliss.
She who gives birth to a deformed child will breastfeed it. A mother never abhors her own child, however deformed. Cf. #1530.
It is up to the father to reprehend his child. No one else should interfere in family affairs. Blame the father if the child is undisciplined.

text: Baba ni baba lau kama ni kahaba.
explanation: The father is the father unless he is a prostitute.
A stepfather is not a father. There is a firm belief that stepfathers are unkind and cruel to their stepchildren.

text: Baba wa kambo si baba: kunichukuza mikoba na ufunguo wa shaba.

explanation: A stepmother is not a mother. Cf. #1543.
Caresses are not the same as a marital agreement, the refusal leads to a troubled life. Marriage is attractive, but is also a great burden.

text: Bubu alisema juu ya uchungu wa mwanawe.
explanation: The dumb mother spoke because of the suffering of her child. It is the conclusion of a story in which the mother recovers speech, in order to remove the danger that threatens her child. People in charge take care of the interests of the subordinates.

text: Bubu alisema sababu ya ngoma aliyoacha baba.
explanation: The dumb spoke because his father left that person a drum. One does not harm one's own, however weak one be. This is used when one member of the family wants to disinherit an orphan of his father's heritage.
The leopard gave birth to a civet cat. Children often disappoint their parents.
A land lizard give birth to a water lizard.
A leopard may be fierce, but its offspring suck.
Blood is [blood] not red banana sap. Kinship is stronger than friendship.

text: Fadhila umpe mama na mola t'akubariki.
explanation: Give your mother grace and gratitude and God will bless you.

text: Fahari ya nchi ni vijana wake.
explanation: The pride of the nation is its youth. Understood: if they are knowledgeable and courageous, disciplined and patrotic. They are the hope of the nation.
A hyena does not eat its offspring.

The knot [i.e., in the string round the bundle] does not hurt the firewood. Often used to mean: tie it well, do your work well. But also refers to punishment of children. A child is carried on the back of its mother. The knot in the cloth does not hurt the child. Therefore: take good care of your child. Discipline it well. Cf. #1689.
It's the parent who knows the child's joy. Close relationship and love is the means to understand somebody else's feelings. Cf. #1531, #1564.

text: Gome huziba gogo, mti humea kwa chane.
explanation: The bark covers the trunk, a tree grows through the small branches. A family does not grow except through the young ones. The young help the parents.

text: Hadhi ya mzazi humfanya mtoto ajivune.
explanation: A parent's honor makes a child proud. The child will be encouraged to follow the good example of its parents. Cf. # 1546A; #1559.
That person has no parent. It means that that child has learned nothing. Without parents a child is not educated for life.
Parents' kindness can never be paid back.
He does not light [a fire], he does not extinguish it, he is no use to us as owner. He is no

text: Heri kuwa mpenzi wa wazee kuliko kuwa mtumwa wa vijana.
explanation: It's better to be the darling of the elders than to be a servant of the young. Cf. #1546A; 1559.
Respect starts at home.
Spare the rod and spoil the child.

text: Hurumia wana wa wenzako, ili wanao wahurumiwe.
explanation: Have mercy on the children of your friends, so that your children may receive mercy.
If it does not make you feel hot, it usually itches. It" stands for
How could a donkey mount a horse? Said when a low class man woos an upper class girl".
You'll not get old with the tooth of your childhood. Forget the ways of your childhood.
The rooster has no in-laws. The unfaithful and frivolous person neglects in-laws and spouse.

text: Katika radhi ya baba huimarika ukoo.
explanation: In the contentment of the father the offspring will prosper.

text: Kidole kingali kizima kizuri, kikiugua ugonjwa kibaya.
explanation: If the finger is intact it is good, but if the finger is sick, it's declared bad. The husband does not easily tolerate a sick spouse.
The lid should fit [the pot] well. Find a good 'fitting' bridegroom for a nubile girl.

text: Kila kitu kina mama, dawa yake na salama.
explanation: Every creature has its mother, its medecine and security. No better medicine than a mother.
Every spouse [has to find a way to live] with his in-laws.

text: Kinachotoka pua na kuingia kinywa si hasara [haramu].
explanation: What comes out of the nose and enters the mouth is not harmful [unlawful]. If an older brother dies his wife can become the spouse of a younger brother.

text: Kinaota ku jicho; kingeota ku pua, ningekitosha.
explanation: It grows in the eye, but if it grow on the nose, I would remove it. The meaning is that a member of the family is sooner supported than a stranger, or endured for that matter.

A protecting device is given to a child still in its mother's womb. A child is separated for protection. A new-born is not shown to the world for this same reason. A child is given protecting devices [amulets] because it will meet good and bad people. But: God has already protected the child for nine months, so don't worry too much about evil spirits: God granted the child to be born, so God will protect the child.
Don't try medicine on a protected place.

text: Kinyesi cha mtoto hainuki kwa mama.
explanation: A child's stool does not stink to the mother. A mother does not find it umpleasant to help her child, where other people find it difficult to lend a hand.

text: Kinywa cha bibi kisipite cha bwana.
explanation: The mouth of a wife should not overpower that of her husband. In the presence of her husband the wife does not take the word. Cf. #1741; #166; #1640.

text: Kisichofanana na mwenyewe ni cha kuiba.
explanation: What does not resemble the owner must have been stolen. This proverb is used when talking about how much a child resembles one of the parents in appearance and behavior: weIl, if it did not, one might suspect something wrong.
If your knife cuts you, you sheath it. You don't throw away your knife. A relative who hurts you is not forsaken and you also try to mend the harm you did.
What comes out of the belly is bitter. Giving birth is painful and therefore children should be cared for, because they were painfully obtained.
One mistake does not warrant the divorce of one's wife. Give a person another chance.

text: Kuamuru na taa, huanza kwa jamaa
explanation: Ruling and obeying begin in the family. Good government begins at home.
To teach is to take good care [of one's children].
Having no children makes a person despised. The Swahili love children. Big families are a source of pride for both the father and the mother.
A hen does not break her own egg. It's hard for a person to harm family or close friends.

text: Kulea mimba si kazi, kazi kulea mwana.
Kuoa bibi mzuri ni kupanda mdimu kando ya njia.
explanation: He who marries a beautiful wife plants a citrus tree along the road.

text: Kuoa ni arusi, kuishi wawili ni ngoma.
explanation: To marry is a joy, to live together is a dance. Marriage is only the beginning of a new joint life in a society. There are players who want to get out and players who want to get in.
To marry is to experience many things.

text: Kuotaota kwa nywele ziliota penye kidevu.
explanation: The continual growth of hair extends to cover the chin. One must support the family members that encroach the household.
To love each other [is] to bring forth children.

text: Kupendwa na mke ni kuchukiwa na wazazi.
explanation: To be loved by your wife is to be hated by your parents. Parents are jealous. They don't want to give up their child.

text: Kuzaa si kazi, kazi kubwa [ni] kulea
explanation: Bearing children is not so difficult but upbringing, that is real work. Cf. #472; #1527.
Giving birth is not the same as going to the toilet. About some people who talk easily about sex.
The same birth, but many lives. Human beings are born in the same way but their lives may be different. Poor, rich, healthy, sickly, strong and weak. Cf 329, #1105.

text: Kweli mwana ni mamae, na mlezi akalea.
Mama akifa, mimi wa ndani sitakufa.
explanation: If my mother dies, I of the family, will not die. I will be taken care of.

text: Mama hawezi kumkana mtoto, hata akiwa na vilema.
explanation: A mother cannot repudiate her child, even if it has defects. Cf. #1515.

text: Mama kwa mwanawe, mtoto kwa mamaye.
explanation: A mother is for her child, the child is for its mother. In love and suffering they depend on one another; nobody else can substitute.

text: Mama mmoja mwema hushinda waalimu wa ulimwengu.
explanation: One good mother is better than all the teachers of the world.
Mother is buying [on the market] so the child cannot grow up. The child is not looked after properly.
Your mother is your other [or second] God.

text: Mtu mamae ni mungu wakwe wa pili.
explanation: A mother is a person's second God. A person looks up to her for advice and follows her orders. After God, your mother is the most generous.

text: Mataya hayangalikuwa ndugu zako, hangalikupondea chikichi.
explanation: If the jaws hadn't been your relatives, they would not have broken palm nuts for you.
The inwards cause disease. A mother says this of a child who causes her nothing but trouble.
Eggs either do not come to full completion or are hatched. Understood is that a child may be born defective.
If you revere your wife as a relative you will not have a child from her. Cf #1941.
Parents who fear the tears of their child will cry themselves. If you leave your child doing things without correcting its behavior, you will weep.

text: Mchea mwana kulia, hulia yeye mkongwe.
explanation: They who fear the tears of their child, weep when old.

text: Mdomo wa kasuku ulikumjama kwa ukwe.
explanation: The beak of the parrot became crooked at the in-laws. Living with the in-laws restricts freedom of speech and actions. There are many taboos to be observed.

text: Mfunze mwanao tabia bora kabla kumsahihisha mwana wa mwenzio.
explanation: Teach your child good behavior before correcting your friend's child.
An orphan should not be left with a stranger to be cared for.
The confused stubborn child got in trouble by birth. If parents are beaten or abused by their children later it is because the trouble started at the children's birth.
A pregnancy cannot be hidden. Cf, # 1297.
Two [hands] do a massage.
The celibate marries a prostitute. The bachelor, perhaps impotent, is reduced to marrying a woman who is despised or [often] sterile.

text: Mjane hana ongeza lingine, ila la kuoa.

explanation: A grandhild is for us a fruit.
One who severs relations with relatives is not wise.
Make your wife happy, do not stay out too long

text: Mkeo akikwambia 'niwache', nawe ridhia na mwingine kimbilia.
explanation: If your wife tells you 'Divorce me,' satisfy her wish and quickly marry another.
The hand does not forget the mouth, not even at night. Members of a family are in helpful cooperation, especially in times of misfortune.

text: Mkono unakinyima kinywa, nacho kitapewa na nani?
explanation: If the hand denies to give [food] to the mouth, the mouth will then receive [food] from whom? About family members helping each other.
Human beings depend on their children. Men's relations to the world depend chiefly on their children for happiness and grief. Cf. #366.
Mr. Wishful and Mrs. Longing do not get children. Wishes and desires are not enough.

text: Mtoto akipenda makamasi yake, mwache ayavute.
explanation: If a child loves to sniff his snot, let it sniff. Don't expect your child to be perfect all the time. Cf.#1539
The child adores its mother.

text: Mtoto humuasi baba lakini baba hamuasi.
explanation: A child rises up against its father, but the father does not renounce his child.

text: Mtoto katika nyumba chechemi ya furaha.
explanation: A child at home is a source of joy.
A bad child endangers what is put aside for him/her.
A child and his parents. They belong to each other. Children depend on their parents.
A child is like a precious stone, [but also] a heavy burden.

text: Mtoto ni mtumbwi, ukiuchonga utakuvusha jito [bahari].
explanation: A child is like a canoe, if you carve one, it will take you across the river [sea]. A child is a security for the future.

text: Mtoto [kijana] ukimnyang'anya kisu [mwembe], mpe banzi [bamba or kijiti] achezee.
explanation: If you take away a knife [razor blade] from a child, give it a piece of wood to play with.
Remove the knife and provide a stick.

text: Ukimnyang'anya mtoto chikichi, umnyanganye na vitunguu vya pori.
explanation: If you take away palm nuts from a child, take away also the wild onions. Being too strict in educating a child is harmful.

text: Ukimyang'anya mtoto muwa, umwachie makamasi yake.
explanation: If you take away sugar cane from your child, leave its snot. Parents who expect their child to be perfect delude themselves. A divorced wife has the right to compensations for the services given to the household she is leaving.
A child becomes as it was brought up.
The first-born is like a shield. Is an insurance against parental disability or old age.

text: Mtoto wa mnyama tumboni, wakimpiga mama yake, atafurahi.
explanation: The animal young in the belly of its mother, will be happy, if you hit its mother. Cf. #1529a.

text: Mtoto wake amepotea katika mgongo wa fisi.

explanation: The husband of my mother is my father. A legalistic proverb. The child of the mother [in or out of wedlock] is considered the child of her husband, and in case the child is a girl, the bride-price goes to the father, when she marries. The father must be respected even if old, poor or weak.

text: Mungu wa wenye ndoa, shetani wa wakaa bure.
explanation: God is with a married people, the devil is with those who are idle [the celibates].

text: Mwaminifu huoa, mwenye hekima hubaki kapera.
explanation: A believer gets married, the learned stays childless. In marriage trust is needed.

text: Mwana huua mzee, mzee haui mwana.
explanation: The child kills the parent, the parent does not kill the child. The equivalent of the saying that love comes down, not up.
For a child is a wound, for a grandchild it is a scar. One is more sensitive to what happens to one's own child than to what happens to a grandchild.

text: Mwana mkuwa nawe ni mwenzio kama wewe.
explanation: The child who grows up with you is your companion like yourself. To encourage people to marry early so that they will have children and enjoy growing up with them.

text: Mwana mtukana nina kuzima enda akiona.
explanation: The child who insults its mother will go and see hell.

text: Mwana muwi ni dawa ya mlango.
explanation: A bad child is [after all] a cure of the family. People are not jealous of that family, so they are saved from people's evil eyes.

text: Mwana mwema kumlea na mui mlee.
explanation: Bring up a good child but also a bring up a bad child.

text: Mwana mwema ni taji tukufu kwa wazazi wake.
explanation: A good child is a crown of honor for its parents. Used also in talking about citizens and the nation. Cf. #1511.
Reprimand the child of your friend with words. Cf. #1550.

text: Mwana ni mamake, kwa kambo ni pahali pa kukaa.
explanation: The child is of its mother, for the stepmother it is a place to stay. The child is the reason that the stepmother can stay.
The kid of a goat carries a donkey. Do not expect that your child will help you along or that it will help you at all.

text: Mwana wa ndugu kirugu, mjukuu ni mtu mbali.
explanation: Your brother's child is like the height of the wall of your house, but a grandchild is quite another person. The height of the wall is so familiar as to be unnoticed and unknown.
A brother's child, however close to you, is never your child.

text: Mwana wa ndugu kirugu, mjukuu mwanangwa.
Mwana wangu utumwapo, njiani usikawepo, enda rudi mara moja.
explanation: My child when you are sent on an errand, do not dawdle on the road, go and come back at once.

Before the tooth there is the gum. Everything has a beginning. The beginning of a child is the parents. So when the child grows up it must not despise its parents in whatever situation they may be, poor, sick or whatsoever, because the child's beginning is from its parents.

text: Mwenye kukataa mwana hukataa mwana wa haramu.
explanation: The parents who renounce their [legitimate] child, renounce also their illegitimate child. One who is hostile to close family is also hostile to the greater family.
She who gets a child does not lack a cradle.
Let the parent punish the child. It is on the parent of the child to reprimand it.
The end of the road is home.
The hen's importance is among her offspring
Guide the child in the right way.
A parent does not self-glorify.
Parents glorify themselves.
A parent never gives up.
A parent does not kill. Used in a situation when one feels a parent is neglecting a child. A parent's action can never be so extreme as to deliberately harm a child. Cf #1526; #1544.

Marriage is like a dancing hall. In a dancing hall there are different kinds of people. Some enjoy the dance from start to finish, and others enjoy certain parts and dislike others. Those who dislike the dance would like to get out of the hall while others who are outside would like to enter the hall.
Marriages contracted in haste end in regrets. Later when each gets to know the other more, one or both of them will regret marriage.
Marriages are made in heaven. God arranges the marriages. Therefore don't blame yourself if you don't find whom to marry.
A bad brother is far better than no brother.
It is better to see well with a bad relative. One day that may be useful.

text: Neno la talaka, silo la dhihaka.
explanation: A word of repudiation must not be lightly pronounced. Cf. #1523.
I am tired, just stop it, let me rest. A woman telling her husband.

text: Nyoka akiingia nyumbani, hukimbii na kuihama nyumba.
explanation: If a snake enters the house, you do not run and vacate the house. You kill it. The meaning is that if a bad person wants to cause confusion and misunderstanding in a family, the family should find a way of removing that person.
Hairs, hairs, may they be plenty. Refers to the view generally held that many children are a blessing.
Guide the child in a rightful way.

text: Pambo la nyumba ni mwanamke asiyenung'unika.
explanation: The non-complaining wife is the decoration of the house. Such a woman will be able to comfort others.

text: Pasipo mwanaume, nguzo ya nyumba, nyumba itavunjika.
explanation: Without a son, the pillar of the house, the family dies. Male descendants perpetuate the line of the family.

text: Pendo za mwana zi matakoni mwa nina.
explanation: The happiness of a child is when its mother's desires are satisfied. Father's love for a child disappears when the mother dies.

text: Pendo la mwana liwa magoni kwa nina.
explanation: The love of a child is on the lap of the mother. The affection of a child is gratified on mother' lap.

text: Radhi ya baba na mama ni ufalme wa dunia.
explanation: The blessing of father and mother is worth an earthly kingdom. Cf. #451; #1559
Mother's blessing is sweet.

text: Radhi ya wazee ni bora kushinda mali.
explanation: The blessing of your parents is better than wealth. Respect and obey your parents first.

text: Radhi za wazee ni fimbo kubwa kwa mwanadamu.
explanation: A parent's blessing is a great stick [help] for a person.
The appeal of the dance has a producer. To continue a work until it is finished a supervisor is needed.
When a hare gets old it sucks the tits of its mother.
Go ahead young maiden, good life is waiting for you. Parents take good care of their daughters until marriage. AL.
A hen's kick does not hurt her chick. Used when parents chastise their children. Cf. #1526; #193.

text: Tembo hashindwi na ulezi wa mwanawe.
explanation: The elephant is not burdened by rearing its young.

text: Titi la mama litamu, jingine halishi hamu.

explanation: The belly [of a woman] is like a garden. Productive.

text: Tunda haliozi juu, ila ugenini tu.
explanation: A fruit does not rot high up [in the tree], except when abroad. Among relatives one shares willy nilly.

text: Ucheshi wa mtoto ni anga la nyumba.
explanation: The laughter of a child is the light of a house.
The bad luck of the blouse, caused harm to the loincloth. The abuse of one member of the family is offensive to the whole family.

text: Uchungu wa mtoto "u katika nyonga" ya mama yake.
Udugo wa upanga si mzuri, afadhali udugu wa kisu.
explanation: Fraternal relationships of the sword [machete] are inferior to those of the knife. To understand this proverb one has to understand the difference between knife and machete. The machete is single edged, the African knife is double edged. A marriage that only cares for their inner circle of relatives [a machete] is not as good as that of a knife, i.e., caring for the in-laws.
Brotherhood is like a scar. It will last your whole life.
A family that does not gather together will be divided.

When a familyhood gathers moss, exploitation thrives. When love and respect for each other in the household erodes by foreign practices, people begin to exploit each other as they become more interested in personal advantages.

text: Ujana ni tumaini, uzee ni kumbukumbu.
explanation: Youth is hope, old age is remembrance. Youth lives on expectation on what is coming; old people live more on remembering what's past rather than on what's coming.
The wages of a parent are known by God. God knows what is due to parents.

text: Ukalamzi wa mtoto sawa na ule wa baba yake.
explanation: The craftiness of the child is the same as its father's.
If you scorn [the advice] of your elder, you'll see evil happenings.

text: Ukigombana na mama asiye mama yako, ni kuchokoza midomo bure.
explanation: To dispute with your stepmother is to tire your lips for nothing. A stepmother does not have the same sentiments as a mother.

text: Ukila na ndege, ule na kuku.
explanation: If you eat with the birds, eat also with the chickens.
If you eat with the birds, remember the chicken. Inviting a visitor for a meal must not harm your family.

text: Ukimlea mwana mwema, na mui mlelee; mwema ukimpa mchele, mui mpe chelele.
explanation: If you bring up a good child, bring up also the bad one; if you give rice to the good one, give rice husks to the bad one. Do not throw out the bad child, give it something. Cf #1546.

text: Ukimwoa mke mpya, hutamsahau wa zamani.
Ukioa bibi ueneze kino na mtwangio.
explanation: If you take a wife, make also room for the pestle and mortar.
If you are afraid to use the stick, you'll harm [spoil] the child.

If you collect lianas, you better be ready to suffer dirt. Lianas for basket making must be split and scraped, releasing lots of dirty matter. A person who marries must be ready to support the family.
If you are predestined to be married, you are married. To be destined by God. What God has decreed will happen. Sacleux.

text: Ukipata chungu kipya, usitupe kile cha zamani

explanation: If you get a new stone pot, don't forget the old potsherd.
Inlaws are like a refuse dump. Marriage is costly. The inlaws are always asking for supplements to the brideprice.

text: Ulimwengu una tata, siikuwe; ambao wamkamata, simtoe.
explanation: The world is full of problems, don't be proud; the one you have, don't let her go. It's better to keep a wife than to take a mistress.
The brother or sister in-law is not afraid of the morning dew. A determined person overcomes difficulties.
Are you a duck that your mind is only on your children?
The one you desire, do not look at her. It would be improper for a gentleman to stare at the woman he fancies.

text: Undugu ni firisi [hirisi] hautafunwi kwa meno.
explanation: Brotherhood is like a charm, it is not crushed with teeth.

text: Upate kumshauria mtoto wa mama yake lazima kukausha macho yako.
Upendo wa mama kwa mwana hauchagui.
explanation: A mother's love for her child is not biased.

text: Usiache mkeo kwa maneno ya kusikia.
explanation: Don't leave your wife on account of what you heard. Cf. #925.
Giving birth has trouble, sterility has trouble. Parenthood has troubles, spinsters and bachelors have trouble too.

text: Uzazi wachekwa na mtu gumba: mzazi ajionea uchungu.
explanation: Parenthood is mocked by the childless person: a parent resents the bitterness. Success of others causes jealousy.

text: Vitu vya myumbani vinajulikana na panya; basi mwewe anapita juu ataweza kujua vilivyo nyumbani.
explanation: The mouse knows about the things in the house; but what does the hawk, that flies overhead, know about things of that house.
All the fingers are not the same. Children of one family may differ.
They were married, they will speak to one another They live together, they will learn to understand each other.

text: Walooana wakipendana, na jingi jonzi huepukana.
explanation: If two married people love each other, they will avoid much sorrow.

Relatives are like the holes made by the termites. Those holes are separate, but they merge deep in the same big hole in the earth. Although brothers may appear to be separated, deep down in their hearts, they are united.
If the elders keep quiet the children will get lost.
People who have their own things do not leave them. They will care for them.
A person who has absolutely nothing, doesn't know what poverty means.
A different use: A drunkard does not know where he is going. Repetition of tota stresses the totality of destitution. Tota, sink down, be drowned.

text: Ardhi ndiyo mali, hakuna itokayo angani.
explanation: The earth is precious, nothing comes from the sky.

text: Asio mali, hasidi wa mwenye mali.
explanation: A poor person envies a rich one. The poor do not love the rich and the rich do not love the poor.
A person who has no food has some vegetable. The meaning is that there is nobody who lacks absolutely everything. A poor person has certain other gifts: health, brains, a child.
A person who has nothing however has God. God does not forget his creature.
The goods of blind people are in their hands. What is held in the hand is really one's property.
What belongs to blind people is what is in their stomach.
Mine is better than what is ours. Because I can use it how and when I want. Used against communal work. Cf. # 221; #? Chako ni chako (Success
What is mine is not totally ours. A little touch of capitalism.

text: Cheza mwenye mali, usicheze na mali.
explanation: Play with the owners of riches, don't play with money.

text: Cheza na mwenye mali, usichezee mali.
explanation: Play with the rich, don't play with their money.

text: La mnyonge halendi joshi, na likenda joshi litazama.
Dau la mnyonge haliendi joshi, likienda joshi ni mungu kupenda.
explanation: The boat of a poor person does not sail close to the wind; if it tacks it is because God wills it.

text: Joshi la mnyonge haliendi vema mpaka mungu akipenda.
explanation: A poor person's boat does not tack well but for God's liking.
The sailboat of a poor person does not tack well. Cf. #138.

text: Dirishani upendo huruka, umaskini uvukapo kizingiti.
explanation: When poverty crosses the threshold, love flies out of the window.
Money [often] brings shame.
Money is useful as a lamp. Money can be used to buy a lamp. True, but there is more to this proverb.
Money produces money. To start a business one needs money. It is difficult to get a loan without collateral. Understood is to use money wisely. EM.
Money harvests/ forges/ produces money. Cf. 1624.

text: Fedha huvunja nguvu na milima ikalala.
explanation: Money broke the power: the mountains are leveled. By reason of spending money one has escaped the use of force.
The heat in the house prevents the owner to enter. Excess of possessions restrains their uses.
A craftsman has no furniture. Understood that that person sells every piece made or gives it away thinking that it can easily be made again. The cobbler's wife goes barefoot.

text: Ganda la mua [la jana], chungu kaona kivuno.
explanation: The peelings [of yesterday's] sugarcane is a harvest to the ant. Something discarded by one may be very useful for another. And, do not despise an old thing.

text: Gari la maskini ni miguu yake.
explanation: The autos of the poor are their legs.

text: Hakuna aliye mdogo wa mwisho kabisa.
explanation: There is nobody who is the smallest of all. There is always somebody who is poorer or more miserable.
So and So is not of noble origin nor has any [personal] attainments.

text: Hana habari yoyote, mke wala dume.
Hawafai neno lolote, jike wala dumu.
Hakuja na chochote, hakuja na make wala maume.
explanation: That one came with nothing, nothing for men or for women.
Respect is better than riches. To be respected is to be valued as a human being.

text: Hindi ndiko kwenye [hindi] nguo, na waendao tupu wako.
Hindi kwa wafuma nguo, na waendao tupu wako.
explanation: India, that is the country of weavers and yet there are some who go naked. Poverty and riches, good and evil, are often found together. Sam.

text: Hohehahe jungu la mavi na mkorogwe.

explanation: Where does a very poor person find real friends?

text: Jibwa lililo na njaa halichezi na lililo na shibe.
explanation: A big hungry dog does not play with a well fed dog. Cf. #1128.

text: Jicho la mkosi halioni, likiona haliangazi.
Kapera hapiki kombe mpaka mwaka wa mavuno.
explanation: The poor man does not cook his bowl [of rice] until the year of abundant crop.

text: Kidege hakina nyumba, nyumba yake mti.
explanation: The little bird has no house, its home is a tree. This is said of somebody in difficulties. Like a bird on a branch, always on the move.

text: na ndani taama ale kwa salama.
explanation: If a beggar arrives at your party, give a dish of food and let the person move inside to eat it in peace.
The big part [put in reserve in the store] will not eat the small part [added to it]. Save. Be frugal.
A trapped hartebeest does not stink to the trapper. The trapsetter rejoices to get meat even if the hartebeest is found dead. Someone in need will be happy to get something even if not perfect.

text: Kuchunga na peku ni kukosa ungo.
explanation: Sifting with a worn out basket means that a good one is missing. This is applied to a person who is not able to do a bigger or better job. Wearing torn clothing; going barefoot.
Lacking is not a fault. No one can be blamed for not having something.

text: Kuku wa mkata hatagi, na angetaga haangui, na akiangua halei, na akilea hutwaliwa na mwewe.
explanation: The hen of a poor person does not lay eggs, and even if she lays eggs, she never hatches, and if she hatches, she never rears the chicks, and when she rears, the chicks are taken by the hawk. This is not entirely true

text: Kuku wa mkata hutaga. Wataka atage la bata? Kuku huyu si mwongo?
explanation: The hen of a poor person does lay eggs. Do you want it to lay a duck's egg? Is that hen then not a liar? Cf. #1621.
Begging begging, the hand turns into a spoon.
There is no justice for a destitute person. The poor have no rights. Cf. #1421, #1601.
Where the well-to-do goes, there the well-to-do returns.
Where kindness goes, kindness returns. Where good things are done, good things will be returned.
Our place is nice. It is nice to be home. Our place is nicer than any place somewhere else.
Much wealth [brings] many enemies.
Becoming wealthy depends on God's secret design.
Property is like a shade [protection].
All the rich things one sees do not fill a bundle.
Give a person what is owned.
A poor person's love is never seen. A poor person has no means to show love for others by giving presents. Cf. #1596.
Money makes money.
The poor person's boat already sank in the river. Whatever the poor try fails at the very beginning.

text: Kupata kwa limbukieni matako hulia pwata.

explanation: The person who got money wants it to make noise.
A poor person has no taboos. A poor person does not observe taboos and can eat forbidden food. Need breaks the law. Cf. #1133.
A poor person has no family. Somebody who has nothing to share does not attract anybody.
A poor person has no friends. Cf. #1587b, 1600

text: Maskini hohehahe, hana mbele wala nyuma.
explanation: An utterly poor and destitute person has no front nor behind. That person has nowhere to look for help or to fall back upon. The expression

text: Wanijua ni mkata sina mbele, sina nyuma.
explanation: You know I am a pauper, without either antecedents or prospects.
His/ her family tree does not go far. V.

text: Huyu si fidia ya gidamu ya kiatu cha baba yangu.
explanation: That one is not worth my father's shoelace.

text: Wala si fidia ya makamasi yangu.
explanation: That person is not worth my snot. Cf. #1577.

text: Maskini kama wanamaji wa bwana muyaka.
explanation: Poor as the mariners of Mr. Muyaka. From a very long poem. Muyaka rounded up all his poor relatives and took them on his ship for a treasure hunt and brought them safely back to Mombasa. (1800?

text: Maskini mtu kwao ugeni si kitu chema.
explanation: For a person, poor at home, it is not a good thing to be in a foreign land.
A poor person may become rich.

text: Maskini ni mtoto wa kwale: ukimleta mjini, anarudia porini.
explanation: A poor person is like a young partridge, if you take it to town, it will return to the wild. Not being suitable for society. Incorrigible.

text: Maskini si yule tu ambaye hana, pia yule amabaye anacho, lakini anataka zaidi.
explanation: A poor person is not only the one who has nothing, but also the person who has, but wants more.
Whatever a poor person says is wrong.
Moonshine is the lamp of the poor.

text: Mbuzi wa maskini hazai, na akizaa huzaa tasa.
explanation: A poor person's goat does not produce, and if it does, it produces a barren goat. If poor people get some property, however much they try, it does not increase as fast as that of the rich. EM. Cf. #1582
A potter will get [to eat] from a potsherd. Workers who are not very shrewd will barely profit from their work.
The potter cooks in a broken pot. Cf. #1574a.

text: Mkata haisi kula na mkwasi, akianza kula swi hulia kichwani.
explanation: A poor person does not know how to eat with a wealthy person; eating fish that person would start with the head. It is not always easy to abandon one's former ways.
A poor person does not enjoy eating with the rich. People of different status don't visit each other. Cf. #1608.
A person looking for food doesn't feel bad. Someone seeking food is so accustomed to denials that that person feels no bitterness.
Abuse me, but give it to me, a poor person is not easily offended.
Poor people do not love their children. They have no material way of showing their love for their children by way of gifts.

text: Mkata hapiki kuku, mpaka mwaka wa sotoka.
explanation: A poor person does not cook a chicken except in the year of chicken pest. Cf. #1588.

text: Mkata hendi mkele, na angenda mkele, akipakia jahazi mtele tele, hurudi na upele.
explanation: A poor person does not go to Makalla, and even when going to Makalla and filling his vessel with abundance of rice, that poor person returns with scabies. From a song. To show how hard it is for a poor person to improve his material condition.
The person who lacks a hoe cannot cultivate. Poverty begets poverty.
A person who has no relish, eats dry food.
Lacking money is not [necessarily the same as] being poor.
A pauper has no kin.
Poor and helpless like a young bird.
Oppress the poor person.
The poor have their pipe. Their troubles.
A traveler is a poor person, even when a ruler. Travelers encounter many dangers. KB.
A poet is poor. Poets are leading an ascetic life, they are men of wisdom and restraint who deserve respect and support. RSP.
A person that owns nothing, walks alone.
The poor is unwanted, ignored, has nothing. No one wants to have anything to do with a poor relative.

text: Mtu akikosa mali hawi mtu mbele ya watu.
explanation: A person without money is not seen as a person by others.

text: Mtu akiwa na pesa, utamjua kwa mwendo wake.
explanation: By seeing how a person walks you know there is money.

text: Mtumaini mahari ya dadake hufa mseja.
explanation: He who puts his hope on the bride's wealth of his sister will die a bachelor.
What is natural to a person cannot be shed. Is permanent, cannot be changed.
The person who has acquired wealth should not forget the one who didn't. Cf. #1128.
The rich person is still lacking things. Greed is often a vice of the rich. Cf. #1615.
A hungry person is not visited.
A hungry person is not greeted. Has nothing to give. Cf. The sultan who has no uji. No: ?
A person used to riding a donkey does not mount a horse. Said by people who feel uncomfortable in a rich and luxurious environment. Cf. #1594.

text: Ndege za mwituni wapita za nchi kavu kulia.
explanation: The birds of the forest complain more than the birds of the dry land.

text: Ng'ombe wa mnyonge hazai, na akizaa ndama wake hukanyagwa na ng'ombe wa mkubwa.
explanation: The cow of a poor person does not procreate, and if it does, the calf is stepped on by the cow of the boss.
The goat of the poor does not give birth. Cf. #1582.

text: Ni rahisi kupata fedha na siyo kuzitunza.
explanation: It is easy to get money, but it is not easy to take care of it. Easy come, easy go.
A moth has no festive clothes. Used as an excuse for poor appearance in public.

text: Nta si asali, nalikuwa nazo si uchunga
explanation: Wax is not honey; "I had them" is not the same as I am herding them now.

text: Nta si asali, nilikuwa nazo, si akiba.
explanation: Wax is not honey. "I had them" is not the same as a reserve.

It is when you have no fingernails that you get scabies. A poor person working hard with his hand cannot keep fingernails and cannot scratch. A Luo saying has: I am so poor, I scratch myself with a potsherd. At the hight of bad luck. Cf.#3914.
Money is like soap [ointment] for the soul.

text: Rahisi kuishi kama maskini, vigumu kujifanya tajiri.
explanation: It is easy to live as a poor person; it is hard to make yourself rich.

text: Si aswili utajiri, ni tunu hutunukiwa.
explanation: Wealth is not something one owns by original right; it is a gift, it has been given.

text: Siku ya utajiri, kumbuka siku ya umaskini.
explanation: On the day of abundance, remember the day of penury. Cf. #???

text: Simba akikosa nyama hata majani hujilia.

explanation: A hungry lion will even eat grass. A desperate person will do anything.
The rich can become poor. Cf. #1620, #1607.

text: Tajiri na maliye, maskini na mwanawe.
Ufukara si kilema, bali pambo la dunia.
explanation: Poverty is not a defect of the earth, but an embellishment.
When poverty gets to a person it really hits.
If you wear a grass skirt, you'll be eaten by goats. If you debase yourself, others will lower you still more.
Negligence leads to poverty. Being tired and being lazy are correlated.
Poverty has no mercy. It is hard to be poor and hard not to be able to help others.
Scabies comes to those who have no fingernails. Without fingernails, there is no scratching. This means that they cannot help themselves. Cf. # 3014.

text: Usicheze [na] mali, cheza na mwenye mali.
explanation: Don't play with money, play with the wealthy. Cf. 1571g.
Don't suck the poor in the hope to get rich.
Wealth is like a shadow. It is cool, but can suddenly disappear.
Wealth is a matter of the heart. Wealth is not possessing many things but having a heart of caring for others and co-operating with them in times of sorrow and of joy.

text: Vundo la kinyesi ni malazi ya bata.
explanation: The resting place of the goose is on a dung heap. Do not despise a poor person who has only a mat to sleep on, or who eats unappetizing food.
The blind eats what's offered to the guests. A blind person cannot be choosy.

text: Wa stara hafumbuki, wa mbili havai moja.

explanation: A self-respecting person is not shamed.

text: Wa sitara hafumbuki, wa mbili havui moja.
explanation: A modest person is not uncovered: a person with two garbs does not discard one. A person who is supported by an important personage does not easily submit to a downfall.

text: Walo wakinuka vumba, leo wako ambarini.
explanation: Those who smelled bad are today in perfume. Cf. #1615.

text: Wavaji mvae! Sisi tutavaa kama maiti.
explanation: Wear your elegant clothes! We will dress like corpses. The poor envy the rich.
Abundance is not a neccessity.

text: Ya mkiwa haiti, na ikita hupapata.

explanation: The [cow] of a poor person, does not give birth to a female calf. It's hard to leave poverty behind.
You can do everything, if you have money.
Disgrace is [usually] hidden.
Those who think that they are standing should be careful not to fall down. Said of a successful person who is very proud.

text: Alimaye kandoni mwa njia huonewa na maharamia.
explanation: A farmer who cultivates near the roadside will be eyed by [highway] robbers. If you are doing good business, hide it, for there are always the enviers.
One who has swallowed a strip of raffia hopes for the best. [Free translation.

text: Amezaye tunda zima zima hujiaminisha koo lake.
explanation: If you swallow a whole fruit you put your trust in your throat. You do that at your own risk. Somebody who boasts should be ready to be challenged.
The osprey goes fast, but does not reach to heaven.
The eagle may soar upwards, but it will return to its tree.

text: Ungenda juu kiboko, makazi yako ni pwani.
Kiboko pake ni pwani maregeo ni majini.
explanation: The hippo's place is on the shore, it will always return to the water. A person may pretend belonging to a higher class of people, but one day that person will come down again.
Anybody who has no defect has at least a blemish.
Every person has a blemish.
Every person has a wound. Every person has headaches and problems.
The one who is naked squats low. When shame befalls, that person keeps quiet, goes in hiding.
One who is derobed squats low.
Somebody else's good is bad, but yours is like sugar.

text: Cha mtu mavi; utakiacha ukiona tu.
explanation: The goods of another person are bad, you'll leave them and you'll be satisfied looking at them.

text: Chemchem si mtemi, lakini atakaye kunywa maji yake sharti ainame.
explanation: A spring is not a king, yet whoever would drink of it must bow. A spring has fresh water and one who wants to drink the water must bow down to reach the water. Thus, it is not only the ruler who is respected; there are many other valuable things which, if one wants to get them, must be sought with respect.
There should not be too much salt in the side-dish, otherwise it will be too salty.
The stone pot does not see its shadow. People do not see their own faults. Cf #1656.
The jar that kept salt keeps its flavor. One does not lose one's good points.
A jar of perfume keeps its smell.

text: Dhambi ikikiriwa ni nusu ya marekebisho.
explanation: A fault confessed is half redressed.

text: Donda kwa mwenzako linanuka, kwako halinuki.
explanation: The sore of your companion stinks, yours does not. Cf. #1656.
Explain your need, so you get what you need. Don't be too proud to ask for help. Cf. #1257.

text: Ewe mtuje, kwambe wali tafi ungalikuwaje?

explanation: There is no mortal who has nothing to be ashamed of.
There is no strong man among strong men. There is no man who can defeat all other men. To stop a booster.
One who despises another will be put to shame.

text: Howe! Ni ya mwenye kufuma: wewe una "howe" gani?
explanation: A hit! Praise is for the successful hunter; what do you shout about? A rebuke to somebody who boasts about nothing.
The rooster has its origins in the egg [as all fowl]. Arrogant people tend to forget their origin.
A monitor lizard is a monitor and never will be a crocodile.
Arrogance is followed by regrets.
Arrogance is not noble.
What floats will sink. Whatever is up will not last.

text: Kila muacha samboye hwenda ali mwanamaji.
Kila ndege mwenye mkia ni lazima aringe.
explanation: Every bird with a tail must show off.

text: Kima alijua jina la mti sababu ya kuzomewa na watu.
explanation: The monkey learned the name of the tree, because it was jeered by people. One who has been ridiculed away from home, brags at home.
The blind one is the lame one's guide. In many vital matters people claim to possess expert knowledge, which they do not have.
Too much shyness means trouble. If one is too ashamed to beg, that person will be in trouble and may die of hunger. It is better to lower onself than to die. Cf. #1206.

text: Kufukuru ya bibi-kisamvu alimwita mungu mjomba.
explanation: The blasphemy of Mrs. Cassava-leaf was that she called God her uncle. Mrs. Cassava-leaf was the housekeeper of Dhanis and ruled over her brothers, whom she disowned. She went as far as to say that she did not know them anymore, because God was her uncle...after the departure of Dhanis, she lived woefully.

text: Mama anna anasema mungu ni mjombe wake.
explanation: Mother Anne says that God is her uncle.

text: Kuhorahora si kwema, mara hanguwa mbichi.
explanation: It is not good to hit fruit with a long stick, suddenly a green one will come down.

text: Kuhurahura si kwema mara uchangia mbichi.
explanation: Stoking is not good, suddenly you will get into the unripe.
On account of its loquacity the bird got its name. One who is boasting too much will make mistakes.

text: La kwanza udhalili, la pili ukamili.
explanation: First humility, then perfection. Cf. #1668.

One's foul-smelling sore does not sicken oneself but merely disgusts. Although a stinking wound may disgust a person, it does not make him sick. One can live with one's own faults. A parent may get disgusted on account of a child's behavior, but does not reject the child.
Water drinks all water. The earth drinks all water. A humble person will receive more than a haughty character, and a modest person will acquire more learning than someone who believes to knows much.

text: Maji yakijaa hupwa, mpanda ngazi hushuka.
explanation: When the tide is high, it will ebb; a person who climbs a ladder comes down.
One who climbs a ladder, usually comes down.
One who climbs up stairs must climb down too. Cf.1649a.
Pride does not bring you anything. Cf. #?? Majisifu
The arms [bows] were not arms, much less the slings. If the properly educated fail, how about the rabble?
If the rope is not a rope, how about palm leaf strips?
The counselor's brain is his head. Is his pride. A pun on

A dog barks at home. A dog knows its home and the inmates. Has self-confidence. In danger it will protect the people. If it barks it shows its domain. If it goes to another place the environment is unfamiliar, and this is not its domain. A person has self-confidence and shows his capabilities when in familiar surroundings.
Gravy is water. There is no gravy without water. Do not despise people or things because they are common; often they are indispensable. Cf. #1131.
Wait for the palm tree climber at the bottom. If a person in a high position despises you, just be patient because that person will come down.
One who climbs a ladder will come down.

text: Mpanda ngazi hushuka, mungu pweke hutukuka.
explanation: The climber of a ladder will come down, only God is truly high. All people will die, even the powerful.
The one who says "I am invincible," do not believe that person.
The one who reads alone makes no mistakes. Without criticism from others one thinks highly of oneself.

text: Mtaka nyingi nasaba hupata mwingi msiba.
Mtu atwawapo na ghururi mbeleye ni maumivu.
explanation: A person possessed by vanity will see much suffering ahead.

text: Mtu haoni aibu yakwe, huona ya mwenziwe.
explanation: You do not see your own defects, but those of your neighbor.
Their own they don't see. Cf. #1656.
Nobody can swallow the sun.
A gentle person is like a lintel. Accepting everything calmly even when stepped upon.
When a person laughs the tongue hides the gap between the teeth. Everyone tries to hide own mistakes and those of the family.
A respected person does not boast.

text: Ni shakwe nina mbawa zangu: maji yatanipatapi?
explanation: I am a sea-gull, I have my wings: where can the sea get me?

text: Nyani haoni kundule, huliona la mwenziwe.

explanation: A cloud of dust covers shame. Of someone who tries to cover mistakes by artful means, or blinds the employer by making the dust fly.

text: Panzi kuingia motoni kajiona mkuu kama moto.
explanation: The grasshopper, entering the fire, felt as great as the fire. The reason why the grasshopper went into the fire was that it thought in its temerity that it could extinguish the fire.
You should hide in your loincloth the ring awarded by the king. If you receive an honor, don't publicize it.

text: Si kila mwenye makucha huwa simba.
explanation: Not all that have claws are lions. Cf. #1185.
Don't imagine yourself praiseworthy. Avoid boasting.

text: Sione tanga la nguo kasahau la miaa.
explanation: Do not dream about a cloth sail forgetting the matting one. Be content with what you have, and what has served you well.

text: Tangawizi kafa bure, mwenye viungo ni majano.
explanation: The ginger died in vain, it's the tumeric that makes the gravy. The ginger is like a person, whose contribution is not fully appreciated. The tumeric, that gives the color, takes all the praise, while the ginger that gives the taste is not mentioned.
Let us praise ourselves at the end. Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
Our lacks are not their greatness. They are not better than we are.
If you eat with a spoon, don't forget your hand. Many people used their fingers instead of a spoon or fork while eating. If you have climbed the social ladder, don't forget those who did not.
You have teeth and cover yourself with your lips. Each of us has received natural gifts; no need for boasting.
The crown of a guinea fowl cannot support a load. Said of a "little" person getting too big a responsibility.
The crown of the guinea-fowl cannot stand the sun. A weak person cannot fulfill a big job. Cf. #1640; #188.
Do not pretend to be a white chicken. Do not pretend other than you are. Cf. #1118.

text: Usikune kibuyu mbele ya mwenye upaa.
explanation: Don't scratch your little calabash in the presence of a bald person. Don't try to impress others.
Don't imitate the elephant in eating thorns. Be modest in your thinking and behavior.
Nobleness is not the same as a noble ancestry. Nobleness comes from the heart.

text: Wale wakinuka vumba leo wako ambarini.
explanation: Those who smelled are today in ambergris (perfume). The parvenu tries to cover the reminders of his origins.
What the Europeans brought, don't try to make it also. Don't immitate them blindly.

text: Za mtu ni mbili--akili na haya.

explanation: If you give clothing to a big fool see giant boasting.
The one who goes slowly will get far.
The one who walks carefully will certainly arrive.
The one who assents usually will get the first look.
Before the accident happens, better think carefully.
Do not wake up one who sleeps: if you do, you will sleep yourself. Let sleeping dogs lie.
Do not wake up one who sleeps; you'll sleep yourself. Cf. #510.
A tree does not fall upon someone who stands aside. Do not unnecessarily expose yourself to danger, or involve yourself in quarrels.
One who is far away will not get hit by the stick. Implied is that one should keep distance from people fighting. Cf. #1671.

text: Aliyekula kitu cha mamba asifike kwa maji.
explanation:
The one who ate what belongs to the crocodile should stay away from the water.
 Cf. #1678.
Trust is having confidence. It comes by practice and experience.
Have trust, but do not go too far
The one who awakens a lion with a start does not have an ostrich to eat. Either the lion will eat the ostrich or set it running. This is either a misprint or a word play.
The person who enters with determination will not fail.
A person who tramples on anything slippery must not be afraid to fall.
If you have no axe, avoid the snake. If you cannot argue well, avoid a clever person.
One who does not consider the outcome will end with an "If I had known.
One who does not know a lion should look at a lion-trap. Before starting anything look; explore possible dangers.

Someone drawing water from a river should not insult the crocodile. Do not provoke a stronger person. 
 Cf. #1673.

text: Athari ya kidole hasara ya mwili.
explanation: A sore finger hurts the whole body. If one member of the household is bad or sick, the whole house will suffer.
One who throws a stone throws a small one.
A rafter for the house should be shortened at home. Otherwise it may be too short to use. Look before you leap.
Sometimes a spider bites. Do not provoke people thoughtlessly. Usually a spider is not harmful to humans, but is capable of hurting if provoked.
A pig does not sleep in a lion's den. Used by a person who hates to live in a place of harassment.
When the skunk cries, hide the chickens.
A small spark of fire can burn down a forest.

text: Cheche dogo litajieneza mji mzima kuwaka moto.
explanation: A little spark will spread and set a whole city on fire.
A small spark makes a great fire.
A spark creates a fire. Small beginnings.
A spark left alone burns the town.

A spark that is not put out burns a town. 
 Cf. #1682.

A leopard is not embraced. 
 Cf. #1711.

text: Chukua maji hata ufikilie katika maji, usiyamwae uliyo nayo kwa tamaa ya maji ya mbele.
explanation: Carry water till you arrive at water, do not pour out what you have in hopes of "water on ahead.
Carry water until you perceive water. Do not use all water until you are certain of being near a well.
If you destroy a bridge, be sure you can swim.
Measure the depth of a pool of water with a rod. Before attempting to do a project you should examine its possibility first.
Don't extend your finger to an insect that bites. Beware of evil people. Don't associate with them. Cf. #1681; #1683; #1711; #1866; #1869.

The stick that hit your rival, throw it far away. You the wife of a polygamist throw far away the stick which your husband has used to beat another wife. A punishment given to a close neighbor can also become yours.

text: Fisi akila mgonjwa, mzima funga nyumba.
explanation: When the hyena ate a sick person, [you] healthy person close your house.
What is well tied does not hurt the hand.

Tying well does not tire the arms. 
 Cf. #1519
Caution brings blessings. Cf. #1669, #1694, #1717A.

text: Haifai kumtukania sungura miguu yake mikubwa na tembo akiwa pale.
explanation: Don't berate the hare for its big feet when the elephant is close by.
There is no ridicule of the throat. The throat is too vulnerable.
Watch out! Watch out! A stick and eyes. Take care, so you do not get a stick in the eye. A warning against carelessness.
To lack good sense is a great disadvantage. From a song by Siti binti Saad

text: Si hoja uzuri, na sura jamali

explanation: Wisdom [creates] well-being. JK. Wisdom saves.

text: Ikiwa tumbo ni laini, huli machicha.
explanation: If you have a tender stomach, do not eat dregs. Do not attempt to do something which will harm you.
Beware of sitting on a bad branch. Beware of what you put your trust in.
When the monitor lizard is out walking, the centipede takes it easy in the sun.
To climb a coconut tree be sure that you can encircle it with your arms. If you want to undertake a difficult task, be sure you can master it, otherwise do not attempt it.
Silence asks that you tie a belt round your waist. Careful planning is needed before taking a decision. Tying a belt stands for doing something big.
The tortoise does not bite the paw of a leopard. A meek person does not fight a stronger one.
A sheep does not follow a jackal.
The goshawk is not the foster mother of a hen with chicks. It would be like leaving the cat in charge of meat in the cooking pot.
Locking up tightly means sleeping outside. You may shut yourself out.

Sitting on a stump is like being in danger of falling off. About people who criticize constantly, such as a woman who is always blaming her husband for everything, and does things that could cause a divorce. HM, FSM. FSM cites #357A to explain its meaning. [Kuti kavu kuanguka si ajabu. a dry leaf falling off is nothing to be amazed at.
A chicken does not fly when there is no danger.
A new fowl does not lack a string round its leg. A foreigner is looked upon with distrust and is observed carefully.
Putting porridge-flour in baskets. To lay in food supplies, store away something for a rainy day.
Don't throw your cooking-stones where you have hidden the calabash Your impulsive reaction may spoil your design.

text: Likishika mkoma liue, kesho litakamata mzima.
explanation: If it took a leper kill it, tomorrow it will take a healthy person. Understood, a dangerous animal: hyena, leopard, lion.
Extinguish the fire in the grass near you.
Ashes which have cooled burn down the house. Cf. #1708A.
Know-how, not force [is the way to do things]. One must proceed thoughtfully. Violence is useless.

text: Mbele ya kuvuta tumbako, yafaa kukohoa.
explanation: Before you start smoking tobacco, you better cough first. One ought to weigh the pros and cons before starting something.

text: Mbuzi siivunje zizi, jicho la nje haliizi.
explanation: Goat, don't break the pen, the eye outside does not refuse. Girls should not leave the parental home before they marry. Their restless eyes may spy handsome but scrupulous men, when they look out.

text: Mfukuza kicheche porini kisha mwonye kuku asitembee kichakani.
explanation: Chase the skunk into the wild, then warn the chickens not to go into the bush.

text: Mfukuza nyoka kwa mikono mitupu hajui afanyalo.
explanation: People who chase away a snake with bare hands don't know what they are doing.
Honor a devil sitting on a throne.
Do not kindle a fire that you cannot put out. Do not start something which you cannot control, for you may fail and perhaps damage yourself.
Wnen the river is high, one sleeps on the bank. Wait until it is safe to cross the river.

text: Mtu halali karibu na mto, ujapokuwa umekauka maji.
explanation: A person must not sleep near a river, even though its waters have dried up. Do not put yourself in danger.

People are asked about what they are dressed in but not about what they have eaten. People do not care what a person does at home, but if that person goes out, then that person is in public, and will be questioned. A person is not asked about secrets, but about obvious things. KA. Indiscreet questions are not answered.
Watch out for the scoundrel who is in the tree. Somebody above you is the one you must watch out for.

text: Mwenye kuwa na macho hapiti katika njia mbaya.
explanation: One who has eyes does not pass along a bad road.
Let the strong-one pass. You can't do anything else.
Strength cannot be bought. A person should not squander his talents.

text: Nyumba ya mnandi haingii ila mnandi mwenyewe.
explanation: None enter the nest of the cormorant except the cormorant itself. The cormorant's nest is said to be attached by a sort of cable to the bottom of the sea. It is in this habitation, crank and flimsy though it be, that the cormorant is supposed to sit and hatch its young; hence, it may be, the above saying: Into such a crazy thing no other bird would venture, even if it might.
Don't put a skunk in a hen's nest. The skunk will eat the chicks.
Don't throw a stone in a dark bush. You might hurt somebody or a wild animal might come out.
When the fire has gone out beware of the ashes. Cf. #1681, #1698.
When mice are many they don't dig a burrow. Safety in numbers.
Where there are safari ants one should pass quickly. Don't expose yourself to danger, pain or abuse.
The place where there is shade is the place I lay my child down. I do not consult one hostile or incapable [ignorant?] about my cherished designs.

text: Penye uvuli ndipo mtu alazapo mwanawe.
explanation: It is only in the shady place that a person lays her child down.
Don't play with a dog, it'll bite your calves. Do not associate with bad people, not even lightly.
Do not play with a wild cat.
Do not play with an adze, it will wound you. Be careful with people who can hurt you.

text: Sile viambiwa ni sumu: alae havimlichi, humpeleka kuzimu.
explanation: Don't eat what is called poisonous; it does not spare the one who eats it, but takes that person to the world hereafter.
If you flee from the sword, don't hide in the scabbard. If you try to escape a danger, don't place yourself where it can be more dangerous.
Don't traveI in a new vessel.
