text: Sisafiri katika chombo kipya kuacha kikuukuu.
explanation: Don't travel in a new vessel leaving the old one. Also: don't leave an old trustworthy friend for a new one, one hardly knows. Cf. #1714; #1661; #925.
Do not fight against water, it will swallow you up. Don't fight authority.
If you find the river flooded, wait. Wait for the right moment to do something.
Careful, careful is better than medicine.
Look before you jump.
Look where you are going, anything is possible.
Consider the things that have passed, they predict what is coming.
Look at what is passed.

text: Tuondoe silaha za kutuharibu, kabla hazijatuharibu.
explanation: Let's get rid of harmful weapons, before they harm us.
Let's not insult the midwives, when birthing has not yet come.
If you play with a fool, he'll pierce your eye. Fools set stools for wise men to stumble at.
If you go forward - don't forget to look back. Remember where you came from.
If you eat with a cruel people, don't startle them. If you cooperate with fools, be careful to tell them what you are doing, because they could make things difficult for you.
If you eat with a blind people, satisfy them.
If you eat fish look out for a bone.

text: Ukimfungia kambuluku mzigo, uangalie miguu yake.
explanation: If you burden a dwarf antelope, observe its legs. The legs are very thin.
If you wake up one who sleeps, you will sleep yourself. Cf. #1670
If you admonish constantly about peace you provoke a quarrel.
When you have hidden the sweet sugar banana, don't call the civet-cat. Don't invite a thief. Probably the end of a story in which the civet eats the banana.
When you drink water think where it comes from.
When you go outside look at the clouds.
When you enter a house look at the faces.
Don't play in still waters. Still waters run deep.
Don't play with the young of a leopard. Its claws will grow. Cf. #1710, #1712.

text: Usicheze na simba, ukamtia mkono kinywani.
explanation: Don't play with a lion, putting your hand in its mouth. That would go too far.
Don't relieve yourself under a palm tree. When a bunch of palm nuts is cut, it may fall in excrement.

text: Usikamate kuku kama mgeni yupo pa mlango.
explanation: Don't grab a chicken [for dinner], at the moment a visitor is at the door.
Do not carry what you cannot.
Don't laugh at a leopard that hides its claws. Be careful with those in power.
Don't buy a wild animal enclosed in a bag. Don't buy a pig in a poke.
Do not pray to meet a lion. Do not ask for trouble.
Don't kick a sharp stick. You will get hurt.

text: Usiushtaki upepo ukiangusha tundu la ndege.
explanation: Don't blame the wind if it overthrows a bird's nest. It's the fault of the bird that built a poor nest.

text: Usiweke mayai yako yote ndani ya kikapu kimoja.
explanation: Don't put all your eggs in one basket.
Do not cross water that is too deep for bathing. Cf. #1686.
When they pull we should let go, and when they let go we should pull. Take it when the other gets tired. Wait for your turn.

text: Wende polepole na utaratibu: utakamata mkia na kima.
explanation: Go slowly and carefully, and you will grasp the tail of the monkey. Be crafty if you want to know the character of somebody.
If you put a leopard in the fold, the regret of it never ends.

text: Anayelaumiwa ni yule mwenye bahati mbaya.
explanation: The unlucky person is always bIamed. Cf. #689.

text: Avumaye baharini papa, kumbe wengine wapo.
explanation: The one who is famous in the sea is the shark, but then there are others. It is not the only pebble on the beach. Cf. #1757.

text: Chombo kilichopikiwa samaki, hakiachi kunuka vumba.

explanation: Let the leopard change just one of its spots.
A leopard cannot change its spots.

text: Chui ni mnyama wa hatari: ana bahati ya shetani.
explanation: The leopard is a dangerous animal: it has Devil's luck.
The blood of a bug is misfortune.
A hyena is not worthy to be served meat. About ungrateful and wasteful people.
Mombasa is a deep hole. It swallows one up.
Mombasa is a dark hole.
A good name shines in the dark.
A good name is better than many riches.
A big cooking pot hides the hard-burnt food.

text: Kendwa hayendwi, mkenda kumi, hurudi kenda.
Kijito kinaweza kukauka maji, lakini jina hubaki.
explanation: The stream may dry up, but retains the name. If a person with a good name, due to his services, declines in his performances, his reputation will still continue.

text: Kikiharibika ni cha fundi, kikifaa ni cha bwana suudi.

explanation: Everyone who makes a mistake loses some self-esteem. After a mistake one blushes.

text: Kila mtu huona mzigo wa mwenzie ukuti.
explanation: Everyone thinks that the burden of a companion is as light as a dry coconut leaf.
Will the Kisauni grow the casuarina? The general meaning is: What good can come from ...? This saying is used by putting whatever name is a propos. e.g.

text: Kutamea barani mivinde, nani kwao pasipo na wende.
explanation: Will there grow casuaria trees inland? Who has no friends in his own town? Every man grows and prospers in his homeland".
Mombasa will not grow the banana-tree. From a song about the haughty inhabitants, by Muyaka.
Mombasa cannot stand the pompous.
It is easier to pull down than to build up. It's easier to see another's faults and destroy that person's reputation than to see the better side and give praise.

text: Kuku hawekwi shahidi, wala hajui sheria.
Lisemwalo lipo; ikiwa halipo, lipo nyuma linakuja.
explanation: What is being talked about is here; if it is not here, it's coming along behind.

text: Liambiwalo liko liko, na likiwa haliko li njiani laja.
explanation: Anything people say is there, and if it is not there, it is on the way It will come soon because people talk about it.
If it has not arrived yet it will, and it will be done. Cf. #1416.
Poor people do not pick up things; if they do, people say that they have stolen them.

text: Mpe mbwa jina mbaya halafu umnyonge.
explanation: Give the dog a bad name and then strangle it.
If the natives of Pemba can get a log, they don't relieve themselves on the ground. Nothing but the best.
A native of Pemba does not run away from a little rain. Because when it rains in Pemba it falls heavily.
A native of Pemba does not sew a small container.

text: Mrima nyarima, usipoliwa na nyani, utaliwa na kima.
Mtu huyu ndiye kijogoo wa mji siku hizi.
explanation: This person is the town rooster nowadays. About a notorious character.
Mombasa has things in great quantities.

text: Mvita kwa mwenda pole, mwenda kwa haraka hukwaa dole.
explanation: Mombasa is for the person who goes gently; a person in haste will hurt his toe. Cf. #1159.
Mombasa is a town of drunkenness.
One cannot leave one's character behind. Said of people who try to hide their faults or pretend to be what they are not; well, they cannot, at some time they will show their true seIf.

text: Mwenye tumbo ni tumbole, angafunga mkaja.
explanation: She who is pregnant is pregnant, even if she wraps herseIf with a wrap-around. You don't achieve something by merely pretending you have achieved it.

text: Naona hutoki unguja, umekunywa maji ya kiponda.
explanation: I see that you have not left Zanzibar, you have been drinking water from the Kiponda fountain..

text: Ni msimbo wa milele, hata kesho kiyamani.
explanation: It is an imputation dishonorable forever, until the Resurrection. Sacl.

text: Nyama wote wangawako, mkuza-pezi ni papa.

explanation: Visit Pemba prudently.

text: Pemba peremba ukija na winda utarudi na kilemba.

explanation: All fish smell, but they suspected the catfish. If a fish stinks, one suspects at once that it is a catfish. A bad reputation always follows you.
The sweetness of tea is the sugar. Although the tea is praised, what makes many people like tea is the sugar in it. So a person's reputation derives from personality and not from appearance.
If you move your homestead, it's not nice to leave your excrement behind. Don't leave a bad reputation behind you.
So and So has committed suicide with his/her own knife. Someone teIling a secret to someone not trustworthy. Cf. #1803.

text: Anayeishi chini ya mti ndiye ajuaye riziki ya mchwa.
explanation: The person who lives under the tree is the one who knows the life of the termite. Riziki: livelihood, needs for a livimg.

text: Anayekueleza ya nengine atawaeleza wengine ya kwako.
explanation: One who teIls you about others will tell others about you. Who chatters to you will chatter of you.
Whenever someone fries, we are under the potsherd. Someone always learns about a secret; it always leaks out somehow.

text: Mngakaanga bizi tu chini mwa taya.
explanation: Whenever you roast maize we are under your jaw.

text: Mukikaanga bisi, sisi tuko chini ya gae.
explanation: If you fry popcorn, we are already at the bottom of the pan [lit., potsherd].
May the person who tells turn to stone. A quite common saying, based on a fairy tale, in which the hero turned to stone.
To someone who cannot keep a secret no word can be whispered. Cf. #1768
Don't tell your friend about your sweet gifts. Keep your secrets to yourself.
A small thing can hold a big secret.

text: Domo kaya samli kwa mwenye ng'ombe.
Gogo la choo, la ona mengi.
explanation: The beam of the outhouse sees a lot.
Do not reveal family matters to a neighbor. Cf. #1771.
It is not in it, it is not in it; [and suddenly] that is where it was.
It is not in, it is not in and there it is in. The meaning is that: Although everybody said "It is not there," nevertheless it was there. The exception proves the rule.
Those who said it does not happen, well it is here now. Cf,#76.
There is no secret when shared by three people.
Revelation pertains to God.
If something burns, smoke will rise up. No secret will remain hidden. Things done in great secret will be revealed and acknowledged.

What lies on its back is yours, what is covered do not uncover. Don't bother with things that do not concern you. What is open for inspection becomes your legitimate knowledge and everyone else's. What lies on its back is open.

text: Kilicho ndani ya ngoma chajuliwa na aliyeitengeneza.
explanation: What is inside the drum nobody knows but the one who made the drum. The maker of a drum puts a pebble or seed inside the drum. Only God knows all the secrets of everyone.
With excessive cleaning, you chance to leave with excrement. Leave weIl alone! You won't improve matters by going on tinkering.
Speaking is giving away.
Walls have ears.

That which should be kept in the room, should not be discussed on the verandah. Where a person not concerned may hear it. This implies that one should not discuss family scandals or quarrels in public. Cf. #1771.
Things from within [the family] should not be told outside. Cf. #1766.

text: Kupata kwa limbukeni, mataka hulia mbwata.
explanation: One who receives something for the first time, his behind clacks. One who receives something much desired is in high spirit.

text: Macho hayali, ushahidi wa kuona tu.
explanation: Eyes don't eat, they are only witnesses. Envy is sterile.
Eyes have no screen. They see all that is in view, good or bad, and cannot be blamed for what they see.
The eye has no boundary.

Big houses conceal a lot. The big houses of our rulers and important people hide much badness, although they are supposed to be an example for other people. Great people are not always in the big houses.

text: Mambo ya ngoma nda ngoma, hwishia papo ngomani.

explanation: What is of the drum belongs to the drum
The things of the drum/dance are of the drum/dance.

text: Mambo ya nyumba kunga, makuti kuungaunga.
explanation: Happenings at home are secret, keep the branches constantly together. The things that happen in a family are secrets of that home. There is no perfect household. Every family has its minor evils, but an outsider must not know.
It is the behind that knows a good chair.

text: Mchawi akifichua mirimo ya wenzake huuawa.

explanation: A mouth with a secret is like a trumpet. An evil tale travels wide and loud.

text: Mjuvi wa siri ni yeye mwenyewe.
explanation: The Knower of secrets is He HimseIf. God only is the possessor of secrets.

text: Mlango unaona mamba ya ndani, na ya nje.
explanation: A door sees what is happening inside and outside. A domestic of the house observes all that is going on among the habitants.
A person who desires to create something does not announce it. That person just turns them into facts.
One who wants to create things does not announce it publicly.

text: Mtambi wa nyumba mbili hawi mdhabidhabina.
explanation: A person who goes from one house to another must not become a gossip-monger. Who frequents two houses must not be a mischief-maker.

text: Mtu akitaka tenda, lake huchimbia shimo.
explanation: A person wanting to act digs a pit for his plan. Do not disclose your plans, your enviers may spoil them.
A person does not sleep with a concern on the heart.

text: Mtu siri husema na moyo wakwe.
explanation: A person speaks of a secret within the heart. And keeps the secret hidden.
The space under the bed is like a mat. There may be somebody there!
The sex of a fetus is unknown. The future is not known.
The corpse-washer does not harm the body. And keeps all the secrets. Cf.#514; #565; #566; #567; #656.
The corpse-washer conceals the corpse. And therefore it seems that the corpse like a miser, does not want to give anything away. Muslims fear to look at a naked corpse. Sacl

The burier of the ivory is also the one who brings the ivory to light. One who has a secret is the only one who can reveal it. In trading up-country, Arabs sometimes purchase ivory that they have not the means of transporting to the coast. In that case they bury it and keep the secret to themselves until they return with another caravan.
Where they hid it there also will they look for it. Be logical, be sensible, reason things out. You must go to the competent person to solve a problem.
A good dream must not be revealed. If you get a lucky break you should not talk about it, otherwise people may harm or slander you.
Dirty clothes are washed in the backyard. Dirty clothes should be washed in a private place. Don't publicize your weakness.
Am I to throw my rice at the chickens? Should I reveal my secrets? Cf. #1788.
A secret meeting has no brother or sister. Evil is planned in secret and secret must be kept.
Keep quiet, let the cripple pass. Cf. #1765.
A big house [family] hides big things. Like quarrels, jealousies, etc. Cf. # 1773. #427. #428.
Where there are many fowls, millet [or rice] is not scattered. It is not advisable to disclose a secret in the presence of a number of people.
When a plate is covered, its contents are hidden. Many uses: Keep your mouth shut. But also, to encourage women to dress modestly.
The ear does not go to bed hungry. There is always plenty of gossip.
Secret son of secret, if overrated it will come out. A secret too well guarded will be given away in the end. One taking too many precautions will draw attention.
A person's secret is know by that person. A secret is known by the keeper.
The secret of a person is unknown.
The secret of the water pot is known by the ladle. To know the inside of a situation, the best way often is to live it.
Ask the ladle about the secret of the waterpot.

text: Ukitaka siri ya mtungi uliza kata.
explanation: If you want to know the secret of the waterpot, ask the cover. The cover is always with the pot and is present to all what is going on.
Don't teIl your secret to a woman.

text: Ukimficha jogoo kwenye pakacha kuna wakati atawika.
explanation: If you hide a rooster in a basket, he will crow sometime. People will know about it.
If you have a treasure, do not dig it up by daytime.

The rope knows the depth of the well. The rope that goes down with the bucket knows how far to go to reach the water level. The one who finished a project knows about its hardship and joy. Cf #1791A; #512; #514.

text: Usemalo ng'ambo ya mto lasikilika na vyura.
explanation: What you say across the river is heard by the frogs. People are eager for secrets.
Do not show on your face wbat you feel in your heart. Cf. #1795.
Time uncovers all.
Those who whisper must abstain from coughing. Cf. #1764.

text: Watu siri huibiana: [ndio hali ya duniani].
explanation: People steal secrets from each other; [such is the way of the world].
Where are they who know [the affairsl of next year?
The affairs of your companions are in the pot, your own are in a potsherd. People speak openly about the affairs and mistakes of others, thinking that their own are little and unknown.

text: Yalahu yalam, mambo siri kwa mungu.
explanation: I swear by God, secrets are with God.
What is inside is inside. Keep your secrets.
Cover yours with mats. Hide your faults.
Someone faking blindness of one eye although seeing well. Said of people who pretend not to see what is happening to suit their conveniences.

text: Ahadi na mithaki ni deni katika haki.
explanation: A promise and a vow are debts indeed. Mithaki: having strength, having perfection.
A promise is a debt.

text: Ahadi ni deni, na deni ijuzie.
explanation: A promise is a debt, and a debt obliges.

text: Ahadi ni deni, na deni ijuzie.
Ahadi ni mtu, msi ahadi si mtu.
explanation: Keeping] a promise is [being] a real human, one who does not [keep a promise] is not a real person.
Promises have obligations.
One who knows much does not say much.
The one who knows much says little.

text: Alindaye ulimi wake, alinda nafsi yake.
explanation: People who watch their tongue take care of [guard] their soul.
Praise a good person, keep silent about a bad one.
People who are told tall stories, have their own to tell. Said when a story is not believed.
It is the tongue that bound its owner What was said lightly has come to pass, and has caught up with that person.

text: Msi hadhari hujifunga kwa ulimi wake.
explanation: If you are careless, you bind yourself with your tongue. Cf. #1841.
The animal] that roars is not the one that will eat meat. cf. # 1852; # 1852.
A person who cannot take a joke is no joker. Don't make jokes on people if you cannot take a joke yourseIf. Cf. #1883.

text: Aso hasanati wala thawabu hufungwa kitaya kama rikabu.

explanation: For a person who understands, half a greeting is enough.

text: Binadamu ana macho mawili, masikio mawili na mdomo mmoja.
explanation: A human being has two eyes, two ears, but one mouth. Watch and listen twice before speaking once.
Study is better than talking.
The only useful things are those that can be put in a pot and eaten. Said by a wife to an unemployed, loquacious husband.
A half empty tin never fails to make noise. Empty vessels make the most sound. People with little knowledge talk most.
A half filled tin does not stop shaking.
An empty tin cannot stop sounding.
An empty tin never stops making noise.
Democracy is not domocracy. Actions, not mere words. Democracy is a way of life, and freedom and discipline are its bases. Domocracy is to rule by mere talk, a lot of words without actions.

text: Fikara ndogo hufanya mtu aseme sana.
explanation: Little thoughtfulness causes a person to say too much.
Much talk, many lies. Cf. #1834, #1850.
Talk is the

text: Habari ya mbalamwezi, kung'aa na kufifia.
explanation: News of the full moon, to shine and to fade away. Do not believe all the rumors one hears in the evening; in the morning, they fade away.
There is no scar for slander. Moral evil cannot be cured.
Nothing will be of any use, neither male nor female. Too much talking.
No word is spoiled if the lips stay together. Cf. #1219A; Contrast #1821A, #1824.
So and So has no lining to the tongue.
To the words of a gossiper nothing is added.
Too much shame killed the partridge. The partridge died of hunger because it did not ask for food or shelter. This is also sometimes said ironically when somebody overeats. Cf.#1206.

text: Heri kukunguwaa kidole kuliko kukunguwaa ulimi.
Heri kujikunguwaa kidole kuliko kujikunguwaa ulimi.
Heri kwaa ya dole kuliko kwaa ya ulimi.
Heri kukuwaa kwa guu kama kwa ulimi.
explanation: Better to stumble with the foot than with the tongue. The toe may be very painful, but the harm the tongue can do, can bring much greater pain and trouble.

text: Hicho ni chuo cha mwangoma, cha majini pepo: endao kifyoma hukiacho papo.
explanation: This is the book of Mwangoma about the demons: the person who is going to read it, leaves it forthwith. About an unpleasant subject of conversation, which you would rather not enlarge on.
Tolerate a joke, there is no wound in it. It does not hurt. RSP. Cf. #46.

text: Huamba ulimi, ni mimi, ni mimi.
explanation: The tongue says, it is me, it is me. Talkers always talk about themselves.
So and So refused you food, but did not stop you speaking.
He talks like a cymbal. A chatterbox.
You cannot think, without holding your tongue.
A big barking dog does not bite. A person who talks a lot and threatens others does not harm others.
A cock will crow to a cock, when he crows the other one will crow too. People will gossip, and what one person says will go around."JKP.
The clever rooster crows. It is the work of the rooster to crow in the morning. It is its duty. Let people know what you can do, what you are worth.
A pen [a word] that has spoken brings the event nearer.
Everyone who has a need goes to the rubbish heap. All people slander".
Silence does not bring harm.
Silence finished the trees in the forest. For not protesting the evil done.

text: Kimya, kimya si ujinga, ni maneno ya kupeleleza.
explanation: Silence is not necessarily foolishness, it could be spying.
Silence is a big noise. Silence predicts storm, silence indicates your enemy is premeditating a big move.

text: Kimya ni sifa ya maiti, yu hai husema.
explanation: Silence is an attribute of the dead, one who is alive speaks.
The mouth like a bell, the legs like the
Grow up and see. Said to a child who is asking too many questions.

text: Kuambiliwa kuna uwongo, mara kumi ukajionee.
explanation: Hearsay is full of error, go and see yourself even ten times.
Being told is not the same as understanding.
Speaking evil you will see it comes back. Persons with evil tongues will soon find they are slandering themselves.
Talking, talking does not cure the cripple. Too many words serve no purpose.
No need to say much. There is no need for many words.
To speak many words is not [winning] an argument.

text: Kusema si hoja, kazi ni kufanya.
explanation: Talking is no necessity, the essence of the job is to get it done.

text: Kusema ni kuzuri, na kutosema ni kuzuri.
Hotuba ni fedha na kimya ni dhahabu.
explanation: Speech is silver and silence is golden.
Speaking is not the same as doing.
Reading is not the same as being told.

text: Kwamba kwema kwenye shukurani ni kumpa mtu atakayo.
explanation: Speaking good words of gratitude is giving a person what is needed.

text: Kweli ya mdogo si uwongo wa mkubwa.
explanation: A little person's truth is not [as acceptable as] the big person's lie. A little person may say the truth about something, but this will not be believed as well as the lies which an important person may say about it.
Going with fools and words never ends.
Just lick the honey, don't ask any questions. Cf. #166.
What is worth explaining, explain; what is not worth, swallow it. One who speaks little has little to answer for.
What is, is spoken about. People speak about the things that are present. So, don't do bad or stupid things, because people will speak about it.
What is in the heart, the tongue steals. Secrets want to be told and often come out inadvertently.

Watch your tongue like a farmer [watches his crop]. In Africa farmers must constantly watch their crops lest they are eaten by birds, monkeys or wild pigs. In the same way, the words we have spoken may be misused by our enemies to harm us.
Bad language is soonest learned. It is easier to learn what is evil than what is good.
Bad language is like a stench.
Still waters are deep.
Roaring water has no teeth. Barking dogs seldom bite. Cf. #1852.
Charcoals do not roast the meat. Dead embers do not roast meat. Fair words butter on parsnips.
It is a surprise why the charcoal did not roast meat. Said of people who do not perform as well as they could.
Forty mouths are like forty spears.
Forty tongues, forty spears.
Ten tongues are ten javelins. Cf. #1860.

text: Makukuu ya tai si mapya ya kengewa.
Mambo yafaayo watu ni yangiayo chunguni.

explanation: Speaking is like silver, but replying is like gold.
Hard words break no bones. Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me.
Sharp teeth do not break a bone. Stay away from quarrels.
Hard words break a bone. Hard words can hurt a person very deeply, as painful as the breaking of a bone.
Kind words are a blessing.

text: Maneno mazuri kama maua yana rangi yake.
explanation: Nice words are like flowers: they have their own color.
Pleasant words will draw a snake from its hole. With kind words one may calm down a dangerous person. It is easier to catch flies with honey than with vinegar.
Sweet words will draw a snake from its hole. Usage in a newspaper
A good word draws a snake from its hole.
A kind word made a snake come out of its hole. To obtain something by trick or flattery.
Many words are like a disease. Chattering and talking nonsense are signs that the brain is giving way.
Many words are like a sickness.
Many words call forth a lot of disgrace. Talkativeness reveals one's faults, weaknesses.
Many words consume the brain.

text: Maneno mengi ya kweli husemwa katika dhihaka.
explanation: Many a true word is spoken jokingly.

text: Maneno ni kama fumo yakitoka mdomoni hayarudi.
explanation: Words are like spears, once when they leave the lips they never come back. Watch what you are saying.

text: Maneno ya mpole yampoza mwenye hasira

explanation: Laments are expressed by tears.

text: Mbele ya kusema uzungushe ulimi mara saba kinywani.
explanation: Before you speak, turn your tongue seven times in your mouth.

text: Mche mnyamavu: ana ngoma za midomo.
explanation: Mistrust a taciturn person, that person has lips like a drum. Has lips for an oration.
Your gossiping mouth tells you what you really are. Deep inside you know what you really are..
The table may be small, but the palavers are many. When unimportant things seem to be important.
Control your lips, to sleep in peace.

text: Mja kiwa sawa, kambiwa yu kombo.
explanation: Even when a person is straight, they will say there is something crooked with him. Even if the newcomer is correct, they'll say that he is imperfect.
One who keeps silent lasts.
A sorcerer speaks not. Keeps silent about evil intent. Keeps away from people.
A brave traveler has many tall stories.
One who is not afraid to be slandered is a fool.
The one who does not have any [word] has God. God suffices as a witness." Koran 24,6 Eloquence is not necessary.
If you have no one, you have God.
One who is spat upon often enough gets intoxicated. If somebody is told a thing over and over again that person will finally believe it.
One who does good does not speak about it; if that person does speak [about it] that one does not do [good] deeds. Also used regarding people who talk a lot but perform poorly.

text: Mtu huanza kumega tonge kwanza, haanzi kupanua kinywa.
explanation: A person starts breaking a piece of bread first, the mouth is not opened first. Think before speaking or doing things. Wait for your time. In due time.
The tongue betrays the head. Puts the head in trouble. Cf. #1803.

text: Mtu kikwambia neno, sijibu upesi mno.
explanation: If someone tells you something, do not answer too quickly.
A blind person is not asked, what do you see. Cf. #1703.
A gentleman is [as good as his] word. Cf. #916.
A slanderer of your friend sends you to tell your friend. Don't talk bad to someone's friend, because that person will tell the friend.
Speaking evil about someone to your friend is the same as sending your friend on a mission to tell that person about the bad thing you said.
Tell it to the person who is willing to listen.
A child that slanders another gives away leftover food [in order to pacify the one slandered].
One who walks in silence quarrels with nobody. Moreover, people respect the silent one because that person is more difficult to understand.
A noisy person has no message.

One who goes to the meeting place will not come back with nothing. Going to the place where people gather to talk things over will enlighten us about happenings, whether true or false. However, because it is also a place of gossip, it can also mean that if you go and listen to gossip, you'll return with many problems.
When someone wears mourning clothes you don't ask why.
A joke needs its own time and place.
If you control your mouth you have much prudence.

text: Natuone ndipo twambe, kusikia si kuona.
explanation: Let us see, then we can talk, hearing is not seeing. Cf. #1333.

text: Neno jiwi ni jeraha la moyo.
explanation: A bad word wounds the heart.

text: Neno jiwi ni kidonda cha moyo.
explanation: An evil word wounds the heart. It does not heal easily, is not soon forgotten. Evil words build a lasting hatred.
I saw it, I saw it! They will make you a witness. Do not talk too much, you might be called to account for it.
Flattery is tasty. Idle praise is sweet. It is better to use kind words than words that hurt.

text: Panya anasema na mwamba, mwenye neno halijui.
explanation: The mouse said to the joist, the one we talk about suspects nothing. We are often ignorant of what people say or think of us.
It came to pass and it happened ... A phrase used in starting a tale. The end of the story
Where there is an abundance of words, sin also is not lacking.
Say what you know. Don't say what you don't know.

text: Shairi ni maneno mazuri ya mawazo matamu.
explanation: A poem is made of nice words and fine thoughts.
A pit [dug by] the tongue cannot be covered up by the hand. A word is past recalling.
A big weapon is the tongue. For cure and harm.

text: Simba mwenda kimya ndiye alaye nyama.
explanation: The lion which moves silently is the one that eats the meat.
A lion that hunts does not roar.
A roaring lion is not a hunter.
A roaring lion is tired of hunting.
I don't vomit bile and come back to lick it. A word spoken cannot be taken back. About nasty words or deeds. Used, e.g., in a divorce.
The poison of a word is a word. Abuse going from bad to worse.

text: Tajiri akinong'ona husikika, maskini akipayuka hasikiki.
explanation: A rich person whispering is heard, a poor person fulminating is not heard.

text: Tone hutoza dosari ambalo ndoo tele haitoshi kuliondoa.
explanation: A drop can cause a stain that a bucketful of water cannot remove. Stain here represents an insult or bad word.

text: Ukiona neno, usinene neno: ukinena neno litakujia neno.
Ukiona neno, usiposema neno, hupatikani na neno.

explanation: If you move your tongue too much, your mouth will be harmed. The silent people and the babblers are asocial people.
When you tell news, do not speak in riddles. Do not slander by allusion.
The tongue has no remedy. Wounds inflicted by the tongue are incurable. Cf. #855, #856.
The tongue cures itself. You cannot put medicine on the tongue. Cf. #2047.
The tongue endangers the body. By provoking fights.
Sweet language makes the elephant leave the plantation. Gentle coaxing often removes a danger. Cf. #1833.

text: Ulimi ukuchome kwa chakula, sio kwa maneno.
explanation: Food should burn your tongue, but not words. It's better to be hurt than hurt others.
The tongue is surrounded by a stone fort. The tongue should be guarded within the wall of teeth.
The tongue stays in the middle of the teeth. We are surrounded by enemies. Be careful of what we say.
The tongue hurts more than the teeth. Cf. #1833, 1854.

text: Usijitende ng'ombe, ukatoa ulimi kutia puani.
explanation: Do not act like a cow, sticking out your tongue and putting it into your nose. Do not put back into your nose what has come from your mouth, [i.e., a promise].
Don't act the cow!

text: Usikaange mbuyu ukawaachia wenye meno watafune
explanation: Do not roast baobab kernels and let those who have teeth chew them. Don't start quarrels among other people by telling tales.
Do not speak loudly so that a passerby hear it.
If you do not speak up, you'll get thin. A silent person is pushed back and cannot hope to have a happy life.

text: Usiseme ni haki unachoweza kuuliza kwa upendeleo.
explanation: Don't say that it is your right if you can ask for it as a favor.
Don't speak about what happened on the road before investigating.
Let them speak in daytime, at night they will sleep. Those who speak against you cannot speak all the time. So you should not mind so much.
Where words are spoken there also words are heard. Be careful what you say. Make your good ideas heard.

text: Wasemayo ni kweli; hata hayajafika, sharti yafike.
explanation: Spoken words are efficacious; even if not yet realized, they surely will come through.

text: Wasikilize wote wasemao lakini washangilie wachache wasemao busara tu.
explanation: They may listen to all the speakers, but applause [only] the few who make sense.
Those who speak a lot during the day, are tired [sleep] at night. Slanderers get tired at the end. So don't worry too much about them.

text: Watu ni gamba, hawakosi la kwamba.
explanation: People are like gramophones, they never stop talking.
People have many tongues. Referring to the talk of the town.
I mean, I mean, does not break a bone. Empty words do not achieve anything.
What is said and what is done are different.

text: Yateue ya usemi, na utawale ulimi.
explanation: Choose eloquent words and control your tongue.

text: Cha kuokota si cha kuiba, cha mfalme kina mwiba.
explanation: Finding is not stealing, but what belongs to the chief has a sting. All things found on the shore belong to the chief.
What belongs to the chief has a sting.
Suspicion does not catch a thief. Dhana: a thought, idea, notion, suspicion.
Scars are not signs of theft. Thieves cannot be easily recognized.
Stolen goods have no blessing.

text: Mbwa hawezi kula furushi waliomfungia shingoni.
explanation: The dog cannot eat the bundle they tied to its neck. One is not allowed to dispose of an object put in one's charge.
The one who is caught with the hide is the thief.

text: Mla cha mwenziwe na chake huliwa.
Mla kuku wa mwenziwe miguu humwelekea.
explanation: One who devours neighbor's fowl [will be discovered because] the fowl's footprints will show the way.. The footprints will show that the fowl went in, and did not come out again.
The one who shouts "So and So be accused," is the one who stole the bone.

text: Mtu akaaye na wevi ataleta nini kama si wivi?

explanation: Send a thief to catch a thief.

text: Mwezi na mtembezi, kiza na mwizi.
explanation: Moonlight and a loafer are like darkness and a thief. They go together.

text: Mwibaji na watwana, mlipi ni mwungwana.
explanation: A thief and rogues, the one who pays is a free person.
The thief does not steal and the snatcher snatches not; you don't believe it, do you? On the impudence of thieves.
The cucumber is not plucked up for a thief. A person is not going to make it easy for a thief.
A thief does not want to be robbed.
The impertinent thief said to the owner of the garden "M". The owner asked the thief to give back what the thief had stolen and the thief said "M", what's next?
The days of a robber are forty. A thief is bound to be caught.
The day of a thief is one. The luck of the thief is probably short.
A thief does not steal once only.
A thief becomes a greater thief if caught.

text: Mwizi ni mwizi, kanuna mwizi mkubwa au mdogo.
explanation: A thief is a thief, there is no big or small thief.
A cat is not put guard over food. A thief is not put to watch over precious things.
A thief finds a bigger and better thief. Cf. #751.
The company of a thief is a thief.
The skate [fish] does not shed its spiny pikes. Don't follow bad people. Don't trust them.
Light does not prevent a thief [from stealing]. Cf. #1190; #390; #391; #399.
If you treat a thieves nicely, they'll rob you at the end.
Do not think that that person does not have five fingers. That person stole once and will steal again. One does not change one's behavior. Once a thief always a thief.
Some put their clothes out to dry and others remove them. If a person has a plan another may undo it.
The one who is laughed at is the one who suceeds.
If somebody else is awarded that person is favored, (but) if I am awarded I have earned it. Used when someone is jealous.

text: Alo na jaha humwambia heri na asofaulu humwambia habalu.
explanation: If you succeed people say nice things to you, but if you fail they call you irresponsible.
A green palm-leaf has befallen on So and So. Somebody has been lucky. A poor person has found good fortune. Instead of
That person has encountered misfortune.
Someone who tastes honey makes a beehive. Nothing succeeds like success.
One who does not admit defeat is not a good fighter. He should not fight. We must recognize that there are things in life that some people can do and others not.
One who does not acknowledge the possibility of being worsted, has never engaged in the struggle.

text: Chako ni chako, usidharau cha mwenzako.
explanation: Yours is yours, but don't despise your friend's. Cf #1895.

text: Fedha ni matokeo, si msingi wa maendeleo.
Filimbi ya mwisho ndiyo huamua mshindi.
explanation: It is the last whistle that tells the winner.

text: Hakuna kilicho kitamu kuliko kilichopatikana kwa shida.
explanation: There is nothing sweeter than what has been obtained at great effort.
No gain without pain.
There is no harm in an increase.

text: Hakuna zaidi mbovu: fungato haiumizi mkono.
explanation: There is no ill increase: bind-well does not hurt the arm. Sometimes applied to explain the acceptance of a gift of no great value.
A repeated miss. That is very hard to take. Although the repeated attacks of an enemy may fail of their object, yet they seldom fail to worry a person.

It's useless, it's useless, it satisfies. It happens that some people mock others who do things that seem to be a waste of time. But as long as they like it, let them be. KA. To show that there is no thing or person totally useless, even if some people think so.
There is no honor without reason. Respect must have been earned.

text: Kamba ya mali haivutwi kwa nguvu.
explanation: One does not pull the rope of riches with force. One should not force one's luck.

text: Katika mawindo ya ndezi hakuna ngozi.
explanation: While hunting the big

text: Kilima uzuri mbali, karibu kuna mabonde.
explanation: From afar the hill is nice, close by there are valleys.

text: Kilima uzuri mbali, karibu kina majuto.
explanation: From afar the hill is nice, close by it causes regrets. Nothing is perfect.
Without either the water being spilt or the pitcher being broken. A wish for a safe journey. Cf. #1233.
Give the Gala man his right. Give a person praise if earned, and blame if earned.
Kill a Gala and give him his due.

text: Mnywa maji kwa mkono [mmoja] kiu yake i palepale.
explanation: One who drinks water with [one] hand, will remain thirsty. Of somebody who does his work half-heartedly.
The receiver today is not [necessarily] the receiver tomorrow. What you receive today is what you have, what you receive tomorrow is uncertain.
One who has tasted honey, throws the porridge away.

text: Mwungwana anajilaumu mwenyewe, pumbavu hulaumu wengine.
explanation: Gentle people blame themselves; fools blame others.
Good judgement [planning] is the road to happiness [success].
Using force constantly is unsuccessful.

text: Pato ni kutunukiwa: ni mola na mwenye huba.
explanation: Becoming prosperous depends on God and on a generous friend.
It is not the color that makes the balloon fly. A person should be judged by his humanity.

text: Tende? Tendeje! Nyama? Nyamaa! Pembe? Kipembe!
explanation: Dates? What can I do? Cattle? Hold your tongue! Ivory? The prison! The profit on dates is "so-so"; on cattle, "not worth mentioning," and as for the ivory trade, disputes are so common and litigation so dangerous, that most ivory traders at some time or another make acquaintance with the inside of a
The monkey failing to get the
If you want to take a bath, you should not be afraid of the cold.
Do not quarrel with the glory of God. Glory manifested in a person's success. Be not envious.

text: Vyako, vyako na wenzio: vikikupata ni vyako peke yako.
explanation: The good that befalls you is yours and your friends'; the evil that befalls you is just your own.

text: Chako chako peke yako, kikikufika kina wenzako.
explanation: What is yours is yours alone, but if it gets you it gets to your friends. When a good thing happens to you it is yours alone, but when a calamity befalls you, you share it with your friends.
Where there are losers there also are winners. One should not give up too easily and should try to learn why one has failed and take the means to do better next time.
The rain] that pours has no clouds. The gifts of fortune are unexpected.
A reserve never goes bad. Always comes in useful.

text: Akiba si mbaya, mlafi ni mkata.
explanation: Reserve is not bad, a glutton is a pauper. Mla: an eater, a consumer, one who eats. Mlaji: someone addicted to food Mlafi: a glutton, gourmandizer

text: akiba si mbi ingawa ni kumbe, siku ya kivumbi hutia motoni.
explanation: A reserve is not bad, even if it a husk of a coconut, in a day of need put it in the fire.

text: Aliyemnyima mwenzake nyama ya ndezi, paa akanyima nyama ya mbogo.
explanation: To one who refused a companion meat of a rodent, the gazelle denied buffalo meat. The egoist must not expect help from others.
For a person accustomed to receive, giving is like a war. Said of a hard, selfish person, a miser. cf. #304.
One who puts down 'an enough' eats with a companion. Every person who puts the spoon down will eat with a companion. The meaning of
The property of a miser is eaten by cockcroaches.

text: Choyo ni shina la maovu yote.
explanation: Avarice is the root of all evil.

text: Furushi analochukua mwenzako kiunoni huwezi kulifungua.
explanation: The bundle that your companion carries on his hip, you cannot open. Don't count on a stingy companion.

text: Kila mweka mwiko hula na wenziwe.
explanation: Everyone who puts down the spoon will eat with companions.
A little goat and another little goat will buy a boat. Small savings accumulate to big savings.
What is of no use today will be useful tomorrow..
What is not eaten by a human being, let the devil eat it.

text: Maji ya kifuu ni bahari ya chungu.
explanation: The water in an empty coconut shell is like a sea to an ant. What often seems very small to one may prove very big to another.

text: Bahari ya chungu ni maji kitobweni.
explanation: The ocean of the ants is water in a small hole. Said when a small person fears a small thing".

text: Mali ya bahili huliwa na wadudu.
Mali ya bahili mwenyewe ni jini.
explanation: A miser's wealth: the owner is a demon. A nursery tale says that the reason a miser does not use his/her wealth is that it is being enjoyed by demons.

text: Mali ya kumtia mwenyewe utumwani si mali.
explanation: The wealth which enslaves the owner is not wealth.
The left-overs of an elephant are withered leaves. The remnants of power are [often] ruins.

text: Maskini na mwanawe, tajiri na mali yake.
explanation: Poor people and their child [are like] rich people and their wealth.

text: Tajiri na maliye, maskini na mwanawe.

explanation: A miser becomes generous abroad.
A miser has no friends. About not sharing. Cf. #1600.
A shepherd does not bury. He does not keep a reserve, he eats it. He does not waste, he consumes it all.
A hand with a hole in it. Said of those who cannot keep what they possess.
One who eats today will not eat tomorrow. Understood is one who finishes all today.

text: Mlevi wa mvinyo hulevuka, mlevi wa mali halevuki.

explanation: The one who squanders property is not the one who worked to get it. A squanderer often did not work for the property and does not know how hard it was to acquire it.

text: Mwanamke [mke] wa sultani mtajiri, aliye na choyo, [siku moja] akaenda kuomba sindano.
explanation: The wife of a rich and stingy sultan one day had to go and borrow a needle.

text: Mziba sikio asimsikilize maskini, akija naye hulalamika, hatasikilizwa kamwe.
explanation: People who turn a deaf ear to the complaints of a poor person will be treated the same way when their time comes to complain.
Do not anoint a person only on the crown of the head. If you help somebody, help him fully.

text: Stahimili ule mbivu, vumbika ule mbovu.
explanation: If you wait you will eat what is ripe, if you accumulate you will eat what is rotten. Waiting for the proper time brings satisfactory results, but piling up goods without using them results in losses.

text: Tone la mungu, mto wa chungu.
explanation: A raindrop from God is like a river to an ant. Cf. #1902.
Use what you have put together [earned] in earlier days.
Look after your own [field], we shall look after ours.
Poverty does not come at once. It comes by wasting one's property.

text: Ukimpa paka utumbo, mwenyewe utakula nini?
explanation: If you give the tender meat of the belly to the cat, what are you going to eat yourself? An ironical question asked a miser, who under pretext that the cat needs choice food, does not feed a poor person.

text: Unakula vya watu, vyako unasirima katika kiwambaza.
explanation: You eat the food of others, your own food you smear on the wall. Don't be so stingy as not to invite anyone.
Do not pick from the belly.

text: Usikae kwa ghururi, tia akiba kwa kesho.
explanation: Do not live with an illusion, lay in a store for tomorrow. Don't think that a good time will last for ever.
Don't spend all your money; when it is finished you'll be destitute.
The goods of the leopard are eaten by rats. Miserliness profits nobody.
There are more selfish people than generous ones.

text: Wape maskini wale, usile pweke husonga.
explanation: Give to the poor that they may eat; do not eat alone, you may choke.
You are like a mudfish, you consume yourself. This is said of somebody who squanders his goods.
Peace does not need a guard. Indeed peace cannot be kept by armed forces, because it is the opposite of quarreling and fighting.

text: Amani haipatikani ila kwa ncha ya upanga.
explanation: Peace comes not save by the point of the sword.

text: Amani haipatikani ila kwa ncha ya upanga.
Suluhu haiji ila kwa ncha ya upanga.
explanation: Appeasement does not come save by the point of the sword.
Peace is not obtained without cost.

text: Amani ni njia ya mapenzi na ufahamiano.
explanation: Peace is a way to love and understanding.
Two points do not stab one another. Two powerful people do not fight one another, because there is mutual fear.

text: Dhuli hwenda kwa kifua, simbo kapata vitani.
explanation: A poor man goes into battle with exposed chest, but acquires weapons through fighting.

text: Dhuli kienda kwa kifua, simbo kapata vitani.
explanation: If a poor man walks proudly, he will get beaten with a stick. A poor person must not show off.

text: Fitina si mtu mwema, heri mchawi.
explanation: A quarreler is not a good person, a sorcerer is better. Wizards keep to themselves.
Honor, water (a well) [and], mother are worth fighting for.
War [causes] destruction. Quarreling is always harmful.

A destructive person spoils. 
 Cf. #1752.

text: Kuregarega si kufa, kufa ni mashinda kondo.
explanation: To be in a battered condition is not dying, death is what decides the conflict.
Tottering is not necessarily falling.

text: Kuregarega si kufa, kufa ni kuoza utumbo.
explanation: Weakening is not dying, dying is when the guts are rotting [when the heart stops working]. It is not good to cut man's activity [speech] short.
Water always has waves.

text: Mchezo wa mbwa kuanguka mkubwa na mdogo.
explanation: It is a dog's play the fall of big and small. In wrestling big and small are made to fall. Dogs stand for bad people; two are fighting, one shall fall.
A quarreler does not come for praise.

text: Mkuki unasema: ua! Mkoba unasema: turudie nyumbani!.
explanation: The spear says: kill!, but the hunting bag says: let's go home! Those who excite others to violence don't pay for the broken pots.

text: Muamuzi kati ya tonge na koo ni mlenda.
explanation: The arbitrator between a big lump [of food] and the throat is the vegetable. Every problem has its own solution. There is no quarrel that has no solution.
A mediator in a fight, his reward is a beating. The instrument of the judge is his stick. Oppression replaces justice.

text: Mwenda pate harudi, kijacho ni kilio.
explanation: One who goes to Pate returns not, what comes back is a mourning cry.

text: Ndovu wawili wakisongana ziumiazo ni nyika.
explanation: When two elephants jostle, that which is hurt is the grass.

text: Ndovu mbili zlkipambana, liumiao ni gugu.

explanation: All have the same translation. When elephants fight grass suffers.

text: Wapiganapo fahali wawili ziumiazo ni nyasi.
explanation: When two bulls fight, it is the grass that suffers. When the mighty fight it is the little people who suffer.
The problem is of humans, not of animals. Cf. #1926e.

text: Nyungu ya mgambo imekwisha kuvunjika, kila mtu atakoya nafusiye.
explanation: The pot of the palaver is now broken: all people must solve their own problems. On the crushing of a sedition. Seditions were common things in former times; in the reign of Saiyid Barghash there began an era of greater tranquility for Arab rulers, at least in this respect.
Where there is peace God is present.

text: Palipo wabaya na wema wa papo.
explanation: Where there are evil people, there are also good ones.
Where a snake has been killed hatred is still present. Even if one evil person has been eliminated in a fight or war, there remains much hatred. Here, a snake represents an evil person.
Where there is calm there is a storm. Trouble comes to peaceful places, and peace to troubled places. People living in a good relationship may become enemies.

text: Raha haiji, ila baada ya taabu.
explanation: Rest comes only after hardship.
After war, relief. Cf. #l455, #1922.
Peace has no aversion. Peace does not hate or dislike. Everybody likes peace. It is when misfortune arrives that people start lamenting.

text: Silaha za siku hizi ni kalamu na karatasi.
explanation: Today's weapons are pen and paper. The pen is mightier than the sword.
Peace and quietness is in the shade of a thorn bush.
If you want peace, prepare yourself for war. Cf. #1922; #1031.
Don't disturb a peaceful time, when you don't know its troubles.
Defense is a slip. It is in defending a matter that a person may make mistakes of speech or action and in that way spoil his own affairs. A defender should be aware of this.
War begets war.
War increases war. Fighting, quarrels produce more of the same.

text: Vita vya panga haviamuliwi kwa fimbo.
explanation: A fight with swords cannot be settled with sticks.

text: Vita vya panzi [ni] furaha ya kunguru.
Vita vya panzi neema ya kunguru.
explanation: War among grasshoppers is a blessing for the crow.
Pulling back in the war is not the same as having lost the war.
So and So is happy as a wizard at a quarrel.
The tools of war are arms. Without tools or know-how you are handicapped.
A prayer over an urchin is a stick. The urchin listens to a stick.
The remedy for a ruffian is a stick.
Being human is better than anything. About values.
One who does not know how to be humane (kind, civilized) is not human.

A handsome finger gets a ring put round it. The person who deserves esteem will get it. A pretty maiden will have a ring slipped on her finger. If you put a ring on a finger, you'll put it on the right finger, not on the thumb or toe (also finger in Swahili). This proverb is used to show that honor and reward be given to the right, the good people.
The finger that has no ring will get one.
On the fingers of the feet (toes) no ring is put.
The big cow of the town does not need to be herded. The cow cannot be lost. An important man or woman in town can go nowhere, cannot be lost.
The big cow of the town does not need shepherding. Cf. #1940.
Nothing can overpower a man as a woman.
You don't find a young girl who has contempt for herself. Girls are vain.

text: Kaburi la mke mwenza li kombo.
explanation: The grave of your co-wife is crooked. Jealousy makes you find faults.
All human beings have their own soul. All people have to learn their own nature and live with it.
Every person has his own preoccupations. Cf #147.

text: Kina cha moyo wa mwanamke ni mfuko wa mumewe.
explanation: The depth of a woman's heart [is as deep as] the [money] bag of her husband.

text: Licha ya uchungu, wanawake hawaishi kutamani kuzaa.
explanation: Notwithstanding the pain, women do not stop longing to give birth.
A widow in a village is a helper for every one.

text: Mke atasahau kufua shati lake, lakini hasahau kupokea bahasha.
explanation: A wife will forget to launder his shirt, but will not forget to receive his pay check.
A wife is a beautiful jewel.

text: Mke mbaya, mpe mwana na mbeleko.
explanation: Give a bad wife a child and a papoose.

text: Mke mpya hana dawa, dawa yake upya wake.
explanation: A new wife wears no love charms, her charm is being new.

text: Mke mpya hana dawa, dawa yake mapendo yake.
explanation: A new wife wears no love charms, love is her charm.

text: Mke mwenye adabu ni fahari kwa mumewe.
explanation: A good mannered wife is a pride for her husband.

text: Mlinzi hulinda ndege, mke mzuri halindwi.
explanation: The birdchaser keeps the birds away [from the millet]: [but] a pretty woman] can not be guarded.
A bird can be guarded, a wife cannot be guarded.
A good wife obeys her husband.
A wife is the key of the house. She opens the house making it accessible.
Your wife is [your] little sister. Treat her gently.
Clothing is to the wife as is weeding to a banana plant. People and things need to be cared for. The spouse is expensive in price-wealth and clothing, but her work is profitable.
A banana tree is to be weeded.

text: Uzuri wa mke ni nguo, wa ng'ombe ni kulimiwa.
explanation: The beauty of a women is in her clothing, that of an ox is in plowing. A woman's best quality is hard work.

text: Mke ni nguo, lakini nguo si mke.
explanation: Clothing enhances women's beauty, but is not of itself more important than a woman.

text: Mke wa kwanza ni kama mama.
explanation:
The first wife is like a mother. Refers also to the vital part first wives play in running homes. 
 Cf. #1941.

A new sleeping mat is not pleasant to sleep on. A young wife has a lot to learn. JK. 
 Cf. 1782.
The beautiful arrow kills life in the scabbard. Is this to say that a beautiful woman upsets life in a village?

text: Mtoto mwanamke methili yake kama vitu viwili, tango na kitunguu, na vitu hivi ni vitu vya kuweka akiba.
Mtu halindi bahari ipitayo kila chombo.
explanation:
A person cannot guard the sea where all the ships pass. A spouse may not always be faithful, but cannot be perfectly guarded all the time. 
 Cf. #1940.
A man is work.
Being a husband means hard work. A husband's love for his family is expressed in hard work. JK.

text: Mume ni kazi, mke ni nguo.
Mtu mume ni kazi; ukikosa cha kuweka utapata cha leo leo.
explanation: A man must work; if you have no savings you'll get today's food.
A human being is intelligent. That separates a person from other creatures.
A person is like a finger. Crafty and weak.
A person is a thing. A creature.
A person is eating. Without food a person cannot survive.
A person is not a thing, the importance is being human. Cf. chapter Excellence.

A person becomes a name. According to tradition and customs, the name given to a child has a meaning. There are many who believe that a person's character and condition resemble the name that is/was given.
A person is character. A person's character reveals us a human being as good, bad, kind, fierce, generous, or selfish.

text: Mtu nyumbani mwake hatiiwi ni mkewe, haonwi kuwa mume, asipompiga, twa.
explanation: A man who is not obeyed by his wife in his [own] house, is not considered as her husband, unless he beats her, thwack. It is not traditional for Swahili women to be beaten by their husbands.
Being a husband is an honor, it is not a relaxation.

text: Mume ni moto wa koko, usipowaka utafuka.
explanation: Man is like a jungle fire, if it does not burn it will smolder. Is not easy to satisfy, has many needs.
A woman is never satisfied.
A woman is nowhere a stranger. In conforming herself to her neighborhood, the woman creates a place for herself in the sun.
A woman will not become a major of the town.

text: Mwanamke mrembo haolewi na bwana mmoja.
explanation: An adorned woman is not married to one man only. She dresses in order to please; jewels are expensive.

text: Mwanamke ni kama maji ya dafu, hayapendezi ila dafuni mwakwe.
explanation: A woman is like the milk of a young coconut, it is not pleasant except in its young coconut. Said of the shyness of women on a visit, away from their own home.

text: Maji ya dafu hayapendezi ila dafuni mwake.
explanation: Milk of the young coconut is not pleasant except in its nut.

text: Mwanamke ni muhogo, popote unapotupwa unaota.
explanation: A woman is like a cassava plant, that grows where it is thrown. A woman must adapt herself to the family she married.

text: Mwanamume ni mti wa muhogo; popote unapotupwa unaota.
explanation: A man is like a cassava plant, which takes roots wherever it is thrown. The husband must adapt himself to the in-laws.
A husband is a creeper, he stretches far away.
Who has a sister will not fail to get in-laws. Every woman is destined to be married.
An old person works like a hen. A hen hatches her chicks, carefully brings them up and always gathers them together and teaches them to stay together. An old man or old woman also functions as a hen.

An old person is like a brewing pot. The local beer has a residue which cannot de drunk. This residue is left or returned to the brewing pot. Thus the brewing pot is used to preserve the unwanted residue. Likewise the youth dump what they do not want on an old person who must exercise forbearance in order to be able to accept this plight and deal with what he/she receives.

text: Nusu mtu nusu nyama, tumo katika dunia.
explanation: In the world we are half human and half animal.

text: Nyama ya kuku mchanga sio sawa na kuku mzee.
explanation: The meat of a young chicken is not the same as the meat of an old one. The meaning is that a youth and an adult are both nation builders, but each has a different contribution to make.

text: Tunda bivu halitaki kwanguliwa, jani kavu hukakatuka kwa jua.
explanation: A ripe fruit does not like being brought down, a dry leaf shrivels in the sun.
Showing off is not honorable for a woman.
A lovely face does not need adornment.
A nice face does not need paint.

text: Uso wa mtu umeumbwa na haya.
explanation: A human face is made to show modesty.
A face has modesty. When somebody has done wrong that face should show shame.
Youth is like smoke, old age is like rust. Young and old, both move towards decline.

text: Ujana ni kuweka, uzeeni ni kula.
explanation: Youth is gathering, in old age it is consuming.

If you revere your wife as a sister, you will not have a child with her. If you venerate a person, even not seeing that person's misbehavior, you'll end up a loser. If a person is not ashamed to treat you badly, you should not be ashamed to tell that person openly.
What gets old is the body, not the soul.
The youth are in expectation, the old are in reminiscence.
Old wells must not be filled in. One day they may become useful again. Respect the elderly and do not discard them. They have wisdom that should be used.
Earthlings are not good people. Human beings are not good. Many are not trustworthy.

text: Wanawake hufanya kazi zote; wanaume hufurahi.
explanation: Women do all the work; men just enjoy life.

The pain of women is on their hips. I heard this proverb being muttered by a vexed husband against a nagging wife. Women (thus a husband told me) will use the children as an excuse for quarreling and complaining.
Two people are two people. They are different.
Two persons are not just one person. Cf. #430.
Said when going hunting or fishing.
A diligent worker will reap the fruits of his industry.
The person who goes to the forest will come back with firewood.
One who complains much does little. Not only does that person do little, but also prevents others from achieving.
So and So sleeps like a puff adder.
A person as tall as the devil.
One who expects to live for free will live in poverty.

text: Avunjaye nazi ni lazima ale tui yake.
explanation: The one who cracks the coconut should consume the cream. The person who does the hard work should enjoy the fruits of that work.
That person can change a garbage dump into wealth.

text: Biashara ya pembe hapana cha kuambulia.
explanation: At the ivory market there is no profit. The ivory market is expensive. Used when people waste time in looking and admiring.
For nothing, for nothing, never satisfies. A beggar is never satisfied. Once you give something away, the receiver will expect the same gift again.
A human being must make an effort.
A valley's beginning is a hill. Before obtaining a state of well-being, we must work for it: Climbing up before we can go down.
A little, but earned, is the best.

text: Bora kidogo kwa haki kuliko mali nyingi kwa wovu.
explanation: The little acquired honestly is better than much but ill acquired.
A thing for nothing is not obtainable.
Dig, dig with perseverance The good and the wicked cannot be distinguished Anyone with a bad intention falls in this well. A well-diggers' song.

text: Fumbe na mleli wake, haulali ndora.
explanation: The widow bird with its long tail never sleeps. This is used as an invitation to workers to work harder. Be active, for the black bird is a memento of dying, since it is associated with the grave".
A craftsman is not hungry. A skilled worker will always find work".

text: Fundi mbaya huteta na ala zake.
explanation: The bad craftsman quarrels with the tools. Cf. #1990.
The car does not move the owner. Because one has a car it does not absolve the owner from making efforts to be accepted in society.
Nothing is free.

text: Hakuna kitu kigumu kwa mtu mwenye bidii.
explanation: Nothing is hard for an energetic person.
Big steps shortens a walk. Used to encourage effort.

text: Heri kwenda bure kama kukaa bure.
explanation: It is better to go in vain than to stay in vain. You regret more what you did not do than what you did.
The donkey works all his life, [and only] the vultures like it [after its death].
One cuts oneself, to put oneself together.
The devil oppresses the lazy. The devil looks for people who have plenty of idle time.

text: Imani hufa kwa sumu ya ujira mbaya.
explanation: Trust dies because bad pay poisons it Trust needs a good satisfying reponse.
Bow down so that you may get it. Refers to effort in order to obtain what you want and need. But of course can also be used as "Courtesy opens all doors". Cf. #159.
A person's sweat is not eaten. Do not exploit or depend on another's work.
God does not ignore a person's sweat. Work is rewarded.
The hoe in the soil [brings] health to the body. Work brings food on the table.
With the hoe in the hand, there will be food to eat. Cf.#1971f.
Scratch yourself where you can reach. Do your own scratching. Help yourself. Do what you can.
Sit near [your own] rope [of the main sail] and hold it in your hand. Don't be a back-seat driver, stick to your job.
Embraze the coconut tree and climb it, start work. Many Swahili workers used to be employed as coconut pickers. They were paid by the number of trees they had climbed.
Work without play does not go well. Mix work with leisure and you will never go mad (Russian proverb).
The work will not progress if one does not know the rules [for the initiated]. The work cannot be satisfactory until you are accepted and know all the tricks. "A specialized knowledge for every job.

text: Kazi isiyo faida kutenda si ada.
explanation: Work without profit, it is not fit for reward. Uselessness is damaging.

text: Kazi, isiyokuwa na manufaa, kutenda si ada.
explanation: Useless work is worthless.

text: Kazi isiyo kipimo mwishowe watu hutetana.
explanation: Work that has no measure, at the end of it people quarrel. Do not overburden a fellow human being.
Work must be done.
Working two jobs is not nice play.
Hard work give it to the Almighty. Do not do the impossible.
Work is a treasure. Work is a source of prosperity and happiness.
Work is income. In order to gain something you must work for it. To desire a thing without work is to fall into the Devil's trap.
Work for the little pot on the stove. To work for food or daily need only, not for a salary.

text: Kazi ya shikazi, niwachia kazi! Kazi ya msira huisira-sira.
explanation: Work for money, leave that to me. The work for a miser I usually scamp.
All work is useful.

text: Kibarua hulima juani, tajiri hulia kivulini.
explanation: A day-worker cultivates in the sun, the master eats in the shade. One toils, the other munches.
That which exposes you [to danger] is your stomach. The stomach commands the Swahili to go out on dangerous journeys to earn their living.
All sweet things [pleasant happenings] have been prepared.
Everything that shines has been brushed.
Everything has its beginnings
Everything has its time [or measure].
Every drum has its own dance. Every work has its own way of being performed. No two works are similar

text: Kilimia kikizama kwa jua huzuka kwa mvua; kikizama kwa mvua huzuka kwa jua.

explanation: A worn out hoe did more hoeing than a whole one. Don't despise a nobody. Sometimes they are or were more useful than 'important' people.
The bed is like a brother/sister.
As it is tapped so it will be drunk. Cf #2000.

text: Kiuno kiteke kinang'aa; hakikai nyumba moja na njamaa.
explanation: The soft waist that shines with perspiration does not dwell in the same house as hunger.
A beautiful thing is made. Cf. #2020.
If the hat fits wear it. Accept a job you like and can fulfill; accept also the praise or blame earned.

text: Kozi mwana mandanda, kulala na njaa kupenda.

explanation: One ordering farm work gets only clearing of undergrowth. If you leave your work to others, it will not be done properly.
Does sending an order imply ability?
To order is not the same as to get the job done. To order a job does not mean that it will be done right.

text: Kufadhiliwa ni kubaya, akufadhiliye ni bwana wako.
explanation: Receiving favors is bad, the one who gives them is your master. Cf. # 1967.
Living is like riding a bicycle. If you ride a bicycle you must pedal if you want to move. If you don't pedal, you will fall off. To live is to work hard. The alternative is death.
Eating is sweet, hoeing is weariness.
Eating is the earnings of work.

text: Kula uhondo kwataka matendo, asiye na matendo hula uvundo.
explanation: In order to eat generously, deeds are needed; without working one eats bad smelling food. In order to live in peace, a person must work hard, if he doesn't he'll live a life of trouble.
Farm work needs measure. You have to know your needs and if you have people working your land, you must arrange payment. Cf. #1974.

text: Kulima kwataka jembe na mikono ya kunyoka.
explanation: Field work requires a hoe and the stretching of the arms

text: Kulima pekee ni kujihiliki; mawe na manyasi hayakusanyiki.
explanation: Cultivating alone is suicide; stones and weeds cannot be raked together.

text: Kulima polepole, kulima na kidole, utalala nacho.
explanation: If you are a lazy farmer, doing work with one finger, you will sleep with that finger [in your mouth]. You'll be sorry. If you work without spirit, you invite penury.

text: Kumpatia mlimaji chakula, mchezaji atapeleka vyote.
Kuna ufundi pia katika kuburura rukwama.
explanation: There is craftsmanship even in dragging along the heavy center pole supporting the roof of a house.

text: Kutema kuni ku bora kuliko kunyosha mkono kwa kiumbe.
explanation: Cutting [firewood] is better than putting the hand out to someone [for alms].  Cf

text: Kutenda kazi twatenda, lakini bamba ni gumu.
explanation: As for] doing the work, we do [it], but the object is hard. Cf. #420.

text: Kutwanga nisile unga, nazuia mchi wangu.
explanation: Grinding the grain and not being allowed to eat the flour, I deny my pestle. No work without profit.

text: Kuvua samaki mwungwana si tua kwa wenye akili.
explanation: For an intelligent person fishing is not a disgrace. Fishing is a degrading job to some people. Here we understand that this should not be so for it is better to fish than to beg or steal.

text: Kuvunjika kwa mwiko si mwisho wa kusonga ugali.
Kuzima koleo si mwisho wa uhunzi.
explanation: Cooling the tongs is not the end of forging. To know how to cool the tongs is not all the work of forging.
First work, then wages.
Even just loitering is better than sitting doing nothing. Cf. #1994.
Attend to what must be done. There is no excuse.
Wind-swept clouds don't give rain. Much ado about nothing.

text: Mchezea chuma huchuma, kama hakuchuma tumbo hunguruma.
explanation: The person who lets the hoe dance will harvest; if there is no harvest that person's stomach will grumble.

text: 4726 mchimba kaburi ana faida, kefu mranda mbao.
explanation: The grave-digger makes a living, so much the more the wood planer in making the coffin. There is no low craft, only low people.
A well-digger is not refused water.
One does not refuse water to the child of the well-digger.
A person who makes a living in the sun, eats in the shade. Rest is sweet after overcoming hard work.
A hawker sleeps without comfort, but eats well. Being away from home, one'll sleep where possible. Cf. #1979A; #1982; #1983; #1988.

text: Mgaagaa na upwa hali wali mtupu.
Mgaagaa wa mpwa hali vyakula vikavu.
explanation: A lazy person with a nephew does not eat dry food. Sends his nephew to get what is needed.

text: Mtafutaji wa mpwa hali wali mtupu.
explanation: One who looks up a nephew does not eat dry rice.
A restless child does not eat plain polenta.
One who cares for the stomach must sweat for it.
They who sit on their hoe are not farmers.
The track made by the hoe does not tell a lie. The meaning is that work is rewarding.

text: Mkokoto wa jembe si bure yao.
explanation: The dragging of the hoe is not worthless. If a farmer drags his hoe being tired after work, it is understood that there is nothing shameful about it. Said to somebody who looks down on a dirty, sweating worker.

text: Mkoba wa mwindaji umevimba; ukikosa nyama, haukosi uyoga.
explanation: A hunter's bag is full; even if it does not contain meat, it contains at least mushrooms. Cf. #1994, #1960.
The farmer does not eat alone. Cf. #1998.
The lazy farmer blames his tools. Cf. #1990.

text: Mkulima ni mmoja, walaji ni wengi.
explanation: The farmer is one, those who eat are many. Many enjoy the fruits of his work. A farmer has many dependents. JK. Richness attracts many profiteers.
The sleeper in the shade, what will that person eat?
Break it up for the cat, don't you have a hand? Telling people what to do, but doing nothing oneself.
One who plants in a disorderly fashion will eat likewise. As you sow, so shall you reap.
If you farm 'What's enough for me," you will harvest "What is finished. If you farm a small piece of land only, you'll have a small harvest. To encourage people to work well.

text: Mpenda cha bure, hufa kidole mdomoni.
explanation: One who loves free things dies with the finger in the mouth.
One who loves to eat is lazy. Said during the rainy season when often the whole day is spent in the field.

text: Mpewa chakula na watu hana uso.
explanation: One who is given food by people has no face. This is said of people who depend on others for their living. People who do not work to earn their daily bread are considered faceless, i.e., they cannot enjoy their rights and cannot express their opinion lest they lose the favor of their benefactors.

text: Mpigwa chini na jembe huinuwa na lilo koongo.
explanation: One who is brought to the ground by the hoe is lifted up by that same delving. One who is bent down working the land, will rise to a good life.
A fool has no work.
Being tossed about is the way the dug-out canoe moves.

text: Mtama ni muwi na wapishi nao.
explanation: If the millet dish is bad, the cooks are no good. If something goes wrong others are blamed.

text: Mchele ni mui na wapishi nao.

explanation: A restless child stays without going to the toilet Not taking time to go. Cf. # 1994.
What a person sows will be reaped. Cf. #358, #2000.

text: Mtu asiwe nawara, uvivu huleta hasara.
explanation: A person should not be idle, laziness causes damage.
One cannot feed on wind. You cannot live on air. One does not live on love and fresh water.
Human beings consume their strength. You should make use of your talents to support yourself, and not be dependent on the work of others.
A lazy person does not sow up a small wound. That person neglects doing small repairs, does not take care of property or health. Cf. #1746.

text: Mvivu hutumaini kupata hapati; mwenye bidii hunenepa.
explanation: The lazy person hopes to get it and does not; the hard worker grows fat.
A fisherman unable to fish makes a fishing line. One can always do something useful.

text: Mwanamume ni kazi, bila kazi hajaliwi, mpuzi hafanyi kazi.
explanation: Being a man is hard work, without work he is not respected, a fool does not work.

text: Mwanzo ni kuchuma, kisha ni kusona.
explanation: First harvest, then rest.

text: Mwenda bure si mkaa bure; huenda akaokota.
explanation: A loafer is better than an idler; usually a loafer finds something useful. Activity is better than doing nothing.
A hunchback cannot lie down on the back. A poor person can never stop working and never rest.
The one who made you walk at night, you'll praise in the morning. All effort, even irksome, is remunerated.

text: Mzigo huwa mzito karibu ya nyumbani.
explanation: A load gets heavy approaching home.
I kill myself for rice: it has already an owner. I work myself to the core cultivating rice, it is mine. Don't attribute to yourself what another has earned. To work for nothing.

text: Nafia pumba la maganda, mchele kwa belgika.
explanation: I kill myself for a ball of husks, while the rice goes to Belgika.

text: Ndimu mpaka uikamue, ndipo utaona maji yake.
explanation: It's not until you squeeze the lemon, that you'll see its juice.
Go away from your relative, do not live together. Do not be dependent on your relative, you'll get on each others' nerves. Be self supporting. Cf #954. # 2009.
It is easier to destroy than to build up.
I'll do it, I'll do it, is negligence.

text: Nyuki anaunda asali, bungo anaunda udongo.

explanation: Begging and begging brings abjection.
A donkey does not move unless a stick is used.

text: Rahisi kufahamu la kufanya kuliko kulifanya.
explanation: It is easier to know what to do than to do it.
No honor comes to a useless person.
B1ack day, white money. Hard work, good pay.
We all would be lazy, if only we could.
We are a-cultivating. A greeting during cultivation time. The rejoinder is

text: Ukimpa mtu kazi pataneni na ujira.
explanation: If you give a person work [first] agree upon the wages.
One who gives work to a person should agree upon wages. Cf. #1974.
When you see them float, [remember] they have been built. JK. Much knowledge and effort went into making the boats.
They float, they have been made.
If you see [a boat] that floats, it has been created. Things have to be done well and must not be taken for granted. Cf. #1979d.

text: Ukitaka chakula wakati wa masika, ujikaze.
explanation: If you want food during the raining season, start working
If you want to eat fish, you must become wet (or, you must fish). When you are fishing you must enter the water. About taking the proper means.
If you count on your neighbor, you'll die a pauper.
If you put your hope in your neighbor, you'll become poor.

text: Ukiwa mkazi jenga; ukosefu wa mwenenzi si wa kazi milele.
Ulichopanda ule, hata hukusugua mkono wake.
explanation: Eat what you planted, even if you have not scrubbed your hand. Your good right to enjoy the fruit of your labor in any circumstances.
The tongue makes no profit. Talking is of no use.
You think about sleeping while dawn is here. The lazy person follows an abnormal life style.
When you scratch your scabies, you enjoy it. The joy of doing things.
Even the most clever child cannot escape sleep. Sleep cannot be avoided. Man's weakness.
Sleep is the wealth of the poor. The poor have no possessions. Sleep temporarily removes them from pressing needs of life.
Sleep is not wealth. Sleep does not bring wealth.

text: Usione mkono wa salamu ukazidisha hadi begani.
explanation: Don't expect a welcoming hand while you add even more on your shoulder. Of people who are workaholics.
When I work on the land you'll pass me by, but not when I eat.
Laziness causes poverty. Cf. #ll27.
September-rains, 'tis in crowds (the people go). The people are eager to be about their cultivation.

text: Ukisikia vuli yaja, kazi za shamba hakonde huzudi

explanation: Break the coconut to get the copra. If you want a good thing you must work for it. It is not easy to get a valuable thing.
If you want to improve your standards, you must leave your bed.
Those who work do not fail to have a reason [or need].

text: Waungwana huchumia juani na kulia kivulini.
explanation: Good men harvest in the heat of the sun and eat in the shade. They work hard for a living.
The ocean does not stop moving. The ocean is full of trouble. The trouble of the ocean never ends. There is no stopping disorder, waste, confusion, changes. Be ready for misfortunes and hardship.
The ocean leads us anywhere. Adventures at sea will teach us all about life.
The world is deceitful, the world is for the brave. There are many attractions in the world; to conquer the world one must deny oneself.
The world does not end. The world will be here long after we leave.
The world has no end. Used to remind an arrogant person that the world will outlast any one.
The world is not hungry. The world will not die of hunger, but will go on. We disappear. Cf. #1790.

text: Dunia haina shukrani; kwale, tengemana nikumeze.
explanation: In the world there is no gratitude; partridge, be assured, I'11 swallow you. Don't expect gratitude for your good deeds. Refers to the story in which the partridge saved the life of a snake by transporting him from a brush fire to an open space, where upon arrival the snake swallowed the partridge.
Lick the world, there are days when she will lick you (for good or bad).
The world brings good and bad things.
The world brings what is good and what is bad. Cf. the following proverbs beginning with
The world is deceitful, mortal be on your guard.
The world is a wretched thing; mortal depend not upon it.
The world is a poor thing, it is useless to boast. Cf,#2046-#2052.
The world is like a withered tree: mortal, rest not thy weight upon it.
The world is like a dead tree, if you rely on it, it will throw you down.

text: Dunia mwendo wa ngisi, kamwe msililiwale.
explanation: The world goes like an octopus, never forget that. The octopus goes backwards. The ways of the world are completely unpredictable. But one day it may catch you in its grip.
The world is like a high rise.
The world is a laboratory. Where various experiments are going on.
